LEAD: A police officer shot one of four youths driving a stolen car after a brief chase in the Bronx yesterday, the police said.

They said the officers tried to stop the car, which crashed into a van.

Review/Opera; Marilyn Mims as Verdi's Violetta
LEAD: Watching the New York City Opera's current production of ''La Traviata'' on Saturday evening at the New York State Theater, I couldn't help wondering who the company imagines its audience to be.
Directed by Frank Corsaro, the production is a superficially traditional look at the Verdi opera, with sets and costumes that are a mismatched, historic pastiche, and with blocking that is unlikely to awaken new insight into the characters for operagoers acquainted with the work.

The Iron Law Of Arms Control
LEAD: In the treaty eliminating Soviet and American intermediate-range missiles, the iron law of negotiation was demonstrated once again: The side in a hurry makes the concessions.
Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in a hurry; President Reagan was not.
So Mr.
Gorbachev made the concessions and agreed to a treaty that he and his three predecessors had denounced as a wicked ploy to achieve American military superiority.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
China's ability to pay back its $20 billion to $30 billion external debt was rated ''satisfactory'' by Standard &amp; Poor's.
It was the first time the rating service had evaluated the country's debt.
The rating corresponds to the lower third of S.&amp;P.'s investment-grade category.
The rating was influenced by China's economic changes over the past decade, in which market forces have replaced some central planning.


Police Close Arab Studies Center in Jerusalem
LEAD: Police officer in East Jerusalem standing guard outside the Arab Studies Center, which was ordered closed after the arrest of its director, Faisal Husseini.
Mr.
Husseini was detained yesterday after meeting with Israeli dissidents in a West Jerusalem theater and calling for direct peace talks between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

Brooklyn Girl Killed When Gun Goes Off
LEAD: A 13-year-old Brooklyn girl was fatally shot yesterday when a handgun some youths were playing with discharged and she was struck in the chest, the police said.


Bridge
LEAD: Players from Washington, New York City, Philadelphia and Los Angeles won major titles at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Saturday night.


Energy Dept. Shows Prudence on Nuclear Waste
LEAD: To the Editor:


Full-Size Portable Bike
LEAD: At a time when bicycle thieves are able to break through the toughest of locks, the idea of a folding bicycle - one that you can carry with you - begins to make sense.


Few Are Jobless in Japan
LEAD: High demand for workers because of rapid economic growth pushed Japan's unemployment rate down to 2.4 percent in June, its lowest level in 67 months, the Government announced Friday.
The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for June was a tenth of a percentage point lower than in May and sixth-tenths of a percentage point below the previous year's level, the Management and Coordination Agency said.


Valenzuela Sidelined
LEAD: The Los Angeles Dodgers put Fernando Valenzuela on the 21-day disabled list today, and the 27-year-old left-hander will miss his turn in the rotation for the first time in his eight-year career.


Montpelier Journal; A Rising Debate Over a Plan to Raise the Skyline
LEAD: The striking gold dome of the State House has long been the architectural focus of this smallest of capital cities.


Congress Facing Key Issues Affecting Military Readiness
LEAD: The Congressional Budget Office has warned Congress that it may soon face a choice between reducing the size of the armed forces or making them less ready for combat because operational and support funds are being held down in favor of buying more arms.


Give Housing Tax Credits More Time
LEAD: The House Ways and Means Committee acted wisely when it voted a year's extension of the housing tax-credit program.
This useful measure is the only low-rent housing production program still on the books after eight Reagan years.
It deserves final approval by the full House and Senate.


Pier Collapse Kills Dozens in Malaysia
LEAD: Rescue workers in the city of Butterworth, in northwestern Malaysia, carrrying a body from the rubble of a pier which collapsed yesterday on thousands of people waiting for ferries to Penang Island.
At least 30 people were killed and more than 300 injured when a section of the structure suddenly gave way.


Revitalized Red Sox Are Back in the Race
LEAD: Forget Michael S. Dukakis.
If this town voted today, Joe Morgan would be president.


Couple in Parked Car Found Shot to Death
LEAD: A couple were shot to death as they sat in a parked car in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday in what the police believe were drug-related murders, the police.


Harness Racing; Looking Beyond Roosevelt Closing
LEAD: Even though harness racing in the metropolitan area suffered a severe setback with the closing of Roosevelt Raceway on Long Island, there is plenty of optimism at Yonkers Raceway and the Meadowlands.


Cable TV Deal Collapses
LEAD: The Times Mirror Company said a deal to trade its cable television operations in Arizona for cable properties owned by Tele-Communications Inc. and United Artists Communications has collapsed.
The decision to call off the deal, which was announced in March and was valued by analysts at about $740 million, ''was a mutual agreement between all three parties,'' Times Mirror, owner of The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and The Baltimore Sun newspapers, said Thursday.


ACTION PERPLEXES ARABS AND ISRAELIS
LEAD: After analyzing and debating King Hussein's moves to cut his links to the West Bank, neither Israelis nor Palestinians in the occupied territories were quite sure today what to make of it.


Loan Talks For Brazilian
LEAD: A Brazilian Finance Ministry official began a tour of Persian Gulf banks today to outline details of a new $63.6 billion debt-rescheduling package and a plan to raise $5.8 billion.


Producers End Talks With Writers
LEAD: Calling negotiations with Hollywood's 9,000 striking writers ''hopelessly deadlocked,'' the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said today that the talks with the Writers Guild of America in the 22-week strike were permanently ended.


One of Every 30 Condemned Since '77 Has Been Executed
LEAD: Of every 30 people sentenced to death since the death penalty was reinstated by the Supreme Court in 1976, 10 left death row and one was executed, the Justice Department said today.


Michael Cohen Wed To Meryl Ilene Stone
LEAD: Meryl Ilene Stone and Michael H. Cohen were married last evening at the Short Hills, a catering establishment in Short Hills, N.J., by Rabbi Irving Block.


Barbara Jordan Reported 'Vastly Improved'
LEAD: Former Representative Barbara Jordan was ''vastly improved,'' her doctor said today, a day after she nearly drowned in her swimming pool.


National League; Hershiser Blunts Astros' Momentum
LEAD: Orel Hershiser pitched a five-hitter today to become the National League's second 15-game winner and John Shelby had a two-run single as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated Houston, 6-1, to snap the Astros' four-game winning streak.

Review/Opera; A New 'Dutchman' for Santa Fe
LEAD: All of Wagner's mature operas are ghost ships, fated to sail about the world in search of the ultimately convincing interpretation.
Vain voyages.
For any important work there is no final port to be reached, at least not while the culture that produced it survives.
Certainly there is life enough left in ''Der Fliegende Hollander,'' Wagner's first great experiment in psychological music drama.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Latin Trade Plan Shaped
LEAD: A Latin American export financing consortium, Latinequip, plans to propose to central banks of Mexico, Brazil and Argentina that foreign debt paper from those countries be used to finance trade.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Officials Split On Inquiring About AIDS
LEAD: Koch administration officials are split over a draft proposal to require all candidates for police, fire, sanitation and certain other ''public safety'' jobs to disclose if they have received a diagnosis of AIDS or AIDS-related complex.

Concern About Lyme Disease Surges
LEAD: Across the New York metropolitan region this summer, health experts are reporting a surge of concern about Lyme disease, a vexing and potentially crippling illness that is spread by a tiny tick.


Boxing; McGirt Knocks Out Davis in Round 1
LEAD: James (Buddy) McGirt retained his International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title when he knocked out Howard Davis yesterday at 2 minutes 45 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 15-round bout at the Felt Forum.

LEAD: Seven years ago, Ashby Harper, who was 65 years old, told a friend that he planned to swim across the English Channel.

LEAD: Things are not the way they were when Imelda Marcos was here.
As a fresh breeze gusted off the sea today outside Lindenmere, her erstwhile country place at the edge of this Suffolk County town, members of the Philippine Presidential Commission on Good Government sat around the kitchen table, eating cake.


Scientist's View of Lasers Helped 'Star Wars'
LEAD: Recently declassified documents show that Edward Teller had viewed the nuclear X-ray laser, a disputed ''Star Wars'' weapon, as potentially vastly more powerful and flexible than had been discussed publicly.

Teamsters Extend Pact With Studio Craftsmen
LEAD: The Teamsters and Basic Crafts Unions have agreed to extend their contract with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers on a day-to-day basis.
The contract with studio drivers, plumbers, electricians, plasterers and laborers was to have expired at midnight Sunday.
A joint statement released Sunday afternoon said negotiations would resume Wednesday, ''with the expectation of negotiating to conclusion.


Drug Thugs and Rambo Guns
LEAD: ''Mushrooms'' - that's the drug gunman's brutal slang for innocent bystanders who pop up unexpectedly in his line of fire.
In the past year 10 New Yorkers have been killed and more than 20 wounded by drug criminals' stray bullets, and the lethal fire is hardly unique to New York.


An Animator Breaks Old Rules And New Ground in 'Roger Rabbit'
LEAD: At the age of 5, Richard Williams visited a movie theater in Toronto with his mother and saw ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.'' ''She said I was never the same again,'' recalled Mr.
Williams with a laugh. ''It just knocked me out.
I said 'That's what I want to do; that's what I have to do.' ''


Baseball Fever Is Spreading
LEAD: BASEBALL pilgrims rivaling the United Nations in geographic diversity are visiting the national baseball museum and library here to worship at the shrine of the national game and, at the same time, pick up expertise that may be used when baseball becomes a gold-medal sport in the 1992 Olympics.

LEAD: AGB Television Research, which took on the A. C. Nielsen Company in a costly war for the business of measuring the American television audience, has surrendered and will suspend its ratings operation in the United States.

LEAD: To Robert Morris, the outlook seemed bleak, despite the hustle and bustle surrounding him on a ramp at the Kansas City International Airport.
On Aug. 31 much of that activity will be ended by sharp service cuts announced by Eastern Airlines.

LEAD: At a time when the boom in personal computer magazines is thought to be over, the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company is gambling that there is room for one more.


China Eases Factory Rule
LEAD: China today enacted a law that ends direct state controls over enterprises and gives factory managers greater freedom over their operations.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced final regulations for cutting production and use of chemicals widely believed to be depleting the earth's protective ozone layer.
The move would bring the United States into compliance with an international agreement to curb the substances.

Trinidad Silva Jr., 38, 'Hill Street' Star, Dies
LEAD: Trinidad Silva Jr., who portrayed a gang leader in the movie ''Colors'' and in the NBC television series ''Hill Street Blues,'' was killed Sunday in an automobile accident that also injured his wife and son, the police said.
He was 38 years old and lived here.


United-Hyatt Link
LEAD: United Airlines said it had signed a marketing agreement for its frequent-flier program with the Hyatt Corporation.
The airline said its frequent-fliers will receive 500 miles credit for each stay at more than 125 participating Hyatt hotels, when they pay the corporate rate or higher.
They also receive a 50 percent discount off a multinight stay at Hyatt with every 20,000 miles awarded by United.


Tigers Lose by 5-3, Lead by Half a Game
LEAD: Bo Jackson hit his third home run in three games and started another rally with a double, leading the Kansas City Royals to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.
The loss trimmed the Tigers' lead in the American League East to half a game over the Yankees and one game over the Red Sox.


Construction Spending Up 0.1% in June
LEAD: Construction spending inched up one-tenth of 1 percent in June as a big increase in investment for new factories helped offset declines in housing and government projects.


Texas Deposit Yields Signs of Big Meteorite
LEAD: A 66-million-year-old rock deposit in a Texas creek bed shows that when the area was part of the ocean floor it was scoured by a massive wave, perhaps triggered by a large comet or asteroid that fell in the Atlantic Ocean, according to a study published in the journal Science.


Protecting the Baby: Work in Pregnancy Poses Legal Frontier
LEAD: Pregnant women and, at times, all women of child-bearing age are being barred from certain jobs that may pose a health threat to a fetus.
Lawyers say such ''protective exclusion'' policies can be a form of illegal sex discrimination.

LEAD: ''If we want a lasting peace, Nicaragua has unfortunately failed us.''  - President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica.  [ A8:5. ]

Corrections
LEAD: A brief report in the Media Business pages last Wednesday about the Washington Post Company's earnings incorrectly characterized the performance of the company's businesses outside of newspapers, television and cable.
Excluding the results of businesses that were sold before the second quarter, those operations reported higher revenue.

Network Computing Lures Husband-and-Wife Team
LEAD: When William Carrico and Judith Estrin resigned as president and senior vice president of the 3Com Corporation in June, their plan was to take three months off and see the world.
But it has not worked out that way.
The husband-and-wife founders of Bridge Communications Inc., which merged with 3Com in September 1987, soon found themselves deluged with job offers and business plans, and yesterday announced they have joined Network Computing Devices Inc., a startup company based in Palo Alto, Calif.

Bank of New York Loses Request for Quick Hearing
LEAD: The Bank of New York suffered a legal setback yesterday in its long-running battle to acquire the Irving Bank Corporation and will be forced to ask the Federal Reserve Board for a third extension for its bid.

Victims of Warsaw Uprising and World War II Are Remembered
LEAD: Poles gathered at the Powazki military cemetery in Warsaw yesterday as they marked the outbreak of the 1944 uprising against the Nazis in World War II.
Many of the 200,000 victims of the two-month struggle are buried there beside the dead of two world wars.
The monument at left is to the thousands of Polish officers killed in the Katyn Forest during the war.

Reviews/Music; Willcocks Leads Mozart Requiem
LEAD: Four years ago, Sir David Willcocks, the British choral director, made his Mostly Mozart debut with a program that included the Mozart Requiem in a new edition by Richard Maunder.
At the time, this edition excited considerable interest, since Mr.
Maunder had not only revamped Franz Sussmayr's awkward scoring (undertaken after Mozart's death, the composer having left this final work incomplete), but did away with several movements believed to be fully composed by Sussmayr, and added an Amen fugue based on a


Mall Stake Sold By Carter Hawley
LEAD: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said it had sold its interest in a California shopping center for $32 million.
Carter Hawley, the nation's 14th-largest retailer, also said it had established $25 million in reserves for consolidation and other costs in its fourth quarter, which ended June 30.

China's Growing Debt
LEAD: China said today that it did not face a debt crisis but admitted that its debt had grown too fast and needed better management.
The magazine Beijing Review said foreign debt had climbed more than 30 percent a year in the last few years and would reach $40 billion by the mid-1990's, with a repayment burden of $13 billion a year.


PCB Exposure Linked to Birth Defects in Taiwan
LEAD: An industrial accident in Taiwan nine years ago that spilled high levels of toxic PCB's into cooking oil has caused an epidemic of birth defects, a new study has found.


Jordanians and Israelis: A History in Maps
LEAD:  1918: British forces under Gen.
Sir Edmund Allenby defeat the Turks in a battle south of the West Bank city of Nablus, ending Ottoman control over Palestine.  1923: The League of Nations gives Britain a mandate over Palestine, an area that includes the East Bank of the Jordan River.
Palestinian leaders protest the decision and demand independence.

Crop-Duster Crash Kills Two
LEAD: A crop duster plane clipped the tail section of another crop duster, causing both planes to crash into a soybean field and killing the two pilots, officials said Saturday.
The single-engine aircraft crashed Friday night near the Almyra Municipal Airport, about 60 miles southeast of Little Rock.

LEAD: If political language is ''the ability to give an appearance of solidity to pure wind,'' as George Orwell noted, then the small class of right-wing pundits who helped popularize the gospel according to Reagan for the first seven years of the Administration deserve special recognition for their achievements as political linguists.

LEAD: A prom in Purdy became much more likely today when a Federal district judge ruled unconstitutional the school district's ban on dances that dates back at least a century.

Reviews/Music; Murder, Suicide and the Black Plague
LEAD: In another life, Krzysztof Penderecki might have found a career producing Hollywood horror films.
The Polish composer, who made his mark internationally in 1960 with his ''Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima'' and filled the stage with sex-crazed nuns in his 1969 opera ''The Devils of Loudon,'' has always been attracted to subjects intended to make the audience's skin crawl.

New York Receives Its Fair Federal Share
LEAD: To the Editor:


Columnist Pleads Not Guilty To Pistol Possession Charges
LEAD: The syndicated columnist Carl T. Rowan, an outspoken supporter of stricter gun controls, pleaded not guilty today to misdemeanor charges that he used an unregistered pistol to shoot a teen-ager who was trespassing in his backyard and who, according to Mr.
Rowan, was lunging at him.


Bank Credit Set For Control Data
LEAD: The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it had secured a $225 million credit facility with a group of banks led by the Bank of America.
It is the corporation's first domestic credit facility since its financial restructuring in 1986.


Editorial Foe of Apartheid Is Reportedly Back in Prison
LEAD: The editor of a leading anti-apartheid newspaper in South Africa has been sent back to prison from a Johannesburg hospital, his lawyer said yesterday.


Freddie Mac Is Offering $650 Million in Securities
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, also known as Freddie Mac, is offering $650 million of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities, or Remics.
The securities are backed by 9 percent Freddie Mac mortgage participation certificates provided by Bear, Stearns &amp; Company.

LEAD: Ever hopeful that North Korea will reconsider its decision not to participate in the Olympics next month in Seoul, South Korea, the organizers of the Summer Games are reserving a building in the athletes' village to house North Koreans and athletes from any of the other five nations that have declined the invitation to attend.

Finnish Shipbuilder Finds Fresh Markets
LEAD: After a half hour, the fish-spotting count was none too impressive: one minnow and a startled salmon.
Mostly, the vista seen from any one of the submarine's 22 portholes was a meager couple of feet of visibility in the dark, murky waters of Lake Simojarvi.

LEAD: Trades through accounts at about two dozen major Wall Street firms are being examined in the investigation of trading based on advance knowledge of articles in Business Week magazine, people close to the inquiry said yesterday.

The Perfect Circle Was a Bad Idea
LEAD: Circular loops were tried and rejected decades ago because roller coaster cars moved too fast at the bottom and too slowly at the top.
The rapid upward climb created excessive centrifugal force that pressed riders into seats uncomfortably.
But the slowdown at the top could let upside-down riders fall out of their seats as centrifugal force weakened and gravity became the cominant force.

LEAD: Seagate Technology Inc., the largest independent manufacturer of hard disk drives, said today that it had reduced its Asia production schedules because of high inventory levels of finished goods, and had lowered its shipment rates.

Stanley Givirtz, 59, Biblical Scholar

Out of South Africa, a Playwright's Raw Material
LEAD: When Jon Robin Baitz was 10 years old, his family, which had left Los Angeles for Brazil two years earlier, moved to Durban, South Africa. ''My first memory of South Africa is getting off the airplane and seeing a sign in the airport that read, 'This door for whites only,' '' Mr.
Baitz recalled the other day over coffee in his Chelsea apartment.


FOR PALESTINIANS, THE SENSE OF JOY AND ABANDONMENT
LEAD: Across the West Bank, many Palestinians expressed joy today over King Hussein's decision to end the Jordanian presence in Israel's occupied territories.
But at least a few Palestinians, still loyal to the King, were distraught.


Seymour M. Klein, 79; Prosecuted Gangsters
LEAD: Seymour M. Klein, a lawyer who prosecuted several gangland figures as an assistant United States Attorney in the 1930's, died Sunday of complications after surgery at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on July 23 about the beginning of the post-convention Dukakis campaign identified a new member of the Democratic National Committee incompletely and misstated her views.
Ruth Ann Skaff is a vocal supporter of the Palestinian cause but not explicitly of the Palestine Liberation Organization; she is also the Texas coordinator for the Arab American Institute.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Campaign Courtship
LEAD: In politics, timing is everything -well, almost.
And so, it would appear, in love as well, when love involves people involved in politics.
Two senatorial press aides started dating a year ago and announced their engagement July 23, just after the Democratic National Convention.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  COMPANIES  Gillette and Coniston signed a cease-fire agreement.
The company and its largest shareholder agreed to drop all litigation stemming from Coniston's attempt in April to unseat four directors.
Coniston agreed not to increase its stake for three years, while Gillette agreed to buy back 16 million shares of its 112 million shares outstanding for $45 each, $7.50 above market value.


S.E.C. Tells Contractors They Must Disclose Inquiry Data
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today put military contractors on notice that subjects of the Pentagon procurement investigation must disclose that fact in their filings with the agency.


NBC Seeks Stake in Foreign News Unit
LEAD: NBC, working under a corporate mandate to put its news operation on a paying basis, is negotiating to buy a substantial portion of Visnews, a European video news agency.
The move would allow NBC to trim many of its own overseas news operations, saving up to $5 million a year, network executives said yesterday.

Rig Count Falls by 9
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States slipped last week by 9, to 894, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
In the previous week, the rig count had increased by 4, to 903.
A year ago, the total was 973, the company said.
Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched measure of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not the number of rigs producing oil.

Koch Sets Up A Peace Talk With Jackson
LEAD: Mayor Koch telephoned the Rev.
Jesse Jackson yesterday morning, and the two arranged, through the intercession of Governor Cuomo and Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan, to meet before the end of the month.


Paul C. Reardon, 78; Led Study Urging Curbs on Trial Publicity
LEAD: Paul C. Reardon, a former Associate Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, who directed a study that advocated restrictions on the release and publication of information about people accused of crimes, died of heart failure Friday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
He was 78 years old.

LEAD: New York State, which just last month took steps to close a $950 million budget shortfall, now faces a new shortfall of $133 million and there is a strong possibility it will increase in the next few months, the Cuomo administration announced today.

Neptune's Magnetism
LEAD: The measurement of radio waves from Neptune has shown that the planet generates a magnetic field.
The observation confirms what had been expected on theoretical grounds, notably because such magnetism is generated by other, nearer planets, including Uranus, Jupiter and the Earth itself.

LEAD: Higher sales and lower expenses and taxes helped to raise the Boeing Company's second-quarter profits 36.8 percent, the Seattle-based aerospace company said today.


Blacks and Jews, New York and Chicago
LEAD: The temptation is to dismiss talk of a Jesse Jackson-Edward Koch peace conference, engineered by Mario Cuomo, as just election-year politics.
After all, these Democrats have a common interest in winning New York in November for the Dukakis-Bentsen ticket, and they know they stand a better chance together than apart.

LEAD: After months of persistent wrangling, the Gillette Company and its largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, said yesterday that they had agreed to drop all litigation stemming from Coniston's unsuccessful attempt in April to unseat four members of Gillette's board.

Crater in Iowa Is Linked to Impact
LEAD: AN analysis of samples extracted from wells has convinced geologists that a crater 20 miles wide was formed some 66 million years ago when an object two miles in diameter struck what is now Iowa.
The crater, long since filled in, is the largest known impact structure in the United States.

Review/Music; Canadian Brass, in a Serious Concert
LEAD: A decade ago, the Canadian Brass was a fairly good ensemble, as brass quintets go - which is to say that it played its constricted repertory of Baroque transcriptions, marches and ragtime works with polish and panache.
Since then, the quintet has discovered that cutesiness and middle-brow comedy are more lucrative than straightforward musicianship, and as its sound grew tarnished, it devoted itself to such gimmicks as dressing in tutus to play ballet medleys and recording an execrable disco track called ''Boy Mozart.

By Design; Pattern of the Moment
LEAD: Polka dots have replaced last summer's leopard spots as the pattern of the moment in Paris.
Printed on fabrics from pique to crepe, dots are being worn by young and old.
No item of clothing is immune.
Everything from inexpensive separates to luxurious dresses to lingerie and accessories is showered with dots.

The W.B.L. is a league for players 6 feet 4 inches and under.

LEAD: Using lines that could have been written for the Rev.

Window Glass Tracks Exposure to Radon
LEAD: GLASS in windows or picture frames retains lasting traces of radon pollution inside homes, a Swedish researcher has found.
Hence the glass in homes could be used to help determine the extent of past exposure to the radioactive gas.


Protein That Helps Nose to Smell Is Identified
LEAD: A complex protein produced in a nasal gland has been identified by researchers as the chemical messenger that carries aromas to the odor-sensing nerves of the nose.

Build Schools, Not Obstacles
LEAD: There is wide agreement that New York City's Board of Education ought to get out of the business of building schools, and the State Legislature is about to create a public authority to take over the task of school construction.
But negotiations are hung up on the Wicks Law, which prohibits use of a general contractor on public construction jobs.


Vice President at G.M. Takes Post at Navistar
LEAD: Roy S. Roberts, who presided over an effort to shake up the General Motors Corporation's entrenched bureaucracy, was named yesterday as vice president for truck operations at Navistar International Corporation.


Our Towns; A Groundswell Of Rent-Revolt Shakes a Domain
LEAD: About 300 families in this seaside hamlet own their houses but not the land underneath them.
That belongs to the American Timber Company, a family-owned business that charges the tenants land rent every year.
And for more than 60 years, the company and homeowners treated each other more like family than like landlord and tenants.

Chess
LEAD: One of the most solidly grounded generalizations in chess is that the bishop pair is stronger than two knights, yet there is the occasional dramatic exception.


Simple Life Helps Amish Survive Drought
LEAD: An Amish farmer in Ohio unloading hay imported from Vermont to help get through the worst drought in 50 years.
The Amish, who have no electricity in their homes and no motorized farming equipment, pay cash for grain and seed and therefore have no debts; they also have money set aside for emergencies.


Sun Reports Record Profit
LEAD: Bouyed by strong shipments of all its products, Sun Microsystems Inc. reported record results for the quarter and year ended June 30.
For the fiscal fourth quarter, Sun earned $25.3 million, or 66 cents a share, more than double the $10.9 million, or 31 cents a share, reported in the comparable period a year ago.

32 Prison Inmates Seize 5 Guards, Then Free 1
LEAD: Thirty-two inmates housed in a special unit for prisoners with disciplinary problems overpowered five guards at the Coxsackie Correctional Facility here Monday morning.
One of the guards was released Monday night, and the other four were held for more than 14 hours, before being released early today.


Walker Has Virus
LEAD: Doctors believe that Greg Walker, the Chicago White Sox first baseman who suffered two seizures over the weekend, has a viral infection in his brain.


Critic's Notebook; At Bayreuth, a Wagnerian Togetherness
LEAD: A true festival, one devoted single-mindedly to a particular composer or theme and taking place far from the distractions of big-city life, does more than provide great performances.
It binds the audience into a community.

LEAD: The Amdahl Corporation announced price cuts of 10 to 14 percent on various models of its 5890 and 5990 mainframe computers, effective immediately.

Bid for Interco
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. told the Rales brothers of Washington in a letter that it was ''highly confident'' it could raise $1.375 billion, or two-thirds of the money needed, for a $64-a-share bid for Interco Inc.
Steven M. Rales and his brother Mitchell lead a group that holds an 8.7 percent stake in the furniture and shoe company and they have offered $2.1 billion for the rest.

LEAD: The days turned to months, and then to years, but the luck in Steve Shields's life never really changed.

LEAD: John Cardinal Dearden, a liberal voice in his church who was the spiritual leader of 1.2 million Roman Catholics in metropolitan Detroit for more then 20 years, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at Providence Hospital in suburban Southfield, Mich.
He was 80 years old.

MICROWAVE COOKING
LEAD: LITTLE is more refreshing on a hot day than a cold bowl of intensely flavored soup for a simple lunch or to start a meal.
And at a time when fat and cholesterol are on everyone's least-wanted list, summer soups can form the basis for satisfying, guilt-free meals.
These soups must be made ahead, but with a microwave oven, they will take little time to cook and even less time to chill.

What Tugboat Strike?
LEAD: Forty-two years ago, a 12-day tugboat strike brought New York City to a standstill.
Coal to make electricity and heat buildings was practically exhausted.
Food supplies were menaced.
Mayor William O'Dwyer ordered all places of public assembly closed to cut travel and electric use and to dramatize the dangers posed by the labor conflict, prodding both sides into an agreement.

Zeffirelli Protests 'Temptation of Christ'
LEAD: The Italian director Franco Zeffirelli said today he was withdrawing his new film from the Venice film festival because ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' was on the program.


TLC Group to Sell Confection Maker
LEAD: The TLC Group, the New York investment company led by the financier Reginald F. Lewis, said it had agreed to sell the Callard &amp; Bowser Group, a British-based maker of confectionary products, to United Biscuits P.L.C., a food company also based in Britain, for about $37 million.
The deal represents the latest divestiture of businesses that are part of the Beatrice International Company, which TLC purchased for $985 million last year.


A Middle East Advance?
LEAD: King Hussein's renunciation of Jordan's responsibilities for the West Bank is the most dramatic gesture in the Arab-Israeli impasse since Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt flew to Jerusalem offering peace.

Braniff Inc., Dallas, a unit of BIA-COR Holdings Inc., said it would cut service in Orlando, Fla., by 30 percent and eliminate 154 jobs.
It has 600 employees in Orlando.

LEAD: ARVIDAS SABONIS has no fear of the giants of the National Basketball Association - not of their elbows, not of their aerodynamics, not of their poise.
But back in the Soviet Union there are men of more modest size who worry Arvidas Sabonis.

Flimflam Men Peddling Medical Gizmos
LEAD: Remember the old-time snake oil pitchmen who huckstered Colonel Goodbody's Magic Elixir?
Their direct descendants are many of today's medical equipment salesmen, who peddle useless and expensive gizmos to the nation's unsuspecting senior citizens - harvesting millions in Medicare profits.


PRETORIA PROPOSES ANGOLA TRUCE SOON
LEAD: South Africa today proposed a cease-fire in Angola starting Aug. 10 that would lead to a withdrawal of Pretoria's troops from Angola and Namibia, and to elections in Namibia supervised by the United Nations next June.


A Revised Proposal On Texas Property
LEAD: The Las Colinas Corporation unit of the Southland Financial Corporation has avoided a foreclosure sale of a 12,000-acre site that was set for today by the Royal Bank of Canada.
Jim Choate, a lawyer for the Royal Bank, said it had received a revised proposal from Southland on Monday and would extend the sale date to review it.

Gemini Partners Sells Armtek Stake
LEAD: Gemini Partners L.P., a New York-based investment group, said it had purchased a 7.5 percent stake in Armtek Inc., with the view towards a possible takeover of the New Haven-based tire manufacturer, but instead sold most of the shares for a profit estimated at $3.5 million.
Armtek, formerly the Armstrong Rubber Company, has received a $40-a-share bid from Mark IV Industries of West Amherst, N.Y.

LEAD: Reader's Digest Association Inc., the magazine and book publisher, said yesterday that it had shuffled the assignments of some top executives after the retirement of several top managers.

60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: BLACK sea bass is popular in restaurants and fish markets today, especially since striped-bass fishing has been banned in many areas because of water pollution.
The black sea bass, while much smaller than the striped bass, has mild-flavored white meat that is well suited to simple dishes made with fresh herbs.


Sears Plans to Sell Xerox Products
LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company announced an agreement to sell the business products of the Xerox Corporation through its catalogues and stores.
Sears will this month begin selling Xerox's personal copiers and an elec-tronic typewriter.
Service for the products will be offered at Sears service centers.


Martha Graham Fall Season
LEAD: The Martha Graham Dance Company is to open its three-week season at the City Center on Oct. 4, with a gala benefit starring Mikhail Baryshnikov, Maya Plisetskaya and Kathleen Turner.
Mr.
Baryshnikov will dance the title role in ''El Penitente'' and Miss Turner will interpret ''She Who Speaks'' in ''Letter to the World,'' a major Graham revival.


At 21, a Black Troupe Looks for a New Path
LEAD: In 21 years, the Negro Ensemble Company has gone from bold experiment in the East Village to $1.2 million-a-year theater company, the longest continuously operating black theater organization in the city's history.
Now it is at a crossroads.


Bulgarian Jet Crashes; 23 Are Reported Dead
LEAD: A Balkan Bulgarian Airlines jet crashed just after taking off from Sofia today, killing 23 people and injuring 14, the official Bulgarian press agency said.

LEAD: Call-in radio shows have become commonplace in this country, but officials of the Voice of America thought it might be stretching things a bit to expect residents of the Peoples Republic of China to telephone Washington with their questions, even on a universal subject like cancer.
After all, such callers would have to go to the local post office from 10 P.M.


Nikko Role Is Expanded
LEAD: The Nikko Securities Company today became the first Japanese securities firm to receive approval to clear trades at the Chicago Board of Trade.


Senate Acts to Enforce Housing Law
LEAD: The Senate, acting to put teeth into a civil rights bill passed 20 years ago, today approved a measure providing tougher enforcement of Federal laws prohibiting discrimination in housing.
The vote on the bill, which the House passed a month ago, was 94 to 3.

LEAD: The E.C.A.C.
Metro Conference has changed its name to the Northeast Conference. ''We feel, by going with a new name, that we give ourselves our own identity,'' said Chris Monasch, the commissioner of the league, which was formed in 1961 under the umbrella of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

Kings Sign Berry
LEAD: Ricky Berry, the 6-foot-8-inch guard from San Jose State, who was the No. 1 draft pick of the Sacramento Kings, has signed a three-year contract with the club.
The Los Angeles Lakers have signed David Rivers, the point guard from Notre Dame, to a multiyear contract.
Rivers was the final player selected in the first round of the draft.


Lorimar Sells Affiliates
LEAD: The Lorimar Telepictures Corporation said Monday that it had sold three network-affiliated television stations for a total of $23 million.
The previously announced transaction involved the stations KCMP-TV, Chico-Redding, Calif.; KMID-TV, Midland-Odessa, Tex., and KSPR-TV, Springfield, Mo.
The buyer was Goltrin Acquisition Partnership, whose principals are Joseph Goldfarb, a former Lorimar executive; Barbara E.

First, and Fast: Cease-Fire in the Gulf
LEAD: As Iran and Iraq are learning, wars are harder to finish than to start.
Iraq's continued attacks, and Iran's offers to help secure release of America's hostages, are moves in a complex end game that could easily become protracted.
That's why so much depends on the efforts of the United Nations Secretary General to achieve the immediate goal, a cease-fire.

Coffee Prices Hit Lowest Level in Year
LEAD: Coffee prices continued to plunge yesterday, and analysts said the international coffee market was in almost total disarray.
At the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the spot September delivery fell an additional 7.84 cents a pound, to $1.0883, a 12-month low.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Earnings Rise 19.2% At Omnicom Group
LEAD: The Omnicom Group, whose major subsidiaries are BBDO and DDB Needham, yesterday reported a 19.2 percent increase in net income for the second quarter.
The company said it earned $12.4 million, or 50 cents a share, in this year's second quarter, compared with $10.4 million, or 43 cents, in the period a year earlier.


Bordeaux Team Comes to L.I. To Share Expertise
LEAD: BOTH the Medoc region of France, home of fine Bordeaux wines, and Long Island, home of an expanding wine industry, have maritime climates.
Both have soils rich in sand, gravel, silt and clay.
They even have cabernet sauvignon and merlot in common.

Review/Music; The Elusive Haydn's 'Paris' Group
LEAD: Listening to music is, in one sense, an attempt to appropriate a little of its power for ourselves.
We are comforted when we can take its measure - assign it a style, a design, a message, a place in history.
Music appreciation involves this process of reduction in which a work much wider than we are is shrunk to form a neat compartment within the listener's sensibilities.

LEAD: With Republicans increasingly alarmed about their political prospects this fall, President Reagan today bowed to the appeals of Vice President Bush and his party's Congressional leaders and said he would not veto a bill requiring companies to provide 60 days' notice of major layoffs or factory closings.

LEAD: At age 29, Rowdy Gaines is as trim and as youthful as ever except for a hairline that keeps sneaking back.
After he won three gold medals in the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, he retired from swimming and has kept busy with appearances, speeches, endorsements, swimming clinics, coaching and television commentary.

2 More Settlements On Go-Video VCR
LEAD: Go-Video Inc. has reached settlements with two more defendants in its year-old antitrust lawsuit over its dual-deck video cassette recorder.
Go-Video, based in Phoenix, agreed to drop its lawsuit against the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and Akai Electric Company.
The Tokyo-based companies paid no damages but agreed to consider manufacturing the dual-deck VCR under license.

LEAD: Florence Eldridge, the actress who appeared with her husband, Fredric March, in several Broadway plays and movies, including ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' ''The Skin of Our Teeth'' and ''Another Part of the Forest,'' died in a hospital emergency room Monday night in Santa Barbara, Calif.
She was 86 years old.

Review/Film; An 'Alice' for Adults
LEAD: Of all the ways to adapt ''Alice in Wonderland,'' the most perverse, it seems, would be to peel back its genteel Victorian veneer.
Without the story's decorum and fairy-tale disguises, the Hatter would seem dangerously mad, the Caterpillar would be a seductive snake, all of Wonderland would be haunted rather than fantastic.

LEAD: The Iraqi delegation to the Persian Gulf talks said today that Baghdad would not accept the cease-fire declared by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, repeating Baghdad's demand for direct talks with Iran before the fighting can stop.

Dow Buyback Plan
LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said it would buy back 10 million of its approximately 190 million shares outstanding.
The repurchase, to be made over an indefinite period, will increase shareholders' equity, said Enrique C. Falla, a Dow vice president.
The company has repurchased more than 20 million shares in nine buyback programs since August 1983; the latest was announced three months ago.

Economic Scene; A Free Market In Water Rights
LEAD: IN the central valleys of California, farmers pay as little as $10 to irrigate an acre of cotton.

LEAD: Registered nurses picketing outside Saint Francis Memorial Hospital yesterday.

Panel Adopts Animal Patent Bill
LEAD: The House Judiciary Committee, in a move applauded by farmers and criticized by biotechnology companies, approved legislation today that would exempt farmers from paying royalties to inventors on the offspring of patented genetically altered animals.

LEAD: WITH many individual investors remaining on the sidelines, wary of a stock market that gives little hint of where it is headed, brokers are scanning the reports of various market strategists for convincing technical or economic projections they can pass on to clients.
But listening to more than one strategist may lead only to more uncertainty.

Factory Center At Old Terminal To Be Expanded
LEAD: Proclaiming success in its effort to turn part of the old Brooklyn Army Terminal into a manufacturing center, the Koch administration said yesterday that it would double the capacity of the center by spending $44.5 million to renovate an additional one million square feet of space by mid-1990.


Fare Fairness
LEAD: Even at $1 - which is to say, 95 more cents than it used to be - many still consider a trip on a New York subway a bargain.
Unless, of course, you have just arrived at 42d Street by way of the IRT or BMT lines and wish to continue your journey on the IND line.
It's a blocklong tunnel away and you've got drop another buck to get there.


Educaton; About Education
LEAD: Demands to make all Americans scientifically literate have become almost as insistent as the call for basic skills.
In the two decades after the Soviets launched Sputnik in 1957, the Federal Government spent several billion dollars for that purpose.
Many colleges include at least a smattering of science among their requirements.

Joseph Costa, Photographer, 84
LEAD: Joseph Costa, a veteran newspaper photographer, died of pnuemonia Monday at a convalescent home in Carmel, Calif.

Trade Bill Nears Passage As Key Obstacle Is Cleared
LEAD: A bill ushering in the broadest overhaul of trade policy in the postwar era is expected to become law soon, following President Reagan's decision today not to veto a separate measure requiring companies to provide 60 days' notice of layoffs or factory closings.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Advertising Growth Slows for Newspapers
LEAD: Craig Standen, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, yesterday told the members of the International Newspaper Advertising and Marketing Executives, who are meeting in Toronto, that the bureau was revising downward its earlier estimates of 1988 newspaper advertising revenues.
It is now calling for revenues of about $31.3 billion, a 6 percent increase over last year, instead of $31.7 billion, about an 8 percent in-crease.

CALIFORNIANS SEEK PRODUCT WARNINGS
LEAD: In a bold new tactic to warn consumers about dangerous chemicals in products, four environmental groups said today that they would bring legal action against the makers and sellers of cigars and pipe tobacco if the Attorney General of California did not.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions of Business Day yesterday about the Bank of New York's attempt to acquire the Irving Bank Corporation misstated the value of a competing offer from Banca Commerciale Italiana.
The Italian bank has offered $775 million in cash for 51 percent of Irving's shares.


Study Backs Heart Benefit in Light Drinking
LEAD: A new study of more than 87,000 women shows that moderate drinking decreases the risk of heart attack and the most common kind of stroke.
Previous studies found similar effects in men, but similar findings in smaller studies of women have been subject to debate.


Washington Talk: Briefing; The Prestige Seats
LEAD: The front row in the White House press room is a place of prestige reserved for the senior correspondentsfrom the three major television networks and the news services.
So chroniclers of Washington ways found it noteworthy yesterday when five of the six seats were occupied by women - the first time, in anybody's memory, that that had occurred.

LEAD: A military investigation of the shooting down of an Iranian airliner by an American warship last month has blamed crew error arising from the psychological stress of being in combat for the first time, Defense Department officials familiar with the inquiry said today.

Trade Canceled
LEAD: The Cleveland Browns yesterday rescinded the trade that brought the wide receiver Daryl Turner from the Seattle Seahawks because Turner failed the Browns' physical examination.
Turner has a congenital problem in his lower back that might keep him from playing or practicing in the future, the Browns' coach, Marty Schottenheimer, said.


life in the 30's
LEAD: SMALL children make useful companions, unless you are interested in eating at expensive restaurants.
You can take them to see movies like ''Bambi,'' and no one will think you are weird enough to want to see those movies yourself.
You can use them as an excuse to go to amusement parks and to consume leftover bits of hot dogs and cotton candy.

LEAD: ''When you cross the Salt River you will be on my land,'' said Ronnie Lupe, guiding a visitor not to his house but to the 1.5 million-acre Indian reservation that he and 9,000 other White Mountain Apaches regard as a remnant of their ancestral home.

LEAD: Six American fighter planes and two bombers that crash-landed in Greenland in World War II have been found 46 years later buried under 260 feet of ice, searchers said today.

Sunflowers Grand and Majestic
LEAD: VANGOGH painted them.
Oscar Wilde wore them.
Milliners at the turn of the century made them out of silk to decorate fashionable bonnets.
Nowadays, sunflowers turn the heads of shoppers by rearing their own -large and luminous with vivid yellow petals and deep brown centers.
Like royalty, they nod to the lowly herbs and the more colorful but less majestic zinnias and marigolds.

LEAD: Uncircumcised men are at greater risk of infection with the AIDS virus regardless of whether they have a history of genital ulcers, a new study of men in Nairobi, Kenya, suggests.

Andre Navarra, Cellist, 77
LEAD: Andre Navarra, a cellist and a longtime professor at the Conservatoire Nationale de Paris, died of a heart attack Sunday at his hotel in Siena, Italy.
He was 77 years old.
Mr.
Navarra had been offering advanced music courses at nearby Chigiana, a summer activity he had pursued since 1954.
The cellist was a respected practitioner of the French school of string playing and an active concert and recording artist.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL  The most sweeping trade bill in a generation was passed by the Senate, 85 to 11, and sent to the President.
The legislation is intended to make the U.S. more assertive and competitive by giving the President broader powers to retaliate against unfair trading practices.
The bill also seeks from foreign governments access to their markets similar to what the U.S.


G.M. to Shorten but Widen Coverage of Its Warranty
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would change the warranty it offers on most of its cars and light trucks from six-year, 60,000-mile coverage of basic engine and transmission parts to a more comprehensive three-year, 50,000-mile package.
The change will apply to 1989 models.
The new warranty will cover virtually all the parts on a vehicle, G.M.

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today accused two of his former aides of presenting Congress with a ''false and distorted picture of the situation'' in the Justice Department.

Home Improvement
LEAD: SUSPENDED ceilings, which consist of lightweight panels supported by a grid of metal strips hung from the existing ceiling or ceiling framework, are easy for amateurs to install.
Available in a wide variety of styles and colors, the panels and structural components can be purchased at home centers in kit form and are inexpensive enough to consider as an alternative to extensive patching and repainting.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: MOTHERS and fathers used to pick up the tricks of the child-rearing trade mostly from their own parents or by trading tips with other moms and dads.
Today, a growing number of parents are turning to formal classes and workshops.
While programs that focus on childbirth and the first year of life deal primarily with the mechanics of child care, classes for parents of older children emphasize understanding how a child or adolescent thinks.

LEAD: The domestic manufacturers of cars and light trucks today reported unexpectedly strong sales for July while imports showed surprising losses.

Ban on Options Trader
LEAD: The Chicago Board Options Exchange today suspended a former trader for profiting from phony options trades that he submitted to the exchange's clearinghouse.
Eric Joseph, a market maker, was censured and suspended from membership on the exchange for five years.
He was also banned from associating with any exchange member in that period.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about President Reagan's decision against vetoing the bill on layoffs and factory closings misstated the timing of some changes in it.
While the disputed provision was still part of the trade bill - which the President vetoed on May 24 - Congress modified the provision to make it apply to fewer companies.

LEAD: Coffee futures prices soared more than 9 cents a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York yesterday in a sharp technical reversal of a trend that had taken prices to their lowest levels in a year.


STARS' DATA HINT AT OTHER PLANETS
LEAD: Astronomers from the United States and Canada have found evidence of 10 planet-like objects orbiting distant stars, a discovery that intensifies speculation about the existence of life beyond Earth.

LEAD: After almost half the judges in the Eastern District of New York excused themselves from his case, a prominent defense lawyer finally found a judge yesterday who was willing to accept his plea of guilty in a tax-evasion case.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis, seeking to quash rumors about his mental health, eased his reluctance to discuss his medical history today and ordered his doctor to release a more detailed report that gave him a clean bill of health.

Ford May Raise Some '89 Prices
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company, following the lead of the Chrysler Corporation, said it tentatively plans to raise 1989 prices on six cars by up to 5.3 percent.

Forsaken Brooch Auctioned for $632,500
LEAD: A Tiffany emerald and diamond brooch, abandoned seven years ago in a safe deposit box in a New York bank, was auctioned yesterday for $632,500 at William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street.
New York State will be the main beneficiary.

LEAD: Martin A. Massengale, the chancellor of the University of Nebraska, has been elected chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Presidents' Commission.

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  International A3-11


Senate Democrats Agree on Contra Aid Plan
LEAD: Senate Democrats agreed today on a plan to provide the Nicaraguan rebels with $27 million for food, clothing, shelter and medical supplies.
But they ruled out any money for arms and ammunition except under carefully circumscribed conditions and a subsequent vote by both houses of Congress.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Anyone Can Play
LEAD: The phrase ''journalism is a a young man's game'' was made at least partly obsolete years ago by large numbers of extraordinarily talented women in all branches of the profession.


Review/Theater; A Love Object Shows Who's Boss
LEAD: Carlo Goldoni's mid-18th century comedy about the battle of the sexes, ''The Mistress of the Inn,'' is something of a Halley's Comet of a play, one that isn't seen very often.
We should be elated that it has landed once again in New York, this time accompanied by a bright star, Tovah Feldshuh, in the lead role at the Roundabout Theater


Detroit Voters Again Reject Casino Gambling
LEAD: Voters in Detroit rejected casino gambling Tuesday while voters in Missouri agreed to aid their struggling lottery by increasing the jackpot limit.


Reward for Morgan
LEAD: Joe Morgan, who has led the Boston Red Sox to pennant contention since replacing John McNamara as manager on July 14, was rewarded yesterday with a new contract through the 1989 season.


Review/Pop; Mostly Fusion By a French Gypsy Guitarist
LEAD: The French gypsy guitarist Bireli Lagrene made a small tactical error at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night.
Though he opened with ''Blues for Ike,'' a composition by Django Reinhardt, Mr.
Lagrene spent most of the set playing anonymous fusion on his electric guitar.
To make things worse, the band, featuring an electric bass, an instrument nearly impossible to make swing, was obviously unrehearsed and had the rhythmic surety of goats on ice.

Freer Export Of Computers
LEAD: The United States has relaxed its curbs on the export of lower-level computers to China and the Soviet bloc, the Commerce Department said Tuesday.
The main changes affect China.
The new rules allow the export to China of computers that work far faster than those now permitted to be exported.
Paul Freedenberg,


Prince Philip's Mother Buried in Jerusalem
LEAD: The dying wish of Queen Elizabeth's mother-in-law was fulfilled today when her body, protected by armed Israeli border police, was laid to rest here 19 years after her death.


It Wasn't a Science-Fiction Movie
LEAD: Firefighters from the Hazmat, or hazardous materials unit, wearing protective clothing as they battled a transformer fire yesterday at Park Avenue and 78th Street.
The smoky fire, which occurred in a manhole, did not cause a blackout, but firefighters cut electricity to 898 Park Avenue, an apartment house, to keep air-conditioners from sucking in smoke.

U.S.-Japan Food Accord
LEAD: The United States and Japan signed a farm trade agreement Tuesday.
The Reagan Administration expects it to double American exports of processed food products to Japan, to $160 million annually, by 1990.
Japan is to phase out quotas on imports in seven categories, including dairy and fruit items, while increasing quotas in two others and compensating the United States for keeping restrictions in two others.

Request on Interco
LEAD: The Washington investors, Steven M. Rales and Mitchell P. Rales, demanded a list of all of the shareholders of Interco Inc.
The Rales brothers have offered to acquire Interco, the nation's biggest manufacturer of furniture and men's shoes, for $64 a share, or $2.1 billion.
In a letter to Interco dated Tuesday, contained in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Rales brothers said that the purpose of their demand is to communicate directly with the company's shareholders.

7 Killed in Oregon Highway Mishap
LEAD: Firefighters extinguishing a burning truck, one of 23 vehicles involved in a fiery crash on Interstate 5 near Albany, Ore., that killed seven people and injured 37.
Dense smoke enveloped the road after a fire set on a farm field to control insects and plant disease burned out of control.
Blinded motorists apparently slammed on their brakes, causing a chain-reaction collision over a half-mile stretch of the highway.


Sports People; Beer Containers Found
LEAD: The Tampa Tribune reported yesterday that sheriff's deputies said they had found eight empty beer containers in the car driven by Bruce Kimball, the Olympic diver, that struck and killed two people and injured six Monday night.
Kimball reportedly told investigators he began drinking nine hours before he lost control of his automobile and ran through a group of teen-agers.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 446 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.66 billion, to $264.70 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 125 institutional funds decreased by $14 million, to $68.73 billion.
Those of the 220 general-purpose funds were down by $314.2 million, to $82.89 billion.

LEAD: American Samoa's nonvoting delegate to Congress has pleaded guilty to a charge that he participated in a $130,920 payroll padding scheme, his lawyer says.

LEAD: A Federal commission today called for a comprehensive policy to combat infant mortality, saying that it costs far less to support health care for pregnant women and newborns than to pay later for critical and long-term care for infants.

LEAD: As this city faces mounting fines imposed by a Federal judge for refusing to accept a housing desegregation plan, Deputy Mayor Henry Spallone has never been so exhilarated.

LEAD: Two years ago, Lady's Secret sailed through the mud to become only the fourth filly to win the Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.
She lost two subsequent starts against males, but at season's end she was named the Horse of the Year.

Bank Bailouts: The Cost of Delay
LEAD: ''The worst is over,'' says William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, after bailing out yet another Texas bank.
But that refers only to bank failures.
He estimates that $50 billion is needed to rescue insolvent savings and loan institutions - and counting.
Every month that goes by without a remedy raises the bill, he thinks, by another billion.

Yugoslavia Raises Prices
LEAD: Yugoslavia raised energy and food prices today despite the prospect of further worker unrest.
Electricity rates soared 40 percent; railway fares, 70 percent, and cooking oil prices, 66 percent.


Mirrors of Life
LEAD: Perched high in a cab behind the engine, the driver of a large truck often cannot see pedestrians in crosswalks directly in front of him.
Sensible legislation proposed by New York City's Department of Transportation would eliminate this dangerous blind spot by requiring inexpensive convex safety mirrors.

LEAD: For Ronald Betso, the injured Vietnam War veteran and former New York City police officer who was acquitted yesterday of all charges in the Wedtech trial, calling the end of his five-month ordeal bittersweet is probably a gross understatement.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Profits Up at Ogilvy
LEAD: The Ogilvy Group reported its second-quarter financial results yesterday.
Revenues were $210.7 million, a 13.9 percent increase from the $184.9 million in the second quarter in 1987, while net income was up 10.9 percent to $9.1 million, or 63 cents a share, from $8.2 million, or 55 cents a share.

LEAD: Demand for electricity at Midwest utilities set sharply higher records in the last few days.
The increases were the largest since the early 1970's.

In Salvador, a New Battle for Hearts
LEAD: After years of fruitless prodding from American military advisers, the Salvadoran Army is undertaking a civic action campaign in guerrilla territory in an effort to win the hearts of civilians.


A. L. Rauschenplat, Airline Executive, 55
LEAD: A. L. Rauschenplat, a former vice president-Latin America for Pan American World Airways, died Wednesday at his home in Torremolinos, Spain, after a long illness.
He was 55 years old.


Sports People; Clot in Boyd's Arm
LEAD: A small blood clot was found in a main artery of Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd's right arm, the Boston Red Sox reported yesterday.


Contractor in Pentagon Inquiry Closes
LEAD: A small Florida company that has figured prominently in the investigation of fraud and bribery in military procurement said today that it had closed its operations because it had lost its major customer.


How Wedtech Worked
LEAD: The tale of how a tiny South Bronx machine shop grew almost overnight into a $100 million defense contractor - the Wedtech Corporation -stretches from the lowest sewer of New York City politics to the Reagan White House.
Now a Federal jury in Manhattan has convicted Representative Mario Biaggi, former Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon and four others of turning Wedtech into a racketeering enterprise.


George Palmer, 81, Retired Parks Official
LEAD: George A. Palmer, a former superintendent of the Statue of Liberty and the first superintendent of the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site at Hyde Park, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Cooper Hospital University Medical Center in Camden, N.J.
He was 81 years old and lived in Collingswood, N


Aloysius Mazewski, 72, Polish-American Chief
LEAD: Aloysius Mazewski, president of the Polish American Congress since 1967, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his summer home in Portage, Wis.
He was 72 years old and lived in Northbrook, Ill., a Chicago suburb.


First Republic's Unit Seized
LEAD: Federal regulators have taken control of the First Republicbank Corporation's remaining subsidiary, a credit card operation in Delaware, resolving a dispute with banking authorities there.


Oregon Law Clinic Battles the Timber Industry
LEAD: A long-running dispute between the University of Oregon Law School and the timber industry has intensified, raising concern about academic freedom and questions about programs at public universities through which students participate in litigation.


The Unsteady Foundation of the Criminal Justice System
LEAD: The idea that guilt must be proved ''beyond a reasonable doubt'' undergirds the American criminal justice system.
But that foundation, it seems, is a bit unsteady.
The legal profession lacks a precise definition of just how much doubt is ''reasonable.'' And confusion abounds, studies show.


Sports People; Driving for Madden
LEAD: Jerry Knick of Woodbridge, Va., who has worked as a Greyhound driver for 15 years, defeated nine other finalists to win a job as special chauffeur for John Madden, the television sports analyst, for the next six months.
The National Football League schedule will have the former coach of the Raiders zipping from coast to coast, but he does not fly.


After 10 Years, the Trauma of Love Canal Continues
LEAD: On this day 10 years ago, Joann Hale was seven and a half months pregnant and ''crying like a baby'' on the living room floor of her home on 99th Street here, in the neighborhood known as Love Canal.


Inquiry on Business Week
LEAD: Trading activity at 26 brokerage firms is being investigated by the New York Stock Exchange, which is conducting an inquiry into trading based on advance knowledge of information in Business Week, the magazine reported in its issue distributed yesterday.


Argentine Banks Reopen
LEAD: Customers entering bank in Buenos Aires at end of Government-decreed three-day closing of banks and exchange houses to carry out its new anti-inflation plan.
New measures begin today.

LEAD: Dr.
Grant F. Walton, a former dean of Cook College at Rutgers University, died Wednesday at Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital.
He was 63 years old and lived in Stockton, N.J.


Stake in Formica To Investor Group
LEAD: A 9.6 percent stake in the Formica Corporation has been acquired by Malcolm I. Glazer, members of his family and companies that he controls.
A filing by Mr.
Glazer, a Rochester investor, said he ''may seek to acquire a controlling interest'' in the Wayne, N.J., manufacturer of decorative laminates.

Most of the 200 people of Eighty Eight get their mail by general delivery.

Soviet Grain Harvest Up
LEAD: A Soviet agricultural official said Wednesday that farmers were bringing in more grain this year than in 1987.
Alexander Zholobov of the State Agro-Industrial Committee told the Tass news agency that harvesting rates were ahead of last year's, when 211 million metric tons were reaped.
Last month, the United States Agriculture Department forecast this year's Soviet crop at 215 million metric tons, while the London-based International Wheat Council predicted it would be 218 million metric tons.

Toshiwo Doko Is Dead; Industry Chief Was 91
LEAD: Toshiwo Doko, a former president of the Toshiba Corporation, who helped to revitalize Japanese manufacturing after World War II and promote recent administrative and fiscal changes in Japan, died today.
He was 91 years old.
No cause of death was given.
Mr.
Doko was born in the southwestern city of Okayama in 1896.

LEAD: Sugar Ray Leonard and Donny Lalonde signed today to fight for the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight (175-pound limit) title held by Lalonde and for a newly created W.B.C. supermiddleweight (168-pound limit) crown.


New Thai Prime Minister
LEAD: Chatichai Choonhavan, a former soldier and diplomat, became Thailand's first elected Prime Minister in 12 years today.
Mr.
Chatichai's nomination by a coalition of parties that won a majority of seats in parliamentary elections July 24 was approved by King Bhumibol Adulyadej.


New Limits On Disposal Are Proposed
LEAD: New York State officials said yesterday that they would soon impose new controls on the disposal of infectious waste from medical centers.

LEAD: The United States would find it ''unacceptable'' if the European Community's 1992 integration plans curb American access to the 12-nation bloc, a senior Reagan Administration official said today.

LEAD: Broderbund Inc., a leading producer of software for home and school use, said that Jostens Inc. of Minneapolis had acquired more than 20 percent of the company's common stock for an undisclosed amount of cash.
Privately held Broderbund, based in San Rafael, Calif., has annual sales of more than $40 million.

Koch, Offering New Rules, Lifts Ban on Vendors in Midtown
LEAD: Mayor Koch, in an unexpected move, yesterday lifted a six-week ban that had prohibited vendors from working in midtown Manhattan, and agreed to a compromise to limit food stands on the most congested corners.
The agreement, which requires City Council action, permits the vendors to return today to their most lucrative spots.

LEAD: Taiwan's Prime Minister Yu Kuo-hua said Taiwan wants a free-trade agreement with the United States, its largest trading partner, a Taipei newspaper said Wednesday.

LEAD: The redesigned 1989 Corvette from the General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet division will have an engine made almost entirely of aluminum, G.M. said.

He was 48 years old.
Mr.
Vehr, born in Green Hills, Ohio, had no formal training in theater.

Clausen, its chairman and chief executive, has said.

LEAD: The family of a Palestinian-American who died of a heart attack in the West Bank last weekend has accused Israeli troops of causing the man's death.

Treasury Working on $500 Million Loan to Aid Argentina
LEAD: The Treasury announced today that it was working to arrange an emergency $500 million loan from major industrial countries to ease the latest economic crisis in Argentina, where inflation climbed 25 percent in July alone.

LEAD: A number of analysts think that the impressive quarterly and year-end financial results reported Monday by Sun Microsystems Inc., the Mountain View, Calif., maker of computer work stations, are strong evidence that the computer industry is headed into an era when the greatest growth will come in distributed, or ''network,'' computing.

'On Art' at Whitney
LEAD: The seventh annual series of ''Film and Video on Art'' continues this weekend at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street.
The program of 14 films and 13 videotapes includes profiles of Alice Aycock, Jennifer Bartlett, Romare Bearden, Alfred Stieglitz and others.
A tape on the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and a filmed interview with the architect Frank Gehry are complements of their work now on view.

LEAD: Modern technology has yielded at least one definite advance in the last 30 years: a better Blob.

It can climb to the ceiling and plop down on anyone below.

Two Banks Agree On Loans to Revco
LEAD: Wells Fargo Bank and Marine Midland Bank have agreed to lend $25 million immediately to Revco D.S.
Inc. and $25 million more when the Federal Bankruptcy Court approves arrangements to keep management in charge of the company during its reorganization.
The deal would assure lenders that management of the drugstore chain has the authority to direct company operations and control its assets.

Britain Plans Sale Of Aircraft Maker
LEAD: The British Government plans to sell Short Brothers P.L.C., a state-owned aircraft manufacturer, as a single unit rather than split up the concern, a company spokesman said. ''The Government has agreed to a Short proposal that the company must remain intact as an integrated design and manufacturing aerospace business,'' the spokesman said.

Pop/Jazz; Classical Jazz By Modern Masters At Lincoln Center
LEAD: JUST by its nature, the programming of a concert series always indicates ideological intent - which apples are included, which oranges get left out in the cold.
Classical Jazz, a five-night series opening tonight at Lincoln Center, doesn't mince words, announcing its intentions in its title.
Mostly programmed by Wynton Marsalis, the jazz trumpeter, critic and artistic adviser to the series, and Alina Bloomgarden, the producer, Classical Jazz is heavy with tributes: the composers Tadd Dameron and Duke Ellington, and the drummer Max Roach are all given a night.

Dining Out Guide: Saturday Lunch
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
Cafe Pierre  * (July 10, 1987), Fifth Avenue at 61st Street (838-8000) - Cafe Pierre is an appealing choice for Saturday lunch in a formal, elegant setting.


Righetti Still Feels at a Loss
LEAD: The night was no escape.
Dave Righetti returned to the solitude of his downtown hotel room late Wednesday, closed the door behind him and tried to sleep.
He tossed and turned.


Quaker Oats Asks Trading Inquiry
LEAD: The Quaker Oats Company has asked the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate trading in its stock, which has jumped recently on rumors of a possible takeover.
Shares in the Chicago-based food company leaped $5.25, to $58, in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange today before falling back to close at $52.50, down 25 cents.


Provocative Art Shows Near New York City
LEAD: In art, there is no straw-hat circuit.
There are no windblown open-air concerts.
Nor are there goings-on beneath a big tent that make us feel we are being served soup on a dinner plate.
Art exhibitions outside New York City in the dog days of the year are a serious business, put on by serious people.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Vice President Bush today leveled his most scalding attack yet against Michael S. Dukakis, charging that the Democratic Presidential nominee would make the world a more dangerous place because he has repudiated the foreign policy vision of John F. Kennedy.


Review/Theater; Milner's 'Checkmates,' Story of 2 Households
LEAD: While it's easy to name a recent Broadway play or two as awful as ''Checkmates,'' it may be necessary to get out the scrapbooks to recall one quite so amateurish and boring. ''Checkmates'' is a comedy in which the characters say such lines as ''A man's home is his castle'' and ''It's a whole new ball game'' - and aren't joking.


Traders Wary on Weather As Grain Contracts Climb
LEAD: Deteriorating crop conditions pushed up prices of soybeans and corn yesterday, while the wheat market was bolstered by continued demand from overseas buyers.


Notes and Bonds Rise in Quiet Trading
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in very quiet trading yesterday, regaining all of the ground lost during Wednesday's session.


Presidents' Checks
LEAD: Apparently there are checks and balances with regard to the executive branch that escaped the attention of the Constitution's Framers: the personal checks written by Presidents and their bank balances.

LEAD: About 30 classic cars owned by Reggie Jackson, the retired baseball star, were destroyed Wednesday night in a fire and explosions that wrecked a warehouse and caused about $4 million in damage.


Restaurants
LEAD: The Lincoln Center area still suffers from a relatively lackluster cast of restaurants, considering the demand for quality dining before and after performances.
Several promising places have opened in the neighborhood over the last year, but none so far rivals five-year-old Cafe Luxembourg for its consistently appealing fare and kinetic ambiance.


GTE Sets Buyback And Dividend Rise
LEAD: The GTE Corporation said that it planned to repurchase 25 million shares of its common stock and to increase its quarterly dividend to 67 cents a share, from 63 cents.
GTE shares closed at $41.125, up 50 cents, in heavy trading of almost 2.9 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

LEAD: In a move to broaden its health care operations, Britain's BOC Group P.L.C. said today that it had agreed to acquire Spectramed Inc. of Newport Beach, Calif., for $12 a share, or $101 million.


HERTZ ADMITS USE OF FRAUD IN BILLS FOR AUTO REPAIRS
LEAD: The Hertz Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding 110,000 customers and other motorists and insurance companies by charging them inflated and sometimes fictitious collision-repair costs.

LEAD: The Glenmore Distilleries Company has agreed to purchase a major portion of the Fleischmann Distilling Company's assets for $70 million.
The price is subject to adjustment at closing, which is expected within 30 days.


El Toro's Fights Go On, But 'Oles!' Are Fewer
LEAD: Although the fighting bulls are a long way from becoming victors instead of vanquished in Spain's national pastime, they have recently been having their day both in and out of the ring.


G.E. Receives Jet Engine Order
LEAD: The General Electric Company said that it would supply jet engines for 15 Boeing planes ordered by Japan Air Lines in a deal that will bring G.E. $400 million.
General Electric said Japan Air Lines had exercised options for 15 Boeing 747-400 aircraft to be powered by G.E.'s CF6-80C2 engines.
The airline ordered five G.E.-powered aircraft last January.


Pinetop Perkins
LEAD: Pinetop Perkins, a blues pianist, is appearing tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 and midnight.
There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.


Gymnastics; Can Karolyi and 'Kids' Break Ties That Bind?
LEAD: Once the women's compulsory round of the United States gymnastics Olympic trials ended Thursday night, it seemed likely that three and possibly four women coached by Bela Karolyi would make the team.


Baker Resigns to Work for Bush; Brady Is Named for Treasury Job
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d resigned today to join Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign, completing the dismantling of the White House team that gave President Reagan his greatest successes.


Joseph Hankerson, Civil Rights Worker, 63
LEAD: Joseph Lester Hankerson, a longtime participant in civil rights activities in the South, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Georgia Baptist Medical Center in Atlanta.
He was 63 years old.


Hambletonian Is Today
LEAD: The 63d edition of the Hambletonian will be staged at the Meadowlands Saturday afternoon with Armbro Goal the early favorite at 7-5.


Reviews/Music; Classical Prokofiev Joins Sensuous Mozart
LEAD: Wednesday's concert at Avery Fisher Hall held out the routine pleasures that Mostly Mozart seems intended to provide.
Gerard Schwarz conducted the Festival's orchestra, Jean-Pierre Rampal played the flute and Stephen Hough was the pianist.
