Challenge for Jet Linebackers
LEAD: They are ordinary players without extraordinary help in front of them or behind them, so the Jets' linebackers find themselves caught in the middle.


Toronto Sun to Expand
LEAD: The Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation, publisher of British-style tabloids in Toronto, and Calgary and Edmonton, Alberta, today announced an agreement in principle to buy the weekly Ottawa Sunday Herald for less than $1 million Canadian ($830,000 United States).
Douglas Creighton, the president of Toronto Sun, said the company plans to transform the five-year-old newspaper into a daily as soon as possible.


Rate of AIDS Infection Found Low in Military
LEAD: The largest AIDS testing program to date in a specific group of Americans has found that just over one in 1,000 active-duty military personnel carry the AIDS virus, lower than the rate among the general population, officials said Thursday.


Horse Racing; Trapp Mountain Triumphs Again
LEAD: Trapp Mountain proved that his flashy debut last month was as good as it looked by returning today to score a four-length victory in the $87,900 Saratoga Special at Saratoga Race Track.
The victory established him as one of the nation's three leading 2-year-olds, along with Houston and King Glorious.

LEAD: ''Everybody said I was an idiot,'' said Steven Peters, founder of Miami-based Video Jukebox Network. ''But it works.''

W. L. Knickerbocker, A Retired Admiral, 84
LEAD: Rear Admiral William L. Knickerbocker, who retired from the United States Navy in 1963 after a 40-year career, died of cardiac arrest on Tuesday in York, Me., where he lived.
He was 84 years old.

LEAD: The Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival got off to a cheerful start on Wednesday with a burst of drumming, clowns, soaring balloons - and the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which formally opened the monthlong free festival with an evening performance at the Damrosch Park band shell.


Mears Wins Pole For Marlboro 500
LEAD: Rick Mears posted a lap of 218.427 miles per hour today despite gusty winds and a hot track and won the pole position for the Marlboro 500 Indy-car race on Sunday.

LEAD: An exhausted Federal drug agent pleaded ''don't hit me anymore'' to his captors in 1985 as he disclosed confidential Government information in a futile effort to save his life, according to tapes that have been played in court.

Japan Data On Economy
LEAD: The Japanese Government issued an optimistic report today on the nation's economy, but officials said the gap between rich and poor was growing, with many Japanese feeling they have been left out of the nation's economic boom.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a company's closing as a result of the Pentagon fraud inquiry misidentified the two companies whose offices were searched in June by Federal investigators.
They were the Unisys Corporation and Armtec Inc. - not the United Technologies Corporation and Diagnostic/Retrieval Systems Inc.

LEAD: A ferryboat carrying workers home from a night shift split in two and sank after it was rammed by a barge, and at least 17 people drowned, officials reported today.
A Red Cross worker put the toll at about 38.

Shareholder Rights Plan for Wendy's
LEAD: Wendy's International Inc., the fast-food restaurant company, said that it had adopted a plan intended to protect shareholder interests in an unfair takeover effort.
Wendy's said the shareholder rights plan was not adopted in response to any known takeover effort.
Under the plan, shareholders will receive for each share a right to buy, if certain conditions are met, a fraction of a share of a new series of preferred stock for $25.

Talks on Acid Rain Endorsed
LEAD: President Reagan has approved continuing negotiations toward American participation in an international treaty to freeze emissions of a precursor to acid rain, the White House said today.

U.N. Plans 250 Peacekeepers for Gulf
LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the Security Council today that he plans to a send a 250-member peacekeeping force to monitor any cease-fire agreement between Iran and Iraq and the disengagement of their forces, diplomats said.


N.F.L. Suspends Four
LEAD: Robb Riddick, a Buffalo Bills running back, and Greg Townsend, a Los Angeles Raiders defensive end, were among four National Football League players who were suspended yesterday by the league for 30 days for violating the league's rules on drug and alcohol abuse.


Rise in Business Payrolls Lifts Dollar, Depresses Gold
LEAD: The dollar rose strongly against the leading foreign currencies yesterday as traders reacted positively to the latest United States employment statistics.


Mullaney Resigns
LEAD: Joe Mullaney, whose basketball teams at Providence College won at least 20 games nine times in the 1950's and 1960's, resigned yesterday as associate athletic director at the college.
He had left Providence in 1969 to coach the Los Angeles Lakers and then coached pro teams at Utah, Kentucky, Memphis and Buffalo before returning to college coaching at Brown in 1978.

Patents; A Machine to Generate Oxygen Under Water
LEAD: Several years ago, Joseph and Celia Bonaventura invented what some people called the ''artificial gill.'' Unfortunately, the device was of limited usefulness because it could only extract small quantities of oxygen from water.


Palestinians Lose in a U.S. Court
LEAD: A United States Appeals Court panel today upheld the Reagan Administration's order to close an information office in Washington affiliated with the Palestine Liberation Organization.


Review/Music; Opposite Styles Attract
LEAD: An attraction of opposites can make chamber music work almost as well as the meeting of like minds.
It depends on one's tastes - do you prefer total harmony or a little healthy conflict?
Thursday's edition of the Mostly Mozart series at Avery Fisher Hall had a little of both schools to it.

LEAD: To the Editor:


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Avon Products Inc., a toiletries and health products concern, restructured the agreement to sell its Foster Medical unit's medical equipment and respiratory therapy business to Ventech Healthcare Corp.'s Abbey Medical unit.
It will sell the durable medical equipment and respiratory therapy businesses to Ventech for $165 million in cash and notes and sell the infusion therapy businesses separately.


McMillan Waived
LEAD: Randy McMillan, the Indianapolis Colts' running back who was the fifth-leading rusher in the history of the franchise, was waived yesterday.
He missed all of last season because of injuries suffered in an automobile accident.

Blanton Concedes in Tennessee Primary
LEAD: Former Gov.
Ray Blanton talking to his supporters Thursday night in Jackson, Tenn., as his wife, Karen, wiped away a tear.
Mr.
Blanton finished third in a four-man race for the Democratic nomination for western Tennessee's 8th Congressional District as State Representaitve John Tanner won with 66 percent of the vote.


Carbide Easing An Ozone Peril
LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation said on Thursday that it had found a way to avoid using ozone-destroying chemicals in making foam used for furniture padding.


A Cool Choice for Treasury
LEAD: For Nicholas Brady to replace the remarkably capable James Baker as Secretary of the Treasury should rattle no one.
Despite the importance of the office and Mr.
Baker's powerful command of economic policy through the second Reagan term, he leaves nothing undone that Mr.
Brady can't handle.


It's Official! Vacations Really Aren't Un-Japanese
LEAD: It is hard work getting Japanese to relax.
But the summer holidays are looming, and the Labor Ministry is gearing up for a tough campaign.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the movie ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' misstated the church affiliation of the Rev.
Donald Wildmon, an opponent of the film.
He is a minister of the United Methodist Church, not a Baptist.

LEAD: For the last 20 years of his life, Lewis H. Latimer, a black inventor and major pioneer in the development of electric lighting, lived in a comfortable two-and-a-half-story frame house in Flushing, Queens.


Arthur Albert Alexander, Executive, 86
LEAD: Arthur Albert Alexander, a former executive with American President Lines, Ltd., worldwide shipping operators, died Wednesday at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, after a brief illness.
He was 86 years old and lived on Shelter Island.

LEAD: John M. Brealey, a Metropolitan Museum conservator who has been on loan to Madrid's Prado Museum to oversee restoration of some of Spain's most important art treasures, has turned down an invitation to extend his stay.


Doctor Describes Bush As 'Active and Healthy'
LEAD: Vice President Bush is ''an unusually active and healthy man,'' his White House doctor said today in a statement highlighting the recent focus on a candidate's health as a central issue in the Presidential campaign.

Ex-Louisiana Aide Sentenced
LEAD: A onetime aide to Edwin W. Edwards when he was Governor was sentenced today to four years in prison for a scheme in which he took thousands of dollars to steer state contracts to consulting engineering firms.
The former aide, Wayne Ray, received consecutive two-year sentences for two counts of filing false income taxes and a five-year probated sentence for an extortion count.


Treasury Prices Fall On Job Data
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes tumbled yesterday after the Labor Department reported a surge in job creation for July.
The department also revised its June statistics to show more new jobs for the month than had previously been reported.

LEAD: An agreement was reached yesterday to give the Long Island Rail Road an greater role in controlling trains and platforms inside Penn Station, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said.

LEAD: Unemployment rates in New York and New Jersey fell to a 19-year quarterly low in the second quarter of the year, an indication of the regional economy's continuing strength, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

Publishing and Jewish Life in Russia
LEAD: The particular spice that the Jews of Russia contributed during the last 100 years to the boiling pot that is the land in which they lived permeates an exhibition room in the grand mansion that houses the Yivo Institute for Jewish Research, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street.


Save Deconstruction From Its Explicators
LEAD: To the Editor:


MOVING PLUTONIUM BY SEA IS ASSAILED
LEAD: Several members of the House and the Senate wrote to President Reagan today to oppose amending a recently signed treaty that allows plutonium shipments from Europe to Japan.
The treaty allows shipments by air, and the changes would permit transportation by sea.


Three Coasts Gain in 'Superstates'
LEAD: The American economy is dominated by a small group of ''superstates'' that to an increasing degree consists of those on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts.


Dr. John G. Keuhnelia, Urologist, 60
LEAD: John G. Keuhnelian, a prominent urologist, died of leukemia on Tuesday at New York Hospital.
He was 60 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.


Kenya a Renamo Foe
LEAD: To the Editor A July 31 front-page story contained a baseless allegation of my country's sympathy for Renamo, the Mozambican rebel group.
Kenya adheres strictly to the principles of the charter of the Organization of African Unity, which include noninterference in the internal affairs of other states.


Moving Fee No One Liked
LEAD: Charges against a woman accused of violating an ordinance that requires a police permit to move into and out of this city will be dropped, a lawyer for the city said today.


The Editorial Notebook; A Planner Faces Reality
LEAD: What many Americans think of as the heart of New York is changing with volcanic force.
Gaping holes along Broadway and Seventh Avenue expose the granite subsurface of midtown near Times Square.
For a brief moment you can see long-concealed structures like the Hotel Edison, on 47th Street, from blocks away.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Curren Advances: Third-seeded Kevin Curren yesterday advanced to the semifinals of the Head Classic tournament in Stowe, Vt., as his opponent, Robbie Weiss, was forced to withdraw with a slipped vertebra.

Curren played an exhibition against Nicolas Pereira and won the pro set, 8-6.

Beefy men in Giant blue and white - supervised by determined-looking assistant coaches - have been doing the same thing these past few weeks of training camp, working out twice a day in conditions that would endanger the health of an average person.

Faltering Yanks Are Swept by Twins
LEAD: The idea, Lou Piniella said, was to use this weekend as an audition for his starting rotation.
After two losses in a doubleheader last night at the Stadium, the casting promises to be difficult.
So far, the aspirants do not appear prepared for the part.


GUIDEPOST: Finishing the Unfinished
LEAD: Summer auctions and country-furniture sales are yielding furniture that may have been stripped of its finish or sold in its natural state.
All such furniture needs some kind of protective coating.
Stains and dyes should be sealed by a clear finish.
If the wood is attractive, a clear finish may be all that is needed.


G.S.A. Voids Postal Pact With Perot
LEAD: The General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals ruled yesterday that a no-bid contract that the Postal Service awarded to a company owned by the Texas billionare H. Ross Perot was ''illegal and void'' because it violated Federal contracting rules.


Ex-Bendix Chairman's Fresh Start
LEAD: The board of the Morrison-Knudsen Corporation tapped one of its own yesterday as chairman and chief executive - William M. Agee, the brash and controversial former chairman of the Bendix Corporation.


UAL to Retain Covia Proceeds
LEAD: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said that it would retain the $500 million gained from the sale of a 50 percent interest in the Covia Corporation, which operates the airlines' computer reservation system.
The announcement disappointed some investors who were expecting the company to distribute the proceeds to shareholders, and the price of UAL shares fell $2.375, to close at $95.375, on the New York Stock Exchange today.


Food Vendors Return to Midtown Manhattan
LEAD: Banned from the streets by Mayor Koch since July 11th, vendors were welcomed back yesterday by pedestrians on Avenue of the Americas with handshakes, backslaps and hungry stomachs.
The Mayor banned vendors after failing to agree on new rules to reduce sidewalk congestion.
New agreement limits the number of vendors at intersections.


Rise in Consumer Credit Fastest in Five Months
LEAD: Americans took out $5.4 billion more in credit than they paid off in June as the growth in consumer credit increased at the fastest rate in five months.


Company Halting Health Plan On Some 'Life Style' Illnesses
LEAD: The Circle K Corporation, the nation's second-largest convenience store chain, says it will cut off the medical coverage of employees who become sick or injured as a result of AIDS, alcohol, drug abuse or self-inflicted wounds.

Ralph Meeker, 67, Star of 'Picnic' And Featured Actor in Films, Dies
LEAD: Ralph Meeker, who starred on Broadway in William Inge's Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''Picnic,'' died of a heart attack yesterday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif.
He was 67 years old and lived at the hospital.

Getting Baby the Card
LEAD: You're a proud new parent.
The baby's home.
The mail comes.
A letter from a record-service company says it will help you get a Social Security card for the child for a $15 fee.
Should you do it?
No.
All that companies like the Federal Record Service Corporation do is charge you for something you can do yourself -faster and for nothing.

A Cast of Hundreds In Nonstop Action

All Aboard for the Queen of India's Railroads
LEAD: Six mornings a week, at 9 A.M., the Rajdhani Express, queen of India's vast railroad network and its only fully air-conditioned train, eases into the New Delhi railroad station from Bombay.
It is rarely late.
But the plushness of this flagship -with tinted windows, uniformed room attendants, six-course meals, special linen for the wide and soft bunk beds and even showers in the bathrooms of the first-class coaches - is in vivid contrast to the overcrowded and dirty trains that are more common in India.


The Right Track on Nicaragua
LEAD: Senate Democrats have stumbled onto a good policy on the vexatious matter of contra aid.
Their approach is to provide further food, medicine and clothing to the Nicaraguan rebels but to keep military aid in the far background.
This tack prevents collapse of the contras and maintains the basis for negotiations.

Ottawa Delights in a Dazzling New Museum
LEAD: Seeing the sprawling new national Gallery here makes it hard not to wonder if there are not two Moshe Safdies.
For there is a world of difference between this building, which is the architect's latest completed work, and the tower he recently designed for Columbus Circle in New York.
The massive, angular New York tower, which was not built (it has now been replaced by a different design by another architect), looked as if it would have been a harsh and overpowering presence.

LEAD: MICHELLE Diamono, a junior at California University in Pennsylvania, doesn't have to worry about her roommate blasting rock music and keeping her awake throughout the night.
It's more likely her roommate will spend leisure hours telling stories about life during the World Wars and the Great Depression.

Last year, Deborah Warner made her Royal Shakespeare Company debut with her stunning production of ''Titus Andronicus'' (starring Brian Cox).
That production has since moved to the small Pit theater in the company's London home, the Barbican.

Review/Music; Hager, Toradze And Mintz
LEAD: Friday's Mostly Mozart program at Avery Fisher Hall provided the first hint that anybody in the concert business here is aware of - or cares about - the 200th anniversary of Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach's death in December.
He was an immense force in 18th-century music, though largely ignored today, and the concert by the festival's orchestra under Leopold Hager began with the E-flat Symphony, one of four powerful works in this format written in the mid-1770's.

He starts singing, and that too fits.

Life Patents: Doubts Are Registering
LEAD: THE House Judiciary Committee struck a compromise between farmers and the biotechnology industry last week when it decided that, in most instances, new forms of animals can be treated like mechanical inventions and patented.
In deciding that farmers should be exempted from paying royalties on the offspring of the patented livestock they buy, and in specifically stating that humans should not be patented, the committee sent a strong signal that cultural, moral and ethical considerations are important factors in drawing up legislation to regulate new biological technologies.

About the Chess Moves
LEAD: Starting this week, The New York Times is changing the notation system it uses to describe chess moves.
The new system, known as algebraic notation, is widely preferred in the world chess community and has been officially recommended by the International Chess Federation.

LEAD: To the Editor: The piece on Revere Beach brought back happy memories of Sunday forays to that crowded beach with its 5-cent frankfurters and tonic, as we Bostonians called soda pop.
Mr.
Kotker talks of piles of Coke bottles but in my day Coke was unknown in Boston.
Moxie, a strange bitter sweet mixture, was the reigning drink.

LEAD: THERE are days - not too many, mind you - when Faith Stewart-Gordon wears a two-piece black dress printed with purple and red elephants.
Before she pulls it out of the closet, she looks at it carefully and talks herself into thinking that it will look just fine.
On it goes, and out she goes, and eventually she passes a mirror somewhere and almost has a heart attack.

Mortadella: Bologna's Bologna
LEAD: Bologna's most famous pork product is mortadella, the original bologna.
Dubbed la Bologna in Milan and outside the region of Emilia-Romagna where it is produced, it is an impressively large, pale pink sausage with a finely ground pork forcemeat.
Sound familiar?
This is the exalted relative of our humble bologna.

HOT TOMATOES
LEAD: WHEN THE FIRST TOMATO ripens on the vine, I resist all temptation to bite then and there into the tight skin.
Instead, I carry it into the kitchen and make a sandwich.
The ritual is always the same: a lather of store-bought mayonnaise on two slices of plain white bread, a couple of thick slices of tomato, a dose of salt and pepper.

POSTINGS: Hartford Neighbor; 114 Units Serving Seniors
LEAD: The snowbirds are returning home to roost, said Paul T. Liistro, the developer of an $11 million retirement community opening in October near Hartford.
But as some abandon Florida for northern climes, many cannot find living space that caters to their needs.
Retirement communities, which are thought to have originated in the Midwest and proliferated across the Sun Belt, are late in coming to New England.


A Shift at the Top Of the Treasury
LEAD: A well-known Wall Street figure may join the Cabinet as head of the Treasury Department.
Nicholas F. Brady has been named to replace James A. Baker 3d, who resigned from the top Treasury post to run Vice President Bush's capaign for the presidency.
Mr.
Brady, 57 years old, is co-chairman of the Dillon, Read investment house and was the head of the Presidential commission that investigated last October's stock market collapse.

Q And A
LEAD:  Leaky Windows in a Co-op  Question: My building was converted into a co-op in June of 1985.
In the year before the closing, the landlord, who was also the sponsor of the conversion plan, installed new windows.
The job was botched and the windows leak, causing damage in many apartments.
The board has been unsuccessful in getting the sponsor or the contractor to correct the problem.

Planning a New Gutter System
LEAD: A WELL-FUNCTIONING gutter system is essential.
Without one, rainwater and melting snow dripping from a roof can easily saturate ground around the foundation, causing basement leakage and settling.
If a gutter system is so badly deteriorated that repair is neither practical nor economical, a new system should be promptly installed to replace it.

LEAD: Citing declining American political support for the deployment of forces abroad, a House Armed Services subcommittee warned today that Western Europe and Japan must rely less on the United States and more on their own forces and funds to defend themselves.

LEAD: Publicly, the United States has praised President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica for leading the quest for peace in Central America.

France
LEAD: To the Editor: Although superhighways radiate out in all directions from Paris, traveling between them is apt to be on two-lane macadam roads, and if you find yourself behind a bicycle road race, as I did, it's best to forget American standards of highway speed and enjoy the scenery.
Finally at Etampes the bike racers took a break and allowed traffic to pass.

LESS CAN BE MORE
LEAD: Robin Marantz Henig's aricle, ''Less Can Be More'' (Body and Mind, June 26) demonstrates some of the strengths and weaknesses of short-term psychotherapy.
As a practitioner of brief treatment, I do not doubt its value.
However, I hesitate to use the word ''cure,'' because it smacks of expectations of instant gratification that are, to my mind, a bane of modern American life.


69 More Opponents Of Abortion Jailed In Atlanta Protests
LEAD: Demonstrations by opponents of abortion led to the arrest of 69 more protesters today.
Those arrested joined more than 120 other people in jail from anti-abortion demonstrations that began July 19 at the time of the Democratic National Convention.


For Lebanon, Slow Return To Business
LEAD: The Lebanese economy is showing signs of recovery despite an increase in factional fighting over the presidential election scheduled this summer.


U.S. STUDIES WAYS TO SPEED UP DRUGS FOR SERIOUSLY ILL
LEAD: Responding to the rising demand for new AIDS treatments, the Reagan Administration is preparing a major regulatory proposal to permit faster evaluation of drugs for life-threatening illnesses.

LEAD: EARLY last year, A. Barry Rand was named as the Xerox Corporation's vice president in charge of the company's $4 billion marketing operation.
A few months later, a group of investors led by Reginald F. Lewis, a Wall Street lawyer and financier, bought the Beatrice International Company, a food products company operating mainly in Europe, for nearly $1 billion.

LEAD: JANI Chinese restaurant, squeezed between Herman's and Toys 'R' Us in Huntington Station's Filene's Shopping Center, is a cooling oasis in what seems like a culinary desert of chain stores.
Although the restaurant is dwarfed by its larger neighbors, Jani is surprisingly spacious.
It is deep, high and handsome.

Infighting Over 'Outsiders'
LEAD: Antiques shows in New York, London and Paris are adding - or soon may invite - foreign dealers, reflecting the increased internationalization of the antiques market.
The stepped-up foreign presence in several major fairs comes at a time when the antiques market is booming and collectors are traveling abroad to acquire the rarest objects.


New Year, Old Story: Jets Sacked
LEAD: The offense, the part of the team that was supposed to work, generated such scant yardage tonight that it was outscored until the final minutes by its kick-blocking unit.


GREEK POLICE ON TERRORISM ALERT
LEAD: The Greek police have been put on alert around the Athens airport and at American military bases and airlines offices here amid fears of terrorist attacks, a senior police official said today.


Heeere's the Band. . . But How Much longer?
LEAD: In a culture whose critical mass has nourished rock and roll for 30 years, the fall of the big bands toward extinction has been inevitable.
The old swing-era infrastructure of bands, ballrooms, broadcasts and booking agencies is gone.
Most of the legendary figures are dead.
And now, Johnny Carson's contract will be up in September.


Wooing The Young Reader
LEAD: CHILDREN in Moscow may be reading translations of books about Ellis Island and American Indian myths when an exchange of books takes place next year between the United States and the Soviet Union in celebration of the Year of the Young Reader.


Putting a Bloomingdale's In Towns Big and Small
LEAD: AN article of faith in shopping center design is that a large nationally known department store lures customers, who then also spend money at the small, local, less well-known stores.
Even as department stores have lost ground to smaller specialty shops, shopping centers with national retailers as anchors continue to outperform those that have only local tenants.


Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
LEAD: The Red Sox have 32 remaining road games, 8 against the Yankees and Tigers (and 13 on the West Coast).
Left-handed relief pitching could be crucial, and the Sox just haven't got it.
I'm sure the Yankee left-handed hitters - Mattingly, Washingon, Phelps and Pagliarulo - and the Detroit lefties - Whitaker, Evans, Sheridan and Nokes - are looking forward to their coming games with the Red Sox.


A Businesslike University
LEAD: AT HAMPTON University in Virginia, learning pays - literally.
Entering students whose combined Scholastic Aptitude Test scores exceed 1200 (out of a possible 1600) get free tuition; those with scores over 1300 get free tuition, room and board.
Students who qualify for the honors dormitory on the city's Hampton River waterfront pay lower rent and enjoy other amenities, such as a swimming pool.

LEAD: Doctors have treated the problem in Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd's right shoulder, but Boyd still doesn't know how long it will be before he can start pitching again for the Red Sox.

'Mass Appeal': 2 Roads to Rome
LEAD: ''MASS APPEAL,'' by Bill C. Davis, seems at first like a routine examination of classic conflicts within the Roman Catholic Church.
However, as beautifully detailed in the current production at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, ''Mass Appeal'' uses arguments between traditionalists and reformers as a container to hold complexities that transcend church dogma.

LEAD: One of the few grand old hotels still left in Spring Lake, N.J. - the Hewitt Wellington - is now being divided into the seaside community's first condominium hotel.
The town became known for its Victorian architecture when it was called the Irish Riviera - for the many wealthy Irish families who summered there.

When Japan Captured the French Imagination
LEAD: When Admiral Perry sailed into Kurihama harbor in 1853, reopening Japan to active trade with the West, he unleashed an esthetic fusillade that was heard round the Western art world, loudest of all in its capital, the city of Paris.
As Japanese prints, albums and objects began to arrive in plenty from the East, a kind of mania set in among artists, critics, designers and collectors alike.


The Pits
LEAD: ''WE DEVELOP NEW VARIETIES of stone fruit,'' Floyd Zaiger says of Zaiger's Genetics, the business he runs in Modesto, Calif., with his daughter and two sons. ''Primarily we work with peaches, nectarines, plums and apricots.'' Lately the focus has been on the last two; Zaiger is cross-pollinating them, and what he has dubbed ''pluots'' are on the way.

Planning a New Gutter System
LEAD: A WELL-FUNCTIONING gutter system is essential.
Without one, rainwater and melting snow dripping from a roof can easily saturate ground around the foundation, causing basement leakage and settling.
If a gutter system is so badly deteriorated that repair is neither practical nor economical, a new system should be promptly installed to replace it.

There's Always a Catch
LEAD: COMMIT A CRIME, they say, and the world is made of glass.
I have long believed it.
As a teen-ager in the Navy, I walked off my ship one shore liberty with half-a-dozen blank notebooks, property of Uncle Sam, hidden beneath the civilian clothes in my bag.
At the end of the gangway, a crusty master-of-arms singled me out of the stream of shorebound sailors (most of them, I thought, with a lot more evil in their eyes than I), glared at the bag and asked me to open it.

Israel's Gallery On a Mountaintop
LEAD: Safad is a natural spot for an artists' colony.
Atop Mount Canaan in Israel's northern region, it has a magnificent view of Upper Galilee's mountains and valleys.
The 20th century has left few marks on the secluded town and its narrow stone-paved alleys, winding streets and ivy-draped houses built around courtyard gardens.

LEAD: TALK about the plays of Lanford Wilson and it is not likely that ''The Great Nebula in Orion'' will come up.
Nor will ''Ikke Ikke Nye Nye Nye'' or ''The Family Continues,'' its companion pieces in a 1971 Off Off Broadway triple bill, that was called simply ''Three Plays by Lanford Wilson.''

LEAD: The National Rifle Association promotes itself as an organization of wholesome sportsmen and gun collectors.
A recent article in Newsday shows that its adherents also include another type: the inner-city gun runner.


A Dangerous Sports Edge
LEAD: FOR EIGHT YEARS, Greg Hall was ''on the juice.'' Like thousands of athletes and body-builders, he was using anabolic steroids to gain a competitive edge.
Now 30 years old, Mr.
Hall, a fitness director for a major health and racquet club in Detroit, says that ''the drug nearly killed me.''

Ryokans
LEAD: To the Editor: Having spent one night (all we could afford) in a ryokan (Japanese inn) during our three-week visit to Japan last summer, we sympathized with Kathy Jones and Clyde Haberman (Travel, June 12).
However, they failed to alert potential visitors to a further hazard.
Our guidebook informed us that it was customary to wear the yukata (cotton kimono) in the passages and public rooms of the ryokan.


FICTION
LEAD:  NIGHTS AS DAY, DAYS AS NIGHT.
By Michel Leiris.
Translated by Richard Sieburth. (Eridanos Press, P.O. Box 211, Hygiene, Colo., Cloth, $22; Paper, $13.) Born in 1901, Michel Leiris has shirked no adventure of the French intellectual left.
Surrealist writer, then ethnographer, he has worked with the giants of modern art and social thought, but his most intrepid explorations have been autobiographical.

LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts.
Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

LEAD: THE first of a string of rainy days received mixed greetings from the campers and counselors of the Elmwood Day Camp, on Dobbs Ferry Road in White Plains.
Boys and girls enthusiastically played ''ga-ga,'' a kickball game suitable for indoors, energetically danced to ''Ballin' the Jack,'' made tile trivots as well as beaded bracelets and played bingo.

Review/Music; Meditations and Ini Kamoze, Two Generations of Reggae
LEAD: Two generations of reggae style, both full of life, shared a double bill Wednesday at S.O.B.'s, opening a two-night stand.
The Meditations, a harmony group formed in 1974, and Ini Kamoze, a singer who made his first record in 1981, led crisply understated bands, putting secure grooves behind the singers' idiosyncratic mixtures of righteousness and playfulness.

Chavez entered the 21st day of a fast to call attention to his boycott of California table grapes.

In exhibitions that encompass the period stretching back to the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920's, the First National Black Arts Festival has assembled a diversity of objects implicitly intended to address this elusive issue.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  THE DEVELOPMENT OF BLACK THEATER IN AMERICA: From Shadows to Selves.
By Leslie Catherine Sanders. (Louisiana State University, $25.) Leslie Catherine Sanders' new book has much to recommend it: thoughtful, trenchant analysis of black theater in America; informed discussions of certain black playwrights; and a deft exploration of the quest to achieve a ''black stage reality'' beyond the confines of European theatrical conventions.

Correction
LEAD: An article July 17 about plans to build a replica of the inventor Guglielmo Marconi's yacht Elettra misstated the time it took for the first trans-Atlantic radio message to travel from England to Newfoundland.
The transmission of the signal was virtually instantaneous; however, it took three days for Marconi's receiving equipment to register the message in Newfoundland.

The Computer Revolution Revised
LEAD: REMARKABLE new technology is introduced into the school system and experts predict education will be revolutionized.
The technology will, as never before, allow the widespread dissemination of new concepts and ideas that will stimulate young minds and free the teacher for more creative pursuits.
Yet the magic fails to materialize, and within a few years articles appear in the popular press asserting that the failure, obviously, arises from teachers not being skilled enough in the new technology.

IN COMMAND: Admiral William J. Crowe
LEAD: IT WAS 3:18 A.M.
WHEN THE SECURE telephone rang beside Adm.

American Words
LEAD: I WAS A small child when I heard the words from my neighbor's apartment: ''You shake my nerves and you rattle my brain . . .'' It was in Poland, in 1958, just five years after Stalin's death, and these were the first English words I had ever encountered.
My redheaded neighbor, who was a singer, took advantage of the first rustle of freedom and bravely changed her repertoire from the Russian ''Dark Eyes'' to ''Great Balls of Fire.


Planning a New Gutter System
LEAD: A WELL-FUNCTIONING gutter system is essential.
Without one, rainwater and melting snow dripping from a roof can easily saturate ground around the foundation, causing basement leakage and settling.
If a gutter system is so badly deteriorated that repair is neither practical nor economical, a new system should be promptly installed to replace it.

LEAD: TIMOTHY F. BANNON, the Commissioner of Revenue Services, administers a staff of 860 employees collecting $3.9 billion in taxes a year.
A 41-year-old Ohio native whose father was from Connecticut, Mr.
Bannon is a 1977 graduate of the Yale University Law School who worked at private law firms and corporations before becoming an aide to Governor O'Neill in 1985.


Personal Ensign Wins Her 10th in Row
LEAD: The last filly to win her first 10 starts was Ruffian, and the last to win the Whitney Handicap was Lady's Secret.
Now there is a filly who has done both of those things, and today she earned a place in history alongside those two.


Care of Animals Teaches Teamwork
LEAD: CHILDREN and animals - they have always been a natural combination.
Animals can teach children about responsibility, love and even how to handle death.


South African Paper Curbed
LEAD: Police officers across South Africa today seized newsstand copies of The Weekly Mail, a prominent anti-apartheid newspaper.

LEAD: JOHN COMBS and Paul Green have been grooming horses at Roosevelt Raceway for 29 years and 23 years, respectively.
Seven days a week, they exercise, feed and rub down the horses and clean out their stalls.
It is the only life they know.

Too Late to Save a Wetland
LEAD: HOW do you kill a wetland?
First you get a zoning variance, then you bring in the bulldozers.


Port of Call for Birds Off Cape Cod's Elbow
LEAD: As an open launch approached the northern beach of Monomoy's north island, the passengers crowded into the cockpit raised a dozen pairs of binoculars to a dozen pairs of eyes.
It was low tide.
To the south and west on the tidal flats of Nantucket Sound, an immense congregation of shore and sea birds probed the shallows with bills of every contour and size.


Jersey Senate to Vote on Changes in Car Insurance
LEAD: With a state-operated automobile insurance system running a deficit of $20 million a month, the New Jersey Senate will vote Monday on a bill intended to solve the system's financial problems, but the measure faces a difficult passage through the Legislature.


Pedal Boats Go High Tech
LEAD: The first versions of the pedal boat often appeared at amusement parks and hotel beachfronts.
These pontoon-based craft, driven by paddle wheels, tended to skid sideways as easily as they moved forward.
New technology has improved the idea, harnessing the power of the propeller and adapting it to foot pedals.

Nassau County Learns to Live With Less Water
LEAD: In this, the first full summer since Nassau County adopted rules to conserve its dwindling supply of drinking water, residents are taking shorter showers, washing clothes in less water and waking up earlier to water their lawns.

LEAD: If the bloody clash early yesterday between hundreds of young people and 450 police officers in Tompkins Square bears the ragged earmarks of political protest, it is rooted in a less gripping social schism: a feud between the area's sleepless over-30 residents and younger, noisier revelers on the streets outside.

LEAD: Tom Blackaller, the San Francisco yachtsman who is a veteran of 6-Meter and 12-Meter sailing, has turned to catamarans.

Johnson Returns And Runs Well
LEAD: In his first successful outdoor competition since last fall, Ben Johnson ran three 100-meter sprints in less than 24 hours at the Canadian track and field championships: a heat Friday night, then the semifinals and final Saturday afternoon.
He won each race, as expected, and posted a winded-aided time of 9.90 seconds in the final.

North Sea Pipeline Plan
LEAD: The Dutch Petroleum Company B.V. said last week that it was leading a $1 billion project to build a 177-mile pipeline into the North Sea to speed up exploration of gas reserves.
The project is scheduled to come on line in several phases starting in 1991, according to Dutch Petroleum, a joint venture of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Corporation.


Turkish Stocks Plunge by 7.9%
LEAD: Turkish stock prices tumbled 7.9 percent on the Istanbul stock exchange last week as banks liquidated portfolios to raise cash after a money supply squeeze at the central bank, brokers said.


Island-Bound
LEAD: The Reagan White House has not yet given up rewarding political supporters.
Robert O. Johns, a California podiatrist with longstanding ties to Mr.
Reagan, has been selected to be Ambassador to Barbados.

2 Suits Against Seagate
LEAD: Seagate Technology Inc., a Scotts Valley, Calif., manufacturer of hard disk drives, said Friday that two suits had been filed accusing it of securities law violations in connection with public statements the company made from Oct. 13, 1987, to July 20, 1988.
The class-action complaints, brought on behalf of everyone who bought Seagate stock in that period, were filed July 29 in United States District Court in San Jose, Calif.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court is expected to rule today on a restraining order that froze some assets of six men indicted on charges that they had engaged in a racketeering conspiracy to create illegal tax losses through fraudulent stock deals.

Murdoch Agrees to Buy TV Guide In a $3 Billion Sale by Annenberg
LEAD: Walter H. Annenberg has agreed to sell Triangle Publications Inc., publisher of TV Guide, Daily Racing Form and Seventeen magazine, to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation for $3 billion, a price that dwarfs the next largest takeover in publishing.


Stream of Victims Tests Pretoria's War Hospital
LEAD: The human cost of the 15-year conflict along the border between South-West Africa and Angola is starkly evident as South Africa's main military hospital receives a small but steady stream of soldiers, both black and white, who were wounded in clashes in Angola and on the border.

LEAD: Joseph A. Caruso, founder and chairman of the board of Bar Harbor Airways, died Friday.
He was 67 years old.

LEAD: The weekend was saved for beachgoers in Brooklyn yesterday as New York City park officials reopened Coney Island and Brighton beaches.
But eight beaches on Staten Island and in Suffolk, Nassau and Westchester Counties remained closed because of medical waste or high bacteria counts.

LEAD: Ordinarily, the annual commemoration of Herbert Hoover's birth is a distinctly subdued affair, drawing only a smattering of family members and others to the Hoover Presidential Library and Museum in West Branch, Iowa.

Atlantic Cable Progress
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had completed laying a 3,160-mile length of the first fiberoptic cable between North America and Europe.
The cable, known as TAT-8, stretches from Tuckerton, N.J., to a point in the Atlantic Ocean on the European continental shelf, A.T.&amp; T. said.

LEAD: When the Mets lose do you ever feel, say, like wringing Gary Carter's neck?
Or, when the Yankees falter, maybe sticking pins in Dave Righetti?
When Darryl Strawberry hits one out, do you feel like giving him a big kiss?
Maybe you wish Don Mattingly were small enough so you could carry him around in your pocket.

Racing Boat Hits Spectators in Pittsburgh; 24 Hurt
LEAD: A speeding Formula One racing boat veered out of control in a race on the Allegheny River today, hitting spectators on the bank of the river and injuring 24 people, eight critically.
Eleven of the injured were children, the police said.


China Futures Roles Widened
LEAD: Foreigners will be allowed to trade on China's planned commodities futures markets, the first in a communist country, a senior official said in a newspaper article.

LEAD: Martha Nause ended 10 years of tour frustration today, winning her first Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament by scoring 14 points under a new format.

Aides Fret, but Bush Has to 'Be Me'
LEAD: There is only one way to describe the look on Vice President Bush's face as he pushes up the throttle on his cigarette boat, sending the craft crashing over the waves and the passengers careening around the deck like pinballs.
George Bush looks demonic. ''I want to go faster but I don't want to hurt anybody,'' he says, flying into the harbor on the red, white and blue Fidelity in a dramatic 40-mile-per-hour spray.


Repairs Completed After Blackout That Hit Harlem and Morningside
LEAD: Repairs were completed yesterday on the last of five 13,000-volt cables that failed Friday night, knocking out electric power to thousands of customers in Harlem and the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan.

8/8/88: Let Octopi Clap And Let the Octets Sing
LEAD: Acht!
It's the eighth day of the eighth month of the eighty-eighth year of this enervating century, but you're far too slow.
The number 8888 sold out faster than any other in the history of the New York State Lottery's Win Four game, all 1,000 tickets gone by 11:37 A.M. on Aug. 1, the first day they were offered.

Saints Win, 23-20
LEAD: Morten Andersen's 36-yard field goal as time expired tonight gave New Orleans a 23-20 National Football League preseason victory over the Minnesota Vikings, who knocked the Saints out of the playoffs last season.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain being greeted with a welcoming song by refugee children as she visited the Site B refugee camp on the Thai border.
Mrs.
Thatcher said Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of one of three major Cambodian guerrilla groups, ''has a crucial part to play'' in achieving peace in Cambodia.


HUSSEIN IS FROSTY ON NEW P.L.O. ROLE
LEAD: King Hussein of Jordan repeatedly asserted today that he considers the Palestine Liberation Organization. ''the sole and legitimate representative of the Palestinian people.'' But there was little enthusiasm in his words, and his attitude toward the P.L.O. was cool throughout a news conference here..


After 20 Years, Fair Housing Teeth
LEAD: Twenty years ago, America recognized the pain of those who suffer the humiliation of housing discrimination.
But the Fair Housing Act of 1968, lacking strong enforcement provisions, has been a paper tiger.
Now Congress, with the support of President Reagan, is about to give it teeth.


Bush Says He Will Debate
LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that he would agree to ''more than one'' debate with Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis but was not ready to be more specific on how many, when or where.


Five Reportedly Slain During Burma Unrest
LEAD: Official Burmese newspapers were quoted as reporting today that five people were killed and an undetermined number were wounded during anti-Government protests over the weekend.
Students in Rangoon, the capital, reportedly called for a nationwide general strike Monday.


Fascination With Faith Fuels Work By Scorsese
LEAD: ''Fundamentalism is not the state religion in this country,'' said Martin Scorsese, with just a trace of anger beneath nervous laughter.
The director of ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' had been discreet and controlled in earlier comments about the opposition of some religious groups to his new film.

LEAD: Former Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., critical of the long delays that have prevented most death sentences from being carried out, suggested today that legislators reconsider whether capital punishment should be retained.


TIMING OF WRITER'S STRIKE MAY BE GIFT FOR NETWORKS
LEAD: FOR weeks, executives of the entertainment divisions at ABC, CBS and NBC insisted that the fall television season announced in May would be a casualty of the strike against producers by the Writers Guild of America.
They scrambled to put together an ''interim season'' that would include reruns, coverage of news and sports events, series that had been completed but shelved, and other programs that could be made outside union jurisdiction.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation plans to cut the number of its suppliers in half and will decide in the next six months which suppliers it will eliminate for contracts in the early 1990's, the company's supply chief said Friday.

Man Freed From Chimney
LEAD: Firefighters used crowbars and sledgehammers to free a man who became stuck while trying to crawl down a chimney after he was locked out of a relative's house in the middle of the night.
Rodolpho Mohoro, stuck in the chimney about two hours, was treated for abrasions at a hospital and released.
The chimney was nearly demolished.

LEAD: Medcom Partners, largely owned by Park Avenue Publishing, has acquired Illustrated Medicine, from Wynwood Publishing.
The publication is Medcom's fourth acquisition since spring.
No details of the deal were disclosed.
Illustrated Medicine is a single-subject, single-sponsor magazine with a 10-a-year publishing frequency.

A $400,000 Fine for Reuters
LEAD: The private British news agency Reuters Ltd. said today that it had taken steps to avoid future ''procedural errors'' like those that resulted in a $400,000 fine for re-exporting United States-origin microcomputer equipment.

And then even Davey Johnson conceded that the summer's ''slump'' had probably ended.

LEAD: I am part of a team of Government lawyers.
I have never received a perfect evaluation rating and I presume very few of my colleagues have.
If one of us was fired for a reason that had nothing to do with his value to the Government - because he was addicted to old B movies, say - it might trigger a Congressional investigation into bureaucratic misconduct.

Gil Janklowicz needed an activity after an injury ended his Olympic dream.

Tomorrow, the Treasury will start the first leg of its quarterly refunding with an $11 billion auction of new three-year notes, followed on Wednesday by a similar-size auction of 10-year notes.

Mark Rothko's Harvard Murals Are Irreparably Faded by Sun
LEAD: Although a quarter-century has passed since they were first displayed, the five murals Mark Rothko painted for Harvard remain a source of controversy and embarrassment at the university.
Fingers have been pointed toward various factions in the Harvard administration and at the artist himself, but no matter where blame rests, the reasons for distress can clearly be seen: What Rothko donated to the university to cover the walls of a penthouse dining room intended for ceremonial functions has been irreparably damaged by overexposure to the sun.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on July 21 about the proposed merger of Texas American Bancshares Inc. and the National Bancshares Corporation misstated the roles that top executives will have after the transaction is completed.
Their roles have not yet been determined.
In addition, the total of nonperforming loans in the combined banks at the end of March was misstated.

LEAD: Genentech Inc. said Friday that the Federal District Court in San Francisco had ruled in its favor in a patent infringement suit brought by the Hormone Research Foundation and its licensee, Hoffman-La Roche Inc.
The court ruled that Genentech does not infringe the foundation's patent by its manufacture and sale of genetically engineered human growth hormone.

LEAD: An off-duty New York City police officer shot and killed a teen-ager and wounded three others Saturday night after he intervened in a fight that had broken out next door to his Long Island home and was attacked by the youths, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Venezuela's Energy Minister, Arturo Hernandez Grisanti, has resigned, the official press agency Venpres reported today.


U.S. Seniors Golf; Charles in Playoff After Losing Lead
LEAD: Bob Charles, the left-hander from New Zealand, apparently had the United States Senior Open championship in hand with a three-shot lead and four holes to play in the final round at Medinah Country Club today.
But he lost it all and finished in a tie with South Africa's Gary Player, the defending champion in this leading golf event for men 50 and older.


The Shame of New York's Election Law
LEAD: It's an embarrassing and pointless August ritual: the orgy of court fights over nominating petitions for New York's ballot.
Endless legal challenges make New York home to fully half the election-law litigation in America.
How many more elections will be marred before the State Legislature rescues voters from this affront to democracy?


Flying the Flag
LEAD: The United States Navy is making no immediate plans to withdraw from the Persian Gulf even though Iran and Iraq are giving indications that they may end their eight-year war, thus reducing the threat to oil tankers the warships were sent to protect.


Review/Music; 'Madama Butterfly' In City Opera Staging
LEAD: The New York City Opera's production of ''Madama Butterfly'' has been in the company's repertory for 21 years, and has long been in need of complete directorial revamping.
At the Saturday afternoon performance at the New York State Theater, the first in this season's run, it was clear that the needed face lift was not on the company's agenda: the aimless and inconsistent staging remains so distracting that the work's emotional drama nearly sails by unnoticed.


McDonnell Douglas Begins Its Own Inquiry
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, under scrutiny in the Pentagon bribery inquiry, has begun an internal investigation of its use of former top-level Defense Department officials as procurement consultants.


Review/Television; 'A Summer Ghost,' on Channel 13
LEAD: A chubby, lonely young English girl, an Italian principessa of fading beauty and the legend of a man who haunts the house where his brother murdered him: ''A Summer Ghost'' has all the elements of an eerie psychological drama.
When we first see the adolescent heroine, Maureen (Susan Bradley), she has tracing paper and crayons, and sits at a table intently re-creating a picture of Jesus while ''Love Letters in the Sand'' plays in the background.

Borden Completes 4 Acquisitions
LEAD: Borden Inc. said it had completed the acquisition of four companies that would be added to its operations in pasta, snack foods and other grocery products.
Terms were not disclosed, but the New York-based company said the operations had estimated annual sales totaling $44 million.


By Design; Holding Up
LEAD: One of the first signs of fall could be the change in the shape of your handbag.
The newest ones are - as they say in the business - structured.
Translate that to mean the bag is no longer pliable or soft, changing its shape by what you put in it.
Instead, the fabric or leather covering is applied around and over a frame.


The Doctor's World; Technique Changes In Bypass Surgery
LEAD: HEART surgeons are increasingly turning to a new technique for coronary bypass surgery that promises longer-term success and fewer complications than the method that has been common for decades.

LEAD: For swimmers already wary of hospital wastes and sewage on the beach, August now brings living pests to the waters of Long Island and New Jersey: jellyfish, isopods, epitokes, hydroids and sea-bathers' eruption.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Antitrust Waiver in Detroit  Overruling his advisers, Attorney General Meese allowed The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press to merge their business operations while they continue to publish separate newspapers.
Page D1.
Changes in Heart Surgery  Blood vessels in the chest that seem to resist clogging are increasingly being used instead of leg veins for replacing blocked coronary arteries.


Duchess of York Has a Baby
LEAD: The Duchess of York gave birth today to a daughter, the first child for her and her husband, Prince Andrew, Buckingham Palace announced.


War Games in East Germany
LEAD: About 14,500 Soviet and East German soldiers began joint manuevers today in central East Germany, the state-run East German press agency reported.
The press agency did not say how long the war games would last.
In Casteau, Belgium, meanwhile, NATO said about 250,000 soldiers, including 17,000 from the United States, will take part in the Western alliance's annual fall maneuvers in Europe.


In New York State Elections, a Sparsity of Contests
LEAD: The number of uncontested primaries and elections in New York for the House of Representatives and the State Legislature has increased dramatically this year.
At least one of every five members of the House and the Legislature does not have a major party opponent and is thus virtually assured of re-election in November.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Why do birds take dust baths?
A.
The gestures that birds make when the put dust on their feathers and then shake and preen it off look like the movements they make when bathing in water, but the purpose is not exactly the same.


Shuttle Firing Rescheduled
LEAD: The test firing of the shuttle's main engine, postponed by a series of leaks and other problems, has been rescheduled for Wednesday, NASA officials said today.
They said a new valve, installed to replace one whose malfunction caused the latest delay, had tested satisfactorily in the shuttle Discovery's engine compartment.


Edward Waldman, Executive, 74
LEAD: Edward Waldman, a retired president of Citicorp Factors, a commercial money lender, died of Parkinson's disease yesterday at his home in Westport, Conn.
He was 74 years old.

Correction
LEAD: An article on Sunday about the New York Times/CBS News Poll on the election characterized findings for the South imprecisely.
The poll showed Michael S. Dukakis leading Vice President Bush, although the lead in the region - 44 percent to 35 percent - did not exceed the margin of sampling error for the 338 interviews there.

LEAD: Publishing industry experts yesterday expressed little doubt about the ability of Rupert Murdoch to finance his $3 billion deal to acquire Triangle Publications Inc., the owner of TV Guide.

Salming Returns
LEAD: Borje Salming, the veteran of 15 National Hockey League seasons, said yesterday in a call from Sweden to Toronto that he had agreed to return to the Maple Leafs for a 16th year.
Salming, 37, who became a free agent last month, said he accepted a one-year deal with Toronto that will pay him the same salary he received last season, approximately $350,000.


Swimming Winner
LEAD: Janet Evans qualifying with the fastest time in the 400-meter individual medley yesterday at the Olympic swimming trials in Austin, Tex.
She later broke the American record in the final.

Steel Output Falls 3.8%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.89 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 3.8 percent from the previous week's 1.965 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 88.6 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 92.1 percent the previous week.

LEAD: Someone said something about a slump.
Dave Winfield merely shook his head and offered a half-smile.
He knew there would be questions.

Angola Truce Now
LEAD: South Africa, Angola and Cuba announced today that they had agreed that their forces would observe an immediate cease-fire in Angola and the neighboring territory of Namibia.
They issued a joint statement declaring that ''a de facto cessation of hostilities is now in effect.''

Malaysia Cocoa Futures
LEAD: The Kuala Lumpur Commodity Exchange began trading in cocoa futures today to coincide with the date 8/8/88, which many Chinese and others in Malaysia believe brings great prosperity.
The exchange is the first futures market for cocoa in Asia.
Malaysia is the world's third-largest producer of cocoa after the Ivory Coast and Brazil.


Marriott Venture
LEAD: The Marriott Corporation said that its Marriott In-Flite Services unit had formed a venture with the All Nippon Airways Company and the Sumitomo Corporation to seek business at the Kansai International Airport in Japan.
The venture will compete for catering and concession operations at the airport, which is scheduled to open in Osaka in 1993, and pursue opportunities at other airports in Japan.


Singapore Growth Seen
LEAD: Singapore expects to register real economic growth of 9 percent in 1988, up from 8.8 percent in 1987, Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today.
He said that gross domestic product grew by 11.1 percent in the first half of 1988, the highest first-half growth since 1975.


Jim Baker and the Virtues of Pragmatism
LEAD: James Baker has given President Reagan outstanding service in two quite different roles.
As low-profile White House chief of staff in the first term and high-profile Secretary of the Treasury in the second, he leavened the Reagan revolution with healthy pragmatism, intelligence and political skill.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Pentagon auditors discovered repeated overcharges totaling hundreds of millions of dollars on military contracts with 95 suppliers.
The four-year investigation is believed to be the most comprehensive ever of the pricing of military contracts.
The confidential report provides detailed evidence that excessive charges by military contractors are common.

LEAD:  HORSE RACING  Fourstardave Wins Close One: Fourstardave and Whodam lumbered to the wire as a team and it took the fourth tight photo finish of the day to decide that Fourstardave had won the $100,000 Albany Stakes yesterday at Saratoga Race Track.
Fourstardave, who conceded 12 pounds to the runner-up while carrying top weight of 126, scored by a nose in the race, restricted to New York-bred 3-year-olds.

At Last, a Joy for All Ages: Central Park Zoo Is Back
LEAD: The Central Park Zoo, closed for five years, reopened its gates yesterday, and the various species on view did predictable things.
Penguins played and people pushed.
Seals swam and babies bawled.
But despite the heat and the crowds, delight descended on the zoo, a series of elegant buildings and enchanting gardens that look as if they had been there all along.

Bridge
LEAD: The American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals ended here last night with a victory for one of the country's greatest partnerships in the Life Master Pairs.
Marty Bergen of White Plains and Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., who won a string of major titles in the years 1983 to 1985, led into the final session and held on to win by almost two boards.

Topics of the Times; Blood and the Park
LEAD: Fair-minded people can only endorse New York City's aim of enforcing a 1 A.M. curfew in Tompkins Square Park, on Manhattan's Lower East Side.
In a crowded city, where recreational and residential space are closely joined, the exercise of personal liberty does not include the right to deprive others of their rest and quiet late at night.

LEAD: With one day to spare, proponents of making English the state's official language got enough signatures to put a proposed constitutional amendment before the voters in November.

Elisa Malinovitz Wed
LEAD: Elisa Malinovitz, a weather broadcaster for KDFW-TV in Dallas, and Jeffrey Eliasoph, a news anchor at KTBS-TV in Shreveport, La., were married yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.
Rabbi Thomas Weiner officiated.

LEAD: Bruce David Kimball, the platform diver who won a silver medal in the 1984 Olympic Games, reportedly had a blood alcohol level of 0.20 percent -twice the legal limit - when his car smashed into a group of more than 30 people, most of them teen-agers, on a dead-end road in Brandon, Fla., last Monday night.

LEAD: IN the four decades since independence, India has used advanced farming techniques to triple its grain output and banish the old specter of famine.
But this remarkable achievement has also brought serious environmental problems.

LEAD: When Mike Ariey flew off to the Giants' training camp last month his friends wished him well.

A Yield of 8.55% For Dow Chemical
LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company is offering $115.6 million of one-year extendible notes with a final maturity in 2015 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company.
The notes were given a coupon of 8.43 percent and priced at 99.887 to yield 8.55 percent, or about one-half a percentage point more than the one-year Treasury bill.

Hughes Move On I.B.M. Bid
LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company, the losing bidder for a $3.6 billion contract to modernize the nation's air traffic control system, has asked the Government to overturn a huge contract award made to the International Business Machines Corporation.
Hughes cited irregularities.
In a protest filed last week with the General Services Administration's Contract Appeals Board, Hughes contended that the Federal Aviation Administration violated procurement law in awarding the contract to I.B.M., which submitted a lower bid.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $400 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Feb. 9 through various securities dealers.
Investors are being offered the securities at par, giving them a yield of about 55 hundredths of a percentage point more than the equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill.

Review/Theater; In Williamstown, Mass., 'Liaisons' Without the Dangereuses
LEAD: A year after its Broadway closing, ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' has achieved a cult reputation well out of proportion to its modest four-month New York run.
Not everyone who saw Christopher Hampton's stage adaptation of the 1782 Choderlos de Laclos novel admired it, but those who did were swept away.


Nigeria Insists It'll Keep AIDS the Rare Exception
LEAD: One Nigerian AIDS patient, a hemophiliac, received blood transfusions in the United States.
Two other Nigerians, carriers of the AIDS virus, lived for some time in Zaire and Zambia, two Central African countries with high rates of the disease.


Science Watch; Serengeti 'Hot Spots'
LEAD: Year after year, animals graze in ''hot spots'' in the grasslands of the Serengeti in Tazania.
Some scientists have suggested that the animals congregate so they can cluster together to protect themselves from predators.
Others have said it is so animals can cooperate in grazing, with some eating high grasses and other eating the lower grasses left behind.


CURBS FOR MINORS SEEKING ABORTION UPHELD ON APPEAL
LEAD: In an important test of state laws restricting minors' access to abortion, a Federal appeals court today upheld a Minnesota law that requires women under the age of 18 years who want abortions to notify both parents or get special approval from a state judge.
The judges ruled 7 to 3.

Soybean Yield Fall Seen
LEAD: A survey of farmers attending the American Soybean Association's annual convention here projects that soybean yield in the United States this year could be almost 40 percent lower than normal because of the drought.
The survey showed an expected average soybean yield of 24.4 bushels an acre, compared with a normal yield of slightly more than 40 bushels an acre.

Science Watch; The Coldest Gas
LEAD: Scientists at the National Bureau of Standards have chilled sodium atoms to the lowest temperature ever recorded in a gas, 43 millionths of 1 degree Centigrade above the absolute zero.
Absolute zero, defined as the temperature at which all molecular motion ceases, is about 273.16 degrees below zero Centigrade, or 459.69 degrees below zero

Business and Health; Curbing Costs Of 'Life Style' Ills
LEAD: THE decision by the Circle K Corporation to deny insurance coverage to employees with problems related to alcohol, drugs and AIDS is an unfair overreaction to surging health care costs that few other companies will adopt, specialists in medical benefits said yesterday.


Bidder Pursuing Miami Developer
LEAD: Metropolitan Consolidated Industries said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it had offered to acquire the General Development Corporation, a Miami-based developer.
The offer involves a share of Metropolitan common stock and a $10, 10 percent debenture that matures in 10 years for each of the 8.5 million General Development shares that are outstanding.


THE SOUND OF 1,000 ACCORDIONS BLOOMS
LEAD: Push came to squeeze this week at the New York Hilton, where at least a thousand accordionists gathered for the 50th-anniversary jubilee of the American Accordionists' Association.
Their fingers skittering over keys and buttons, their bellows pumping enough air to fill a fleet of dirigibles, they came to compete and to celebrate the accordion's latest surge of popularity.


Moscow Begins Destruction Of SS-20 Missile Launchers
LEAD: The Soviet Union has begun to destroy launchers and vehicles for SS-20 medium-range nuclear missiles under the recent superpower treaty, the Tass press agency reported today.


TADD DAMERON'S GENTLE MELODIES
LEAD: The first half of ''The Music of Tadd Dameron,'' the opening concert of Lincoln Center's ''Classical Jazz'' series on Friday night, was infused with gentleness.
This was partly due to Mr.
Dameron's compositions, which have an unhurried, calm melodic sense.
But it was also due to the musicians - the pianist Tommy Flanagan, the bassist George Mraz, the drummer Kenny Washington and the tenor saxophonist Charlie Rouse.

LEAD: Voicing new concerns about errors by air traffic controllers in Chicago, the National Transportation Safety Board yesterday issued 11 new recommendations for safer handling of flights there.

LEAD: About 30 sites in Upper Manhattan remained without power through most of yesterday, and the Consolidated Edison Company continued to search for the cause of a blackout that left tens of thousands of Manhattan customers without power for 22 hours over the weekend.

Korea Royalty Payments
LEAD: South Korean companies paid $321 million in royalties for high-technology imports from the United States and other countries in the first half of the year, up from $226 million a year earlier, a Finance Ministry report showed today.
Officials attributed the sharp increase to South Korea's growing demand for high technology in the electric, electronic and chemical industries.

Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States jumped last week by 51, to 945, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago the count stood at 983.
The rig count measures the number of rigs being used to explore for oil.

Market Place; The Sharp Rise In DeKalb's Stock
LEAD: IN the 10 months that the DeKalb Corporation has been telling Wall Street about its unusual restructuring plan, the company's stock price has nearly doubled.
The idea is for the Illinois-based conglomerate to split into three, possibly four, publicly traded companies by the end of this month.
That would allow its disparate lines of business, which include oil and gas exploration, oil well servicing, irrigation equipment manufacturing and agricultural genetics, to stand alone.


Black Peruvians in Pictures
LEAD: Recent photographs of the black population of Peru are on display at the Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street.
The photographs are the work of Ricardo Salcedo, a young Peruvian who lived for two years with the people of El Carmen, the country's largest black community.
Gallery hours are 11 A.M.


Dollar Firm In Spite of Pressures
LEAD: The dollar held firm against major foreign currencies yesterday, despite efforts by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of England and the Bundesbank of West Germany to slow its advance.

Chess
LEAD: In one of the most remarkable feats ever by an 11-year-old, Judit Polgar of Hungary tied for first place with her 19-year-old sister, Zsuzsa, one of the strongest female players in the world, in a small invitational international tournament in Egilsstadir, Iceland, June 5-15.
They each scored 6 1/2-2 1/2 against an otherwise all-male field that included two grandmasters.

Determining Why Smog Can Be Deadly
LEAD: MOST episodes of smog are simply annoying, but some can cause severe illness and death especially among the elderly and people with respiratory problems.
Despite thousands of smog-related deaths here and abroad in recent decades, scientists are still uncertain why smog can sometimes be deadly.

LEAD: Boris Becker, the two-time champion of Wimbledon, withdrew yesterday from the $815,000 Player's International tournament in Toronto with injuries to both feet that could jeopardize his participation in the United States Open at Flushing Meadows, Queens, later this month.

LEAD: Although recent United Nations successes in arranging cease-fire agreements have improved the organization's tarnished image in Congress, prospects that the United States will make good on $467 million in back dues to the organization remain dim, lawmakers said today.

LEAD: An exterminating company has been convicted of violating Federal pesticide law for failing to monitor the fumigation of a house in which two people later died.
The concern, the Atlanta-based Orkin Exterminating Company, could be fined up to $500,000.


Batus Raises Offer For Farmers Group
LEAD: Batus Inc., struggling to win regulatory approval for a hostile takeover of Farmers Group Inc., sweetened its buyout offer yesterday to $72 a share in cash, or more than $4.9 billion, in an apparent attempt to win a friendly agreement.
Batus, the American subsidiary of B.A.T.
Industries of Britain, had previously offered $63 a share, or $4.5 billion.

CELEBRATING NAPOLEON AS CORSICANS DO
LEAD: MONDAY is the 219th anniversary of the birth of Napoleon Bonaparte and to celebrate, La Colombe d'Or, 134 East 26th Street, is holding a Corsican dinner at 8 P.M.
Game bird pate, vegetables in pastry, grilled sardines, macaroni with meat, leg of lamb with wild herbs, anise sorbet, lemon tart and fresh figs - all typical Corsican dishes -along with Corsican wines are on the menu for $50 per person plus tax and gratuities.

Most of the players who will compete -also including Kenny Smith, Shelton Jones, Rodney McCray, Ed Pinckney and Walter Berry - learned the game while growing up in the New York City area.

LEAD: Insider trading is becoming as hot a scandal in the Tokyo stock market as it is on Wall Street.

Skywalks and Tunnels Bring New Life to the Great Indoors
LEAD: The temperature had just broken 100 here for the third consecutive day, but Linda Gibbons was not even warm.
She did her banking, left her pumps at the shoemaker for new heels, picked up the photographs she dropped off for developing the day before, had a manicure and bought her lunch.
And she never stepped outside.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it is putting landfills off-limits to millions of gallons of untreated hazardous waste produced each year by industry.

LEAD: Israeli fighter bombers raided Palestinian positions in southern Lebanon today and knocked out a radio station that reportedly broadcast messages from the Palestine Liberation Organization encouraging the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

LEAD: The official Soviet Human Rights Commission recommended today that the Government pardon all prisoners jailed under laws limiting religious activities, the official press agency Tass reported.

Classroom Booth Asked For Girl, 6, With AIDS
LEAD: A Federal district judge has ordered school officials to build an isolation booth with a glass front inside a classroom so a 6-year-old girl who has AIDS can be taught with other children.


60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: FRESH mussels abound in seafood shops at this time of year, and they can be used for all sorts of tasty and inexpensive summer meals.
The simplest way to prepare mussels is to steam then quickly in some white wine and shallots.
But you could just as easily use ginger and fresh coriander or another combination of herbs and spices.


FROM DRUGS, ALCOHOL, EMBEZELLING AND DEATH, A ROAD TO HAPPINESS
At the start of ''Clean and Sober,'' Daryl Poynter (Michael Keaton) finds himself at rock bottom: he wakes up with a bad hangover, heavy debts and a comatose stranger in his bed.
Daryl's alcohol and cocaine habits are the source of all this trouble, and they might have remained out of control indefinitely.
But when Daryl's date fails to wake up at all and his irregular bookkeeping practices are in danger of being discovered, he thinks it wise to stage a temporary retreat.
A chemical dependency center with a 21-day detoxification program sounds like just the place.
Daryl enters this rehabilitation center with the firm conviction that he does not have a problem.
The film, directed by Glenn Gordon Caron, works slowly, carefully and finally quite affectingly to trace the process whereby he discovers otherwise.
Though it covers only a monthlong period, ''Clean and Sober'' is so slow and deliberate, approaching its subject in such an intent, realistic manner, that it seems to have spanned several lifetimes.

LEAD: In a move to underscore its resolve in fighting inflation, the Federal Reserve Board voted unanimously today to raise its discount rate by a half point, to 6 1/2 percent.

LEAD: The Children's Acting Company, an organization that offers year-round theater classes to children between the ages of 5 and 19, will present excerpts from several plays, ranging from ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' to ''Vanities,'' on Monday at 6 P.M. at 311 West 43d Street.
The show involves 18 students from the company's Summer Acting and Creative Drama Program.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Thomson Net Up 22.7%
LEAD: International Thomson Organization Ltd., a diversified international information, publishing, travel and natural resources company, reported yesterday that earnings in the first six months of the year rose 22.7 percent.
International Thomson, which is based in Toronto, said that net income in the first half rose to $54 million, or 19 cents a share, from $44 million, or 15 cents a share, in the comparable 1987 period.


Correction
LEAD: A recipe for plum torte in the De Gustibus column last Wednesday misstated the required quantity of sifted, unbleached flour.
The correct amount is one cup.

LEAD: Two of the nation's leading retail store chains reported yesterday widely differing results for their latest fiscal quarters.

LEAD: The Fine Arts Work Center in Provincetown, Mass., will mark its 20th anniversary tomorrow by opening a $2.5 million capital and endowment campaign.
Robert Motherwell, the painter, and Stanley Kunitz, the poet, both trustees of the center, are among those scheduled to speak at a 4 P.M. program at the center.


Olympic Gymnastics; Peters Explains Why He Quit
LEAD: Don Peters said yesterday that he resigned as coach of the United States women's Olympic gymnastics team when it became apparent that he could not do an effective job in what he felt had become a turbulent atmosphere.

Sports People; Boxers Injured
LEAD: Three members of the 1988 United States Olympic boxing team are injured and will not compete against the Canadian team in the 1988 Carolinas Invitational at Fort Bragg, N.C., Saturday.
The injured boxers are Kennedy McKinney of Killeen, Tex.; Roy Jones of Pensacola, Fla., and Riddick Bowe of New York.

LEAD: Mohammed Ali Hamadei unexpectedly admitted today that he took part in the 1985 air hijacking for which he is on trial in a Frankfurt court, but he denied that he killed an American hostage.

LEAD: Broadway may be on the verge of losing one of its landmark playhouses - not to the wrecking ball but to neglect, vandalism and arson.

LEAD: The special grand jury investigating the case of Tawana Brawley has had its term extended two months, until Oct. 7, to permit it to prepare a report on its findings, the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, announced yesterday.
