Before Jerry Rubin
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bridge
LEAD: British legislators are far more likely than their American counterparts to enjoy playing bridge.
The 14th annual match between the House of Commons and the House of Lords was played on April 22, and the Commons players missed their chance to even the series.
The Lords were victorious and now lead 8-6.


Navy Takes Responsibility for Beach Trash
LEAD: The Navy said today it was apparently responsible for medical debris that washed onto North Carolina beaches remote from any metropolitan area, but said it did not know how it happened.


Chip Makers' Pace Slows
LEAD: The semiconductor industry's main barometer fell in July as chip makers in the United States, Europe and Japan reported a decline in orders and shipments, a trade group reported today.

The Call of the Lake is Music to Southern Ears
LEAD: All around the hydroelectrically blessed South, reservoirs created by power-company dams have turned utility-making into a sacred socio-recreational institution.
From the Memorial Day season opener until the Labor Day finale, the Friday-afternoon cry of ''Let's go to the lake!'' defies the work week pressures of efficiency and progress wrought by promoters of the Sun Belt.

A Mecca for Psychedelic Pilgrims?
LEAD: ON a balmy night a few weeks ago, 2,000 people filled an outdoor amphitheater in the Hollywood Hills at a benefit for the world's first LSD library and museum.
Named after the drug's Swiss discoverer, Albert Hofmann, the acid archive has neither home nor opening date.
Still, spirits ran high.

LEAD: As the Civilian Complaint Review Board continued yesterday to receive allegations of police brutality arising from weekend clashes over a curfew in Tompkins Square Park, Mayor Koch said Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward had commissioned an internal management review of police procedures in the East Village melee.

LEAD: Denise LaSalle, the veteran rhythm-and-blues singer, made her first appearance in New York in over 15 years Saturday afternoon at the Central Park Band Shell.
Ms.
LaSalle, wearing a dark blue sequined dress, is a natural crowd pleaser; radiating good cheer despite the scorching heat, she launched into a program heavy on her soul hits and interspersed with blues.

LEAD: Maybe it is not a potential best seller, but plans for a book on the Omnibus Trade and Competitive Act of 1988 is a manifestation of the interest in the legislation, even before President Reagan signs it.


Home Savings Bid
LEAD: The Home Savings Bank announced yesterday that its board of directors had unanimously rejected an unsolicited merger proposal from the Emigrant Savings Bank, based in New York.
It also said it was more than doubling its dividend to 37.5 cents a share, from 15 cents previously.
The dividend will be payable on Oct.


Metro Datelines; Judge Agrees to Hear '80 Fire Convictions
LEAD: state judge agreed yesterday to hear a motion to set aside the guilty verdict of a man convicted of setting the 1978 Waldbaum's supermarket fire that killed six firefighters.


Trading Bill Is Backed
LEAD: The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved a bill on insider trading by a voice vote after key House Democrats agreed to remove a provision that opponents called peripheral.
The provision would have given parties injured by insider trading connected with a tender offer the right to seek damages.


Correcitons
LEAD: A headline on the Washington Talk page yesterday about Senator John McCain misstated his tenure in the capital.
His election to the Senate in 1986 did not begin his service in Washington.
He had spent four years with the Navy's Senate Liaison Office and four more in the House of Representatives.


Metro Datelines; Trenton Takes Over Jersey City Schools
LEAD: New Jersey seized limited control of the Jersey City school system yesterday in a move that gives the state broad powers over the district's spending and personnel actions.

Market Place
LEAD: DURING a crisis, Wall Street seeks out companies that appear likely to emerge stronger for the experience.
The current drought in the Middle West is a case in point.
Surprisingly, some analysts are taking a long look at a sector that one would assume would be particularly ravaged: the agricultural banks.


Topics of The Times; Weighty Eights
LEAD: The portentous parade of eights continued all through Monday, 8/8/88:


COURT HALTS FINES
LEAD: A state board declared Yonkers to be in financial crisis today and froze all hiring and discretionary spending by its government.
Hours later, an appeals court panel suspended the daily fines imposed on the city for its defiance of a Federal desegregation order, giving it temporary relief from the threat of bankruptcy.


EXECUTIVES
LEAD: CBS-Fox Video promoted Robert DeLellis to president, North America, responsible for all consumer-products division activities.


Neglect and Vandalism Threaten a Broadway Theater
LEAD: The Biltmore Theater on West 47th Street.
The 63-year old theater, damaged by arson last December, appears to be deteriorating rapidly.
A group of people camp out regularly under the marquee and scavengers have been seen walking away with fixtures.
Page B3. (NYT/William E. Sauro)


Education; Class of '87 in a Small Missouri Town Thinks Big
LEAD: The farm financial crisis hurt the stores on Courthouse Square, and it looks like the drought is going to hurt them again.
But Gallatin, population 2,060, is producing something that seems to lift everybody's spirits.


Olympic Swimming
LEAD: On Monday night, Matt Biondi became overly excited and lost a race he might have won.
This morning, he forgot to adjust his racing glasses and missed breaking a world record.
Tonight, he did everything right and qualified for the Olympic swimming team in a second event.


Sports People; Campbell in Hospital
LEAD: The pain shooting through Earl Campbell's body did something no football opponent ever was able to do in the years when the running back bulled his way to a Heisman Trophy while at the University of Texas and all-Pro honors with the Houston Oilers.
Campbell, a special assistant to the president at the University of Texas, was awakened by the pain Saturday, gasping.


Manhattan's Peaceable Kingdom
LEAD: What can you say about a project that took eight years and $35 million to complete?
If you're talking about the new Central Park Zoo you can say, quite simply, that it is wonderful.


Sports People; Miller Off Team
LEAD: She led Southern Cal to National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championships in 1983 and 1984, and she helped the United States win a gold medal in women's basketball at the 1984 Olympic Games, but there'll be no glory this year for Cheryl Miller.
In Colorado Springs yesterday, she was released from the 1988 Olympic squad because of an injury to her right knee.

The Pop Life
LEAD: Lewis's Gray Areas ''Small World'' (Chrysalis), the fifth album by Huey Lewis and the News, a band whose sound epitomizes clean-cut, all-American rock, is the first record by the West Coast band to venture into international musical waters.


Drexel and Jefferies Deals Are Studied by Labor Dept.
LEAD: The Labor Department is conducting an inquiry into whether transactions involving Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. defrauded pension funds and other customers.


Eating Well
LEAD: ON an average Friday in August 1,200 customers stream through the door at Henry's Fish Market in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.
But last Friday was not an average day in August. ''I could read 'War and Peace' today and not be interrupted,'' said Michael Stein, who has owned the shop for 37 years.


Koch Seeking 775 More Police Officers for an Anti-Drug Blitz
LEAD: In response to the growing outrage over blatant drug dealing in the streets of New York neighborhoods, Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city plans to increase its police narcotics division by 50 percent and blanket drug-ridden areas with hundreds of new narcotics officers.


Taiwan External Debt
LEAD: Taiwan's external debt will hit a 14-year low this year after years of huge repayments, the Finance Ministry said today.
The debt dropped to $1.65 billion (United States) at the end of June from about $2.2 billion a year earlier, a ministry official said.
He said he expected the debt to fall to about $1.4 billion by the end of this year.

Jo Henderson, 54, Nominee for a Tony For 'Play Memory'
LEAD: Jo Henderson, a stage and film actress who was nominated for a Tony Award in 1984, died in an automobile accident Saturday in Chinle, Ariz.
She was 54 years old and lived in Pomona, N.Y.


Dollar Up Sharply on Rate Rise
LEAD: The dollar soared against major foreign currencies yesterday, propelled by an unexpected half-point rise in the Federal Reserve Board's discount rate to 6 1/2 percent.


Arafat Says Jordan Didn't Consult Him On West Bank Move
LEAD: In his first comments on Jordan's decision to sever ties with the Israeli-occupied territories, Yasir Arafat expressed anger today that King Hussein had not consulted him and that other Arab countries had not informed him of the King's plans.


5 Are Shot, 2 Fatally, From a Passing Auto
LEAD: Two men were killed and three others, including a 15-year-old boy in a wheelchair, were wounded yesterday when they were shot from a car in Brooklyn, the police said.

A 15-year-old boy was arrested in the incident.

Corrections
LEAD: The Westchester Guide in the Westchester Weekly on Sunday gave incorrect dates for two events in Garrison, N.Y.
The book sale at the Alice and Hamilton Fish Library will be held Aug. 20, not this Saturday.
The arts and crafts fair at the Garrison Art Center will be Aug. 20 and 21, not this weekend.

Results Plus
LEAD:  Tennis  Canadians Break Hold: Glenn Michibata, a veteran, and Andrew Sznajder, newcomer, ended a six-year Canadian losing run at the National Tennis Center yesterday when both won their first-round matches at the $815,000 Player's International in Toronto.
Michibata, one of the last Canadians to win in Toronto, in 1982, defeated Jorge Lozano of Mexico 7-5, 6-3.

Post at Arthur Young Is Shared by Partners
LEAD: Arthur Young &amp; Company, one of accounting's prestigious Big Eight firms, said yesterday that it was promoting two of its partners to the position of co-managing partner.


Making It Easier For Disk Jockeys
LEAD: The radio station disk jockey has traditionally led a frenetic life at work.
He must insert tape cartridges into playback machines, maintain a log of everything broadcast, juggle reports from the traffic helicopter, the newsroom and the weatherman while keeping up a witty patter.
Everything must run smoothly and with split-second timing.


Education; Doubts Abound on Boston U. Plan to Run Schools
LEAD: The decision by school officials in the Boston suburb of Chelsea, Mass., to allow Boston University to manage their troubled schools has left some education experts concerned that the move could erode public supervision of schools.
At the same time, educators were intrigued by the idea of a university managing a school system but skeptical that it could be done.

LEAD:  Killed: 420,000 (described as conservative by some scholars) to 1 million  Wounded: 900,000 to 1.7 million  Refugees: More than 1.5 million  Casualties in shipping attacks: At least 300 killed and 300 wounded  Economic cost: $400 billion +  Ships attacked: About 600 (90 destroyed)

LEAD: Tommy Dolan, left, and Kevin Lynch, lifeguards from Coney Island, carrying victim, Kelly Connaghan, as they won the two-man rescue event at the 10th annual Lifeguard Olympics at Orchard Beach in the Bronx.
One hundred of 900 lifeguards who guard the city's six beaches, 33 outdoor and six indoor pools, competed in six different events for trophies and medals.

Two American F-16's are practicing for war low over the sun-drenched vineyards.

Don't Merge Police Forces, Study Advises
LEAD: The transit police department, which came under sharp criticism last year after officers were accused of making improper arrests, should be left independent and not merged with the larger city Police Department, as the Koch Administration has advocated, an independent consultant has concluded.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article on Aug. 6 profiled a Metropolitan Museum of Art conservator, John M. Brealey, who has been on loan to the Prado Museum in Madrid to oversee restoration of Spanish art treasures.
It said he had turned down an invitation to stay past October, when his agreement ends.
The article said Mr.
Brealey cited dissatisfaction with working conditions, though some of his complaints had been resolved.

LEAD: The Daiwa Investment Trust Management Company will set up a five-year investment trust fund on Aug. 26 to invest in dollar-denominated bonds, a company spokesman said.
Daiwa Investment is an affiliate of the Daiwa Securities Company.

LEAD: Rogers Communications Inc. has agreed to sell its United States cable television business to a subsidiary of Texas-based Houston Industries for $1.3 billion, the companies announced today.

LEAD: ''The Island,'' the two-character play that Athol Fugard created with the black South African actors John Kani and Winston Ntshona, is one of the more Beckettian works by an author for whom the South African tragedy symbolizes metaphysical struggles that extend far beyond the horrors of apartheid.

Prodigious numbers of red hots are eaten at Wrigley Field, Comiskey Park, O'Hare Airport and other spots around town.
Which hot dog is paramount?

LEAD: Jean C. Harris, a professor of art at Mount Holyoke College and the former director of its art museum, died of cancer last Friday at Holyoke (Mass.) Hospital.

He was 55 years old.

Lawyer Gets 4 Months in Jail For Role in Trading Scheme
LEAD: Michael N. David, the central figure in a 1986 insider trading conspiracy involving five young professionals, was sentenced to four months in prison and four years' probation yesterday.


Taiwan Stocks Surge
LEAD: An index of the Taiwan stock market soared past 7,000 for the first time today, less than two weeks after it first topped 6,000 points.
Today's gain of 121.4 points brought the index to 7,120.09.
Brokers say the surge, which has nearly tripled the index since the start of the year, was caused by the huge number of small private investors who see the stock market as a quick way to make huge profits.


Sears to Open McKids Stores
LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company said today that it would open 20 to 40 free-standing McKids specialty stores by 1990, under an exclusive license from the McDonald's Corporation.
The move represents a deepening alliance between the nation's largest retailer and the nation's largest restaurant chain and reflects Sears's strategic decision to compete with specialty retailers.


3 Rescued From Burning Bronx Apartment
LEAD: Firefighters fought their way through thick black smoke to rescue a woman, her 4-year-old son and a man from a burning 14th floor apartment in a Bronx housing project yesterday, the authorities said.


Sports People; Atkinson Looks Ahead
LEAD: Jess Atkinson, who never missed a kick with the Redskins, will not get a chance to extend his streak with Washington.
Atkinson was released by the Redskins Monday night, leaving Ali Haji-Sheikh and the rookie Chip Lohmiller to duel for the team's place-kicking job.
The move ended Atkinson's bid to reclaim the job he lost almost 11 months ago when he dislocated his left ankle in the Redskins' season opener against the Philadelphia Eagles.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Yorker Circulation Reaches Record Level
LEAD: The New Yorker's publisher, Steven Florio, announced yesterday that the magazine had reached record circulation heights, an estimated average of 632,754 for the first six months of the year.

About New York; The Department Of Correction's Little Acre
LEAD: Summertime on Rikers Island.
No air-conditioning, few fans and most windows opening just a crack.
Outside the island's six jails are towering fences within even higher fences -all entangled with miles and miles of razor ribbon glistening meanly in the relentless sun.
Every minute or so another jet roars off from neighboring La Guardia Airport, as if to underline the fact that nobody here is going anywhere.

LEAD: C. George Dandrow, a retired sales executive of the Johns-Manville Corporation and a past president of the New York Building Congress, died of a heart ailment Tuesday in Jacksonville Beach, Fla., where he lived in retirement.
He was 89 years old and had been a longtime resident of Bronxville, N.Y.

LEAD: In taking control Tuesday of Yonkers's spending, the Emergency Financial Control Board declared a financial crisis even though daily fines imposed on the city for rejecting a court-ordered housing desegregation plan were still relatively small, totaling $12,700, and even though a Federal appeals court panel was considering suspending the fines until they could be appealed.

LEAD: The Senate narrowly approved a Democratic plan today to provide the Nicaraguan rebels with $27 million for food, clothing and medical supplies through March 1989, but no immediate money for arms and ammunition.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. In one of your columns you advised against using paint on exterior wood shingles.
However, my wood shingled house has already been painted several times, and is peeling and flaking as you predicted.
What advice can you give?
A.
The ideal solution is to take all the paint off with a remover or by pressure-washing with chemicals.

LEAD: The Senate Judiciary Committee today unanimously recommended confirmation of Dick Thornburgh, a former Republican Governor of Pennsylvania, as Attorney General.
Full Senate approval is expected Thursday.


Review/Dance; Giddy Festival Within a Festival Makes a Splash
LEAD: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival's new Splash festival is just about as giddily adventurous as its name.
The event sprawls out into Pillow studios, an open-air forest amphitheater and the venerable little Ted Shawn Theater.
Twenty-six top dance, music and performance-art soloists and companies will be presented in the festival by its close on Aug.


Seoul Agrees to Meet with North
LEAD: South Korean political leaders decided today to accept a North Korean proposal for a preliminary meeting at the truce village of Panmunjom next week, the first meeting between the two hostile neighbors in almost three years.


Insilco Gets More Takeover Inquiries
LEAD: The Insilco Corporation, which has agreed to a buyout at $29 a share, or $950 million, by an investment group led by the First Boston Corporation and senior members of its management, has received ''several unsolicited contacts from parties who have expressed interest in acquiring'' the company, according to the First Boston group.


Review/Theater; Going Home Again, to Argentina
LEAD: Nelly Fernandez Tiscornia's ''Made in Lanus'' looks like a simple domestic comedy, but it has a sharp emotional punch that leaves people dabbing their eyes while they laugh.
On one level, the Argentine playwright's argument is that not only can you go home again, even from exile, but also that home is a place you can never leave.


U.S. NEWS &amp; WORLD REPORT SETS CHANGE IN EDITOR'S POST
LEAD: U.S.
News &amp; World Report has named its senior writer, Roger Rosenblatt, to replace David Gergen as editor.


Gould's Hong Kong Plan
LEAD: Gould Inc. said today that a joint venture it owns equally with the Nippon Mining Company would build a plant in Hong Kong to produce copper foil used in printed circuit boards.
Gould, an electronics company based here, said it is building the plant in response to increased demand from markets in Southeast Asia and China.


Illinois Housing Authority Starts Dual Bond Offering
LEAD: The Illinois Housing Development Authority is tentatively offering $54.2 million of residential mortgage revenue bonds.
More than half are subject to the alternative minimum tax.

LEAD: The United States Postal Service plans to allow competitive bidding for part of the contract it awarded without bidding to the Perot Systems Corporation, Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said today.

LEAD: The commander of American and allied forces in Europe said today that the United States could achieve ''a fairly significant reduction'' in its nuclear warheads on the continent over the next decade.

LEAD: RANSEN DAILY knows what it means to sweat for money.

Soviets Check 2 U.S. Bases
LEAD: Soviet inspectors today finished checking two United States cruise missile sites in Belgium under terms of the treaty to eliminate medium- and shorter-range nuclear weapons.
The 20 Soviet experts visited the air base at Florennes, about 40 miles south of Brussels, and the European repair site at nearby Gosselies.

Mr.
Galloway will continue to serve in an advisory capacity.

Bill Rich, Alcan's vice president for British Columbia, said the power would be used for extra aluminum smelting in the region and that surplus power would be sold to the Government-owned British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority.

LEAD: Greg Walker, the Chicago White Sox first baseman, was released yesterday from Christ Hospital in Chicago where he underwent tests after suffering two seizures.
He was expected to begin workouts in 10 days to two weeks.
Walker suffered one seizure during batting practice on July 30 and another at the hospital the next day.

Corrections
LEAD: A chart yesterday on the timetable for a peace plan in southwestern Africa described the status of one point incorrectly.
South Africa has called for a withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola to be completed by next June 1, but Angola and Cuba have not agreed on that date.


Public Funds Proposed For Campaign Measure
LEAD: The New York City Charter Revision Commission yesterday agreed to a highly unusual proposal to require the city temporarily to pay for its own recently passed public campaign finance law.
The measure, which sets no dollar amounts, is among the commission's first significant charter amendments planned for the ballot this fall.


Political Memo; Some Fear Reagan Embrace Of Bush Could Be Suffocating
LEAD: President Reagan has now made it clear that he will do everything possible to help elect George Bush this fall, even if it means altering some strongly held views and policy goals.


Dollar Stages Late Retreat On Rumors of Intervention
LEAD: The dollar fell yesterday after rumors circulated in the foreign exchange markets that central banks around the world had agreed on a plan to prevent further appreciation of the American currency.

Health; Study Questions Coronary Bypass Benefits
LEAD: Having a coronary bypass operation improves the chances of survival for heart disease patients who are considered at high risk, according to a study of more than 750 men.
However, after five years, the differences in survival between those who have the surgery and those who are treated with drugs begin to diminish, the study found.


Jets Provide Tempting Targets
LEAD: It was interesting to hear how chipper the Jets' rookie defensive backs sounded this week after the club decided to cut two veterans and go with youth.


KOCH URGING GIFTS TO CHARITIES, NOT BEGGARS
LEAD: In a step that harks back to the Great Depression of the 1930's, Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city was planning a publicity campaign to urge the public to contribute to established charities rather than to street beggars.


Olympic Swimming; Biondi Sets Mark; Carey, Gaines Fail
LEAD: Matt Biondi said he had a good time today.
He swam fast in the morning, watched a television rerun of ''Leave It to Beaver'' in the afternoon and broke his world record at night by swimming the 100-meter freestyle in 48.42 seconds.


Aspin Threatens to Cut Money for the B-1 Bomber
LEAD: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin, has warned the Pentagon that unless it demonstrates how problems with the new fleet of B-1 bombers can be fixed, he will move to cut off money for operations and maintenance.

Business Digest: Thursday August 11, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


FATAL SYNDROME IN INFANTS RAISES PAINFUL QUESTIONS FOR DOCTORS
LEAD: Every six months or so, Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Bioethics at the University of Minnesota, gets a call from a troubled doctor.
A newborn baby has developed short-gut syndrome and lacks any functioning intestines.
It will never be able to absorb food normally.


Fiscal Worries, But Politics, Too
LEAD: The state agency that declared a financial crisis in Yonkers on Tuesday acted even though the daily fines imposed on the city for its defiance of a desegregation order were being appealed and bankruptcy was far from imminent.


Paul Thek Dead at 54; An Artist of the Surreal
LEAD: Paul Thek, an artist best known for installations of objects depicting surrealistic scenes of death and renewal, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 54 years old.


Paying the Price of Peace
LEAD: ''The U.S. is in favor of peace,'' the U.S. delegate to the United Nations, Vernon Walters, said lamely this week. ''Peace has its price,'' retorted U.N.
Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, and he's right.
The U.S. is the U.N.'s biggest deadbeat, owing $467 million in back dues.
Its continued failure to pay endangers the flourishing peace efforts of a revived U.N.


KEEPING LONDON 'ZIEGFELD' AFLOAT WITH COSMETICS AND FAST WORDS
LEAD: Most of the London critics have so far not enjoyed their second viewing of the musical ''Ziegfeld'' much more than they did their first.
One leading reviewer summed up its reworking, its restaging and the replacement in the title role of Len Cariou by the Israeli actor Topol as ''rearranging the furniture on the Titanic.


Biaggi Rethinks Tactic To Get Off of the Ballot
LEAD: Faced with possible objections by Federal prosecutors, Mario Biaggi is reconsidering whether he can remove his name from the Sept. 15 primary ballot by changing his legal residence from the Bronx to Washington.


WARD IS CRITICAL OF POLICE IN CLASH
LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday sharply criticized his department's handling of a disturbance last weekend in Tompkins Square Park, saying that poor supervision and questionable tactical decisions at the scene caused crowd control to fail.

LEAD: Now it's Montreal's turn.

LEAD: The New Zealand Challenge chairman, Michael Fay, has acquired a catamaran for use as a trial horse against his America's Cup challenger yacht, which must face one of the dual-hulled boats in next month's cup regatta.


Result of Trade Is Sinking In
LEAD: The trading of Wayne Gretzky, hockey's incomparable scorer and unparalleled craftsman, outraged a community, stunned a nation and electrified an entire league.
A day later, it still remains hard to believe and difficult to describe.


PRETORIA STARTING ANGOLAN PULLOUT
LEAD: South African soldiers began moving south in Angola today in preparation for their withdrawal from the country, the Pretoria Government said.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Yonkers desegregation case misstated the circumstances under which the Emergency Financial Control Board took over Yonkers' finances in 1984.
It acted after the Yonkers school board, facing a deficit, threatened to close the city's schools.


U.S. to Alter Chip Pricing
LEAD: The Commerce Department is planning to revise its formula for computing minimum prices for Japanese chips under the 1986 semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan.
The changes, instituted in response to requests from chip producers and users, would help reduce prices for new generations of chips.

For Blind Children, A Place to Have Fun
LEAD: WHEN Cornell Williams first came to Camp Wapanacki 14 years ago he was terrified of boating, a fear camp counselors say is shared by many 5-year-olds.
But for Mr.
Williams, who is legally blind and ''rather fond of solid ground,'' learning to row made him feel, he says now, that he could ''conquer the world.


Security Pacific's $200 Million Issue
LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation, a Los Angeles-based bank holding company, is offering $200 million of 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1991 at par through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton.


Woolworth Profit Rises
LEAD: The F. W. Woolworth Company reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent while sales increased 13 percent.
Net income was $43 million, or 68 cents a share, up from $37 million, or 56 cents a share, a year before.
Sales, helped by currency fluctuations, grew to $1.84 billion, from $1.63 billion.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Science Times on Aug. 2 about people who crave the thrill of riding a roller coaster misidentified brain chemicals that are believed to respond to excitement.
They include adrenaline and noradrenaline, but not monoamine oxidase.


ONE MAINSTREAM DUKAKIS ...
LEAD: In attacking Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis for being ''far outside'' the ''mainstream'' of postwar American foreign policy, Vice President Bush has raised a campaign issue that may boomerang.
For it is the Vice President who in recent speeches has not merely taken himself out of the mainstream but climbed way over on to the right bank.


New Housing Posts a Rise
LEAD: Completions of new homes rose 2.1 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.49 million units, after falling by 12.6 percent in May, the Commerce Department said today.

LEAD: Seve Ballesteros, who won the British Open for the third time last month, said today he did not intend to rejoin the PGA Tour as a card-carrying member in 1989.


IRAN SAYS INQUIRY MUST ASSAIL IRAQ
LEAD: The acting commander of the Iranian military said today that a United Nations inquiry must condemn Iraq as the aggressor in the Persian Gulf war or the region will face grave consequences.

Bar Condemns Sexual Barriers
LEAD: The American Bar Association adopted a resolution today that commits the group and its 346,000 members to ''refuse to participate in, acquiesce in or condone barriers to the full integration and equal participation of women in the legal profession.''

LEAD: ''We have a policy around here that's more than four years and eight months old and that's how long I've been here.
And that is responsibility and accountability.
You take the money, you wear the brass, you carry the badge along with it, and everybody is responsible for their own action.''  - Benjamin Ward, New York City Police Commissioner.

ARNULFO ARIAS, 87, PANAMANIAN WHO WAS PRESIDENT 3 TIMES
LEAD: Dr.
Arnulfo Arias Madrid, who long dominated civilian politics in Panama even though he was deposed from the presidency three times by the military, died in Miami today, the Panamanian consul here said.
He was 87 years old.


Sears President to Retire
LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company said today that its president, Richard M. Jones, would retire at the end of the year.
Mr.
Jones, who has been with the nation's largest retailer for 38 years, will be 62 years old at the time of his retirement.
The company said that Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman and chief executive, would add the title of president upon Mr.


Sports People; 60 Days for Youmans
LEAD: The drug-related suspension of Floyd Youmans, the Montreal Expo pitcher, has been set at 60 days, the baseball commissioner's office announced yesterday.
Youmans, suspended June 25 ''for failing to comply with his drug-testing program,'' will be placed on the disabled list Aug. 24, provided he continues in a drug treatment and testing program, the commissioner's office said in a statement.


Corrections
LEAD: Articles on June 7, July 2 and Aug. 3 about a Federal trial involving sanctuary for illegal aliens incorrectly described a defendant, the Rev.
Glen Remer-Thamert.
Mr.
Remer-Thamert was removed from the clergy roster of the Lutheran Church in America several years ago and is not affiliated with its successor, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.

Review/Music; Pop Classics for Horn
LEAD: Jazz musicians rarely get credit for keeping Tin Pan Alley standards current through the rock era.
Yet they continue to honor that repertory, both by reclaiming pop melodies with eloquent phrasing and by evading them to reveal ingenious harmonic structures. ''Standards on Horn,'' part of the ''Classical Jazz'' series with Wynton Marsalis as artistic adviser, drew almost equally on pop standards (''Body and Soul,'' ''Embraceable You'') and be-bop tunes (''Confirmation,'' ''Blue Bossa'').

Research Shift For SmithKline
LEAD: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said yesterday that Stanley T. Crooke had resigned as head of drug research.
He will be replaced by George H. Poste, a former cancer researcher and vice president of the company's Smith Kline &amp; French Laboratories.
Dr.
Crooke, 43 years old, led an unsuccessful effort to find products to replace Tagamet, SmithKline's ulcer drug.

LEAD: The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday that it had formed a unit to market pieces of its $25 billion private placement portfolio and to syndicate portions of new investments to institutional investors.


Group Buys 8.3% Of Best Products
LEAD: The Prospect Group Inc. has purchased an 8.3 percent stake in the Best Products Company and said it may hold talks with management about possible transactions, including an acquisition of the chain of catalogue showrooms.
At today's closing price of $15.625 a share, down 62.5 cents, Best Products, with 26.8 million shares outstanding, is worth $418 million.

4 Die in British Air Collision
LEAD: Two Tornado jet fighters collided while on separate low-level night training flights, killing three British airmen and a West German trainee navigator, the Defense Ministry said today.
Rescue workers recovered the bodies from wreckage scattered over a wide area in the Cumbrian hills of northwest England.

LEAD: The News Corporation, owned by Rupert Murdoch, plans to raise money to help finance its $3 billion takeover of Triangle Publications Inc. by selling shares in Reuters Holdings P.L.C. as well as land in Britain and Australia.

Johns, the journalist, author and screenwriter, died yesterday morning in the South County Convalescent Hospital in Arroyo Grande, Calif., her grandson, George St.
Johns, said.
She was 94 years old and had lived in Arroyo Grande for several years.

LEAD: The Islanders added a little more muscle to their corps of left wings by signing Mike Stevens, a free agent, who had 265 minutes in penalties last season in 63 games with the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League.

LEAD: After an emotional and sometimes anguished debate, conservatives held the line in the Republican platform committee tonight and kept the party's official doctrine implacably opposed to abortion and silent on the proposed Federal Equal Rights Amendment for women.


Sports People; Lakers Sign Woolridge
LEAD: Orlando Woolridge, the 6-foot-9-inch forward who played a season and a half with the Nets before entering a drug rehabilitation program last February, signed a multiyear contract yesterday with the Los Angeles Lakers.
Terms were not announced, but it was believed that the Lakers, the defending National Basketball Association champions, will pay Woolridge $500,000 a year.

LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., and Fujitsu Ltd. of Tokyo said today that they had signed a five-year agreement valued at a minimum of $280 million under which Fujitsu would market Sun's ''S Family'' products.


CARL HOLMAN, 69, A MAJOR FIGURE IN CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT, IS DEAD
LEAD: M. Carl Holman, president of the National Urban Coalition, a major figure in the fields of civil rights and urban affairs over four decades, died of cancer Tuesday night at Howard University Hospital in Washington.
He was 69 years old and lived in Washington.

Life in the 30's
LEAD: MY favorite city mouse/country mouse story is the one about the flat tire in the parking lot of the small-town supermarket.
Naturally, it happened when the car was carrying two children, nine bags of groceries and no spare, and when I was carrying $11 in cash.
The service station across the street called the body shop around the corner, which sent a man to pump the tire up and lead me back to his lot.

LEAD: After weeks of delay and a false start, engineers ignited the main engines of the space shuttle Discovery today and, to their relief, the engines apparently fired without serious flaw.

President Signs Law to Redress Wartime Wrong
LEAD: President Reagan, moving to ''right a grave wrong,'' signed legislation today that apologizes for the Government's forced relocation of 120,000 Japanese-Americans in World War II and establishes a $1.25 billion trust fund to pay reparations to those who were placed in camps and to their families.

We know it in our guts viscerally, and we know it in our minds.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone Profit Off
LEAD: Foote, Cone &amp; Belding Communications yesterday reported a 17.5 percent drop in net income, to $4.7 million, or 55 cents a share, from $5.7 million, or 68 cents a share, in the comparable 1987 quarter, when the results were lifted by a one-time gain.
Revenues rose 13.8 percent, to $97.2 million, from $85.4 million.

LEAD: Last summer, the Cleveland Quartet and two notable collaborators appeared at the Mostly Mozart Festival for a chamber-music program that eventually lifted itself to a distinguished level of music making.
But one of the collaborators didn't seem entirely compatible stylistically, and there was an oddly unsettled quality to some of the playing early on.

44% of Doctors Report Tests For AIDS on Donated Semen
LEAD: Forty-four percent of the nation's 11,000 physicians who perform artificial insemination do tests on the donated semen for the AIDS virus, according to a study conducted for Congress.

LEAD: A Federal judge has refused to halt the publication of ''Bare-Faced Messiah,'' by Russell Miller, a biography critical of L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of the Church of Scientology.

Lessons of 60's Forgotten in Park Riot
LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's preliminary indictment of his force's handling of last weekend's protest in Tompkins Square reflects the unusual degree to which the police's own lapses in planning and tactics allowed a threatening and unruly situation to degenerate into a riot.


Reporter's Notebook; Bar Group Widening Net and Impact
LEAD: The American Bar Association, once the exclusive preserve of white male practicing attorneys, has made some effort in recent years to include other elements of the legal profession.
As a result, more women, more blacks and members of other racial minorities, more law professors and even more representatives of foreign legal associations were present at the weeklong annual bar association meeting that concluded here today.


Penn State Upsets Syracuse
LEAD: Penn State and Syracuse, longtime powerful rivals in Eastern college football who have met annually since 1922, will end their rivalry in 1990 for an indefinite period.

LEAD: The co-defendant in the cocaine-smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas was declared indigent Tuesday and his trial lawyer was reappointed to serve as his appeal counsel.

LEAD: While researchers still disagree about the function of dreams, whether they are central or peripheral to our well-being, proponents of modern dream research say that they have discovered new ways to explore mind and body relationships, to assist people in psychotherapy and to promote creative problem-solving.

Falwell Supports Protesters At Anti-Abortion Rally in Atlanta
LEAD: Police officers arresting a protester, left, outside the Feminist Women's Health Center in Atlanta.
The Rev.
Jerry Falwell, above right, watching the demonstration, rallied with protesters from several states and gave one group leader $10,000 for legal expenses.
The 57 arrests yesterday pushed the total to 333 charged in several protests that began last month during the Democratic convention.


Sports People; Dodgers Release Sutton
LEAD: The Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday released Don Sutton, the active pitcher with the most victories in the major leagues.
Sutton, 43 years old, failed to complete any of his 16 starts this season.
He was 3-6 with a 3.92 earned run average.
He was on the disabled list with a sprained elbow from June 29 until Tuesday, when he was activated and started against the Cincinnati Reds.

LEAD:  International A3-13  The Nicaraguan rebels were provided with $27 million in a Democratic plan that the Senate approved 49 to 47.
Coming after a week of negotiations with the White House, the vote was a bittersweet victory for Democrats.

LEAD: A man was jailed Wednesday night after the police said he punched a police officer's horse in the face.

Hernandez became angry and punched his horse, then grabbed the reins and shoved him and the horse into the street.

Review/Art; Presenting Photos As Historical Relics And Curiosities
LEAD: WHEN photographs are framed and hung in museums and galleries, we can assume they are meant to be considered works of art.
Yet because they are often records of specific times and places, photographs also function as historical relics, showing us what our forebears considered worth preserving with a camera.

LEAD: A Federal judge upheld a crucial patent ruling in favor of the Polaroid Corporation today, saying that another judge who ruled against the rival Eastman Kodak Company was unbiased even though a relative of the judge owned Kodak stock.

Southwest Orders 20 Boeing Jetliners
LEAD: The Boeing Company said it had received a $560 million order from the Southwest Airlines Company for 20 of its 737-200 aircraft.
Boeing said the order brings the total value of announced jetliner orders for 1988 to $20.3 billion, a record for any full year.
It said the number of aircraft ordered this year reached 458, second only to the 1978 total of 461.

Restaurants
LEAD: Three years ago, when Montrachet opened on one of those exasperating you-can't-get-there-from-here blocks in TriBeCa (just wait till your cabbie tries to find it), it was a gamble for a French restaurant with such lofty aspirations, something akin to Lutece relocating on Staten Island.
Montrachet's unpretentious style, excellent Provencal food and modest prices soon lured legions of normally unadventurous uptown diners into this alien Z


Expos Making Their Move
LEAD: ''Beat the Mets?'' Buck Rodgers asked, sounding surprised at the question. ''I think so.
We've got the pitching now.
As good a defense as anybody, maybe the best in the big leagues.
Our hitters are coming around.
And we can run.'' He paused for effect, and added: ''We'll be there.'' After three months of skidding, three months of bragging about Andres Galarraga and little else, the Expos are recast and revived, and they are making a remarkable turnaround with runaway speed on the bases.


A HOT ISSUE: THE CHURCH THAT WASN'T
LEAD: At the end of a sun-washed Wall Street, as depicted in the newly issued New York statehood stamp, the spire of Trinity Church rises smartly over the city.
The scene is labeled simply ''July 26, 1788.'' That's the problem.
Anyone looking west on Wall Street on that date (when New York ratified the Constitution and joined the Union) would have seen - at most - the charred shell of the first Trinity Church, which burned in 1776 and remained in ruins during and after the Revolution.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 447 money market mutual funds increased $840.3 million, to $265.55 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 125 institutional funds were down $86.7 million, to $68.64 billion.
Assets of the 221 general-purpose funds were up $791.1 million, to $83.7 billion.


House Votes for More Pretoria Sanctions
LEAD: The House of Representatives approved a measure today that would impose stringent economic sanctions against South Africa because of apartheid, including a requirement that American companies, institutions and individuals withdraw all investments in that country.


Burma's Ordeal: Months of Upheaval
LEAD:  March 20: Reports reaching Bangkok say as many as 28 people were killed the week before in Burma's most violent anti-Government protests since 1974.
According to later reports, estimates of fatalities range from 2 to 200.
May 11: An Amnesty International report says Burmese Army units have killed and tortured members of ethnic minorities in defiance of Burmese and international law.

Best Products
LEAD: The New York-based Prospect Group Inc. has raised its stake in the Best Products Company to 9.9 percent, from 8.3 percent.
Prospect, a consumer products and railroad concern, said Wednesday that it might approach Best's management with a takeover proposal.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Prospect said it had bought a block of 315,000 Best shares on the open market Wednesday for $15.50 a share.

Gould to Sell Chip Division
LEAD: Gould Inc. said that it had agreed to sell its semiconductor division to the California Micro Devices Corporation for about $70 million.

Bush running for President and aiming for the votes of middle-class Americans, his advisers are getting sensitive about how he is pictured.

LEAD: The Republican platform committee approved a set of anti-drug proposals today that call for the death penalty for major drug traffickers and urge states to suspend eligibility for a driver's license to anyone convicted of a drug-related offense.

LEAD: Hope D. Brock, a member of the board of directors of the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan for 22 years, died Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston after a short illness.

Sports People; Majors's Pact Extended
LEAD: The Tennessee athletic director, Doug Dickey, announced that Johnny Majors, the football coach, had been given a three-year contract extension through the 1994 season.
The contract includes a raise in base salary from $85,000 to $96,000 a year and an equal amount from radio and television shows, or a total of $192,000 a year.

Auctions

At the fourth annual Richard W. Oliver Antique Fishing Tackle Auction, held in Kennebunk, Me., June 30 to July 1, world-record prices were established for the three major fishing-tackle categories of lures, rods and reels.

Drought Cutting U.S. Grain Crop 31% This Year
LEAD: In the gloomiest assessment yet of damage wrought by the drought, the Agriculture Department said today that the United States grain harvest this year would be 31 percent lower than last year.
The harvest, estimated at 192 million metric tons, would be the smallest since 1970.

Navy Takes Responsibility for Medical Debris on North Carolina Beaches
LEAD: Marines searching for debris on a beach in Atlantic Beach, N.C.
About 26 miles of beaches are being cleaned after medical debris, including syringes and vials, were found. ''The debris which is washing ashore appears to be connected with the Navy,'' said a spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet in Norfolk, Va., but he did not know how it came to be dumped in the ocean.

LEAD: Homicides in Westchester County rose 50 percent last year, to 48, the medical examiner's office said today.

Review/Art; Synopsizing the Graphic Fabric of Modern Life
LEAD: No doubt with conscious irony, Matt Mullican has left untitled his work on view at the Brooklyn Museum.
This is perhaps the single aspect of the large-scale project that refuses to state its own name.
With otherwise relentless persistency, Mr.
Mullican's images speak in a disconcerting babble of tongues, each busily labeling experiences and objects from our everyday lives.

Review/Film; Nostalgia For Israelis Off to War
LEAD: Any film about young men heading off to war is an easy trap for sentimentality, and a semi-autobiographical look at the naive idealism of high-school days is dangerously prone to myopia. ''Late Summer Blues'' stumbles into both these pitfalls, as it tells of four Israeli high school graduates about to be drafted in the summer of 1970, when soldiers were dying in the war of attrition over control of land bordering the Suez Canal.

Review/Art; Notebooks of an Artist Without Enough Time
LEAD: As might be expected, ''The Sketchbooks of Ree Morton,'' currently on view at Franklin Furnace, is a modest, ephemeral exhibition.
Morton did not have time to mature as an artist or to qualify for the major leagues of art history.
A mother and homemaker who did not turn to art full- time until she was past 30, she died in an automobile accident in 1977 at the age of 41.


Vast Amazon Fires, Man-Made, Linked To Global Warming
LEAD: Like eerie ghosts of the trees and animals dying below, thick clouds of smoke are rising over the rain forest as the man-made fires of the annual dry season are once again upon the Amazon.

LEAD: Two years ago the Michigan Legislature enacted the nation's first state-run program to guarantee college tuition for students whose families invested in a special tax-free trust fund.

Sports People; Starling Bout Voided
LEAD: Larry Hazzard, the New Jersey State Athletic Control Board commissioner, yesterday voided the controversial welterweight fight in Atlantic City July 29 in which Marlon Starling, the defending champion, was knocked out by Tomas Molinares.
Hazzard, who has studied tapes of the ending, ruled that Molinares's knockout punch, a right cross, was thrown after the bell ended the sixth round.

He is replacing Gary W. Rhodes, who, for personal and family reasons, has decided to take on the job of chief financial officer.

LEAD: Larry Bowa, dropped as manager by San Diego two and a half months ago, will return to the city where he started his pro career to coach third base for the Philadelphia Phillies.
Lee Thomas, the club's personnel director, said Bowa would be in uniform Tuesday in Los Angeles against the Dodgers.
He replaces John Vukovich, who will assist Manager Lee Elia in the dugout.

Tours and Attractions Offered by Metro-North
LEAD: In an effort to increase traffic and revenue in off-peak hours, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, which operates commuter train service on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven Lines, now offers 16 different tours -some combining rail and bus service - to various points of interest not far from New York City.


Big Banks Lift Prime By a Half Point, to 10%
LEAD: Several major banks, led by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, yesterday raised their prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 10 percent, the highest level since June 1985.
The increase was the third this year and economists said it was not likely to be the last.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on July 22 about the politics and economy of Fiji and an article on July 28 about the Peace Corps role there misidentified the nation's Prime Minister.
He is Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, who first served as Prime Minister from 1970 until April 1987; his successor, Timoci Bavadra, was deposed by a coup in May 1987.

LEAD: The head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that the agency was closely monitoring one or two major banking institutions that may need substantial Government assistance.

Corrections
LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday about the DeKalb Corporation described an aspect of the company's restructuring plan incorrectly.
For each share of DeKalb stock, shareholders will receive one share in the oil well service company, to be renamed Pride Petroleum Services Inc.; DeKalb will keep the oil and gas exploration business.


NEW YORK TO BEGIN FREE-NEEDLE PLAN FOR DRUG ADDICTS
LEAD: New York City health officials said yesterday that they would begin a long-debated experiment to distribute free, clean needles to 200 drug addicts in an attempt to slow the spread of AIDS.

Hewlett-Packard Sets 10% Purchase of Octel
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would buy a 10 percent stake in the Octel Communications Corporation, a fast-growing Silicon Valley company that supplies voice-processing systems.
Octel products will also be distributed in Europe under the Hewlett-Packard name.

Why We Can't Afford Reaganomics Anymore; Shrinking Middle Class
LEAD: To the Editor:





PGA Championship; Gilder Sets Mark to Take a 1-Shot Lead
LEAD: The Oak Tree Golf Club's 7,015-yard, par-71 course, promoted as ''the toughest course in the country'' by its real-estate developers, proved a patsy for many of the golfers in today's opening round of the 70th PGA Championship.


A Congressman's Complex Relation to a Military Contractor
LEAD: Two years ago, when Representative Bill Chappell Jr. urged a fledgling military contractor named Armtec Inc. to open its plant in his Florida district, he said he was doing what politicians are supposed to do: bring jobs and revenue to his constituents.

Brash Clubs or Haute Cuisine For Sultry Summer Nights
LEAD: IN this summer of discontent for so many restaurants and clubs, not all is gloom and thunder.
Sure, Il Palazzo has gone belly up.
Maxwell's Plum has succumbed.
Nobody talks about Nell's or Bice anymore, and there are empty banquettes at the Four Seasons and the Quilted Giraffe.
But the Darwinian struggle rages on, and, while the pace has slowed, the fickle populace still has an insatiable taste for adventure.


Review/Theater; Angelina Reaux Sings Weill at the Public
LEAD: Kurt Weill was such a musical chameleon that the challenge of constructing a dramatically cohesive one-person show around his songs is daunting.
After moving from Germany to the United States in 1935, Weill largely abandoned the mordant music-hall idiom of his collaborations with Bertolt Brecht for an airier, more melodious Broadway-oriented style.


Review/Film; Hollywood's Youn Bloods in 'Youn Guns,' Tale of Outlawry
LEAD: The western ''Young Guns,'' which opens today at the Manhattan Twin and other theaters, is less like a real movie than an extended photo opportunity for its trendy young stars.
Dressing up in badges and holsters has often been an irresistible temptation for groups of photogenic young actors, and this film, in the tradition of ''The Long Riders,'' is happy to watch its cast play cowboy on an elaborate scale.

Profits Up 29% At Sotheby's
LEAD: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the parent of Sotheby's auction house, reported yesterday that its profits rose 29 percent in the second quarter, lifted by strong art sales in North America.


At the 9th Precinct, Pride Is Unshaken
LEAD: Until Saturday night, the officers of the Ninth Precinct in the East Village thought they had managed what one of them called ''a juggling act'' - keeping the ethnically, culturally and economically diverse neighborhood relatively harmonious.


Going Straight To the Source In the Drug War
LEAD: Last April, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d toured the vast coca plant fields of Latin America pledging United States support for local efforts to attack cocaine production at its roots.
It was just talk.
The Reagan Administration has done virtually nothing to help Latin Americans curb the flow of cocaine to our shores.


Owner Reportedly Criticized Gretzky
LEAD: Peter Pocklington, the owner of the Edmonton Oilers, said that Wayne Gretzky's ego had prompted his trade to the Los Angeles Kings and that the superstar's tearful departure from Edmonton on Tuesday was skillfully acted.


Manuel Kulukundis, Shipowner, Dies at 89
LEAD: Manuel E. Kulukundis, the Greek-born shipping magnate who went bankrupt in the early 1960's, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Southampton, L.I.
He was 89 years old.


Topics of The Times; Burma on the Brink
LEAD: The defiant protests exploding across Burma testify to more than a quarter century of repression and misrule.
Despite an overwhelming advantage in firepower, the military Government is on the ropes.


In New York City, Volunteering Can Become a Full-Time Job
LEAD: To the Editor:


Washington Talk: Foreign Affairs; U.S. AND JAPAN PONDER A FREE TRADE PROPOSAL
LEAD: It is an idea searching for its time to come.
For some, that may be the next Presidential term, and for others it may be the 21st century.

Power Goes Out in Brooklyn
LEAD: About 8,000 Consolidated Edison customers in the Bay Ridge, Dyker Heights and Bensonhurst sections of Brooklyn lost power for parts of last night and early today.
The blackout occurred when three power cables shorted out for an undetermined reason, said a spokeswoman for the utility.
The blackout began at 9:50 P.M., and power was restored at 1:50 A.M.

House Gets a Sweeping Bill to Combat Drugs
LEAD: The House of Representatives today received a sweeping and politically appealing anti-drug bill that includes an amendment allowing the death penalty to be imposed on those who commit murder in the course of a drug-related felony.


WAS OPERA DIRECTOR AND DESIGNER
LEAD: Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, one of the most successful of present-day operatic directors and designers, died yesterday in a hospital in Munich, West Germany, where he maintained an apartment.
He was 56 years old.


Corrections
LEAD: The Personal Computers column in Science Times on July 25 gave an incorrect telephone number for Ocean Communications of San Jose, Calif., producer of a videotape on desktop publishing.
Its number is (408) 437-8990.


Pop/Jazz; Celebration Of Pop Fluff From the 50's
LEAD: Watching ''The Taffetas - A Musical Journey Through the Fabulous Fifties'' at the Cherry Lane Theater, one wonders: Were we really so innocent all those years ago?
The show, a celebration of pop fluff that has made its way from cabaret to Off Broadway, offers an amusing reminder of just how far pop culture has advanced - or declined, depending on one's taste - in the last 35 years.


Bally Sets A Spinoff To Holders
LEAD: Under mounting pressure from investors to improve its financial performance, the Bally Manufacturing Corporation announced a plan today to spin off its hotel and casino businesses to its stockholders as a tax-free special dividend.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Wall Street Journal Shifts Work to GSD&amp;M
LEAD: The Wall Street Journal is pulling its business out of both Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis and the troubled British-owned Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein in New York and consolidating it at GSD&amp;M, in Austin, Tex.


Macmillan Profit Falls 10%; Harcourt's Loss Narrows
LEAD: Macmillan Inc. yesterday reported a 10 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, while another publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., posted a loss.


Regan Finds Additional $400 Million Budget Shortfall
LEAD: New York State, which is already taking steps to close a budget gap of more than $1 billion, is facing an additional revenue shortfall of $400 million, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said today.


Secretary Bennett's Words
LEAD: William Bennett, the third Secretary of Education, is already the most memorable.
Mr.
Bennett, who resigned this week, has never shied from controversy and gladly used his post as a pulpit.
But often, he was better at raising provocative questions than providing thoughtful answers.
His tenure will likely be remembered more for polemics than education policy or planning.

Bonn Cuts Ghana's Debt
LEAD: West Germany will write off 400 million marks, or about $210 million, in loans to Ghana, a West German official said Thursday.
The amount represents slightly less than half the $495 million that the West German Government has loaned to the West African republic, the official, Dr.
Volkmar Koehler, said while visiting Ghana.


Olympic Boxing; U.S. Team Awaits Decision on Coach
LEAD: There is still one spot on the Olympic boxing team to be determined and it will not be decided in the ring.
On Sunday, in Denver, Ken Adams, the head coach who was suspended for six months because of an altercation with an official of the United States Amateur Boxing Federation, will have his appeal heard by an arbitrator, who will render a decision within five days.


The Big Dividends of a Gulf Peace
LEAD: In the wake of the cease-fire announcement in the Iran-Iraq war this week, foreign delegations have been descending on the capitals of the two Gulf nations to put diplomatic relations on a closer footing and to promote economic interests.

Over 300,000 Somalis, Fleeing Civil War, Cross Into Ethiopia
LEAD: More than 300,000 Somali refugees, fleeing civil war, have walked across the Ethiopian border in the last two months, relief officials say.
The officials called the outpouring of refugees among the most sudden they have seen.


Nicaragua Challenged On Jailings
LEAD: Lawyers for five prominent opposition leaders who have been jailed for the last month are challenging the authorities' application of Nicaraguan law in the case and contend that their clients' fate will ultimately be decided by Sandinista political leaders, not the courts.


Ortega Offers to Resume Talks
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua offered today to renew peace talks with the contras, either in Managua or Washington.
Mr.
Ortega, who is visiting Ecuador, also criticized the United States Senate for approving a package of aid for the rebels, calling it an act of ''aggression.'' He demanded that such aid be stopped.

Cuomo, in Yonkers, Meets With N.A.A.C.P. Officials
LEAD: Governor Cuomo traveled to Yonkers today for the first time since the city was declared in contempt for defying a court-ordered desegregation plan and met with leaders of the N.A.A.C.P. who have criticized his handling of the controversy.
He later blamed the ''failure of the political system'' for the continuing opposition to the plan.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Baseball; Red Sox Set Mark By Beating Tigers
LEAD: The Boston Red Sox set an American League record tonight with their 23d straight victory at home, beating the Detroit Tigers, 9-4.


'Borrow and Spend' Policies Led To Interest Rise, Dukakis Asserts
LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis, hammering at the Reagan Administration's fiscal policy, challenged the Republican Party today to use its convention to explain the ''borrow and spend'' philosophy that he said was driving up interest rates.


Blaze Forces Tourist Exit Of Skyscraper
LEAD: A stubborn electrical fire broke out on the 86th floor of the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon, creating clouds of billowing smoke and some scary moments for hundreds of sightseers and office workers high up in the famed 102-story skyscraper.


Nixon Exercises His Civil Rights in Legal Dispute Over Papers; Proust Understood
LEAD: To the Editor:


Louis Balducci, Grocer, Dies at 89 After Years as Chefs' Inspiration
LEAD: Louis Balducci, the grocer who put Italian sunshine on New York tables with the ripest tomatoes and the finest focaccio, died of leukemia Thursday at Flushing Hospital in Queens.
He was 89 years old and lived in Flushing.


Parts of Racism Suit Against F.B.I. Dismissed
LEAD: A Federal district judge has dismissed major elements of a lawsuit charging racial harassment that a black agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation filed against the bureau, but the agent can file a new complaint.


Jackson Wins Video Delay
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson today won an extension of a court order barring a businessman from selling videotapes of Mr.
Jackson's speech to the Democratic National Convention.


Prices on Treasury Bonds Fall Modestly
LEAD: Treasury bond prices fell modestly yesterday, capping a week of declines totaling 3 points, the largest weekly drop of the year.

If You Run in the Heat . . .
LEAD: Running when the temperature is in the 90's is potentially dangerous, but it becomes even riskier if the relative humidity is also extreme.
Body heat generated by exercise can be carried away only through evaporation, and when temperature and humidity are high, evaporation is severely limited.

Contract Stalemate
LEAD: The head of the National Hockey League officials' union said yesterday that job security, not money, is the major issue in contract talks.
Larry Bertuzzi, the N.H.L.'s chief negotiator, said that during meetings Thursday and yesterday the league offered increased salary and bonus packages under which senior referees could earn between $130,000 and $150,000 a year.

Big A.T.&amp;T. Computer for Complexities

Review/Music; Aphoristic Kafka, for Soprano and Violin
LEAD: The entire Monday evening installment of the Contemporary Music Festival at Tanglewood was devoted to ''Kafka Fragments'' (Op. 24), a spare but often wrenching 75-minute duo for soprano and violin by the Hungarian composer Gyorgy Kurtag.
Completed in 1986, the work is a collection of mostly aphoristic settings of excerpts from Franz Kafka's letters and diaries.


Big Payday Predicted
LEAD: Mike Tyson will get a gross purse of ''well over $5 million'' from his heavyweight title defense Oct. 8 against Frank Bruno of England, the champion's manager predicted yesterday. ''And I'm being conservative,'' Bill Cayton said.

85 Get $20,629 in Pick-Six
LEAD: Cadillacing hung on by a neck to win the $115,000 Ballerina Stakes today at Saratoga and complete a Pick-Six betting sequence that rewarded 85 bettors with $20,629 apiece.
The gross Pick-Six pool of $2,481,566, which included a five-day carryover, was the largest in New York racing history.

Harbingers Of Gloom
LEAD: Lately I tense up and start to worry whenever I see young white men in business suits, especially if they are carrying briefcases.
I have only a shred or two of evidence to back it up, but I now operate on the theory that young white men in business suits are a sure sign that bad news is not far off, especially if they are carrying briefcases.


LOTION TO SOAK UP OIL
LEAD: To control oily skin, a special problem in hot, sticky weather, cosmetics companies have introduced products with a new technological twist.


New Law Sets $100 Fines For Taking Shopping Carts
LEAD: People who take shopping carts home from the store to carry groceries or who steal milk crates for storage will be subject to $100 fines under a bill signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

Rights Chairman Is Chosen
LEAD: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today concurred in President Reagan's selection of William Barclay Allen, a California professor, as its chairman.
He succeeds Clarence M. Pendelton Jr., who died June 5.
The vote was 5 to 1, with Commissioner Mary Frances Berry in opposition.
Mr.
Allen, a professor of government at Harvey Mudd College who has served on the commission since April 1987, said he would not allow the commission ''to become an arm of advocacy groups in the civil rights movement.

LEAD: The hay fever season doesn't start until Monday, but don't tell that to Dr.
Herbert I. Cohen, a Central Park West allergist, whose waiting room is already full of sneezing, sniffling patients who have had trouble breathing for weeks, long before ragweed pollen began its windblown mischief.

Insilco Holders Sue on Buyout
LEAD: Stockholders of the Insilco Corporation have filed suit in Superior Court here to block a leveraged buyout of the company by management, contending that the value of the deal is ''grossly unfair and inadequate.''


Sex Ring Had List of 40,000
LEAD: A prostitution ring of about 70 women listed more than 40,000 clients' names in a computer, the police have disclosed.
The ring, which had been in operation since the early 1970's, charged clients $200 to $275 an hour, investigators said Wednesday.
Five people were charged with pimping and pandering.

YANKS RALLY
LEAD: The Yankees soared and fell and soared tonight.
After losing a three-run lead and then almost losing the game, they were revived when Rickey Henderson hit a two-run single in the ninth inning that gave them a 6-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins at the Metrodome.

COMPANY NEWS Bid for Zondervan Allowed to Stand
LEAD: The Zondervan Corporation said that a Federal court in Grand Rapids had refused to stop a $13.50-a-share offer for up to a million Zondervan shares by Harper &amp; Row Publishers Inc., a unit of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.
Zondervan, a Grand Rapids-based maker of religious books and records, has about 4.2 million common shares outstanding.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Aunt Nellie's Farm Kitchens, Clyman, Wis., a food processing company, said that its management had purchased the company from American Brands Inc., Old Greenwich, Conn.
Terms were not disclosed.


COMPANY NEWS T.W.A. Meeting
LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc. scheduled a special shareholders meeting for Sept. 7 to vote on the proposal by its chairman, Carl C. Icahn, to take the company private.
If the proposal is approved, T.W.A.'s shareholders will receive $20 in cash and $30 in debt for each of their shares, the company said.

Reviews/Music; More Than 2 Concertos, but Fewer Than 3
LEAD: It was an evening of two, almost three, concertos at Mostly Mozart on Wednesday night.
Bona fide specimens by Mozart - the one for clarinet in A and the Piano Concerto No. 25 - stood in the middle of this program at Avery Fisher Hall.
But there was also Schubert's Third Symphony, from his 19th year.


Review/Film; 'MAC and Me,' Family From a Distant Planet
LEAD: If you made a film about a homesick extraterrestrial befriended by a little boy, would you dare to have the creature look like E. T.'s cousin? ''MAC and Me'' is such a shameless clone that its cute little alien has E. T.'s gangly, prune-skinned body, his elongated arms and fingers, his enormous, mournful eyes - that look of a cross between an infant and his own grandfather.


COMPANY NEWS Genentech Stock Falls After Report
LEAD: Shares of Genentech Inc., the nation's largest biotechnology company, dropped today to their lowest level this year amid speculation that the company's heart attack drug, Activase, may face tough competition from a much less expensive therapy.
The drop followed a satellite news conference from London on Thursday announcing the results of a study that showed that the use of the drug streptokinase, which is considerably cheaper than Activase, in combination with aspirin could save thousands of lives each year.


Italy Accuses Getty Museum on Sculpture Loan
LEAD: Italian Government officials today accused the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., of acting imprudently and irresponsibly in returning to an anonymous collector pieces of ancient Greek sculptures the authorities here believe were taken illegally from Sicily.

Nixon to Return
LEAD: Even though his team's 39-75 record is the worst in the National League, Manager Russ Nixon of the Atlanta Braves will be back next season, according to General Manager Bobby Cox.
Cox said: ''He's the guy we want managing this ballclub.
We're high on him.'' Nixon replaced Chuck Tanner as manager when Tanner was dismissed May 22 after posting a 12-27 record.


Business Week Broadcaster Is Dismissed Over Holdings
LEAD: Business Week magazine said yesterday that it had dismissed Rudy Ruderman, who broadcasts its daily stock-market radio reports, for violating the magazine's disclosure requirements by failing to disclose all of his stock holdings.

PGA Championship; Azinger Grabs the Lead by One Stroke
LEAD: Paul Azinger could not swing a golf club a week ago because he was suffering so much from back pain and muscle spasms.
Since then, he has not slept well because of the back problems, he said, although medical treatment has allowed him to play golf this week without pain.


Man Stabbed to Death While Delivering Pizza
LEAD: An 18-year-old pizza deliverer was stabbed to death yesterday afternoon on a busy Manhattan sidewalk, apparently during a robbery attempt or a dispute, the police said.

I.R.S. Bows to Pressure From Rail Workers
LEAD: Senators Alfonse D'Amato, left, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan with Ed Yule of the American Transportation Union, center, as he announced a temporary victory in a dispute with Internal Revenue Service.
The I.R.S. waived tax rules that would have forced the early retirement of thousands of Long Island Railroad workers.


Left at Airport Gate? Hope for the Best
LEAD: It happens to hundreds of thousands of Americans each year.
They arrive at the airport for that long-scheduled vacation or business trip, look at the electronic board to check the departure gate and discover that their flight has been canceled.


A Skirmish Along the Wall Between Arab and Jew
LEAD: A dark tunnel, barely wide enough for one person, lies more than 40 feet beneath the Old City of Jerusalem, ending in a mud-filled ancient cistern below the Via Dolorosa.

LEAD: After a month of protests and angry rallies by groups that consider the movie blasphemous, Martin Scorsese's ''Last Temptation of Christ'' opened today to long lines, sold-out theaters and scattered picketing.

22.9 Percent: A Youth Emergency
LEAD: According to the U.S.
Bureau of Labor Statistics, nearly half the working-age residents of New York City are neither employed nor looking for work.
Only 22.9 percent of the city's 16-to-19-year-olds - less than half the national average - are in the labor force.
Though worse in New York, the same problem also stirs concern in other cities.

Moderate Quake in Tokyo
LEAD: A strong but brief earthquake rocked central Tokyo today, sending skyscrapers swaying and snarling rail transportation at the beginning of O-Bon, an annual holiday.
Though the earthquake measured 5.3 on the Richter scale, enough to do moderate damage, no injuries or damage beyond broken glass were reported.

Ex-Manes Aide Helping Inquiry Into Corruption
LEAD: Richard L. Rubin, a convicted former Queens Democratic Party official described as a ''power broker'' for the late Donald R. Manes, is cooperating with Federal prosecutors and other authorities investigating official corruption, court papers disclosed yesterday.


OPEC Leader to Travel
LEAD: OPEC's secretary general, Subroto, will visit Iran, Iraq and Kuwait later this month, the oil group said today, The visit is apparently being made in hopes of finding a way to drive up oil prices.
A spokesman for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Kemal Saiki, said Dr.
Subroto was likely to make his tour in the last 10 days of August, the OPEC News Agency reported.


Hunt Suit Nearing End
LEAD: Lawyers for a Peruvian mineral concern asserted yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan that evidence they had presented during five months of trial proves that the Hunt brothers of Texas were part of a conspiracy to drive up silver prices.


BRIDGE
LEAD: Bridge-players have sometimes been real-life murder victims, from Joseph B. Elwell of auction fame to the Bennett card-table murder and Barry Crane.
And there have been fictional bridge mysteries, of which the most notable is Agatha Christie's ''Cards on the Table,'' with the vital clue provided by the discarded score-pad.


More Texas Banks Fail
LEAD: The record for Texas bank failures in a year has been broken slightly more than halfway through 1988.
Federal regulators declared three more Texas banks insolvent on Thursday and also decided to count the 40 former subsidiary banks of the First Republicbank Corporation as failed institutions.

Patents; Edmund Andrews Devices To Improve Athletic Skill
LEAD: Today's athletes need more than strength and ability, some inventors contend.
Plenty of hard data is also necessary, they say: the speed of a bat, the power of a punch, the shock of a blow, the length of a stride.
So inventors are now planting sophisticated measuring devices in everything from football helmets to running shoes.

What Lawyers Owe to Justice
LEAD: Judge Learned Hand once said that if we are to keep our democracy, there must be one commandment: ''Thou shalt not ration justice.'' Yet current national trends, raising the cost of private legal counseling while diminishing the availability of public law services, seem to break this rule.
As a consequence, economic constraints, rather than the judge or jury, have become the arbiters of justice.


World Cup Soccer; Berth At Stake For U.S.
LEAD: The United States Soccer Federation has all sorts of ambitious plans for the World Cup in 1994, but its immediate hopes for the World Cup are in danger of suffering a severe setback this afternoon.

LEAD: The Miami Beach industrialist Victor Posner has agreed to return 13 Norman Rockwell paintings he took from the Sharon Steel Corporation after he bought the company in 1969.

LEAD: David Berkoff after setting a world record of 54.91 seconds in the 100-meter backstroke in the final at United States Olympic trials.
He bettered the mark of 54.95 he had set in an earlier heat. (Agence France-Presse) Page 48.

'Cocktail' and 'Rabbit' Top Ticket Sales
LEAD: Two Walt Disney films - ''Cocktail,'' starring Tom Cruise as a sex-symbol bartender, and ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' joining animated and human performers - took first and second places last weekend among the top 10 box-office revenue producers. ''Cocktail'' earned $8.2 million and ''Rabbit'' $5.8 million.


Five Years Later, Austin in No Hurry
LEAD: For the last five years, Tracy Austin has been on the outside of women's tennis looking in, waiting for the chance to answer the skeptics who said she would never play competitively again.
Ever since a chronic back injury and foot problems sent her into involuntary retirement in June 1983, Austin watched Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova divide most of the spoils, until a West German teen-ager with an overpowering forehand ended their domination last year.

Reviews/Music; 'Lucio Silla' in Concert At Mozart Festival
LEAD: Throughout the performance of ''Lucio Silla'' on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, one thought kept returning: Mozart must have had incredible singers at his disposal to write such a bel canto marathon.
Composed in the reigning opera-seria style when Mozart was 17 years old, the work is in effect an aria competition, an Olympic event for vocal gymnasts.

The American Foot
LEAD: The metrication of America moves slowly; this is one of only three countries (the others are Burma and Liberia) that do not conform to the metric system.

Even the American ''foot'' is out of step.

Patents; Electronic Shoes
LEAD: Puma A.G., the West German manufacturer of athletic shoes, has patented electronic running shoes.
Each shoe contains a miniature transmitter, receiver and time-counter.
As a shoe hits the ground it emits a signal that bounces off the second shoe and returns.
A computer, located nearby, monitors these signals and translates them into stride length.


WESTERN SAHARA MAY GET U.N. TEAM
LEAD: The United Nations has proposed sending a peacekeeping force of about 2,000 soldiers and administrators to the Western Sahara as part of a plan for ending the war there between Morocco and the Polisario guerrillas, diplomats and United Nations officials say.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Choosing and Using Exterior Paints
LEAD: Today's outdoor paints are long lasting and easy to apply with either a brush or a roller, and most can be used on different surfaces.
But anyone who is tempted even in the full heat of summer to redo the shutters or the garage door should remember that no one paint can be used for everything or under all conditions, so read instruction labels carefully.

LEAD: Business inventories climbed for the 18th consecutive month in June, prompting some economists to warn that companies may be stockpiling goods in expectation of higher prices.
