Gunner in Squadron Disputes Bush on Downing of Bomber
LEAD: A man who says he witnessed the downing of George Bush's Navy bomber in World War II has disputed the Vice President's recollection of the incident, according to an interview reported yesterday in the New York Post.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City on Monday.
Other regulations remain in effect.


Collins Suspended
LEAD: Tony Collins was suspended by the National Football League for at least a year yesterday because he failed a drug test after signing with the Indianapolis Colts last month.

LEAD: The dollar fluctuated without direction yesterday as traders began looking ahead to next week's release of United States trade figures.

COMPANY NEWS Fieldstone in Deal For BCE Holdings
LEAD: The Fieldstone Company, a San Diego home builder, said it had agreed to buy most of the Southern California land holdings of the BCE Development Corporation for $250 million.
The holdings include 2,700 acres near the La Costa Spa and Resort in Carlsbad, Calif.
The deal includes the purchase of the land near La Costa, where 3,000 houses are planned;a stake in a resort development on Catalina Island, offshore California, and an option to become an equal partner with BCE in a 1,200-acre northern San


A New Recreation Center for the Elderly
LEAD: Mario Parisi, left, and Charles Hubert playing shuffleboard at a new senior citizens' outdoor cafe and recreation area opened by the Port Authority at Ninth Avenue and 39th Street.
The new facility is next door to the Project Find Coffee House, catering to area elderly in need of a safe gathering place.

It's a Jungle Out There
LEAD: New York City really is a tropical rain forest.
The National Weather Service says so.
For forty days and forty nights, the temperatures along the Hudson have been comparable to those along the Amazon.
So has the humidity.
Small wonder the natives talk more frequently than usual about thinking they are going mad.

What Have Musicians Done to Music?
LEAD: ''The Survival of the Symphony: What Musicians Have Done to Music'' is the subject of six radio lectures from the BBC that can be heard on WNYC-FM (93.9) beginning Aug. 21 at 8:30 P.M.
The series is part of the ''Reith Lectures,'' which have been broadcast on British radio for 40 years.
Alexander Goehr, a professor of music at Cambridge


Taking a Look at Lasix
LEAD: Saratoga in August is far more than 24 days of racing.
It has long been an unofficial international convention for thoroughbred racing.
The races occupy only the afternoon hours, preceded by formal meetings by various groups in the mornings and followed by auctions in the evening, and increasingly spirited discussions of the game into the night.


Police Studying Adoption Of 'Side-Handled Batons'
LEAD: The New York City Police Department is studying whether to adopt a new plastic nightstick used in other cities called the ''side-handled baton.'' The nightstick's backers say it is more versatile and offers an officer better protection than the 24- to 26-inch wooden sticks the department now uses.


Militia Fighting Feared in Beirut
LEAD: The danger of violence in the Lebanese presidential election appeared to increase today as anti-Syrian Christian militiamen went on alert to forestall the election of an ally of Syria as president of Lebanon.


Car Makers of the World Revive Horsepower Race
LEAD: The auto industry is getting into a horsepower race not seen since the ''muscle car'' era of the late 1960's.
And this time it is not just Detroit that is stuffing more powerful engines into family cars.
European and Japanese auto makers, seeking to enhance the glamour of their most expensive models, are playing the horsepower game as well.


New Blood at Neiman-Marcus
LEAD: A retailing dynasty ended today with Allen I. Questrom's appointment as president and chief executive of Neiman-Marcus Group Inc., whose department stores are known worldwide for their extravagant goods.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Tuesday about a Federal appeals court ruling on minors' access to abortion misidentified the President who appointed Judge Theodore McMillian and incorrectly associated judges with dissents.
Judge McMillian was appointed by President Carter, not President Johnson.
He signed both the dissent by Chief Judge Donald P.


Flight Delays Rise in Europe
LEAD: The Association of European Airlines said today that the number of delays in scheduled European flights in June was at least three times higher than in June 1986.

LEAD: They may look out of place among the video gadgets and exercise gear, but stun guns are showing up in a number of mail-order catalogues.
Marketed as personal protection devices, they are promoted to appeal especially to women, joining Mace and other chemical sprays as methods of repelling, but not killing, an attacker.

Ipanema Is Lovely No More
LEAD: Rio's Ipanema beach, famous for its bikini-clad girls, has been closed until December because of a pollution threat caused by a smashed sewage pipe.
The pipe broke in a storm that sent 13-foot waves crashing onto the shore.
City authorities decided to move the pipe instead of repairing it.

Olympic Swimming; Backstroke Record Is Set by Collegian
LEAD: A Harvard senior with a 3.0 grade-point average in anthropology seems an unlikely choice to take a year off from college to swim.
David Berkoff is in the middle of such a year, and the move paid off today when, using his unusual underwater style, he twice shattered the world record for the men's 100-meter backstroke.

India and Tribal Guerrillas Agree to Halt 8-Year Fight
LEAD: Leaders of a tribal insurgency in northeast India signed a peace accord with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government today.
The agreement came after eight years of guerrilla warfare in Tripura state that killed more than 2,000 people.

LEAD: Sussan Deihim, Richard Horowitz and Jon Gibson are to perform works of their own in a free concert at the Central Park Band Shell, at 72d Street, at 3 P.M today.
The collaborative works by Miss Deihim and Mr.
Horowitz combine Middle Eastern vocals and electronic sound.
Mr.
Gibson, a reed player who has worked with Terry Riley and Philip Glass, composes and performs music in the Minimalist style.

George Woods, 62, An Ex-Book Editor At The Times, Dies
LEAD: George Woods, for 21 years the children's book editor of The New York Times, died of lung cancer Thursday, at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J.
He was 62 years old and lived in Demarest, N.J.

Patents; Measuring the Blows Received in Football
LEAD: John A. Carlin, a Denver entrepreneur and sports fan, received two patents this week.
The first covers a device to measure the cumulative battering sustained by an athlete during a game.
The second invention does the opposite, measuring the amount of shock an athlete can dish out.

LEAD:  Yellowstone Visitors Face Road Closings


Needed: A New Pollution Industry
LEAD: ''Beach Waste Raises New Fears''  [ July 17 ]  makes me feel an even stronger urgency about this problem.
Ocean dumping of all refuse must end.
Land dumping of all refuse must end.


The Pleasures of Just Watching a Son Grow
LEAD: I AWAKEN to the sound of your voice issuing commands from the front yard.
My dreams are interrupted and I refocus on you; I welcome the diversion.
In my mind's eye I see your confident presence as you stand at a makeshift home plate, see your bat make contact as I hear the smack and see your slight but sturdy figure start to run.


Otto Passman, 88, Louisiana Congressman Who Fought Spending
LEAD: Otto E. Passman, an acid-tongued son of Louisiana sharecroppers who served in Congress for 30 years and pursued a relentless battle against spending for foreign aid, died yesterday at a hospital near his home in Monroe, La.
He was 88 years old.


Cities, Stadiums and Responsibility
LEAD: If George Steinbrenner feels unappreciated in New York, he can take comfort in the likelihood that he is still probably more popular than Walter O'Malley.
For the younger set, O'Malley was the last owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers, a franchise beloved by its borough, more successful than any other in the National League after World War II, and richer than any other in baseball including the Yankees.

LEAD: To the Editor:


In Heart of Seoul, an Unwanted U.S. Presence
LEAD: In the center of this crowded city lies a green expanse of rolling hills, complete with split-level homes, baseball diamond and 18-hole golf course.
It is Yongsan, the United States military base that for many South Koreans has become a nagging symbol of the dominant American presence here.


Reviews/Music; A Finale at Tanglewood For New-Music Festival
LEAD: The final concert of the Tanglewood Festival of Contemporary Music tonight was a satisfyingly varied program, played by the student orchestra of the Tanglewood Music Center and led, in all but one work, by Oliver Knussen, the British composer who has overseen this new-music festival the last few summers.

LEAD: Scores of young men and women surged around the bulletin board not long ago at St.

LEAD: HUGH L. McCOLL JR. learned a long time ago about the danger of confronting big challenges head-on.
Some 30 years ago, on the lacrosse fields at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, he was bashed so hard by an opposing player that he was knocked unconscious.


Reviews/Music; Capobianco's Staging Of Boito's 'Mefistofele'
LEAD: Tito Capobianco's staging of Boito's ''Mefistofele'' counts as one of the New York City Opera's great triumphs and oldest active productions, dating back to 1969.
Originally conceived as a vehicle for the late Norman Treigle, with his black, booming bass and spidery athleticism, it has survived handsomely with a notable succession of Mefistofeles, Fausts, Margheritas and Elenas.


About Cars; Honda Driver Rolling Along After 94,000 Miles
LEAD: Dear Mr.
Schuon, I read your column in 1984 on the Honda Prelude.
I drove it, loved it and bought it.
Everything you said was true.
I have 94,000 miles of commuting on the odometer, get 34 miles to the gallon, and just got my first set of new tires at 92,000 miles.
Jack Ader  Levittown, L.I.

Kasparov's Style: Turning a Defense Into an Attack
LEAD: THE world champion, Gary Kasparov, and his four-time opponent for the title, Anatoly Karpov, are poles apart on the question of defense: Whereas Karpov believes it is just something to get through without losing, Kasparov believes it presents another opportunity to win.


THE WORLD: Debate Today Has Echoes of the Past; U.S. in Central America: Years of Conflict and Suspicion
LEAD: FOR a century and a half, United States Governments and citizens have argued about the country's role in Central America.
How do they reconcile North American interests with Central American sovereignty?
How deep and direct should United States involvement be?
How much should Americans presume to direct these other lands in methods of governing themselves, even if the ostensible motive is to promote democracy?

Repairing Mortar Joints
LEAD: EVENTUALLY, almost all mortar joints in brick masonry deteriorate.
Prompt repair is required, because even small cracks and crumbled areas admit moisture, which in time can cause major damage, especially in regions where freezing occurs.

INTO THE GARDEN
LEAD: I HAVE JUST RETURNED FROM THE GARDEN WITH A basketful of blossom-tipped squash to cook for dinner.
This squash will need no butter, not only because it is so fresh, but because it is an old-fashioned crookneck.
It is funny looking, small and so frail that no commercial growers bother to ship them.

When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain which we cannot seem to remove.
We tried scouring powder, then tried rubbing with fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years).

Bayreuth Remains The Standard
LEAD: A visitor to this summer's Bayreuth Festival, the Wagnerian shrine inaugurated in 1876 by the composer himself and located in this eminently pleasant northern Bavarian town, would have been hard pressed to detect signs of endemic ill health.


A Traveler's Finest Hour
LEAD: EVERY tourist, it has been said, wants to be taken for a traveler, but the real achievement is to be mistaken for a native.
To be looked on as a native, however fleetingly, is one of the most sublime pleasures travel can offer.
It is a sign that often your worst fear - of standing out, appearing different -is unwarranted.

TOBACCO AND TRADE POLICY
LEAD: The fundamental flaw in your article ''Pushing Cigarettes Overseas'' (July 10) is Peter Schmeisser's inability to distinguish between health policy and trade policy.
Our trade policy is simple and straightforward.
We want the same market access and treatment for United States tobacco products that is afforded to the tobacco companies of the country in question.


Primary Questions On Coverage Of the Conventions
LEAD: The evolving nature of Presidential politics and the medium of television together have all but reduced party conventions to the level of the electoral college, which is to American politics what the vermiform appendix is to the human body.
The trend has progressed to the point that the only question now is whether the national conventions will vanish entirely or be recognized for what they have largely become: unpaid advertising on as much prime-time television as can be grabbed off in the name of public service.

Where Luminaries Let the Good Times Roll
LEAD: What follows is a portrait of New Orleans from the collective palette - and palate - of those whose personal or professional histories give them more than a passing familiarity with the city.
That the portrait has many features is not surprising, given the city's culture and history.
While some of those who were asked for their favorite New Orleans attractions mentioned well-touristed places, a few gave more private spots.


TALKING: Management; Buildings That Go It Alone
LEAD: DISSATISFIED with the service they have received from managing agents over the years, a sizable number of condominiums and cooperatives are changing to self-management.
Others report doing so because their management companies went out of business or no longer serviced buildings of a certain size.


Make Work Pay More Than Welfare
LEAD: Two bills, one in the House of Representatives and one in the Senate, call for raising the minimum wage, now at $3.35 an hour.
The House version would raise it by 40 cents a year until it reaches $4.55.
Sar Levitan, professor of economics at George Washington University and director of the Center for Social Policy, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about America's declining wages and the need to increase the minimum wage.

O'Connor Criticizes Movie
LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor said today that he did not have to call for a boycott of the controversial movie ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' because sensible Christians would avoid it on their own.
During a homily at a Mass at the Don Bosco Marian Shrine, the Cardinal said he had received many letters asking him to call for a boycott of the film, which portrays Christ as a man who questions his role on Earth.


When Insurance Coverage Falls Short
LEAD: In recent years, an increasing number of policyholders have taken aim at insurance companies in so-called bad faith lawsuits.
The suits, which accuse the insurers of improperly rejecting claims brought under existing policies, have drawn a lot of attention.
But another type of suit has been gaining ground with less fanfare.

BY GYPSY WAGON, THROUGH THE JURA
LEAD: The Jura, in the northwest corner of Switzerland, is all wide, rolling valleys, good-sized climbs and descents and primal surroundings of unending green in the summer and gaudy colors in the fall.
The gypsy wagon, called the zigeunerwagen in German, is an old, accepted mode of transport in the Jura, which is horse country.


COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Foundations; Learning to Cope With Myriad Subterranean Surprises
LEAD: BEFORE an office tower goes up, it must go down - far enough for a rock-solid foundation.
Far enough to expose a subterranean stew of manmade trouble - sewers, subway lines, highway tunnels, electrical substations, water mains, gas lines, diverted streams and assorted relics of the urban underground.

A Narrow Escape From Poetry
LEAD: WE all have our demons, our fears of the decline and fall of culture.
Mine sometimes takes the form of regretting that we don't read much poetry anymore.
Where will our flair come from, I sometimes wonder, our hyperbole, our mots justes?
Unless we read poetry, we'll never have our hearts broken by language, which is an indispensable preliminary to a civilized life.

Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
LEAD: I say no - a thousand times no.
He should not gamble and push his luck.
I say this from my experience as a retired fighter.
I have had three retina operations - back in 1933 - all unsuccessful and I have been blind in one eye all these years.
We didn't have laser in those days, but percentages are the same.

With an Introductory Essay by Edward Shils.  354 pp.
New York: The Free Press. $21.95. $ TTHIS book will probably remind a lot of people of ''The God That Failed'' or ''Witness'' by Whittaker Chambers or Norman Podhoretz's ''Breaking Ranks'' or some other entry in the growing library of up-from-leftism confessionals.


Revising Guatemalan History
LEAD: To the Editor:


On Vcation, There Is No Escape From Home
LEAD: SUMMER is proverbially vacation time, but running into someone you know can pop up at any time, wherever you go.
And on a recent trip to St.
Croix our adventure was marked by several such instances.


Italian Razzle-Dazzle at a Casual Cafe
LEAD: IF your idea of dining out is serene surroundings, soft music, thick carpets and quiet conversation, forget Westbury's Caffe Baci.
This casual cafe delivers crowds, excitement and razzle-dazzle.
Caffe Baci is the latest in an unending stream of contemporary Italian cafes inundating Long Island.
The Soho Grill had a short sojourn of six months at this location.


Convention a Conservative Gathering
LEAD: The delegates to the Republican National Convention are a very conservative group, separated by a vast ideological chasm from the Democrats who met in Atlanta, a poll conducted by The New York Times shows.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs.
Edward Adelson of Potomac, Md., have announced that their daughter, Nancy Robin Adelson, and Lewis Richard Clayton, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Stephen Clayton of New York, plan to marry Sept. 25.


Edward Bennett Williams, 68, Influential Trial Lawyer, Dies
LEAD: Edward Bennett Williams, a celebrated trial lawyer and influential Washington insider whose clients included the teamsters leader James R. Hoffa to Senator Joseph McCarthy, died today after a long illness.
He was 68 years old.


TOBACCO AND TRADE POLICY
LEAD: We appreciate Peter Schmeisser's article.
The fact that so-called responsible leaders both in government and industry can ''push'' cigarettes when they know that smoking is ''as addictive as heroin'' and that it significantly increases the risk of illness and death suggests a serious flaw in the character of those leaders.


Soviet Folk Dancers Make Sparks Fly
LEAD: Men dressed in fancy military uniforms spin and dance on the stage to a raging drum tempo, their legs flying in all directions.
As they whirl, they clash their swords together so sharply that sparks actually fly.


BREAKING OUT
LEAD: AMONG THE STILL LIFES, NUDES AND wildly abstract paintings at a recent official art exhibit in Tallinn, capital of the Soviet Republic of Estonia, hung two portraits of Josef Stalin that, even a few years ago, might have earned their artists a one-way ticket to Siberia.
But on a Saturday afternoon last May, they prompted little surprise from the viewers who flowed around me in the gallery.


A Wren Restoration Illuminates the Uses of Light
LEAD: Acknowledged by architectural historians as the jewel of Sir Christopher Wren's smaller churches in the City of London, St.
Stephen Walbrook (1672-79), Wren's own parish church on the street where he lived, was designed as a laboratory of the neo-classical forms that became the model for St.
Paul's Cathedral.

Therapy for Wife Batterers
LEAD: ALL the men in the group are there because they have re- sorted to violence.
In moments of rage, they have beaten their wives or girlfriends.
Some say they ''only'' pulled a woman's hair or shoved her - never intending to break the woman's arm.
Others blame the women for their actions and continue to deny that their behavior is abusive.

Erik Bagger of Copenhagen.

Peter Ohrt, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at Dragsholm Castle in Horve, Denmark.

LEAD: The New York, New Jersey and Connecticut delegations to the Republican National Convention this week in New Orleans will include a greater proportion of public and party officials and be considerably more white and more male than their Democratic counterparts in Atlanta last month.


NEW JERSEY GUIDE
LEAD: GLENN MILLER SOUND  The Glenn Miller Orchestra - authorized by the Miller estate to carry on the big band sound and tradition of the bandleader who was on an aircraft when it disappeared in 1944 - will perform at the Ocean Grove Auditorium Saturday evening.


Kimball May Dive
LEAD: His father, who also is his coach, says that Bruce Kimball, the Olympic silver medalist, will try to qualify for the United States Olympic diving team next week, despite having been involved in a car accident Aug. 1 that killed two teen-agers.


ALL OF AN AGE
LEAD: INFANT, TODDLER OR TEEN, TODAY'S CHILD IS GARBED WITHOUT regard to the classic age categories.
This year's back-to-school clothes make no big deal of when black may become part of a pre-teen wardrobe, or when color should be bright or muted.
All ages may, and do, wear all varieties.


Farmers' Markets Aid Needy Families
LEAD: IN recent years Connecticut's farmers' markets have helped farmers stay in business and shoppers find the freshest produce.
This year some of the markets, including a new one in Bridgeport, are also helping low-income families to eat a little better.

Repairing Mortar Joints
LEAD: EVENTUALLY, almost all mortar joints in brick masonry deteriorate.
Prompt repair is required, because even small cracks and crumbled areas admit moisture, which in time can cause major damage, especially in regions where freezing occurs.

LEAD: THE needles, syringes and other medical waste that have washed up on beaches this summer point to a larger problem confronting every medical institution: how to deal with infectious wastes that are increasingly barred from the hospitals' own incinerators.

THE NATION: A History of Republican Conventions; Despite a Well-Managed Game Plan, Republicans Play Intramural Hardball
LEAD: THE Republicans are back in the South again, which is almost getting to be a habit.
The national party that was founded in 1856 to fight slavery did not hold a Presidential nominating convention in a city of the Old Confederacy until 112 years later, when its delegates gathered in Miami Beach in 1968.

Headliners; Little Princess
LEAD: The line of heirs to the British throne got a little longer last week.
The Duke and Duchess of York had their first child, a 6-pound, 12-ounce girl.
Andrew, the 28-year-old Duke of York and second son of Queen Elizabeth II, was with his wife, Sarah, when the as yet unnamed Princess of York, fifth in line to the throne, was born Monday at 8:18 P.M.


IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: PARTNERS.
By John Martel. (Bantam, $18.95.) There's a joke going around that lawyers are now being used in place of rats in laboratory experiments.
First, because there's an overabundance of them and, second, because there are some things rats just won't do.
If we are to believe John Martel, the trial lawyer who is the author of this first novel, it's no joke.

Headliners; Big Deal
LEAD: Come next winter, Los Angeles may no longer be to hockey what Edmonton, Alberta, is to filmmaking.
The owner of the Los Angeles Kings, which have had only five winning seasons in 21 years, last week made a deal for Wayne Gretzky, who helped make the Edmonton Oilers world champions four times in nine seasons and who is considered by many to be the best player ever to bounce a slap shot off a goalie's teeth.

Fighting Smoking, India to Ban Tobacco Ads
LEAD: The Indian Government announced this week that it planned to ban advertising of cigarettes and other tobacco products as part of a campaign to reduce smoking after recent reports that 800,000 Indians are dying of tobacco-related diseases every year.


30 Killed in Iran Bus Crash
LEAD: Two buses collided in northern Iran, killing 30 people and injuring 50, the Teheran radio reported today.
The radio also said two strong earthquakes jolted the southern city of Bushehr, with no injuries or damage immediately reported.
The two buses collided on the heavily traveled Teheran-Tabriz highway Friday, the report said.

Or at least one part of the company's business: Along with novelties new and old, and occasional up-to-date productions, the company seems to feel a mandate to present bread-and-butter repertory in stagings that are traditional to the point of defiant dowdiness.

LEAD: In reference to Rhoda M. Gilinsky's article, ''Demand Grows for English Classes''  [ July 17 ] , your readers might like to know that the Ossining Public Library has free daytime and evening classes for foreign-born people who want to improve their conversation skills.
This program is one of the services provided by the library's Education/Job Information Center.

The A,BC's of Assisting New Parents
LEAD: IT'S a boy!
Excitement, relief, pride, love, and the wonder of grandparenthood flooded me.
Right behind them swelled a maternal wish to make everything perfect; erase discomfort, eliminate fatigue, brush away tears and guarantee the return of a trim figure.
I didn't want to steal the joy, just banish the pain and inconveniences.

Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
LEAD: Sugar Ray Leonard has proven himself to be a great boxer, and by all accounts a smart boxer.
But the decision to box again is not smart.
Whether Leonard wins or not, he is telling young athletes by his example to set aside health, conditioning, and age considerations for one more grab at the brass ring.

Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
LEAD: At age 32, Sugar Ray Leonard still performs with all the spirit, vigor and gallantry of an Olympic athlete.
In a sport full of human cash registers, whose sole incentive is money, Sugar Ray is a delightful aberration.
When I watch him fight I feel privileged.
ERIC H. MORRISON  New York

Finding Profits in Day Care and Kettle Drums
LEAD: Fifteen years ago, the National Association for Female Executives was started to help women learn such business skills as writing resumes, asking for raises and surviving office politics.
Its members are mostly white-collar workers who earn $32,000 on average.
Now, the group has decided to bet its own money on its members and has set up a venture capital program for entrepreneurial women.

LEAD: For the eighth year in a row, Barry Switzer of Oklahoma has the top winning percentage among major-college football coaches, according to the 31st annual Top Twenty Coaches list.

Switzerland
LEAD: To the Editor: Marcia Lieberman's article about climbing the Breithorn in Zermatt, Switzerland (Travel, July 3), was exciting, but there are a myriad of other walking opportunities in Zermatt.
There are over 280 miles of marked trails and many more unmarked ones.
With cable cars and even an underground lift, one can reach the higher altitudes in a matter of minutes.

The Words Should Matter, Too
LEAD: Why don't composers of contemporary operas want me to know what the singers are singing about?
Perhaps I am merely suspicious by nature, but I have begun to think there must be a secret they are trying to keep from me.
Are the words a code of some sort?
If not, why am I so seldom allowed to know what they are saying up there on that stage?

LEAD: Congress is considering an amendment to the Small Business Administration Act that would allow private organizations to receive financial assistance for projects to benefit small businesses owned and controlled by women.
Enactment of this legislation would be a victory for groups that provide training programs for women entrepreneurs, among them the American Women's Economic Development Corporation.

LEAD: IT has been 10 years since Dennis Kucinich, dubbed Cleveland's ''boy mayor'' when he was elected at age 31, won a recall election by 236 votes.

LEAD: Neil Young has a simple reason for not joining some fellow rock stars in singing for commercials: ''I don't sing for nobody/ Makes me look like a joke,'' he declares in ''This Note's for You.'' He didn't suggest that making commercials ruins songs and betrays fans, or insist that advertising should leave rock alone, or snarl at the commercial tie-ins that infest most American cultural events.

A Little-Known Corner of Switzerland
LEAD: The facade of every house in Guarda, in the Lower Engadine, is boldly painted, sometimes with whimsical creatures, sometimes with elegant geometric designs.
The big white-washed houses are set close together on cobbled streets that occasionally widen into little squares centered on a fountain.
Green slopes rise on every side of the compact village: the main street ends abruptly in fields and meadows, and across the narrow valley stands a wall of rugged mountains.

The Spare, Sure Line Of Matisse
LEAD: People think they know all about Henri Matisse, but most often they don't.
None of the great painter/sculptor/printmakers of the 20th century has more surprises to spring when a major retrospective comes along.
The most recent example of that is the unforgettable survey of his years in Nice that was put on at the National Gallery of Art in Washington by Jack Cowart and Dominique Fourcade in 1986.


WHAT HAYDN TAUGHT MOZART
LEAD: The relationship of Haydn and Mozart has been the subject of much comment, most of it (as far as 19th-century and 20th-century scholarship is concerned) of a slightly surprised nature, because Mozartians have always considered Haydn a second-rate composer.
But contemporary and near-contemporary documents and Mozart's own compositions make it clear that Mozart treated the elder composer and his music with loving attention.

Orientalisms Are Heard in Americans' MusicInfluence the Music of Americans Crystal.
LEAD: ''East is East,and West is West/And never the twain shall meet'' was one of Kipling's less accurate predictions, at least where music is concerned.
From Mozart's time to the present, superficial Orientalisms have lent local color to many a composition.
In the 20th century, and especially since World War II, matters have advanced far beyond this harmless form of musical tourism.

LEAD: WHEN Greeks and others debate the American military presence here, the talk turns generally on a blend of high drama and deep passion, political theater and diplomatic machismo.
The negotiations currently under way on the future of the United States' four main bases and a string of lesser military installations have mixed in another ingredient: a cynical belief that, whatever public figures may say in public, in private the deal is as good as done.

GENERATIONS OF TORMENT
LEAD: Coverage by the press of events in Northern Ireland has produced an unintended, and unwelcome, consequence for British authorities - the awakening of conscience among Americans of Irish descent.
Non-jury trials, detention without cause, mistreatment of prisoners, official cover-ups and sanctioning of police and military brutality are but some of the more recent examples of an atavistic Whitehall meanness toward the Irish people that are provoking anger among normally passive Irish-Americans.


In Amsterdam, 300 Years Of Jewish Life
LEAD: The red brick building crowned with a crystal dome, its shell gable characteristic of Dutch classic style, carries a single clue to its past as a house of worship.
Two lines from the Psalms, inscribed in Hebrew letters, flank the Ionic columns of the main doorway on the Jonas Daniel Meijerplein.

LEAD: Marilyn Goodreau works from noon to midnight taking care of 9 horses, 6 ponies, 5 goats, 2 geese, a rabbit and a rooster on 200 acres of rolling farmland here in southern Maine.

Voters Reject Gambling
LEAD: A referendum today showed continued strong opposition to return gambling to this island where casinos once flourished.
Supporters had hoped that a favorable vote would persuade the Texas Legislature to pass legislation enabling legalized gambling.
Unofficial returns from all 14 precincts showed 7,368 votes, or 59.3 percent, against legalized casino gambling to 5,962 votes in favor.

Saving the Trellis: A Roslyn Landmark
LEAD: The organization which has funded the restoration of the Milliken-Bevin Trellis at the Nassau County Fine Arts Museum in Roslyn (more accurately Roslyn Harbor) is the Roslyn Landmark Society, not the Roslyn Historical Society.
There is not, and so far as we know, never has been, a Roslyn Historical Society, but this by no means indicates a lack of interest in local history in Roslyn.


Exit for Soviet Jews, Conflict for Americans
LEAD: THE Israeli Cabinet's approval of a new emigration policy that would effectively require most Jews who leave the Soviet Union to go to Israel has created a dilemma for many American Jews, who want to help Israel but who also say that Soviet Jews should be able to choose where they want to live.


Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
LEAD: It isn't a question of Leonard boxing again that's at issue here.
It's about money.
Leonard is a box-office gold mine, the greatest entertainer the sport of boxing has seen.
In the end, I will be surprised to see Donny Lalonde come away with a victory.
Not because of Ray's efforts inside the ring, but because of his importance outside of the ring.

TUNNEL VISION
LEAD: To the Editor: Readers who plan to do any driving in Italy and who speak little or no Italian can save themselves some grief by memorizing the phrases that appear at tunnel entrances along the Autostrade.
Those with enough Italian will recognize immediately that the signs instruct drivers to turn on their headlights in the many tunnels through which the Autostrade run.

The Cost of Money Is Definitely Up
LEAD: The cost of money rose decisively, as the Federal Reserve voted unanimously to raise the discount rate to 6 1/2 percent from 6 percent, and the nation's leading banks raised their prime lending rate to 10 percent, from 9 1/2 percent.
The discount rate, which is what the Fed charges on its loans to banks, is now at its highest level since July 1986.


Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
LEAD: Sugar Ray is still physically able to fight in the professional ranks - albeit a weight class higher than he's used to.
He still has hand speed, though some may contend his legs are suspect.
He still loves to box.
So let him box.
Pay him whatever the market will bear.
BOB WATERS  Whiting, N.J.

Who Risks . . .
Who Gains . . .
Who Loses . . .
By Martin Mayer. (Norton, $18.95.) The tremors that shook world financial markets last October have been closely scrutinized, yet thus far the reams of reports have done little to reassure anxious investors.
Nor have they so altered the rules of the game that professionals on Wall Street would be willing to wager against the possibility of another blowout.

LEAD: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months.
When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain which we cannot seem to remove.
We tried scouring powder, then tried rubbing with fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years).

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: THE ADVENTURES OF TELEMACHUS.
By Louis Aragon.
Translated by Renee Riese Hubert and Judd D. Hubert. (University of Nebraska, $18.95.) Published in 1922, Louis Aragon's novel ''The Adventures of Telemachus'' occupies a pivotal position in which Dadaism and Surrealism overlap.
A subversive Dadaist impulse certainly figured in Aragon's choice of Francois Fenelon's 17th-century prose epic ''Aventures de Telemaque'' for a parodic model, since Fenelon's earnestly moralistic retelling of Homer and Virgil provided a target rich in literary reference and high-mindedness.

South Africa Lifts Fuel Price
LEAD: South Africa's Government announced major steps Friday to shore up the economy, including a 15 percent increase in fuel prices and higher surcharges on luxury imports.


Rival Publishers Gain by Teamwork on Books
LEAD: Competition for big books and well-known authors is intense.
But houses that are at each other's throats for acquisitions sometimes team up to publish, usually one in hardcover and the other in paperback.

Students in Burma Appeal For New Round of Protests
LEAD: Students who led five days of demonstrations in Burma last week called today for more protests, and there was a growing sense that the calm in the capital was a temporary one.


Toyon-Wintu Center Journal; Rooted to Land in a Sea of Troubles
LEAD: When outsiders visit this tiny Indian settlement 220 miles northeast of San Francisco, they see windowless houses with no running water or electricity.
They see yards full of weeds and rubbish.
They see dogs and chickens sharing the potholed streets with rusting, seemingly abandoned cars.


The Talk Of Waverly Street; In Divided Yonkers, a Block Lives With Its Differences
LEAD: Anthony Cancellaro, the son of Italian immigrants, grew up at 154 Waverly Street.
When he got married, he moved six houses up the block into his wife's family's house, at 128 Waverly Street.
In his lifetime he has seen the Vivianos's house, two doors away, turned into a black Baptist church, the Italian grocery turned into a bodega, the apartments above the grocery become housing for single mothers on welfare.


Karen Isenstein Married
LEAD: Karen Joy Isenstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Melvin Isenstein of Lincolnwood, Ill., was married yesterday to James B. Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Irwin Cohen of Hartsdale, N.Y.
Rabbi Michael Siegel performed the ceremony at the Palmer House in Chicago.
The bride, a graduate of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, teaches first grade at the Anshe Emmet School in Chicago.


Mets Perk Up and Win Two From Expos
LEAD: The Mets acknowledge that when their noses haven't been too far in the air, their heads have been somewhere in the clouds.
As a result, only rarely over the last couple of months have they had their minds on the game in front of them.

Edward Bennett Williams, Trial Lawyer, Dead at 68
LEAD: Edward Bennett Williams, a celebrated trial lawyer and influential Washington insider whose clients ranged from the teamsters' leader James R. Hoffa to Senator Joseph McCarthy, died Saturday after a long illness.
He was 68 years old.


Heat Fells Carriage Horse
LEAD: Police officers helping a carriage horse after it collapsed from heat exhaustion at Second Avenue and 62d Street.
City regulations prohibit using the horses when temperatures exceed 90 degrees, but the temperature had hit 95 degrees at that hour.
After being hosed down and given medication, the recovering horse was taken away in a police Mounted Unit trailer.


Play Better Tennis In Mixed Company
LEAD: TENNIS is one of the few sports in which men and women compete against each other.
A mixed-doubles match can be a sociable, energetic outing, or it can turn into a battle of the sexes, often on the same side of the net.

A Spacious Village Resists Making Room for a Valley of Ashes
LEAD: This genteel Dutchess County village, so protective of its open space that most of the area has 10-acre zoning, now may fall victim to its own farsightedness.
Even the town's dump has so much extra space around it that the county is eyeing it as a site for a huge landfill for all the ash from the county's new incinerator.

A Summer Session for Kindergartners
LEAD: Alan Gordon reading to his class last week at Public School 192 in Harlem.
The youngsters were among more than 9,000 students enrolled in the Board of Education's first summer kindergarten session.
Page B3. (The New York Times/Neal Boenzi)


Bridge
LEAD: Few octogenarians win major bridge titles, but one of them did at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, which ended Aug. 7 in Salt Lake City.
Among the winners of the Senior Knockout, a three-day regional event that attracted an entry of 49 teams, was Chester Hirsch, a retired New York businessman, 82 years old, who now lives in Palm Springs,


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.

Doctors Find No Malignancy In Lung Biopsy on Mandela
LEAD: The condition of Nelson R. Mandela, the imprisoned South African nationalist leader, has improved since he was admitted to the hospital for a lung ailment, a physician reported today.

LEAD: The inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services has found that 6.6 percent of a sample of Medicare patients received substandard hospital care, an amount significantly higher than local doctor groups had found earlier.

LEAD: Although it never achieves full freeze, there are chilling moments in ''Out of Time,'' a play set in the London blitz.
It is today's episode of ''Four on 13,'' the Channel 13 series that brings shows from Britain's Channel Four to New York screens.
It will be broadcast at 11:30 P.M.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Metropolitan Sunday Will Handle Puck Sales
LEAD: Metropolitan Sunday Newspapers Inc., which sells the national advertising space in both the comics sections and magazine supplements of 101 Sunday newspapers, is also going to take over the selling for Hearst's Puck, The Comic Weekly, which has been the national sales rep for Sunday comics in 171 newspapers, generally in smaller markets.

Police Horse, Spooked by M-80, Killed After Fall
LEAD: A police horse, frightened by exploding firecrackers at Coney Island early yesterday, stumbled and fell, losing his rider, and then fell again galloping back to his stable, injuring himself so badly he had to be killed, the police said.

If Heat Weren't Enough, Mosquitoes Are Worse, Too
LEAD: If you're parading your cool summer whites in Manhattan, you might have a fighting chance.
But if you're sweating in dark clothes on Staten Island or in New Jersey, you may as well face facts - the mosquitoes are going to find you.

It is the second such scandal in London within a week.

Tax Watch; Need for Changes In Withholding
LEAD: MOST people thought that filling out new W4 forms, which employers use to determine how much tax to withhold from workers' paychecks, was last year's headache.
Legally, it was, because the Government required every employed person to fill out a new W4 as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
But it's time to take out the calculators again.


Question Box

Did it exceed the amount of r.b.i.
Babe Ruth had from his 60 homers in 1927?


Town House Made A Landmark Again
LEAD: Landmark status has again been given to a Manhattan town house known as the ''Castle,'' at West End Avenue and 85th Street, after a recent decision by a state judge which overturned an earlier designation.

Pronouncing a Dry Spell

One syllable.

Drought?

Sunday in Sweden: Vikings Beat Bears

Chubb would make a tidy profit from a clever product, and the farmers would be protected against a lack of rainfall.

Review/Music; A Country Blues Mood
LEAD: About halfway through his relaxed set at Tramps on Friday night, the veteran bluesman Louis Myers settled down.
Where his guitar lines had been fragmented, choppy and out of control, they became long and fluid.
His singing, permeated with a country blues loneliness, became more extreme, more evocative.

LEAD: Michael Krasnopolsky, a double bass virtuoso who studied with Alexander Glazunov and played in the NBC Symphony under Arturo Toscanini, died in Seattle last Monday.
He was 94 years old.

Panel Says Care Is Still Lacking For Mentally Ill
LEAD: Patients released from psychiatric centers in the New York area often find that transitional care is seriously lacking and that the mental health system loses track of them, a report released yesterday by a state monitoring group said.


Iran Says Britain Must Also Act on Hostages
LEAD: A Government-run newspaper said in an editorial today that Iran would work to free British hostages held in Lebanon, but it also made it clear that the effort was linked with attempts to find Iranians believed held in Lebanon.

Olympic Basketball; U.S. Cuts Are Still Posing Problem
LEAD: The exhibition games were expected to clear the air, providing John Thompson with some needed insight on who should stay and who should be cut from the Olympic basketball team.
Instead, the more Thompson watches, the more he changes his mind, back and forth and back again, making him wonder whether anything will ever be clear to him.


Clean Air, Still Beyond Reach
LEAD: Eighteen years after passage of the Clean Air Act, 100 million Americans still breathe unhealthy, ozone-laden air, and acid rain continues to kill lakes and burn forests throughout the United States and Canada.
Air pollution has been reduced, but not by enough.
The White House, Congress and polluters resist the hard choices necessary for further protection of public health and the environment.


A Guide to Water-Skiing Fundamentals
LEAD: SURVEYS of sports participation show that today there are nearly 11 million water-skiers in the United States.
The American Water Ski Association reports that there are more than 400 water-ski clubs and that nearly 2 million new participants are attracted to this sport each year.
You can be one of them.


Ferraro's Son Spends Term in Luxury Abode
LEAD: John Zaccaro Jr., son of the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, is spending his four-month prison term for selling cocaine in a $1,500-a-month luxury apartment in Vermont with maid service, cable television and privileges at the Y.M.C.A. next door.

U S Sprint Complaints
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission is satisfied with the U S Sprint Communications Company's efforts to resolve billing complaints from its long-distance telephone customers, an F.C.C. official said Friday.
The F.C.C. had sent U S Sprint a letter last month warning the phone company it faced sanctions unless it did a better job responding to billing complaints.


Angry Inmates Set Jail Afire
LEAD: Prisoners angry about heat and crowded conditions set fire to a county jail today, destroying one wing, and the police used tear gas to subdue two inmates who tried to escape in the confusion.
At least eight people were injured in the three-hour uprising at the Essex County Jail and House of Correction, a pre-Civil War building, including five inmates and one firefighter who were treated for smoke inhalation and cuts.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
China's Politburo will meet today in an effort to settle differences over the Government's decision to remove some controls on prices of goods and services.
The decision has caused public discontent and the highest inflation since the Communist takeover in 1949.
The Wen Wei Po newspaper in Hong Kong said that officials are divided on how much prices should be allowed to fluctuate as they seek their market levels.

Ocean Glow
LEAD: Someday somebody will come up with a scientific explanation for the curious glow that a three-man submarine discovered recently one mile deep in the Pacific Ocean.
Its immediate source is a jet of hot water emerging from some rock chimneys on the ocean floor.
The cause of its strange flicker is unknown.

LEAD: For the first time in his 17 years as president of the New York Road Runners Club, Fred Lebow was booed by runners at the start of a race.
The runners were responding to his decision to change a road race in Central Park yesterday into a ''fun run,'' with no official clock, because of the extreme temperature and humidity.

The Needle Question
LEAD: It's a tormenting choice.
Does giving drug addicts free, clean needles promote drug abuse?
Does failing to give them clean needles promote the spread of AIDS?
No American city has yet implemented such a needle program.
But New York officials now have finally approved an experiment involving 200 addicts that could begin this fall and help resolve the dilemma.

LEAD: Americans had more babies in 1987 than in any year in nearly a quarter of a century and had the lowest marriage and divorce rates in more than a decade, the Government reported today.


Barry Bingham Sr. Is Dead at 82; Louisville Newspapers' Publisher
LEAD: Barry Bingham Sr., whose newspapers in Louisville, Ky., were leading liberal voices in the South, for decades, died yesterday at his Louisville home.
He was 82 years old and had been undergoing treatment for cancer.

LEAD: Max A. Geller, an advertising executive for more than half a century who entered several other businesses when called upon to rescue companies in trouble, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y.
He was 89 years old.

LEAD: What's to be done about nearly one million West Bank Arabs who face a loss of basic services now that Jordan has curtailed its role there?
There's bound to be hardship since Israel isn't likely to let the Palestine Liberation Organization or the United Nations pay civil service salaries.
But the amount needed is modest.

On Horse Racing; Java Gold's Trainer Gets Timely Award
LEAD: A year ago, Paul Mellon, Mack Miller and Java Gold were the toast of New York racing, and they were toasted again tonight.
At the New York Turf Writers' annual awards banquet, Mellon was honored as the outstanding breeder, Miller received the Red Smith ''Good Guy'' award for both his training and personal popularity and Java Gold was the first winner of the New York Horse of the


New Rehabilitation Project Begins in the Bronx
LEAD: Mayor Koch officiating during inauguration ceremony yesterday for a rehabilitation project that will provide 900 apartments for homeless and low- and middle-income families.
The $70 million project will provide new apartments in 14 vacant city-owned buildings and three vacant lots along Walton and Townsend Avenues in the Bronx.


Rig Count Falls by 5
LEAD: The number of working domestic oil and gas rigs fell by five this week, to 940, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
Last week the rig count jumped by 51, to 945.
A year ago this week, the count was 998, the company said.
Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil as of Friday, not the number of rigs producing oil.

Science Watch; Infants' Crying
LEAD: When infants less than three months old cry too much, they are often treated on the assumption that they are suffering gastrointestinal pain caused by an allergy to milk protein.
But Dr.
Bruce Taubman of The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, found that direct parental attention to a baby's crying was twice as effective in stopping the tears as eliminating milk from the baby's diet.


Karl Nyren, Editor, 66
LEAD: Karl Nyren, a retired senior editor of Library Journal, a weekly publication for librarians, died of intestinal cancer Saturday at Castle Point Hospital in Beacon, N.Y.
He was 66 years old and lived in Beacon.


Appliances Still Work in Electricity Cuts
LEAD: The 8 percent voltage reduction to Consolidated Edison customers on the Upper East Side of Manhattan yesterday is unlikely to seriously affect such motor-driven appliances as refrigerators, freezers and air-conditioners, a spokeswoman for the utility said.

Steel Output Falls 3.6%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.822 million tons in the week that ended on Saturday, a decrease of 3.6 percent from the previous week's 1.890 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
Production totaled 85.4 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 88.6 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK has been named to handle advertising for three new buildings owned by Solomon Equities, a Manhattan real estate developer.
The budget, exclusively for print ads, is $1.5 million.
For starters, a full-page ad for a building in the works at Broadway and 48th Street appears in The New York Times today.


Bond International Stake Is Acquired
LEAD: FAI Securities Ltd., a Hong Kong-based investment firm, said it had purchased a 7.1 percent stake in Bond International Gold Inc. for $48.4 million.
Bond International Gold is the new mining company formed by the Australian investor Alan Bond.

Topics of The Times; Legal Protectionism
LEAD: For years New York, the capital of lawyers, graciously welcomed attorneys from other states.
It admitted them to the bar without requiring an exam as long as they had been practicing for five years elsewhere.
No more.
A new state law amounts to destructive protectionism.

Bridge
LEAD: The third Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest, played June 3, had one surprising result in a quite different field: The wall poster for the event, which showed playing cards converging on a globe, won the Cannes Sponcom Grand Prix Design award.

LEAD: A woman still new to New York City recently put a damaged rocking chair on the curb.

Louis-based brokerage house founded in 1871, has tapped Wyse Advertising, Cleveland, after a 20-agency review.
The budget is around $6 million, mostly for consumer campaigns.

Louis, and Martin Williams, Minneapolis.

Car Insurance Premiums Average $1,000 in Jersey
LEAD: New Jersey, with more people and more automobiles to the square mile than any other state, has been trying since 1973 to curb a steady rise in automobile insurance premiums.
The average cost of a policy now exceeds $1,000, after a rate increase and two surcharges totaling about $200 this year.

In Wake of Hurricane, Research Surges at Kew
LEAD: The hurricane that ripped across southern England last October devastated the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew, the 300-acre repository of plants and trees from throughout the world.
Nearly 1,000 trees, almost 10 percent of the collection, were severely battered or destroyed.

LEAD: Rejecting the advice of Attorney General Robert Abrams, a special New York State grand jury has voted to subpoena Tawana Brawley, investigative officials said yesterday.

Mexico Will Extend Freeze On Wages, Prices and Rate
LEAD: In its first major economic action since last month's tumultuous presidential election, the Mexican Government announced late Sunday night that a freeze on prices, wages and the exchange rate would be extended until Nov. 30.


Lintas Wins Hotels
LEAD: Lintas: New York has won the Inter-Continental Hotels account over D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles, New York, after a two-month review.
The budget is in the $10 million range.
Initially in the running were a half-dozen agencies, including the incumbent, Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK.
Inter-Continental, based in Montvale, N.J., and a unit of London-based Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., runs more than 100 hotels worldwide, with a dozen in the United States.

Artificial Brain Again Seen As a Guide To the Mind
LEAD: FOR most of the last two decades, a quixotic science called neural network theory has been suffering through a dark age.
All but a handful of enthusiasts had given up their dream of making intelligent computers by using networks of artificial neurons to electronically mimick the brain's circuitry.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  HORSE RACING  Glowing Honor Scores Upset: Glowing Honor, making her first stakes appearance and facing older fillies, led almost all the way to score a 2 1/2-length upset victory in the $122,800 Diana Handicap yesterday at Saratoga Race Track.
The daughter of Seattle Slew and Glowing Tribute, owned by Paul Melln's Rokeby Stable and trained by Mack Miller, was keeping alive a family tradition.


Vital Town Is Retaken, Afghan Says
LEAD: A day after the Soviet military commander in Afghanistan announced that anti-Government guerrillas had captured a major town, the Afghan President, Najibullah, announced today that the town, Kunduz, had been recaptured by the Afghan Army.


Ad Shop Loses Health Account
LEAD: Minnesota health officials have canceled a $1.7 million contract with an advertising agency hired to produce anti-smoking commercials because the agency merged with one that has a $35 million tobacco account.


Explosion in the Desert
LEAD: Tomorrow in the Nevada desert, America will explode a nuclear device.
On site, recording the explosion, will be a team of Soviet scientists and engineers.
An unprecedented event, to be sure, but just another example of how the Administration's strategy in pursuing arms control has been the correct one.


IGX Is Acquired For $150 Million
LEAD: The A. B. Dick Company said it had bought the privately held IGX Corporation for about $150 million.
A B Dick, the Chicago-based subsidiary of the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain, makes office equipment, including offset duplicating machines and mimeograph and microfiche products.
IGX, based in Waltham, Mass., was formed in the 1986 leveraged buyout of the Itek Graphix Corporation.


Fast by Chavez Over Pesticides Passes 29th Day
LEAD: Cesar Chavez, the 61-year-old president of the United Farm Workers of America, lies on a small bed in a room kept dark against the relentless afternoon sun here, gradually weakening as he continues his third and longest fast.

AEL Industries, Lansdale, Pa., an electronic equipment manufacturer, said it had received a $4.3 million Navy contract.

Careers; Training Financial Planners
LEAD: LAST week a financial planner in Miami who had invested money for a group of doctors disappeared, leaving a note of apology and $25 million missing.
A recent 30-state study by the North American Securities Administrators Association found that investors had lost $400 million in the last two years because of fraud by people calling themselves financial planners.


Executives Offer Pleas In Health-Care Fraud
LEAD: Two executives of a large health-care company pleaded guilty today in what state prosecutors called the largest Medicaid fraud case ever uncovered in the nation's home health-care industry.


Hong Kong Rates Rise
LEAD: The prime lending rate at Hong Kong's two leading banks, the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank and the Standard Chartered Bank, went up a half-point today, to 9 1/2 percent.
The increases had been expected after the Federal Reserve in Washington lifted its discount rate last week.


Contradictory Tests
LEAD: A second drug test on Miguel Lora, the World Boxing Council bantamweight champion from Baranquilla, Colombia, has revealed that no amphetamines were in his system.
On Aug. 4, three days after Lora successfully defended his championship against Albert Davila of Pomona, Calif., at the Forum in nearby Inglewood, a test revealed amphetamines and methamphetamines in his system.

Looking for Answers to Medical-Waste Problem
LEAD: To the Editor:


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  U.S. factories, mines and utilities raised output 0.8 percent in July.
It was the biggest monthly increase this year and broader based than had been expected.
As the latest evidence of a booming economy, it raised the possibility the Government will have to take steps to raise interest rates again to contain inflation.


Congress's Real Drug Bust
LEAD: With much bipartisan posturing, the House of Representatives has passed a ''tough'' anti-drug bill that will have about as much effect on the drug traffic - to borrow a phrase from the late Everett Dirksen - as a ''snowflake on the bosom of the Potomac.''


Acquisition By Itel Unit
LEAD: Anxiter Brothers Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Itel Corporation, said it had agreed to acquire Cable TV Industries for $45.25 a share in cash.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. How do the glowing plastic necklaces sold at fairs and carnivals work?
A.The necklaces and other temporary chemical lights work by imitating the chemical reaction called bioluminescence that allows fireflies to light up, according to Dr.
Bruce H. Baretz, a chemist.

By Design; Doubling Up
LEAD: There's nothing like getting two things - or more - for the price of one.
A good many of the newest and most stylish fall suits, for example, have a jacket made of one color or fabric, while the skirt or pants are cut from another fabric in a contrasting shade.

35 Aliens Found In Boxcar
LEAD: Thirty-five Salvadorans spent five hours Sunday inside a sweltering boxcar with almost no ventilation, the authorities said.
The Salvadorans had been locked inside since they boarded the Houston-bound freight at Brownsville at 5 A.M.
Officials said the illegal aliens could have suffered the same fate as 18 aliens found dead last summer inside a locked boxcar near the west Texas town of Sierra


LEBANESE SHIITES RESUME WARFARE
LEAD: Violence between rival Shiite Moslem factions has surged in the last few days as the nation's Shiites began a 10-day religious celebration.

Murat Khan Journal; A Place Where the Broken People Are Mended
LEAD: ''Bomb shrapnel had almost torn his shoulder off,'' Dr.
Csaba Hethalmi recalled matter of factly about a young Afghan guerrilla he had treated the month before. ''His shoulder blade was broken in a couple of pieces.
We did several operations.
He was with us for three weeks and then he went straight back to fight.

For Fall, Eastern Air Plans Low Florida-Northeast Fare
LEAD: Eastern Airlines, hit by a decline in passengers and heavy losses, said today that it would offer a $69 one-way fare between Florida and 16 Northeast cities this fall in an effort to build traffic after the summer travel season ends.
Competitors quickly followed suit.

LEAD: Gov.

LEAD: Edmonton players should let their emotions on the trade of Wayne Gretzky die down before they decide what, if anything, they will do about it, Coach Glen Sather said yesterday. Scientists Dream Up Bold Remedies for Ailing Atmosphere
LEAD: AS scientists and public officials urge painful, expensive measures to prevent climate change -reducing energy use, developing alternative sources of power, curbing production of destructive pollutants - a breed of visionaries is dreaming of more direct, if seemingly fantastic, countermeasures.


When Designers Test the Waters
LEAD: The new fashions introduced in New York this month range from swimsuits to ball gowns.
They are all labeled resort, but the tag can be misleading.
These are the clothes that will be in the stores in November, after fall styles have presumably been picked over and put on sale; they are not limited to casual clothes for a season in the southern sun.


Random House Buys Crown
LEAD: In a transaction that caught the industry by surprise, Random House Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Crown Publishing Group, one of the last family-owned major publishing houses in the United States.


Pepsico Offering $150 Million Notes
LEAD: Pepsico Inc. offered $150 million of five-year notes yesterday through a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation.

New York Area Remains Costly
LEAD: Prices of single-family homes in New York and the surrounding area are among the highest in the country but are increasing at slower rates than those in Southern California.


Polaroid Rises On Bid Rumor
LEAD: Shares in the Polaroid Corporation rose 37.5 cents, to $42.50, today amid speculation that Roy E. Disney's Shamrock Holdings Inc. might make a hostile tender offer.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I'm against the Democratic platform because it didn't say anything.
I'm against the Republican platform because it says too much.''  - Senator Lowell Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut.  [ A22:4. ]

Deady Qualifies
LEAD: When Mark Deady, a 20-year-old senior at Indiana University, finished third in the men's 1,500-meter race to qualify for the United States Olympic team last month, he had little time to celebrate.
His time, 3 minutes 41.31 seconds, was still 2.41 seconds off the Olympic qualifying standard of 3:38.50.


Seeking Job-Seekers
LEAD: The Federal Government is sponsoring a job fair to recruit nurses, engineers, computer scientists and microbiologists.


Two Are Cut
LEAD: Sean Elliott, Arizona's all-America forward, and the Stanford forward Todd Lichti were cut from the United States men's Olympic basketball team yesterday.
The cuts reduced the roster to 14 players.
The team must be cut to 12 players by Sept. 2.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL  LOS ANGELES (NL) - Recalled Ken Howell, pitcher, from Albuquerque of Pacific Coast League.
MILWAUKEE (AL) - Activated Bill Schroeder, catcher, from the 15-day disabled list.
Placed Paul Mirabella, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list.
BASKETBALL  DETROIT (NBA) - Agreed to terms with James Edwards, center, on a multiyear contract.


Baseball; Viola Beats Tigers for No. 19
LEAD: Frank Viola became the first 19-game winner in the major leagues and John Moses went 4 for 4 with a game-winning home run in the seventh inning tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat the Detroit Tigers, 2-1.

Dukakis Asserts That His 'L Word' Is 'Leadership'
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis, responding to criticism by President Reagan and hoping to block further attacks from the Republican National Convention, took his campaign into the heart of his home state today and declared that the ''L word'' of his candidacy was not ''liberal'' but ''leadership.''

Cuomo Announces Education Aid Panel
LEAD: Fulfilling an agreement made in April, when a dispute over education aid held up passage of the state budget, Governor Cuomo announced yesterday the appointment of an 11-member commission to study the distribution of state aid to local school districts.


W.H.O. Fights Disease With Dollar Magic
LEAD: To the Editor:


Power Shut Off at 13 Manhattan Towers
LEAD: The miseries of a torrid summer reached a nadir for thousands of New Yorkers yesterday as the Consolidated Edison Company cut off power to as many as 13 of the largest apartment buildings on the Upper East Side to prevent a wider blackout.


Prosecutors' Duel
LEAD: Officials of the Justice Department and Republican strategists are deploring an apparent feud between the United States Attorney in Boston and his predecessor.


Jersey Man Is Fatally Shot at a Queens Synagogue
LEAD: A 49-year-old New Jersey man was shot to death at a Queens synagogue early yesterday, apparently during a robbery attempt after a ''Las Vegas Night'' at the synagogue, the police said.


The Messenger Business: Far More Than Bikes Now
LEAD: The messenger business - home base for thousands of traffic-weaving bicyclists with knapsacks on their backs - is taking on bigger challenges.


Error in Budget Estimates Could Reduce Spending
LEAD: Reagan Administration budget experts have made an error in calculation that cannot be rectified under current law and is preventing Congress from approving as much as $1.2 billion in spending programs for the 1989 fiscal year.

Plunkett Released
LEAD: The Los Angeles Raiders released the quarterback Jim Plunkett yesterday, ending a comeback attempt by the 40-year-old former Heisman Trophy winner, who was the oldest active player in the National Football League.
Asked if he planned to try to catch on with another team, Plunkett laughed. ''I don't think there's too much demand for 40-year-old quarterbacks,'' he said.

S.E.C. Action On Short Sales
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously approved a rule today that would prohibit investors from knowingly covering their short sales of a stock with securities bought in a secondary offering.


Learning, Then Talking
LEAD: NETTALK, an artificial neural network that can be trained to pronounce English words, consists of about 300 neurons arranged in three layers - an input layer, which reads the words, an output layer, which generates speech sounds, or phonemes, and a middle, ''hidden layer,'' which mediates between the other two.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Media Business page yesterday about the Newspaper Guild misidentified Paul Steiger.
He is the deputy managing editor of The Wall Street Journal; the managing editor is Norman Pearlstine.

GEORGE MICHAEL CONCERT
LEAD: Behind his stubble, his black leather jacket, his dangling-crucifix earring and his pirate-style head scarf, George Michael - or the character he plays in his songs - is the kind of guy most teen-age girls could bring home to meet the folks.
In a way, many of them have; his album ''Faith'' has sold nearly five million copies, and screams and shrieks greeted almost every move when he performed Sunday at Madison Square Garden, where he opened a sold-out three-night stand.

John Howard Sweet, A Former Executive Of Magazine, 81
LEAD: John Howard Sweet, chairman emeritus of U.S.
News &amp; World Report and a publishing executive for more than five decades, died Sunday of a heart attack at the Carriage Hill nursing home in Bethesda, Md.
He was 81 years old and lived in Washington.

Review/Architecture; Walk-Through Models In Frank Gehry Show
LEAD: When ''The Architecture of Frank Gehry'' opened at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis in the fall of 1986, it seemed to make the definitive statement on the work of this brilliant, iconoclastic architect, increasingly one of the critical figures in contemporary American architecture.
The one regret was that New Yorkers would not get to see this important and wonderfully spirited exhibition.

BUSH CHOOSES SENATOR QUAYLE OF INDIANA, A 41-YEAR-OLD CONSERVATIVE, FOR NO. 2 SPOT
LEAD: Vice President Bush today chose Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, a wealthy, 41-year-old conservative with scant national reputation, as his running mate on the 1988 Republican ticket.


British Airways
LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. said it had placed a $250 million order with the Boeing Company for two additional long-range Boeing 747-400 aircraft.
The jets, which will be powered by Rolls-Royce engines, will be delivered to British Airways in January and April 1990.
The airline, which has now ordered 19 of the 747-400's, said that if the 12 additional options it holds are exercised, its total investment in the 400 jet series would amount to $4.5 billion.

Gordon Scherer, 81; Served in the House And United Nations
LEAD: Gordon H. Scherer, a former member of Congress who became the ranking Republican on the House Committee on Un-American Activities in the 1950's and who later served on the executive board of Unesco, died Saturday at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati after suffering a heart attack.
He was 81 years old.

Excerpts From Platform: 'For Our Children and Our Future'
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the Republican platform, ''An American Vision: For Our Children and Our Future,'' approved today at the Republican National Convention: Preamble An election is about the future, about change.
But it is also about the values we will carry with us as we journey into tomorrow and about continuity with the best from our past.


Hechinger to Buy Bradlees Leases
LEAD: The Hechinger Company, which operates retail home centers, said it had agreed to buy the leases of 47 Bradlees discount stores from the Stop and Shop Companies for about $118 million.
The stores involved are in the Philadelphia-Baltimore-Washington corridor, Hechinger said, and no inventory, fixtures or other Bradlees assets are involved in the transaction.


BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


Malaysia Check Curb
LEAD: Beginning today, anyone who in one year writes three checks that bounce will not be allowed to have a bank account for six months.
Jaafar Hussein, the governor of Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, said that too many people had been issuing bad checks.
Currently, anyone issuing bad checks is fined 100 ringgits, about $37, a check.


Sticks to the Teeth, Not to the Ribs
LEAD: If it's slithery, bear-shaped and translucent, candy manufacturers are betting children will love it.


A Faster Way To Make Chips
LEAD: Making silicon chips is a time-consuming and complex process that can require days and an entire factory floor.
LASA Industries of San Jose, Calif., has developed a method that manufactures a semiconductor chip in half an hour or less using a machine the size of a walk-in closet.

Review/Film; 'The Wash,' an Exploring of Ties That Break and of Ties That Bind
LEAD: A Japanese-American woman in her 60's, so average and middle-class she might have stepped out of a detergent commercial, glares at her stubborn, self-absorbed husband.
With a controlled intensity that carries the weight of 40 years, she asks, ''Why don't you want me anymore?'' That emotionally honest moment at the center of ''The Wash'' is one of many powerful scenes that shape this story of an older couple's painful separation and funny new romances.

LEAD: This is about a fire that never happened, in a way.
It did not make big headlines in yesterday's newspapers.

The fire occurred in a modest Brooklyn dwelling.
No one was killed.
And what the firefighters suffered passed officially as ''minor injuries.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Saturday, with an article about marketing opportunities in the Middle East, misstated the 1986 current account balances of Iran and Iraq.
The correct figures are minus $1.7 billion and minus $3.8 billion.


In Middle of the Action and Missing It
LEAD: One of the worst places in America to follow the Republican National Convention, it turns out, is at the Republican National Convention.
It's so hard to hear in the cavernous Louisiana Superdome that some delegates have gone to their hotel rooms to find out what is happening by watching television.

EATING WELL
LEAD: WITHIN the last decade, the shelves in health-food stores have come to look more like the shelves in supermarkets with their packaged mixes, frozen dinners and frosted cakes.
At the same time, supermarkets have been filling their shelves with products labeled ''natural,'' ''no preservatives'' or ''low salt.


Tawana Brawley and the Law
LEAD: The grand jurors in the Tawana Brawley case can hardly be blamed for feeling frustrated.
For months Miss Brawley, alleging victimization, has allowed her family and their advisers to toy with the jurors, the legal process and the truth.
But the grand jury's decision to subpoena the Dutchess County teen-ager can only aggravate the frustration and further degrade the legal process.


51 Demonstrators Held In Rangoon Are Freed
LEAD: The authorities today released 51 people who were arrested during anti-Government demonstrations in Burma's capital, Rangoon, last week, the state-run Rangoon radio said.


O.E.C.D. Warns Britain On Consumer Spending
LEAD: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned Britain today that its inflation rate could grow too high unless it reined in its robust consumer spending.


For Those With AIDS, Numbers Don't Count
LEAD: To the Editor:


Ex-Farm Town Fights to Harness Growth
LEAD: Until June, Ginny Shanahan and Dick Creter were strangers.
Both had moved with their families into new housing developments here three years ago, at the start of this rural town's population boom, but they had little else in common.
Mr.
Creter ran a family concrete business.
Mrs.
Shanahan, a teacher and artisan, spent her time raising her three young children, making yarn and weaving.

Scarfs, Natty and Cool
LEAD: ALL it takes is a little dexterity and some motivation - hot, sticky weather, for example, which makes for hot, sticky hair.
People with even slightly longish hair are finding that scarfs 12 or 17 inches square pull it all together in style.
The scarfs, in solids, tiny polka dots or paisley, are wrapped around ponytails, braids and chignons.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration has asked Australia and New Zealand to cut back on meat exports to the United States, an Australian diplomat said today.


Banks Shut In Poor Areas Stir Worries
LEAD: At a time when New York City banks are under intense pressure to cut costs and streamline their operations, experts say a spate of bank branch closings may be hurting small businesses and undermining the economic development of poor neighborhoods.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors are increasing the pressure on some of the targets in the Pentagon fraud and bribery investigation, warning them that time is running out to make deals to cooperate with investigators in return for immunity from prosecution.


Learning Experience: 350 Cases of Wine
LEAD: AT least one grape-decorated T-shirt at the 12th annual conference of the Society of Wine Educators read, ''Life is a cabernet, my friend.'' That turned out to be a rather circumscribed view.
Life at the society's meeting was also a chardonnay, a malbec, a merlot, a Muller-Thurgau, a pinot noir, a sauvignon blanc, a silvaner, a zinfandel and more.


Olympic Diving; Despite Charges, Kimball Decides He'll Compete
LEAD: Bruce Kimball, the diver facing alcohol-related manslaughter charges for his involvement in a fatal car accident two weeks ago, said today in a quivering voice that he intended to compete in the United States Olympic trials this week.


SOVIETS QUESTION A BALTIC PROTOCOL
LEAD: In a rebuff to people in the Baltic republics, Soviet officials insisted today that there is no conclusive evidence that Stalin and Hitler secretly agreed to Soviet annexation of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

LEAD: Elliott Graham, a publicist at E. P. Dutton, the publisher, died of colon cancer Saturday at Yonkers General Hospital.
He was 62 years old and lived in Yonkers.

LEAD: The United States Attorney's Office is expected to contend today that it could confiscate between $30 million and $50 million if it won a racketeering case against five executives of Princeton/Newport Partners and a former official at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

CREDIT MARKETS;
LEAD: The Chemical Bank Credit Card Trust, a unit of the Chemical Banking Corporation, is issuing $350 million in debt backed by Visa and Mastercard credit card receivables.
The 9.30 percent notes are due in 1993, with an average life of 1.92 years.
They are priced at 99.813, to yield 9.37 percent.


U.N. Reports Soviet Pullout From 10 Afghan Bases
LEAD: The Soviet Army has withdrawn from 10 of its 18 main bases in Afghanistan and handed them over to the Afghan Army, the United Nations military observer team monitoring the Soviet pullout reported today.


Hispanic Dropouts Studied
LEAD: New findings indicate Hispanic students with no major problems still drop out of school at rates double or triple those of others.
Page B8.


Trade Gain For Canada
LEAD: Canada's trade surplus soared to its highest level in nearly three years in June as a result of a drop in imports from the United States and a jump in exports to Japan, Statistics Canada reported today.

Rent-Program Shift Sought
LEAD: Mayor Koch asked the City Council yesterday to pass a bill that would raise the income limit on the Senior Citizen Rent Income Exemption program.
