LEAD: THE timing of the Federal Reserve Board's increase in the discount rate last week has made some big investors nervous about the leadership of the central bank.


Pilgrim Will Buy Hanson Fire Units
LEAD: Hanson Industries, a British industrial management company, said it had agreed to sell most of its worldwide fire-detection operations to Pilgrim House Group P.L.C., a British engineering group, for $265.8 million.
Under the agreement, Pilgrim House will pay about $253.8 million in cash and assume about $12 million in debt in exchange for Walter Kidde North America, Fenwal, and Kidde's Fire Protection Group


Now, PC's That Read A Page and Store It
LEAD: The ability of computer programs to accurately read a printed page, including both text and graphics, and store the page's contents in a computer is improving rapidly, and the cost of the software is dropping.
This will soon make the new technology widely accessible to many personal computer users and could significantly speed the work flow in many offices.

LEAD: On Sept. 2, members of about 40 American families will gather at the Washington Cathedral for a memorial service to commemorate victims of the shooting down of Korean Airlines Flight 007 by a Soviet fighter plane five years ago.
All 269 persons aboard were killed.
There were 63 American citizens aboard that flight, bound from Anchorage, Alaska, to Seoul on Sept.

LEAD: A 12-year-old school integration policy intended to prevent white families from abandoning the New York City public school system is likely to be overhauled or even scrapped this fall, Robert F. Wagner Jr., the president of the Board of Education, and others say.

Review/Film; Soviet Youth, in 'Burglar'
LEAD: Glasnost has made it possible for the Soviet director Valery Ogorodnikov to turn his cameras on a rebellious teen-age culture that must seem shocking by Soviet standards, though to Western eyes it will look relatively tame.
Much of it can be found at the community centers where, under very noticeable adult supervision, Leningrad's adolescents gather to sing the rock-and-roll songs that constitute their main means of expressing individuality.


Alone in Dissent in Korea; Although Student Protests Set the Agenda, This Year They Fail to Gain Wide Backing
LEAD: A year ago, when students protested for democracy, tens of thousands of people cheered them on.
On Monday, when they tried marching to a meeting with their North Korean counterparts, they were alone.


U.S. Rebukes Soviets on Afghan Mine Clearing
LEAD: The United States accused the Soviet Union today of rejecting Washington's appeals for help in removing millions of mines from Afghanistan.


Jersey Supreme Court Overturns Death Sentence of Murderer
LEAD: The State Supreme Court today upheld the conviction of a death row inmate in the murder of an elderly Mercer County woman, but reversed his capital sentence because of trial errors.

No Muse Can Live By Art Alone
LEAD: William Gnade pulled his blue pickup truck next to a fieldstone cottage nestled in the woods.
He surveyed his cargo: a dozen picnic baskets with labels like Alexander, Mixter and Monday Music.
He chose one that matched a nameplate above the cottage door and placed it, unannounced, at the threshold.

Textron Plans Sale Of Gorham Unit
LEAD: Textron Inc., a diversified manufacturer of aerospace and commercial products, said it planned to sell its Gorham division, which makes sterling silverware, fine china and crystal.
John Carberg, a Textron spokesman, said that several companies had expressed interest in buying the division.
He declined to put a price on the unit.

Education; Education Specialists Put Emphasis on Inspiration
LEAD: For most of the 1980's, advocates of improving public schools have concentrated on making new regulations to mandate better performance by students, teachers and schools.
Now, according to those attending a recent conference of educators, that focus is shifting to emphasize ways to inspire better instruction by teachers and a hunger for achievement among students.

LEAD: David Cuevas, a dancer with American Ballet Theater, died of AIDS-related causes yesterday at his home in New York City.
He was 33 years old.

Roy Buchanan, 48, a Guitarist
LEAD: Roy Buchanan, who was once described on a television documentary as ''the best unknown guitarist in the world'' and who went on to produce two gold records, hanged himself in a jail cell Sunday night, the Fairfax County Sheriff's Department said today.
He was 48 years old.


Output Rate Up to 83.5% Of Capacity
LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 83.5 percent of capacity in July, the highest operating level in eight years.

Bridge
LEAD: European players who have represented their countries in international championships vastly outnumber their American counterparts and are thus better prepared psychologically for play at world level.

LEAD: Public libraries in at least some Soviet cities have been ordered to remove from their collections all political and economic books written before Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader in 1985, a librarian disclosed tonight in the Government newspaper Izvestia.

August '44: A Month too Hot for Satan
LEAD: At City Hall, the Mayor - his jacket off, his tie loose, his shirt damp - told constitutents he did his best work when he was ''physically overheated.'' Carriage horses collapsed in Central Park.
In subways that felt like rolling blast furnaces, people worried about how soon the fare would go up.

How Syndicators Have Shifted
LEAD: Two years ago, the big companies that sold real estate limited partnerships saw nothing but gloom in their future.
The real estate syndicators, as they were called, faced a number of threats that seemed likely to change significantly the way they did business, and even drive some from the field.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Manhattan Ice Account Moves to Murray Salit
LEAD: Manhattan Ice Inc., a maker of skin care and beauty products, has picked Murray Salit &amp; Associates, a division of Biederman &amp; Company, to handle its Le Zink Suncare line and the introduction of Gottex Systeme Soleil sun products.
The combined budget is $2 million, with the bulk going toward Le Zink, whose advertising was previously handled in-house.


Anxious Utilities Meet Record Demand
LEAD: Utilities in the New York region have met this summer's record demand for electricity with only scattered blackouts so far, but some officials are warning of problems in the next few years if demand continues to soar.

Palestinians Receive Their Last Jordanian Paychecks
LEAD: Civil employees in line at a cashier's window at a bank in Ramallah in the occupied West Bank yesterday to pick up their last salary checks from Jordan.
About 5,200 Palestinians have been laid off as part of a move by King Hussein to cut ties with Arabs in the occuipied territories.
Another 16,150 people employed in the health, education and agriculture sectors will continue in their jobs receiving salaries only from Israel, according to an official of the Jordanian-run West Bank Health Department.

LEAD: Lino S. Lipinsky de Orlov, an artist, a designer of historic museum exhibits and a curator of history at the John Jay Homestead State Historic Site in Katonah, N.Y., died at his home in Katonah last Thursday.
He was 80 years old.

Tyco Labs to Buy Mueller Holdings
LEAD: Tyco Laboratories Inc. said it had agreed to buy Mueller Holdings Corp. from affiliates of Investcorp and other shareholders in a deal valued at about $350 million.
Mueller, a privately held company based in Annapolis, Md., is a leading maker and distributor of flow-control products for water and gas distribution systems in the United States and Canada.

Horse Racing Notebook; Nerud Prescription: Hay, Oats, Water
LEAD: The programs at most American race tracks outside New York's have become cluttered with little B's and L's over the last decade.
Those letters, following a horse's name, are meant to indicate that he is being treated with either the anti-inflammatory Butazolidin (B) or the diuretic Lasix (L).
Now it turns out that in Kentucky, even in the Kentucky Derby, those letters can stand for many things.

Suspect Charged in Death Of Officer Slain by Partner
LEAD: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man on probation for a burglary conviction was in police custody yesterday, charged with second-degree manslaughter in the death of an undercover narcotics policeman who was accidentally shot by his partner.


Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: THE ways children tease each other and the ways they respond to being teased can tell us much about their mental and emotional development.
Beneath the taunting are clues to how well children can think in abstractions, and how well they understand the feelings and situations of others.
Most important, child development experts say, teasing and being teased are ways for children to practice some of the social skills they will need as adults.


ABC Suing Israeli Agency for Showing News Tapes
LEAD: The ABC television network is suing an Israeli media relations agency for showing taped copies of the network's evening news coverage of the Arab uprising.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Our vacation house has electric baseboard heat.
In the large living room the heating element makes clicking and banging noises constantly.
This is much less of a problem in the bedrooms, which are smaller, and no problem at all in the smallest rooms.
Do you know if anything can be done to stop this noise?


U.S. ENVOY, 28 OTHERS DIE
LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan and the United States Ambassador to his country were killed today when a Pakistani Air Force plane exploded in midair and crashed in eastern Pakistan.


Found, the Lost Murals of Queens Hospital
LEAD: One of eight oil-on-canvas murals by William Palmer that were misplaced for 34 years and recently found.
The series, titled ''The Development of Medicine,'' was commissioned in 1935 by the Works Progress Administration for display at Queens General Hospital.
The murals were misplaced during reconstruction of the hospital in 1954 and were not found until April, when a maintenance worker remembered storing a box of old paintings in the basement.

LEAD: JACK ROSS, who started his track lighting business, Track by Jack, 15 years ago, thinks track lighting can be a smart choice for the home. ''You can view a wall of artwork without having to overcome the glare of a lamp,'' he said.
He has found that people with young children like to get lamps off the floor.

Yields Rise Significantly
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds increased significantly for the week ended yesterday, with short-term rates posting the biggest gains since last Oct. 7.

Franklin Roosevelt Jr., 74, Ex-Congressman, Dies
LEAD: Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., a former United States Representative from New York and a son of the 32d President of the United States, died of lung cancer yesterday, his 74th birthday, at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
He lived in Millbrook, N.Y., and Manhattan.

LEAD: They tell the story of the frontier town that had no lawyer, so they sent East for one.
He set up shop, but there were no clients.
He was about to head home when the town fathers got a bright idea.
They brought in another lawyer.

Lawyers generate conflict - despite new-fangled law school courses in dispute resolution.

Pakistan After Zia
LEAD: The catch phrases about Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, were largely correct.
He was a strong man, a devout Moslem certain it was his mission to impose unity on a fractious country.
He brooked no rivals, groomed no heirs.
His death at 64 in a still-unexplained air accident leaves a vacuum that could invite turmoil, even intervention by meddlesome neighbors.

Review/Theater; Strindberg Tormented

The Quayle Questions
LEAD: Vice President Bush faced the press in New Orleans yesterday and gave his most impressive performance of the 1988 campaign.
Relaxed in manner, crisp in response, he controlled the session with an authority that seemed to announce: President Reagan's gone.
I'm in charge of this party now.
But still he could not fully dispel the questions surrounding his choice as running mate of the young man who stood somewhat awkwardly by his side, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana.

Chemists Challenge a Theory on Life's Origin
LEAD: A theory that life on earth may have originated at hot water vents in the ocean floor has been challenged by chemists who reported findings yesterday that organic compounds produced in such high-temperature environments would decompose almost as soon as they were made.

Harrowsmith Is Sold
LEAD: Harrowsmith, a country-living magazine issued out of Vermont, is now part of Telemedia Inc. of Canada, which has acquired a majority interest in the bimonthly's parent, Camden House Publishing Inc.
The cost of the transaction was not disclosed.
Telemedia, the largest publisher of consumer publications in Canada, already owns the magazine's older Canadian counterpart, Harrowsmith Canada.

Anxiety Linked to Some Chest Pain Cases
LEAD: People who complain of chest pain but who have no evidence of heart disease score higher on tests for anxiety, depression and other neurotic traits than do people with pain from genuine angina, a new study indicates.

Maxicare Cuts Off Coverage in Utah
LEAD: Maxicare of Utah Inc. has announced its withdrawal from Utah, leaving 20,000 health-care subscribers uninsured.
Harold C. Yancey, Utah's commissioner of insurance, said he hoped health-care providers would honor Maxicare contracts until the state could act to fill the vacuum left by the company's sudden departure.

LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq so thoroughly dominated Pakistani public life since he seized power in a military coup in 1977 that his death in a plane crash today left no individual in line to succeed him.
But given the military's preponderance since independence in 1947, it seems likely that General Zia's sweeping, authoritarian powers will be claimed by the army.

British Bank Has Profit
LEAD: Standard Chartered P.L.C., Britain's fifth-largest commercial bank, reported strong profits for the first half of 1988.
Pretax profits for the six months to June 30 were $:156 million, or $265 million.
In the comparable period last year, the company had a loss of $:224 million, or $381 million, because of problems with its third-world debt.

LEAD: Two of the nation's leading college basketball conferences, the Big East and the Atlantic Coast Conference, have agreed to join forces to solve one of the perennial problems of big-time college basketball - how to keep fans awake during the early portion of the season when major schools traditionally schedule pushover opponents.

LEAD: Halfway through an already late and over-budget rehabilitation project for the troubled Manhattan Bridge, state transportation officials are stopping the work to bring in a new contractor and new designs.

LEAD: Fred G. Sullivan, his wife, Polly, and their four children hope that Friday is the hottest day of the year in New York City.
They hope that the air-conditioning at every triplex and sixplex movie theater in Manhattan goes on the blink.

Brooklyn Legislator Pleads Guilty To Hiding Source of Contributions
LEAD: State Senator Martin Markowitz pleaded guilty yesterday to misdemeanor charges of illegally hiding the sources of $25,000 in political contributions to his unsuccessful 1985 campaign for Brooklyn borough president.

Treasury Prices Little Changed
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in very sluggish trading yesterday, as market participants struggled to drum up business on a largely eventless day.

Now Mr.

Woman Accused of Hijacking Pleads Guilty to Lesser Crime
LEAD: A woman accused of hijacking a jet to Cuba 19 years ago, using a gun and taking a 2-year-old child hostage, pleaded guilty yesterday to the least of the charges against her - that of interfering with the plane's crew.


China Issues Bonds
LEAD: China's Communications Bank in Singapore issued $100 million of five-year bonds denominated in United States dollars, China's official press agency reported yesterday.
The notes, which are the first the bank has issued abroad, have a yield of 9.375 percent.
The bank said the issue would be used to back ''municipal construction and technological renovation.


In Dual-Faith Families Children Sturggle For a Spiritual Home
LEAD: MICHAEL LERNER'S father was Jewish and his mother was Episcopal.
In the home of his youth, both faiths were practiced at various times, he says, and there was little conflict over religion.
But as an adult, he found the two faiths at odds.
Rather than embrace either, he turned to the spiritual tradition of yoga, studying with the Hindu teacher Swami

LEAD: For years it had been a big stink, the pungent odor of horse manure that dots southern sections of Central Park.
Joggers step around it, bicyclists nose their wheels away from it, and the condominium dwellers looking out on it shut their windows to its smell.

Gandhi was joined by other Indian leaders in expressing grief at the death of a man they had confronted and often bitterly criticized over the years.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Muller Upsets Cash: Unseeded Gary Muller, ranked 173d in the world, stunned fourth-seeded Pat Cash yesterday in the second round of the Association of Tennis Professionals championship at the Jack Nicklaus Sports Center in Mason, Ohio.
Cash, the 1987 Wimbledon champion who is now ranked seventh in the world, lost by 5-7, 6-3, 7-6, and became the fifth of the 10 top-seeded players to be eliminated in the first two rounds.

LEAD: Arnold L. Raphel, the United States Ambassador to Pakistan who died in a plane crash there yesterday, was the first American Ambassador in nearly a decade to be killed while performing his duties.

LEAD: A Federal appeals panel subjected both sides in the Yonkers desegregation case to hard questioning yesterday as the city and four councilmen appealed a judge's contempt order against them.

Puerto Rico Bonds
LEAD: The Puerto Rico Highway Authority is issuing $287 million of highway revenue and refunding bonds in three tranches through Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
The notes have coupon rates from 6.50 percent for notes priced at par and due in 1990 to 8.125 percent for notes priced at 99.00 and due in 2013.
The funds will be used to pay for the continuing long-range development of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's highway system.

Pakistan: At A Glance
LEAD:  Government  Mohammad Zia ul-Haq came to power in a military coup in 1977, deposing Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was executed two years later.
For much of General Zia's tenure, human rights groups criticized Pakistan for imprisoning citizens without trial.
The press was also under censorship.

LEAD: The Israeli Army has adopted a newly aggressive and pre-emptive approach to crushing the Palestinian uprising, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said in an interview today.

At New Zoo, A Menagerie Of Plantings
LEAD: IS it possible to miss the fauna for the flora?
In the new Central Park Zoo, where bobbing sea lions send waves over the side of their glass pool, exuberant new plantings are giving these zoo favorites some serious competition.
Brilliant pink-petaled coneflowers, bright purple asters and silvery gray Russian sage vie for the visitor's attention in one of the most luxuriant public gardens this side of Great Britain.


THE REPUBLICANS IN NEW ORLEANS: Man in the News; A Self-Effacing Nominee: George Herbert Walker Bush
LEAD: Almost by definition, politicians are self-promoters.
But George Bush's entire public career has been built on self-effacement, on loyalty, on his willingness to button his lip, on his readiness to play second or, if need be, even third banana.


A Tale of Two Cities
LEAD: On a visit earlier this month to Moscow, home of Russia's czars, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci couldn't altogether escape the procurement scandal that has gripped the Pentagon this summer.


Tuktoyaktuk Journal; Happy Days in Arctic (Unless You Sell Ice Cream)
LEAD: Jean-Baptiste MacLeod is an exhausted man.
Out here on Canada's Arctic shoreline, 2,500 miles northwest of his native Montreal, he has been working 18-hour days in an attempt to bolster the fortunes of the business he bought five years ago, the Hotel Tuk Inn.

22 Killed as a Train to Moscow Derails and Burns
LEAD: A passenger train traveling from Leningrad to Moscow derailed and burst into flames on Tuesday, killing 22 people, including children, and leaving 107 injured, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today.


Mexican Airline
LEAD: Mexico will have a new international airline in 45 days, replacing the bankrupt, Government-owned Aeromexico, officials said.
The Banobras bank, which is handling the bankruptcy proceedings, said the new airline would obtain financing from the pilots' union and private investors.

LEAD: Stuart Kreisler, the president and chief executive of Ralph Lauren Womenswear Inc., will leave the company in September, it was announced yesterday.

He said Rooney's prognosis was guarded.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about Senator Dan Quayle's work in newspapers and his interests in the Pulliam publishing empire, Central Newspapers, misstated the circulation of The Arizona Republic.
It was 320,409 daily for the 12 months ended Dec. 27, 1987.

Just -just think - 82 days from now George Bush and I are going to win one for you - win one for America's future, and yes, win one for the Gipper.


Catholics Fight Crime That Has Shut Churches
LEAD: There is a special collection box in the center aisle at St.
Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church on West 23d Street with a sign that says, ''Keep Our Church Open.'' With the dollars and quarters and dimes that worshipers have dropped into the box, the church has hired a security guard this summer to sit at the door every afternoon, a time when until recently the church had been closed.

Auctions
LEAD: There's the aura of a Cecil B. DeMille spectacle in the news this week: furnishings, artworks, jewelry and memorabilia from the home of the fabled Hollywood producer will be auctioned by Christie's East in New York in October.


Results PlusConnors Defaults: Third-seeded Jimmy Connors, suffering from tendinitis in his left elbow, had to default his third-round match yesterday in the Association of Tennis Professionals Championship in Mason, Ohio, to 14th-seeded Kevin Curren. Connors decided to rest the elbow in hopes he will be able to play in the United States Open, which starts Aug. 29. Bill Norris, the trainer for the association, said the elbow could recover in a week to 10 days.   Ninth-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador was charged with four code violations and forfeited his match to Carl Limberger. Gomez argued with the chair umpire, David Littlefield, over several calls in the first set, which he lost, 6-2. He trailed in the second set by 3-1 when he was called for his fourth infraction, resulting in a forfeit. Gomez was fined $2,350. '' (AP)  Giammalva Advances: Sammy Giammalva, seeded sixth, returned service well in the final two sets to defeat Tobias Svantesson of Sweden, 2-6, 6-4, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals of the $125,000 Mennen Cup yesterday in Livingston, N.J. Giammalva finally broke Svantesson's serve in the fifth game of the second set after failing to convert two service breaks in the first game of the second set and another in the third game.(AP)  Navaratilova Routs Hanika: Martina Navratilova routed Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Player's Challenge in Montreal. Navratilova, seeded first, has not lost to Hanika since 1982. Chris Evert, seeded second, also advanced by completing her rain-suspended match and beating Rene Simpson of Canada, 6-1, 6-2. Third-seeded Pam Shriver struggled past Nathalie Tauziat of France, 7-6, 6-4. (AP)  Golf  Watson Eliminated: Tom Watson came up a point short and was eliminated yesterday in the completion of first-round play at the $1 million International Golf Tournament in Castle Rock, Colo. Watson, needing a birdie-birdie finish to advance to the second round of the tournament, birdied the 17th hole but missed a birdie putt from four feet on the 18th.   Under the modified Stableford scoring system used for this tournament, eagles are worth 5 points, birdies 2 and pars nothing. Bogeys cost players 1 point and double bogey or worse cost 3. John Cook, the defending champion, also failed to advance. Ben Crenshaw and Mark O'Meara led 39 qualifiers from the 81-man field in the second half of the first round. Each had six birdies and two bogeys and tied with 10 points. Jeff Sluman, the new PGA champion, also advanced with 5 points.(AP)  Horse Racing  Lukas Wins Stakes Again: Pat Copelan led all the way to score a 10-length victory over Channel Three and Premier Playmate in the $96,000 Adirondack Stakes yesterday at Saratoga Race Track, giving the trainer D. Wayne Lukas his fourth straight victory in the race. Pat Copelan, who won her debut at Saratoga Aug. 4 by three lengths, is a 2-year-old daughter of Copelan and the Dr. Fager mare Ahrex, and is owned by William T. Young. She paid $3.20 for $2 to win as part of a Lukas-trained entry with Darby Shuffle, who finished fourth. The winner ran the six furlongs in 1:10 4/5 under Pat Day. Lukas won the previous three Adirondacks with Nervous Baba in 1985, Sacahuista in 1986 and Over All last year.  Cycling  Wilches Sprints to Victory: Pablo Wilches gave Colombia's Postobon team its first stage win in this year's Coors International Classic yesterday with a first-place finish in stage 11, the 107-mile Aspen to Copper Mountain Road Race. Davis Phinney of Team 7-Eleven regained the race leader's jersey from his teammate, Alex Stieda. Phinney finished third, edged out in a final sprint by Alex Grewal of Team Crest. The two led a chase pack that crossed the finish line about one minute 30 seconds behind Wilches, who finished in 4 hours 35 minutes 42 seconds.   In the third stage of the women's Coors, Leslie Schenk of Team Lowrey's broke from a lead group of racers on the second ascent up Fremont Pass to claim her second straight victory in the Copper Mountain road race. Schenk, of Cincinnati, finished the 54-mile course in 2 hours 27 minutes 1 second.

William H. Phelps Jr. Dies at 85; Ornithologist and Conservationist
LEAD: William H. Phelps Jr., an ornithologist, explorer and former trustee of the American Museum of Natural History, died of circulatory problems last Saturday at his home in Caracas, Venezuela.
He was 85 years old.

Many Tried to Join Guard at War's Height
LEAD: At the height of the Vietnam War, many Americans tried to enlist in the National Guard and the Reserves of the Army, Air Force and Marines as an alternative to being drafted into a combat unit.


New Mexico Utility
LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Mexico said it is abandoning a two-year-old reorganization plan that has encountered heavy opposition from state and local regulators and the utility's industrial customers and has led to a steep drop in the company's stock price.
Under the proposal made last year, the utility planned to form a holding company for its generating and distribution operations.

A Day of Nonstop Haydn
LEAD: A Haydn Marathon will be offered on Sunday as part of the Mostly Mozart festival at Avery Fisher Hall.

Tickets are $12 a session, or $17 for both sessions.

Woman Found Fatally Stabbed In Her L.I. Home
LEAD: A 50-year-old woman was stabbed to death in her home here Wednesday morning, two days after a slaying in Dix Hills, 10 miles away.


Chicken by George
LEAD: Geo.
A.
Hormel &amp; Company announced it had bought Chicken by George Inc., the company founded by a former Miss America, Phyllis George.
The price was not disclosed.
Under the agreement, Hormel will buy all the assets of Chicken by George, based in Louisville, Ky., and operate the company as a division.


N.H.L., Officials Plan New Talks
LEAD: The National Hockey League and its officials held another negotiating session today in an effort to reach a new collective bargaining agreement.
The officials' three-year pact will expire Aug. 31.

Fewer Britons Lack Jobs
LEAD: Unemployment in Britain in July was a seasonally adjusted 8.2 percent of the work force, down from 8.4 percent in June and 10.2 percent in July 1987, the Government said today.
Last month's unemployment was estimated at 2.31 million people, down from 2.37 million in June and 2.87 million in July 1987.


Hostage Dies as German Drama Ends
LEAD: A hostage was killed and two fleeing bank robbers were seriously hurt today when they were captured in a shoot-out with the police on a highway near here, ending a two-and-a-half-day ordeal for a busload of people held hostage.


Federation Plans For '94 World Cup
LEAD: The United States became an automatic qualifier for the 1994 World Cup when it was designated as the host nation for the event last month.
Since then, the United States Soccer Federation, the national governing body for the sport, has been working to establish what Werner Fricker, the federation's president, called a competitive environment for the players.

Sports People; Round 4 for Leonard
LEAD: In a news conference in Manhattan to confirm Nov. 7 as the date for his return to the ring, Sugar Ray Leonard said yesterday that he had something in common with Jason, the masked murderer in the ''Friday the 13th'' movies. ''We both keep coming back,'' he said.


Bush Makes a Choice
LEAD: Even before questions began to surface about Senator Dan Quayle's National Guard service during the war in Vietnam, it could hardly be said that George Bush had made a conventional political choice that clearly bolstered his ticket, or that he had picked a running mate whose stature would enhance his own.


Restaurants
LEAD: The cast of dining spots along restaurant row in the Broadway theater district (West 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues) has changed dramatically in recent years.

With Peace Near, Namibian Softens
LEAD: Sam Nujoma, the rebel leader who may become leader of a free Namibia if American-brokered peace talks succeed, has begun to temper the fiery oratory that is his hallmark.


Mexico Plan on Oil Exports
LEAD: Mexico is prepared to reduce its oil exports to help stabilize prices, but only if the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries develops a reasonable plan for similar action, Energy Minister Fernando Hiriart said today.

LEAD: The Saturday Brass Quintet - Terry Szor and Scott McIntosh, trumpeters; Lawrence DiBello, horn player; Richard Kessler, trombonist, and Kyle Turner, tuba player - is to play works by Bach Gabrielli, Holborne, Gershwin and Lutoslawski at Wave Hill, West 249th Street in Independence Avenue, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, on Sunday at 5 P.M.

LEAD: The body of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was flown here this evening while investigators searched 330 miles away for the cause of the midair explosion and plane crash that killed him and the United States Ambassador on Wednesday.

Free Park Concert
LEAD: Christopher Keene is to lead the Long Island Philharmonic in a free concert at Heckscher State Park, Main Street at New York Avenue, Huntington, L.I., tomorrow evening at 8:30.
The program is to include Rossini's Overture to ''La Gazza Ladra,'' Borodin's ''Polovtsian Dances,'' Handel's ''Water Music'' and Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Capriccio Espagnole.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about Women's Wear Daily incorrectly reported the status of a dispute between John B. Fairchild and the designers Hubert de Givenchy, Giorgio Armani and Bill Blass.
Mr.
Fairchild, chairman of the company that publishes the newspaper, currently permits coverage of those designers.


Delta Is Planning Aircraft Purchase
LEAD: Delta Air Lines Inc. hopes to place an order for new long-range aircraft by the end of the year, but it has not yet decided on the size and the type of plane, a Delta spokesman said.
Jim Lundy, a spokesman for Atlanta-based Delta, made the comments after The Wall Street Journal had reported that the airline might order as much as $6 billion in new planes.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Brightening Outlook for Fox Network
LEAD: EVEN after spending $3 billion for Triangle Publications, Rupert Murdoch is apparently not concerned about making ends meet.
But if money worries should develop, he can take comfort in knowing that up-front sales for his Fox Television Network are up 30 percent this year.
Industry experts say that means the network has already sold about $130 million in time.


Botha Says He Is Seeking a Way To Permit the Release of Mandela
LEAD: President P. W. Botha said today that he was trying to reach an agreement that would allow the release of Nelson R. Mandela, the imprisoned South African nationalist leader.

LEAD: The Financial Services Corporation of New York City, which is normally in the business of lending money to eligible businesses at below-market rates, is acting as an investment banker for West Mill Clothes Inc. of Woodside, Queens.

LEAD: At times this week, it has appeared that every third person at the Republican Convention is named Bush.
Here is a daughter-in-law named Columba who was born in Mexico.
There is a daughter nicknamed Doro who turned 29 yesterday.
One son after another speaks out, at the microphone of one state delegation or another, on behalf of ''the finest father in America.


An Ultimate Choice for the P.L.O.
LEAD: Can the Palestine Liberation Organization step into the breach opened by King Hussein's official detachment from the West Bank and transform itself into an acceptable negotiating partner with Israel?
Yes, if it renounces terrorism and explicitly recognizes Israel's right to exist as a Jewish state.


Cuomo Signs a Bill Creating Parks Panel
LEAD: Governor Cuomo signed legislation yesterday that forms a special commission to study whether the state should create a Hudson River Greenway, a chain of parks, open spaces and trails stretching from New York City to the Adirondacks.


C-130 Hercules: A Workhorse in World Skies
LEAD: Over the last 30 years, the Lockheed C-130 Hercules transport plane has been a workhorse in 60 nations, including the fleets of the United States Air Force, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard.


Achilles Head Called a Fake
LEAD: A marble head of Achilles that was once regarded as one of the J. Paul Getty Museum's significant antiquities has been determined to be a fake, a museum spokeswoman said today.

LEAD: Eight independent agencies that monitor health-care needs and hospital services in New York State may close because of a dispute over state financing, state health officials and legislators said this week.

LEAD: The prices of coffee futures rose sharply yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, but analysts said that fears of weather damage to the Brazilian coffee crop - the major reason for the rally - were unrealistic.

LEAD: People, Life and McCalls magazines are teaming up to offer advertisers a group-magazine buy for a joint special supplement called ''Our Children, Our Future.'' The 24-page section, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, will appear in February and is expected to reach a circulation of 49 million.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company, which last week ended its four-year relationship with Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, on good terms, has decided to consolidate its advertising for computing products at its other main agency, Saatchi &amp; Saatchi DFS/ Compton, San Francisco.
The new business amounts to about $20 million; the amount of the entire account was not disclosed.

LEAD: The United States sent two teams of experts to Pakistan today to help the Government investigate the airplane explosion that killed the nation's President and the American Ambassador there.

India Looks Toward Future Relations With Pakistan
LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi signing a memorial book yesterday at the Pakistani Embassy in New Delhi.
The Indian Government said yesterday that the next Pakistani Government must end assistance to Sikh extremists in Punjab if it wants to improve relations.
Pakistan denies providing such aid.
In the disputed Indian state of Kashmir, meanwhile, 3 people were killed and 10 wounded as the Indian authorities clashed with pro-Pakistan rioters.

LEAD: Jonathan Demme is the American cinema's king of amusing artifacts: blinding bric-a-brac, the junkiest of jewelry, costumes so frightening they take your breath away.
Mr.
Demme may joke, but he's also capable of suggesting that the very fabric of American life may be woven of such things, and that it takes a merry and adventurous spirit to make the most of them.

LEAD: The Government asked the Soviet Union to scale down a planned military exercise in the Sea of Japan beginning Friday, Foreign Ministry officials said today.

Reagan Signs Transition Bill
LEAD: President Reagan signed a bill Wednesday that increases the amount of money for Presidential transitions, beginning with his, early next year.
The amount for the incoming President and Vice President is increased from $2 million to $3.5 million and the amount for the outgoing President and Vice President goes from $1 million to $1.5 million.

LEAD: A wildfire near Helena, Mont., quadrupled in size yesterday, growing into a wall of flame that destroyed at least five homes and forced dozens of residents to flee.


In Yonkers, 4,000 Units Are Delayed
LEAD: When four members of the Yonkers City Council decided to defy a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, they did so by voting down an amendment to the city's zoning ordinance that would dramatically change future development in Yonkers.

Olympic Diving; Louganis Leads; Kimball In Sixth
LEAD: Greg Louganis found himself in his accustomed place today, first, halfway through the 3-meter springboard competition at the United States Olympic diving trials.
With his highest point total of the season, 722.88, he easily led the field of 12 into the final round Friday night.


Gooden Throws Lightly
LEAD: Dwight Gooden threw lightly on the sidelines for 10 minutes today and reported no problem with his right shoulder.
But a more important test will come Friday in San Diego, when Gooden will pitch from the bullpen mound in the customary workout between regular starts.

LEAD: To the Editor:


The Candidates' Military Records b
LEAD: George Bush: Bush served in the Navy from 1942 to 1945 and was a carrier pilot in the Pacific.
He was shot down and rescued by a submarine.
Bush was discharged as a lieutenant and was decorated with the Distinguished Flying Cross and three Air Medals.
Dan Quayle: Quayle served in the Indiana National Guard from 1969 to 1975.


Sports of The Times; Still Living on the Line
LEAD: SINCE losing both feet in a rocket explosion in Vietnam, Bill Demby has driven drag racers and learned to ski and taken up track and field.
And as the television commercial graphically shows, with the help of a new device called a Seattle Foot, Demby can play basketball with the able-bodied.
Same game.


Hard Rock Co-Founder Has Expansion Plans
LEAD: Peter A. Morton, one of the co-founders of the original Hard Rock Cafe in London, has formed his own holding company and plans to export the noisy, perpetually crowded restaurant to Canada and Brazil.

LEAD:  Zimbabwean Pop


Yow Picks 12 for Seoul
LEAD: Kay Yow, the coach of the United States Olympic women's basketball team, made her final cuts today.
She reduced the team to the dozen players who will compete in Seoul, South Korea, next month.


Lawyer Ordered To Jail by Judge In Federal Trial
LEAD: A Federal judge said yesterday that he had ordered the seven-day confinement of a defense lawyer for civil contempt of court and to ''make sure of her presence'' until the end of a narcotics and racketeering trial.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  The Economy


Wilting Defense Can't Support John
LEAD: The Yankees have lost six of their last nine games and 10 of their last 15.
Their pitching has given up 43 earned runs in the last five games.
Their hits come in the greatest numbers when they are superfluous, and often dry up altogether when they're most wanted.


SAVINGS UNITS SOLD IN A TEXAS RESCUE
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had sold 12 insolvent savings and loan associations in Texas to an investment group headed by a Chicago banker and backed by a Texas steel company.
The Government will provide an assistance package that could reach $1.3 billion over 10 years.

Metropolitan Baedeker; Living History at West Point
LEAD: BECAUSE of its beauty, historic importance and training mission, the United States Military Academy at West Point - on the west bank of the Hudson River about 45 miles north of New York City - attracts hundreds of thousands of visitors a year, including an increasing number of foreign tourists.
Military officers estimate the visitors at 2.5 million to 3 million a year, although some tourism officials put the number at perhaps half that.


Study of Small Concerns
LEAD: The Federal Reserve and the Small Business Administration plan to survey 4,000 small concerns on how financial deregulation has affected them.
The concerns, selected at random, will be asked about the financial services they use.
The study will be conducted for the Government by the Research Triangle Institute in North Carolina.


Lebanese Unable to Muster Quorum to Elect a President
LEAD: The Lebanese Parliament failed to muster a quorum today to elect a new head of state, causing concern about a further decay of the political situation as President Amin Gemayel's six-year term nears an end.


At Fulcrum of Conflict, Regulator of AIDS Drugs
LEAD: Dr.
Ellen C. Cooper has emerged as the most important gatekeeper for AIDS drugs in the nation, a role that has caught her in a spotlight of conflict that is rare for someone who is a mid-level manager at the Food and Drug Administration.

LEAD: Vice President Bush accepted the Republican Presidential nomination tonight with a pledge to ''keep America moving forward, always forward,'' but the beginning of his campaign was marred by an intense controversy swirling around his chosen running mate, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana.

Polish Labor Unrest Spreads In Port City and to Five Mines
LEAD: Labor unrest in Poland spread today as the number of coal mines being struck rose to five while transport workers joined port workers on strike in Szczecin, opposition leaders said.


Israel Outlaws Local Panels Behind Arab Uprising
LEAD: Israel formally outlawed Palestinian ''popular committees'' today, saying the organizations had been helping run the eight-month uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired a majority stake in the appliance business of the Dutch electronics company N. V. Philips.

A.T.&amp;T. Price Cut
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was reducing prices on three models in its line of I.B.M.-compatible computers by up to 28 percent in an effort to make the machines more competitive.
A.T.&amp;T. said it was reducing the prices of its 6286, 6312 and 6386 Workgroup Systems, with larger volume discounts.


The Foes of Zia: So Many, So Bitter
LEAD: As speculation continued that the death of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan was caused by sabotage, Western scholars noted yesterday that the general had many opponents, both Pakistanis and foreigners, who might have felt they had reason to kill him.


You Could Look It Up, but You'd Be Wrong
LEAD: If the Encyclopaedia Britannica says there's a dam on the Rappahannock River that's 194 feet high and 8,850 feet long, it must be true, right?
Wrong.
The Salem Church Dam has existed since 1944 - but only on paper, as a proposal by the Army Corps of Engineers.

Foreigners Are Detained in Prague After Marking '68 Soviet Invasion
LEAD: About a dozen Western European demonstrators briefly unfurled banners on a crowded central square here today demanding ''freedom and human rights'' in Czechoslovakia.


Koch to Take Steps To Protect Horses
LEAD: Reacting to an uproar over the treatment of carriage horses, Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the city would take steps to protect the animals during hot weather.


Toying With Child Safety
LEAD: For years, the American Academy of Pediatrics has urged that toy package labels explicitly warn about small parts on which a child might choke.
A bill sponsored by Representative Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut and just approved by the House Energy and Commerce Committee would require reluctant toy makers to do just that.


A Folk Singer Is Part of the Haydn Marathon
LEAD: Jean Redpath will become the first folk singer to appear in the Mostly Mozart festival when she performs in its Haydn Marathon on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall.
Ms.
Redpath, who is acknowledged internationally as the foremost interpreter of traditional Scottish music, will sing Haydn's Scottish Songs in afternoon and evening programs.

AMC Plans to Sell 605 Movie Theaters
LEAD: AMC Entertainment Inc. said it plans to sell about 40 percent of its movie theater screens for about $200 million to New York-based TPI Enterprises Inc.
The Kansas City-based movie theater chain, which owns almost 25 percent of TPI's stock, would manage the theaters, under the AMC name, and would continue to negotiate for their films.

LEAD: P-O-P Times, a magazine devoted to the point-of-purchase industry, will bring out its first issue next month.
The magazine, from Hoyt Publishing of Chicago, will be sent free to 15,000 people in marketing.
Beginning in January, it will be issued bimonthly.

LEAD: A Superior Court judge ruled today that New Jersey's 39-year-old law banning motorists from pumping their own gasoline is unconstitutional.

LEAD: The four little children of Fred G. Sullivan, a k a ''Adirondack Fred,'' do not want to starve.
And they don't want to be sold to the gypsies, either.
They say as much, several times, during the course of Mr.
Sullivan's ''Beer Drinker's Guide to Fitness and Film Making,'' in hopes that this film will let their father strike it rich and stop having to worry about where the next diaper is coming from.

Chavez Plans to End Fast Sunday at Mass
LEAD: Cesar Chavez, the leader of the United Farm Workers, plans to end his fast Sunday at an outdoor mass at the union's compound here, a spokeswoman announced today.

Treasury Issues Climb Modestly

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Health page on Aug. 4 about a new test to detect herpes viruses misstated the number of cases of blindness caused by the viruses.
Herpes infections cause severe vision loss or blindness, usually just in one eye, in 10,000 to 20,000 people each year, according to Dr.
Edmund C. Dunkel of the Eye Research Institute in Boston.

LEAD: The Defense Department's office of acronyms continues to work overtime, with new creations emerging from the continuing investigation into possible fraud and bribery in the letting of Pentagon contracts for weapons and equipment.
In bidding for a contract, an arms maker is asked to make a ''best and final offer,'' a BAFO.

LEAD: A Brooklyn physician was arrested yesterday and charged with illegally disposing of medical waste - 11 hypodermic syringes, 2 needles and 2 culture tubes - outside his Bedford-Stuyvesant office, the Brooklyn District Attorney announced.

Hedging Plan For Aluminum
LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has authorized a Federal power agency to buy option-like contracts to protect it against falling aluminum prices, officials of the agency, the Bonneville Power Administration, said today.
The contracts would be bought from a broker - not acquired through trading.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 447 money market mutual funds increased by $3 billion, to $268.56 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 125 institutional funds increased $575.3 million, to $69.22 billion.
Assets of the 221 general purpose funds were up $1.66 billion, to $85.36 billion.


Review/Blues; Despair Dotted by Smiles
LEAD: A performance by Bobby (Blue) Bland, the great rhythm-and-blues singer who's appearing through Sunday at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street), can be dizzying in its ironies.
His songs hold the essence of desolation as he sketches misfortunes and betrayals in a voice that sounds as if it's been worn nearly threadbare through long suffering.


Editor Says He Helped Quayle Enter Guard in '69
LEAD: A retired senior editor of a newspaper owned by Senator Dan Quayle's family said today that he had tried to help Mr.
Quayle enter the National Guard at the height of the Vietnam War.

Stephen Gardner, Stepher Felter and Marcus Kemp have been named senior vice presidents at Ammirati &amp; Puris.


Review/Art; Sculptors Make a Case For Expressionism
LEAD: Among the few shows currently on view during these slow August days, two exhibitions devote space to works by sculptors who make persuasive cases for the vitality of expressionistic art.


Police Officer Is Mourned
LEAD: Colleagues of Police Officer Joseph Galapo lining 67th Street in Brooklyn as the hearse carrying his coffin left the Magen David Congregation Synagogue.
Officer Galapo was killed by a bullet from his partner's gun during an arrest of narcotics suspects Tuesday.
He and Sgt.
William Martin were attempting to make the arrest when one of the suspects spun and struck Sergeant Martin's arm, causing his gun to fire.

LEAD: B.A.T.
Industries extended its $63-a-share hostile tender offer for Farmers Group Inc. until Wednesday, but failed to take any action on its $72-a-share, or $5 billion, offer, which expires Friday.

Nuclear Adviser Assails Methods At U.S. Plants
LEAD: The head of a panel that advises the Department of Energy on safety at its nuclear reactors said yesterday that the procedure for dealing with the unexpected at the plants was ''very bad.'' He compared the system to testing an airplane for structural strength, seeing a wing flutter unexpectedly and then flying even faster.

A Look at the Splashiest Shows in Town
LEAD: AFTER its dry spell of several months, the Bethesda Fountain - the bronze wings of its angel newly polished and the cracks in its basin fully repaired - will be turned on again today in Central Park.
Built in 1863, it is the oldest working public fountain in New York City, and for more than a century it has attracted visitors in search of a cooling interlude.

Zenith Processor
LEAD: Zenith Data Systems Corporation introduced a new multiprocessing computer that is based on as many as six Intel 80386 microprocessors operating simultaneously.
The new multiprocessor was developed for the unit of the Zenith Electronics Corporation by Corollary Inc. of Irvine, Calif.
Designed to run both the Unix and MS-DOS operating systems, the new computer is aimed at the market traditionally served by more expensive minicomputers.


Iraq Trying to Buy an Idled Steel Works in Texas
LEAD: The USX Corporation wants to sell its idled Texas steel works to Iraq for more than $100 million.
Iraq wants to take the plant apart and ship it home, where it would be reassembled and used to produce pipes for oil production and irrigation.

LEAD: The Spanish Broadcasting System, which owns five Spanish-language radio stations in New York, Los Angeles and Miami, said yesterday that it planned to buy WEVD-FM in New York from the Forward Association.

Swiss Joblessness Low
LEAD: Unemployment in Switzerland, already the lowest in the industralized West, dropped to a six-year low last month, while the number of vacant positions reached a seven-year-high, the authorities said today.
The Federal Office for Industry and Labor said that a total of 20,963 jobless were registered in July, an 8.7 percent drop from the previous month.

Why Fundamentalists Reject 'Last Temptation'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Canada Inflation Rate
LEAD: Canada's annual inflation rate dipped slightly in July despite a surge in the cost of housing, food and transportation, the Government's statistical agency reported today.
Inflation eased to 3.8 percent, from 3.9 percent in June. ''This is the lowest year-to-year increase since June of 1986,'' Statistics Canada said in its monthly commentary.

LEAD: The afternoon began with a smattering of fans scattered through a largely empty stadium.
And it was, if anything, slighty emptier when the evening ended.


The Editorial Notebook; 'The Hippies Really Bug Us'
LEAD: At noon on an August day, the sweet smell of marijuana drifts through Tompkins Square Park.
A pudgy woman tosses crumbs to pigeons; a young man soaps himself in the wading pool; another sleeps in the tattered bandshell. ''There's no more stories.
Everything's been written.
Give us a break!'' a third yells to a woman with a notebook.


3 Hurt as a Highway Chase Ends in Shootouts in Conn.
LEAD: A Connecticut state trooper, a West Haven police officer and the man they were pursuing were wounded yesterday in two shootouts that ended a brief chase on Interstate 95 and through nearby woods in West Haven, the state police said.


Unisys Leaving South Africa
LEAD: The Unisys Corporation, the second-largest American computer company, said today that it had agreed to sell its South African subsidiary to a South African company that has interests in electronics.


Judge Rescinds Term Promised In Swindle Case
LEAD: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan withdrew a promise of a light prison sentence to an admitted swindler yesterday after ruling the defendant had tried to trick him into imposing an even lighter sentence.

The Rowan Case Belongs in Court
LEAD: On June 14, Carl Rowan, the syndicated columnist, shot and slightly wounded an intruder at his Washington home.
As a result, Mr.
Rowan now faces gun possession charges that could bring him two years in jail.
He has pleaded not guilty and calls the decision to prosecute him one that turns ''fairness and the law upside down.

LEAD: ''Learning from the past,'' Burma's new leader, U Maung Maung, once wrote, ''may give us humility and help us grow big.''


Cocoa Plunges on Rumors Of Sales by the Ivory Coast
LEAD: Cocoa futures prices dropped sharply yesterday amid unconfirmed rumors the Ivory Coast had sold some of the 135,000 metric tons it has been withholding from the market.


Some Now in Congress Joined Reserve or Guard
LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana is among at least a dozen members of Congress who, as young men in the Vietnam War era, joined local Reserve or National Guard units and served out military tours near their homes.

LEAD: From the beginning, it was a most unusual project: a work of art and a work of landscape architecture; a kind of miniature wooded city with crisscrossing gravel paths instead of streets and avenues; a living sculpture made of earth and sky, grass and gravel, wind and water, buildings and flowers.

Patents; An Antiperspirant Based on Antihistamines
LEAD: The Bristol-Myers Company has developed an antiperspirant based on antihistamines.
Traditionally, antiperspirants have used aluminum chlorohydrate as the active ingredient, but researchers have long thought that antihistamines - the agents that stifle allergic reactions to pollen - might be more effective.

LEAD:  The Unlicensed Gun


Joseph Barnett, Psychoanalyst, 62
LEAD: Dr.
Joseph Barnett, a psychoanalyst who specialized in the field of personality development, died of heart failure Sunday at the Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital.
He was 62 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I., and Sarasota.


Patents; A Process to Store Aircraft in Shrink-Wrap
LEAD: Shrink-wrap is a taut, tough plastic covering used to package everything from soft drinks to stereo equipment.
This week, James Talbot, co-founder of Fana Inc. of Springfield, Pa., patented a process to store large military aircraft in shrink-wrap.
The Army, Air Force and Marines have begun using the covering for storage of aircraft components, and aircraft manufacturers are considering it for use in shipping.

WALESA THREATENS A STRIKE IN GDANSK
LEAD: Lech Walesa today threatened to stage a strike at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk if the Government refused demands by striking coal miners and dockworkers to legalize the Solidarity union.


Gas Leak in Space Shuttle Is Repaired on Launching Pad
LEAD: Technicians today apparently sealed a gas leak in a steering engine compartment of the space shuttle Discovery, another step toward clearing the space shuttle Discovery for launching in late September or early October.

LEAD: Engineers at the Unocal Corporation have designed a system that makes it easier to tap the energy of geothermal steam.

LEAD: An Iraqi who lost both legs in the eight-year war with Iran being wheeled past a mural in Baghdad depicting President Saddam Hussein with workers and military equipment.

Those New Disposable Contact Lenses
LEAD: Extended-wear soft contact lenses, introduced seven years ago, have been redesigned so that they can be worn for a week or two and then thrown away.
The earlier version has been blamed for a variety of eye problems, but the new lenses promise added safety and convenience.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Tim Perry, the 6-foot-9-inch forward from Temple who was the top draft pick of the Phoenix Suns and the league's seventh pick over all, has agreed to a multiyear contract.
Perry said he had agreed to a five-year guaranteed contract, but would not disclose salary figures.
Sources told The Phoenix Gazette that the contract was worth more than $3.5 million.


NBC and CBS Reduce Role of Self-Censors
LEAD: Two of the nation's television networks took important steps last week to reduce further the internal censorship of the programs they broadcast.
NBC has disbanded its office of broadcast standards and practices, and CBS, which has been steadily diminishing the size of its censorship operation for several years, said it would eliminate the position of vice president of program practices.

LEAD: The dollar finished mixed yesterday in quiet trading, after central banks intervened in the market for the third straight day.

Blasts Rock Gloucester, Mass.
LEAD: A series of about 10 underground explosions ripped through this seacoast city today.
Two houses were damaged and 200 people were forced to evacuate their homes and businesses, but no one was injured.
Fire Chief Barry McKay said the explosions had apparently been caused by gasoline in the sewer system, a result of a petroleum distribution yard's effort to remove a gasoline tank.

LEAD: LCI Communications Inc., a medium-size telecommunications company, has agreed to be acquired by two investment firms, E. M. Warburg, Pincus &amp; Company and Primus Venture Partners, for about $200 million.
The cash transaction includes the Litel Communications Corporation, an LCI subisidary based in Worthington, Ohio.

PRESERVING FOOD AT HOME
LEAD: The tomatoes are beginning to ripen all at once now, and there are more of them than you can use.
Home canning, the traditional answer to the overabundance of summer's harvest, must be done with care to avoid the risk of botulism and other toxins.
Always use only the freshest, firmest unblemished fruits and vegetables.


Peugeot Introduces New Models in U.S.
LEAD: With its minuscule presence in the United States automobile market continuing to decline, the French automobile maker Peugeot S.A., is pinning its hopes for recovery on a new model that Europe has named its car of the year.
The front-wheel-drive Peugeot 405 is being offered in three models, and its base price is $14,500.

LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said that its 1,750-mile All-American Pipeline, which it started building three years ago, would be sold to pay debts.
Goodyear's chairman, Robert E. Mercer, said that while the company was developing a plan for selling the oil pipeline to a group of purchasers, ''no consortium has been formed, no negotiations have been held and no specific terms have been discussed, including price.

The previous $44-a-share offer from Carlyle Investors V Ltd. was rejected by the chemical company, based in Berkeley Heights, N.J.

Lafleur Gets a Shot With the Rangers
LEAD: On Sept. 7, Guy Lafleur will be inducted into the National Hockey League Hall of Fame in Toronto.
Three days later, his place in the sport's history secure, Lafleur will attempt to gain a spot on the Rangers' roster.
The team announced yesterday that it would grant Lafleur a tryout next month when its training camp opens.


Rufus C. Harris, 91, Educator in the South
LEAD: Rufus C. Harris, former president of Mercer and Tulane universities, died Thursday.
He was 91 years old.


Polaroid Says Cuts in Jobs Will Be More Than Planned
LEAD: Looking for ways to cut costs and improve profitability as it prepares for a possible takeover battle, the Polaroid Corporation said today that it wanted to trim its work force by more than it had planned.


Greenwell Drives Red Sox Past A's, 7-6
LEAD: Mike Greenwell took over the major league lead in runs batted in, driving in three tonight, including the game-winner in the seventh inning, to rally the Boston Red Sox past the Oakland Athletics, 7-6.

LEAD: Tony Jones, who isn't even an agent, might have helped Mark Gastineau earn $825,000 this season with the Jets.

LEAD: An Ohio judge dismissed all but one claim today in a $319 million lawsuit filed by the city officials of Norwood, Ohio, against the General Motors Corporation in an effort to block the closing of G.M.'s assembly plant in Norwood.


Pakistanis Quietly Showing Rare Unity After Zia's Death
LEAD: As officials prepare for the funeral of Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, Pakistanis of all regions, creeds and ethnic groups, shocked and subdued by their President's violent death, have been drawn into a rare and perhaps tentative spirit of unity.


International at Yonkers
LEAD: Lou Guida is not very diplomatic when it comes to the $200,000 International Trot on Saturday night at Yonkers Raceway.
Guida doesn't regard any of the six foreign horses as a threat to his Mack Lobell.
All that concerns him is Go Get Lost, the other United States entry in the mile-and-a-quarter race.

LEAD: A land mine destroyed a military bus carrying British soldiers to their barracks tonight, killing seven soldiers and wounding 29 others, the police said.

Sir Frederick Ashton, 83, Dies, Ending a Choreographic Era
LEAD: Sir Frederick Ashton, one of the greatest Classical choreographers of the 20th century and a former director of the Royal Ballet, died in his sleep Thursday night at his home in Sussex, England.
He was 83 years old.
Sir Frederick's death brings to a close an era in ballet shaped and presided over by three great innovators: George Balanchine, Antony Tudor and Sir Frederick.


No Green Card, No Day Care
LEAD: There are three women in Arlington, Va. - a teacher, an artist, a secretary - all married, each with a young child.
They are able to work because they share a baby sitter.
Maria, the sitter, comes from Latin America, has two children of her own, a year of paid experience, great warmth and no visa.

Nowadays, the more astute municipal-bond investors constantly re-examine their holdings to see whether bond swapping might be in order.

The second and more important criterion relates to the impact of the trade on the teams involved.

A $200,000 Slip-Up
LEAD: A design error will force workers to take down and rebuild the center section of a partly completed $16 million bridge near downtown Minneapolis.
The mistake will cost up to $200,000, take three to four weeks to correct and force an overnight shutting of Interstate highway ramps.
Al Pint of the Minnesota Department of Transportation said the state's design consultant inadvertently included a rise in camber in a 30-foot section of the bridge, which is more than a half-mile long.

The Life of a Fisherman's Mate
LEAD: I AM up at daybreak, filling the old metal thermos with fresh coffee, the red and yellow jugs with juice.
Efficiently I pack the cooler: ham and cheese for the men, tuna salad for the girls, chips and Oreos for the kids.
I remember the light beer for my Dad, the Coors for my Coloradan husband and the diet soda for myself.

LEAD: To the Editor:


SOUND
LEAD: When compact disks made their first appearance, everyone marveled at their dynamic range.
For the first time in the history of recorded sound, it was possible to hear the entire span from pianissimo to triple forte.
The merest whispers could be captured in all their delicacy, and at the other end of the scale, orchestral thunder would burst forth undiminished.

Readings compiled last week by the Environmental Protection Agency confirmed that ozone in urban areas has been at its highest levels of the decade.

It was not this way during the summer nights of my childhood.
The heat was noticed, and I well remember those nights.

Nuclear Phobia Over Shoreham
LEAD: NUCLEAR power plants have generally performed safely during the last 34 years, with only one major accident, at Chernobyl in the Soviet Union, and one minor accident, at Three Mile Island in the United States.
Since 1954, 408 nuclear power plants worldwide have had more than 4,500 reactor-years of safe operation.

ROUGH PASSAGE
LEAD: Tom Wicker's rough passage could have been foretold.
Any good sailor knows that you do not change the name of your ship.
A ship is christened only once, or else the sea gods become unhappy.
Perhaps the son has a lesson or two yet to learn from his father.
PATRICK R. DIXON  San Marino, Calif.

POSTINGS: Conversion on East 66th Multiple Choices
LEAD: At the conversion of 301 East 66th Street, the sponsor is offering outside buyers 22,000 possibilities.

While an option package is as common in new construction as in new cars, it is unusual in the conversion of older buildings.

Taping Between Drywall Panels
LEAD: ALTHOUGH gypsum wallboard, more often called drywall, is much easier to apply than plaster, one part of the process is a common stumbling block: sealing the seams between panels with drywall tape.
This is a crucial step in finishing a surface, because if done poorly the taped seams are difficult to disguise by sanding and painting.

LEAD: Driven by strong demand for showroom space, Chicago's 24-story, 4.2-million-square-foot Merchandise Mart - the world's largest wholesale buying center under one roof - is undergoing a $100 million, 10-year renovation.
It is the first major renovation of the building, which was put up in 1929.

LEAD: LONG ISLAND, you had your second chance and you blew it.

LEAD: The Massachuetts system for the mentally ill, now in the midst of a five-year overhaul, is being faulted for poor care and unsafe conditions by legislators, patient advocates and mental health professionals and administrators.

LEAD: WHEREAS the 20-year-old Jacques Brel musical with the unwieldy title hammered away at its themes through songs, dispensing with a standard ''book,'' the new Brel musical at the John Drew Theater in East Hampton through Saturday - ''Jacques Brel Blues,'' it is called - talks itself into oblivion.

The Winner in the Straw Vote
LEAD: Think of straw hats as romantic reminders of earlier, easier times.
Or think of them as portable shade, which these days can qualify as a priceless commodity.
Better still, don't think of them at all; just sit back and enjoy their grace and beauty, the sweep of those wide brims decorated with flowers or ribbons like something from a Degas or a Renoir.

LEAD: An article about Leonard Bernstein on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect time for part of the Tanglewood gala honoring him.
The final program, which he will conduct, is scheduled for next Sunday at 2:30 P.M., not in the evening.

LEAD: The Mariners looked at the lineup the Yankees sent to their clubhouse last night and laughed.
Claudell Washington was listed at first base, Don Mattingly as the right fielder and Ken Phelps as the left fielder.
It all turned out to be a mistake, though, and eventually a corrected lineup was relayed to the clubhouse.

Now I feel younger at seventy than I did at sixty. . . .

The 13-member commission would have the power to require labeling of some classic films that have been altered by coloring or other technology.

Trade Deficit Takes Turn for the Worse
LEAD: The trade deficit worsened in June, coming in at $12.5 billion, the largest since February.
Imports in June rose 5.7 percent, to $39.3 billion, and exports fell 2.4 percent, to $26.8 billion.
That was taken as a sign that the American economy, and its appetite for foreign goods, remains strong, perhaps strong enough to persuade the Fed that it must further tighten up on the money supply.

LEAD: The publishing industry witnessed further consolidation last week when Random House Inc. agreed to buy the Crown Publishing Group.
Once an industry made up of dozens of independent, family-run companies, book publishing is now dominated by six major companies: Advance Publications, Hearst, MCA, the Pearson Group, Bertlesmann A.G.

Woody Plants for Summer Blossoms
LEAD: THE recent hot spell delayed lawn work especially seeding or sodding of new lawns; since cooler growing weather is coming next month, major lawn work can now be organized; for established lawns continue setting mowers to cut high - at least two inches - to encourage deep root growth.
If they have finished blooming, dig carefully, divide roots and replant day lilies, phlox, astilbes and other spring-blooming perennials.


A Man for the Ages on Staten Island

He has been Staten Island's official historian since 1934, and his research has helped to preserve its heritage.

Reviews/Music; Chicago Group in Premiere of Mozart Scoring
LEAD: If the string quartet and the orchestra had largely aristocratic ties in Mozart's day, the wind band was a more populist and adaptable ensemble, as much at home in a parade or a concert in the town square as in a more intimate salon performance.
The Chicago Symphony Winds have been specializing in this literature for a decade, and at a Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening the group and a half-dozen guest singers and players presented an ample selection of Mozart's music for variously configured wind ensembles.

LEAD: THE sad plight of the savings industry has recently become front-page news.

Noted With Pleasure

Taping Between Drywall Panels
LEAD: ALTHOUGH gypsum wallboard, more often called drywall, is much easier to apply than plaster, one part of the process is a common stumbling block: sealing the seams between panels with drywall tape.
This is a crucial step in finishing a surface, because if done poorly the taped seams are difficult to disguise by sanding and painting.


College Denied Liquor License
LEAD: The Boston Licensing Board Thursday rejected Boston College's petition for a license to serve alcohol at its Alumni Stadium football field and in the Silvio O. Conte Arena.
At a hearing on the petition Wednesday, residents of Newton and the Brighton section of Boston near the college asked that the license be denied.

THE NATION: Pro &amp; Con: Do the Poor Benefit?; What a Minimum Wage Does to the Economy
LEAD: SINCE 1938, when the Government required employers to pay their workers at least 25 cents an hour, periodic challenges to the New Deal idea of a statutory minimum wage - which now stands at $3.35 an hour - have rarely amounted to more than academic exercises.
This year, things could be different.
Committees in the House and Senate have cleared legislation that would raise the minimum for the first time since 1981.

Premature Praise?
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Computer As Carry-On Bag
LEAD: COMPUTERS you can take with you - variously called notebooks, laptops and portables, depending on size, features and marketing strategies - are enjoying a boom in sales.
Although they can serve just as space savers on a cramped office or home desk, since they usually take up less room than conventional desktop machines and can easily be packed away when they're not needed, presumably most portables are bought to be taken along on business or vacation trips.

INDIA'S SOUL FOOD
LEAD: TO AN INDIAN FAMILY, THE tandoori meal is not just food.
Like Sunday supper for some Americans, this meal is the high point of the week.
I remember gathering with my family and friends in cool breezes at an outdoor concert in New Delhi under tamarind and mango trees.
There, we would dig a pit to smoke, grill and roast chicken and meat.

LEAD: The last balloon has been swept from the Superdome, the last hangover attended to, the last rhetorical cannon spiked.
With a gavel's bang Thursday night, the long and largely unedifying process by which America selects its Presidential candidates came to a merciful end.
Two candidates survive, one to be chosen.

LEAD: Coach Bobby Bowden of Florida State said he would rather be top-ranked at season's end than at the beginning, but yesterday, he gladly accepted his team's first No. 1 ranking in The Associated Press's preseason college football poll.

Buy Out Steinbrenner
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Taping Between Drywall Panels
LEAD: ALTHOUGH gypsum wallboard, more often called drywall, is much easier to apply than plaster, one part of the process is a common stumbling block: sealing the seams between panels with drywall tape.
This is a crucial step in finishing a surface, because if done poorly the taped seams are difficult to disguise by sanding and painting.

LEAD: Mill Native, a 40-1 long shot, roared past Equalize through the stretch today to win the Arlington Million in track-record time at Woodbine.


IDEAS &amp; TRENDS: Beyond the Droughts; The Green Revolution: How Much Farther Can It Go?
LEAD: BY the end of the fall harvest, world grain supplies could be the tightest since World War II.
While the Department of Agriculture says there is little danger that the world will run out of food, some experts outside the Government insist that the extent of the damage is being seriously understated.


Ideas for Tomatoes, Even Green Ones
LEAD: AT last, real tomatoes are back.
Though fancy shops have taken to stocking them all winter long, tomatoes from hydroponic farms in Israel and the Netherlands never taste like the sun-ripened ones from your garden or the farm down the road.
As for those pale pink numbers from Florida, we won't even discuss them.

Airliner's Tires Blow Out
LEAD: An Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 jet blew two tires today as it landed and skidded to a stop at National Airport, but none of the 156 people aboard was injured, officials said.

Safety Remains Elusive at Morrell
LEAD: JUST after she took the job last summer, Carri Lee Miller knew it was a mistake.
Her hands would ache after every day at Morrell's meatpacking house here, where she sometimes had to make 1,900 cuts an hour on the hogs' heads that passed by her station.
At night, she would wake up in pain with her fingers clenched in a fist that she could not open alone.


Tuning In the Universe Sites
LEAD: THE RADIO TELESCOPE, WHICH makes pictures from the radio waves emitted by distant objects (as opposed to the optical telescope, which focuses on light waves) has been with us since World War II.
It has revealed previously undetected entities in the universe and, because radio waves are not distorted by the earth's atmosphere to the degree that light waves are, it has the potential to unveil the clearest possible images of astronomical phenomena.

Norway Arsonist Set 62 Fires
LEAD: The police say they have arrested a man who admitted setting 62 fires in three years, an arson record in Norway.
No one was injured in the fires, which caused an estimated $15 million damage.
The 36-year-old man told investigators he had used paper and a lighter to start the fires, always on weekends.

LEAD: A series of about 10 underground explosions, apparently caused by gasoline in the sewer system, ripped through this seacoast city today.

Florida-Bound in a Behemoth

The Shadow of a Stranger
LEAD: IN OUR AREA, Michael Ross is a household name.
It rides past you on people's bumpers (''Electric Fry Michael Ross'').
It calls to you from headlines and editorials about capital punishment.
Recently I heard it used as a grim verb by one of my high school students.
He was describing to a friend the plot of a movie he had rented: ''Then this guy took this girl out to a pond and he Michael Rossed her.

Answering the Mail
LEAD: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months.

We tried scouring powder, then fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years).

Taping Between Drywall Panels
LEAD: ALTHOUGH gypsum wallboard, more often called drywall, is much easier to apply than plaster, one part of the process is a common stumbling block: sealing the seams between panels with drywall tape.
This is a crucial step in finishing a surface, because if done poorly the taped seams are difficult to disguise by sanding and painting.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Spain may have to raise its inflation target of 3 percent for the year, after an unexpectedly sharp rise in the consumer price index.
The index rose 1.3 percent in July, which puts inflation so far this year at 2.9 percent.
That compared with monthly rises of four-tenths of 1 percent in June and 1 percent in July last year.

News from Nee-kha-rahg-wah
LEAD: It's becoming fashionable among TV and radio correspondents on the scene and politicians in Washington to pronounce Nicaragua the way the Nicaraguans do.
Other countries south of the border get standard American treatment - mex-ih-co not meh-hee-co, bruh-zill not brah-seel, chilly not chee-lay.
But the standard nicka-rahg-wuh often comes out nee-kha-rahg-wah, rolling the r and curling the g.

British Inflation Rate Up
LEAD: Britain's inflation rate edged up to 4.8 percent in July from 4.6 percent in June, the Employment Department said Friday.
The retail price index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in the month, mostly from higher prices of cars, driving insurance, non-seasonal food, electricity and gas, the department said.

Fujitsu D-RAM's
LEAD: Fujitsu Ltd. said it would become the first Japanese company to produce one-megabit dynamic random access memory microchips, known as D-RAM's, in the United States.
The company said that its Fujitsu Microelectronics subsidiary would upgrade a plant now under construction in Gresham, Ore.
Fujitsu said its strategy stems from an unexpected shortage of D-RAM's, a key electronics component.

To Complete the Look
LEAD: The horizontally striped shirt is a strange animal.
It's a shirt maker's shirt, unusual to the eye and unforgiving to the wearer.

LEAD: The Chemical Banking Corporation, formerly the Chemical New York Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 1/2 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.87 to yield 9.55 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
For purposes of investment, the four-year notes are noncallable and yield about 67-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
