LEAD: MOST hospitals have historically been operated as not-for-profit institutions, but in recent years some have formed subsidiaries and begun new businesses to make money and supply badly needed revenue to the parent.

Review/Music; Celebrating Cage in All His Variety

Cage at its free Friday and Saturday evening Summergarden concerts, and Lincoln Center joined the party on Saturday with two free concerts in its Out-of-Doors series.


Showers Fall in Midwest; Grain Contracts Plummet
LEAD: Prices of soybean, corn and oat futures plummeted their permitted daily limits on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday in reaction to rainfall in Iowa and weak foreign demand for American grain and soybean products.
Wheat futures also closed sharply lower.





Gen. Lewis A. Mologne, 56, Hospital Chief
LEAD: Maj.
Gen.
Lewis A. Mologne, commander of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, died yesterday of cancer at the center.
He was 56 years old and lived in Washington.


Tiny Snail Is Credited as a Force Shaping the Coast
LEAD: TO a surprising extent, the rock-bound New England coast may be the work of a relatively recent interloper from Europe.
The interloper, a dime-sized brown snail called the periwinkle, was introduced in Nova Scotia almost 150 years ago, and, according to researchers, it has been working its way south ever since, slowly turning muddy marsh areas into cobbled beaches.


His Bold Statement Transforms the Debate On Greenhouse Effect
LEAD: SITTING in his office near the Columbia University campus, seven floors above the internal combustion of fossil fuel along Broadway, James E. Hansen held a large pair of what he called loaded dice.
He was making a point last week about the probabilities of drastic climate change as a result of the greenhouse effect.

LEAD: The political air of Pakistan is suddenly full of hope and challenge.

LEAD: Robert Speidel, the Rutgers linebacker who is facing criminal and university charges stemming from his role in an alcohol-related car accident in May, withdrew from training camp yesterday.
If he is convicted, Speidel could face a sentence of up to 30 years in prison and a $100,000 fine and expulsion from Rutgers.

They also bespeak a cavalier attitude toward the heat.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court upheld a lower court ruling that blocked Swiss-based Gurit-Heberlein A.G.'s takeover offer for the Essex Chemical Corporation.

17 Prison Guards Suspended
LEAD: Seventeen Trenton State Prison guards were suspended with pay after refusing to submit to urine tests for drug use, Corrections Department officials said today.
And another officer was suspended after he was accused of selling cocaine on the street.
The actions are part of a wider investigation into drug activity among the prison's guards, said a department spokesman, James Stabile.

How Pigeons Navigate
LEAD: The view that homing piegons can use the magnetic field of the Earth to find their way has been challenged by experiments involving 659 birds set free in 35 releases.
Some had magnets attached, to counteract the Earth's magnetism, and they did just as well as those without magnets.

Particle Accelerator Hindered by Defects

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Why do men have nipples?
A.
The presence of nipples and other breast tissue in men ''exemplifies the fact that the basic body plan of men and women is similar,'' according to Dr.
Bruce McEwen, an expert on sex hormones. ''There are exaggerations in each sex based on early development and later hormonal influence,'' he said.

LEAD: The creator of the bankrupt Sasson jeans empire surrendered yesterday and was ordered held without bail for violating an agreement that had freed him while he awaited trial on a charge he threatened a judge's life.

A Correction
LEAD: An editorial, ''The News From Peary,'' on Sept. 7, 1909, acclaimed the discovery of the North Pole after this cable was received from Robert E. Peary: ''I have the Pole.'' The Times asserted that further proof was unnecessary, given Peary's reputation.
The editorial also took note of the contested claim of Dr.


Merger in Apparel
LEAD: The Russell Corporation, a maker of athletic and sports apparel, and Quality Mills Inc., a North Carolina apparel maker, said today that they had reached an agreement under which Russell will acquire Quality.
Under the deal Russell will exchange either 1.2 of its shares or $18.30 for each Quality share.

WRIGHT TO START FOR PACKERS
LEAD: Randy Wright was awarded the Green Bay Packers' quarterback job by Coach Lindy Infante yesterday, but another long-time starter, Neal Lomax of the Phoenix Cardinals, found his position in a bit of jeopardy.


Fire in Amtrak Engine
LEAD: Amtrak service was back to normal today after service between New York and Washington was blocked for four hours by a fire Sunday night in the locomotive of a passenger train heading for Washington from New York, officials said.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD: MARKETS  The dollar surged higher against the mark and other European currencies, but the rise was curtailed by coordinated dollar selling by the Federal Reserve, the Bundesbank and eight other central banks.
Though the intervention was broader than last week's, traders said the effects of the move might wear off quickly.


Dow Reaches Lowest Level Since May
LEAD: The prices of stocks continued a pattern of Monday listlessness yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 25.78 points in exceptionally slow trading.
The drop brought the blue-chip index to 1,990.22, its lowest closing level since May 27.

LEAD: Temperatures fell, the wind died down and the Army arrived yesterday, improving conditions for the weary crews battling forest fires that have charred thousands of acres of Montana and Wyoming, especially in Yellowstone National Park.

LEAD: At first, Irv Klein hired a few retarded adults to work at his 13 McDonald's as a do-gooder thing.
But soon he realized that the retarded handled Lot and Lobby, Happy Meals and Salad Bar beautifully and that they didn't go quitting on him in a few months, as teen-agers did.


Judge Issues 2 Bench Warrants To Jail Kenmore Hotel Operators
LEAD: Two operators of the Kenmore Hotel, one of the largest remaining single-room-occupancy residences in New York City, were sentenced yesterday in Manhattan Civil Court to from 15 to 20 days in jail for refusing to correct violations and make repairs.


Harvey of St. John's Ineligible
LEAD: The Redmen of St.
John's, whose 17-12 record last basketball season was largely fashioned through the speedy and agile backcourt performances of Michael Porter and Greg (Boo) Harvey, announced yesterday that Harvey had been declared academically ineligible for the fall semester.
He will miss at least seven games at the beginning of the season.

POLAND DECLARES EMERGENCY RULES TO QUELL STRIKES
LEAD: The Polish Government moved tonight to curb a wave of labor turmoil that has shaken the country for seven days, imposing special security measures on three regions where strikes are under way.

P.&amp;G. Brazil Deal
LEAD: The Procter &amp; Gamble Company said it had agreed to buy a controlling interest in Perfumeria Phebo S.A., a Brazilian cleaning and personal-care products company, for about $70 million.
While P.&amp;G. has extensive dealings in Latin America, the purchase would mark its first asset ownership in Brazil, the company said.

Enough on the Guard, More on Quayle
LEAD: The controversy grows over Senator Dan Quayle's decision to enlist in the National Guard in 1969, thereby reducing the threat of his exposure to combat in Vietnam.
But the furor may now threaten useful inquiry into other aspects of the Quayle nomination and risk reopening wounds of the Vietnam era long since closed.


Review/Music; A Haydn Program, All in D Major
LEAD: To Kurt Masur and the Israel Philharmonic fell the privilege of representing Haydn's most popular symphonic work in the Mostly Mozart festival's Haydn Week at Avery Fisher Hall.
They played the ''father of the symphony's'' 104th child, by traditional count, and in any case his last, the ''London'' in D Major.

Wild-Card Entries
LEAD: The United States Tennis Association announced yesterday that 16 players from this country, eight men and eight women, have been awarded wild-card entries into the singles draws of the United States Open, which will start Monday at the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows, Queens.
The women are Carrie Cunningham, Elise Burgin, Debbie Graham, Beth Herr, Stacy Martin, Laxmi Poruri, Jennifer Santrock and Shaun Stafford.

Sutcliffe Explains
LEAD: Rick Sutcliffe said yesterday that reports the Chicago Cubs were thinking about trading him were a misunderstanding. ''It was my agent, Barry Axelrod, who had asked the Cubs about the clause in my contract concerning what eight teams I would not play for, and not the Cubs who made the request,'' Sutcliffe said.

An Intruder, Bleeding, Dies Trying to Scale a Rail Fence
LEAD: A homeless man apparently bled to death early yesterday after he slashed his arms and wrists while trying to scale a fence rimmed with razor wire, the Transit Authority reported.


Cuba Data Curbs Ended
LEAD: Restrictions on importing and exporting books, films, phonograph records and other informational material to and from Cuba are eliminated by the trade bill signed into law yesterday by President Reagan.
The ban also applied to newspapers, posters, photographs, microfilms, microfiche and tapes.

First Sea Water Battery
LEAD: The Norwegian state oil company, Statoil, said today that it had discovered a way to provide power on the ocean floor without using miles of expensive cable.
The company said it would install the world's first commercial sea water battery in a project connected with an oilfield development off central Norway.

Tyson Hurt in Scuffle  Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, injured his right hand in a scuffle with Mitch Green, another boxer.


Interco Files Suit On Takeover Bid
LEAD: Interco Inc. has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court here accusing groups led by Steven and Mitchell Rales of Washington of violating securities laws in their $2.7 billion bid for the retail company.
The lawsuit, filed against the Cardinal Acquisition Corporation and City Capital Associates L.P., contends that the $70-a-share offer involves so much debt and so little equity that it would, if consummated, violate Federal margin regulations.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
American Greetings Corp., Cleveland, said a director, Samuel J. Krasney, had resigned to prevent any conflict that could arise because of the seat he holds on the board of Revco D.S., which is a major American Greetings retail account.
Revco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on July 28.


A Long, Dry Summer Promises Fine Wines
LEAD: THROUGHOUT the Middle West, long hot days devoid of rain have stunted the fields of corn that cover so much of the landscape.
But the drought has not been a disaster for all growers in the region.
For some wine makers, the unusual weather may result in a better-than-usual product.


Koch Orders Agencies to Prepare Budget Cuts
LEAD: Spurned by both Albany and the City Council in his requests for tax increases to hire more police officers to fight drugs, Mayor Koch yesterday ordered nearly all city agencies to prepare to trim 1.5 percent from their current budgets as a way to finance his $110 million anti-drug plan.


Education; Judge Orders Bankrupt School to Close
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge has ordered Bishop College, a 108-year-old predominantly black school, to close because it failed to come up with the $1.85 million needed to cover its 1988-89 deficit.

LEAD: Dan Quayle's enlistment in the Indiana National Guard in 1969 was handled by high-level Guard officials, apparently without the knowledge of his unit's commanding officer.

LEAD:  Marinated Green Beans and Yellow Peppers  Preparation time: 15 minutes  Cooking time: 10 minutes  1 pound green beans  1 large yellow sweet bell pepper  6 tablespoons olive oil  2 tablespoons tarragon vinegar or other white-wine vinegar

Courtnall's a Capital
LEAD: Because an arbitrator ruled that the bylaws and contracts of the National Hockey League are subject only to the interpretation of its president, a 26-year-old forward has become the property of the Washington Capitals.
Geoff Courtnall, a left wing who played out his option with the Edmonton Oilers in May and as a free agent signed an offer sheet with the Rangers, went to the Capitals after a ruling by John Ziegler, the league president, who said that a team could trade its right to match an offer for a free agent who was formerly its property.

LEAD: The Navy said today that it had charged a warship captain with failing to obey standing orders by refusing adequate assistance to a boat carrying Vietnamese refugees, many of whom later died of exposure and starvation.

LEAD: Two health organizations asked the Government today to require that AIDS-related drugs and vaccines developed with Federal assistance be made readily available to patients at the lowest possible prices.


Dow Slips 0.89 as Low Volume Continues
LEAD: The prices of stocks finished slightly lower yesterday as volume remained at the slow pace of recent days.


Review/Pop; Wonder's World Of Peace
LEAD: Stevie Wonder is a pop creator whose concerts are more than just musical events.
The concentrated power of his musical personality and his integration of a sweeping variety of idioms into an indelible style, along with his charisma and enthusiasm, combine to make his concerts communal celebrations at which divisions of race, class and nationality melt away.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Ali Haji-Sheikh was cut by the Washington Redskins yesterday, even though he did not miss an extra point or field-goal attempt during the preseason.
His job was in jeopardy from the start of training camp because the Redskins' top draft choice was Chip Lohmiller. . . .
The New England Patriots said they intend to place the quarterback Tony Eason on the injured reserve list next week, because he has not recovered sufficiently from off-season surgery on his throwing arm.

LEAD: Wade Carroll Stephens, the director of studies at the Lawrenceville School, a coeducational New Jersey boarding school, died of a heart attack Sunday while vacationing in Ogunquit, Me.
He was 55 years old and lived on the Lawrenceville campus.

LEAD: Last year a Federal court finally smashed a milk dealers' cartel, handing consumers an immediate benefit in the form of lower milk prices.
But now that victory appears threatened: the dealers' cartel could be replaced by a dairy farmers' cartel.

Jail's Robots Tough, but Not Bulletproof
LEAD: Officials of Alameda County, across the bay from San Francisco, are borrowing technology from the computerized factory to help automate a new jail.
Robot carts will be used to feed the 3,000 prisoners.
The carts, which will be 2 feet wide, 7 feet long and 17 inches high, will be guided by computers and will follow magnetized wires embedded in the roadway.


Mets Getting Back On Winning Track
LEAD: The Mets, who still deny that they can ''turn it on,'' turned it on again tonight and beat the Los Angeles Dodgers for the second straight game, 5-1.


Hans G. Adler, 78; Survived Nazis
LEAD: Hans Gunther Adler, a scholar and German-language author who wrote about his experiences in Nazi concentration camps, died of heart failure Sunday at the Mead Bank Nursing Home in Battersea, England, his son, Jeremy, said.
He was 78 years old.
Mr.
Adler won the Leo Baeck Prize, a major Jewish award, in 1958 for his first major work, ''Theresienstadt 1941-45.

LEAD: Here he is, Kirk Douglas, 71 years old now, his dimpled chin still very much intact, sitting in a friend's East Side apartment.
The star of ''Champion,'' ''Lust for Life,'' ''Spartacus,'' ''Lonely Are the Brave,'' ''Paths of Glory'' and many other films.
The actor the French nicknamed la Brute Cherie (the Darling Brute).

LEAD: Representative Mike Synar today defeated a primary challenger who labeled the five-term Democrat too liberal for his largely rural district in northeast Oklahoma.

LEAD: Time-Life Books, Alexandria, Va., has assigned Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis, to handle seven titles in its Time-Life library.
The seven-figure budget will cover the Epic of Flight; Time Frame, a history of the world; the Kodak Library of Photography; Gardener's Guide; Vietnam Video; World War II Video, and Victory at Sea Video.

Judge Approves Revco Financing
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge approved $145 million in financing for Revco D.S.
Inc., a drugstore chain that sought protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code last month.
The package approved by Judge Harold White puts trade creditors and bank creditors ahead of all other parties - including unsecured creditors, bondholders and shareholders - to be paid should the company be liquidated.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  BASEBALL  Taiwan Team Rallies: Tai Chung, Taiwan, was on the verge yesterday of being the first Far East team to be knocked out of the Little League World Series in the first round since 1970.
But Taiwan came back from a 4-0 deficit to defeat Curundu, Panama, 5-4, in Williamsport, Pa.
Jui-Cheng Chen, the winning pitcher, reached base on an infield hit with two out in the bottom of the sixth to cap a two-run rally and to drive in the winning run.

LEAD: Prices of soybean futures tumbled to a 12-week low of $8.07 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday in reaction to rain and cooler weather in the drought-stricken Midwest.
Corn and oat futures also declined, but wheat advanced.


The Olympic Flame Heads for South Korea
LEAD: A runner carrying the Olympic torch through Olympia, Greece, shortly after it was lighted by mirror-amplified rays of sun.
Tomorrow, the flame will be flown to South Korea, where it will be used Sept. 17 in the opening ceremony of the Summer Games. (AP)

LEAD: HOW long does it take to roll rice into a won-ton wrapper?


Review/Television; Gregory Peck: Snippets of 40 Years
LEAD: In the obligatory opening montage of ''Gregory Peck - His Own Man,'' two glimpses of the actor in the 1940's leap out of the jumble of scenes from films as different as ''Roman Holiday,'' ''Moby Dick'' and ''The Omen.'' Here, in ''Gentleman's Agreement'' and ''Spellbound,'' is the young Gregory Peck staring into the camera: dark wavy hair, nearly gaunt cheeks, eyes that threaten to burn through the screen.


Forfeiture of Profit in Pentagon Fraud Cases Urged
LEAD: Leaders of the House Armed Services Committee called on the Pentagon today to require its suppliers to agree to forfeit profits on any contract that is found to have been won through fraud.


Bell Atlantic Names Successor to Its Chief
LEAD: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that Raymond W. Smith, president and chief operating officer, would succeed Thomas E. Bolger as chief executive when he retires on Dec. 31.
Mr.
Bolger, 61 years old, will remain chairman for a transition period into 1989, Bell Atlantic said.

Restore Bus Service to the Williamsburg Bridge
LEAD: To the Editor:


Olympics; Controversy Over Coe's Status Grows
LEAD: The president of the national governing body for track and field in the United States, Dr.
Leroy Walker, yesterday questioned the possibility that Sebastian Coe of Britain would be allowed to participate in the Seoul Olympics as a ''wild-card'' entry.


BUSH WEAK ON LAW, DUKAKIS ASSERTS
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis charged today that Vice President Bush's insistence that schoolchildren be required to recite the Pledge of Allegiance suggested that Mr.
Bush did not understand the Constitution well enough to be fit to be President.


Robots to Make Fast Food Chains Still Faster
LEAD: Restaurant industry experts are predicting that the fast food business will undergo a technological revolution in the next few years that will place increasing numbers of robots and other labor-saving devices in the kitchens.
The machines will flip hamburgers, bag french fries, spread pizza dough, fry chicken, bake biscuits, stuff burritos and deliver drive-in orders to cars in about half the time and at about half the cost that human workers require.


6,000 AIDS Patients Face Cutoff Of Drug That May Prolong Lives
LEAD: The expiration next month of a $30 million Federal grant to buy a costly drug against AIDS will jeopardize the ability of 6,000 patients around the country to continue receiving the treatment, which may prolong their lives.

Philips Units' Sale
LEAD: Cambridge Electronic Industries said it had agreed to acquire two American electronic component businesses from the North American Philips Corporation for about $54 million.
North American Philips is the United States subsidiary of Philips N.V. of the Netherlands.


Kelly to Resign Oct. 1 As Chairman of Beatrice
LEAD: Donald P. Kelly, the 66-year-old executive who led a $6.2 billion leveraged buyout of the Beatrice Company in 1986, will resign as Beatrice's chairman on Oct. 1, the company said today.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Portland, Ore., branch of the Bank of Tokyo Ltd. yesterday began offering $50 million of 9 3/8 percent deposit notes, due in 1991, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.

Back to the N.B.A.
LEAD: Bill Musselman, whose extensive resume includes a Big Ten Conference championship and more than 100 N.C.A.A. rules violations at the University of Minnesota in the 1970's, was named yesterday as the first head coach of the Minnesota Timberwolves, a National Basketball Association expansion franchise that will begin play in the 1989-90 season.


At Ellis Island, Another Kind of Sunken Treasure
LEAD: Divers trying to raise the once-famous Ellis Island Ferry, which sank in its slip in 1964, 10 years after it was put out of service.
All that remains of the boat that carried thousands of immigrants to the reception center on Ellis Island is the hull lying a few feet below the surface of New York Harbor.

U.N. Panel Says Iraq Used Gas on Civilians
LEAD: United Nations inspectors said today that Iraq used poison gas against Iranian civilians in a bombing raid earlier this month, before the two sides accepted a cease-fire in the eight-year-old Persian Gulf war.


Just One Under Par In the Metropolitan
LEAD: Although the rough is short and the greens are huge, only one player, Tom Joyce of Glen Oaks, was able to break par in the first round of the Metropolitan Open at historic Baltusrol Golf club today.


New Consolidated Chief Will Keep Store's Style
LEAD: In a 30-year career with seven different retailers, James M. Guinan has discovered the secret to a successful store is no different for Bloomingdale's than for Pic 'n Save.


Why Angelenos' Weekends Are Easier
LEAD: ONE of the distinct differences between the West Coast and the East - specifically between the rival metropolises of Los Angeles and New York City - is the observance of weekends.
We vacate differently, especially during these hot months.
This was made apparent to me in my first and only year of college in New York, when the locals fled on Friday night leaving behind a city of hot, deserted


Taylor Files Report
LEAD: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants linebacker, has filed a traffic report with the police in Morristown, N.J., recounting the events that prompted him to dent the door of a truck after a traffic incident last week.


A Cheer And a Challenge
LEAD: There is still enough bad news to fill the headlines - earthquakes, tribal massacres, terrorism and such.
But something is happening in the world, a movement away from the fist and the gun.
It remains true in many places, as Mao Zedong proclaimed, that ''power comes from the barrel of the gun.'' But the notion is also spreading that such power has limited use and sooner or later brings only unsatisfactory results.

Cigna to Sell Horace Mann for $500 Million
LEAD: The Cigna Corporation agreed today to sell the Horace Mann Companies, a personal insurance company that sells mainly to teachers, for about $500 million in cash to a group led by the leveraged buyout firm Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd.


Dropout Program Is Sought At Elementary School Level
LEAD: New York City will begin shifting some of its dropout-prevention resources from high schools to the elementary grades, the Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, said yesterday.


Education; Lessons
LEAD: If computer programming colleges, truck driving academies and other profit-making trade schools did not exist, politicians and journalists would have to invent them.


Insilco Talks To Another Suitor
LEAD: The Insilco Corporation said it had talked with another potential purchaser of the diversified industrial company.
Insilco, which did not name the potential suitor, has received a $29-a-share offer from a management-led group, ISC Holdings Inc.
The company said that it continued to provide information to other parties and that it could not assure that a transaction would result from the new talks.


Tootsie Roll Pact
LEAD: Tootsie Roll Industries said it had agreed to buy the Charms Company, a private candy maker, for $65 million in cash.
The proposed transaction is expected to be completed by October, the company said.
Charms, based in Colts Neck, N.J., had sales of about $38 million in 1987 and a pretax income of about $3 million.

Xerox Spins Off Intelligence Unit
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation has spun off its artificial-intelligence business as an independent company, the Envos Corporation.
Envos, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., will be owned by its employees, with Xerox and a British affiliate holding minority stakes.


British Economy Gains
LEAD: Britain's economy grew at a faster-than-expected 1.3 percent rate in the second quarter from the first quarter, the Government said today.
The country's inflation-adjusted gross domestic product, measured by the total output of goods and services, rose 5.1 percent from the second quarter of 1987, the Central Statistics Office said.


Ex-Aides Assail Depiction of Johnson as Paranoid
LEAD: Charges by a former White House aide that Lyndon B. Johnson displayed paranoid and irrational behavior as President have provoked criticism and hostility from several other officials who served in the Johnson Administration.


New Doskocil Bid Urged by Wilson
LEAD: The Wilson Foods Corporation, facing a takeover threat by the Doskocil Companies, said it was willing to discuss the possibility of an improved offer that could lead to a friendly merger.


Traffic Official Named to Head Medical Agency
LEAD: Thomas B. Doyle, the head of traffic control at the New York City Department of Transportation, was named yesterday to run the Emergency Medical Service, which has been the subject of widespread criticism.


Cocaine Glut Pulls New York Market Into Drug Rings' Tug-of-War
LEAD: Experts believe that the war between the world's two largest cocaine-trafficking organizations over the New York market is a result of a worldwide glut of cocaine and a decision by one of the cartels that it can no longer afford to stay out of the nation's most lucrative drug market.


Review/Film; Love, In the Style Of Lelouch
LEAD: The enduring appeal of Claude Lelouch's film ''A Man and a Woman'' is largely due to its aura of head-over-heels love.
However problematic the romance and sentimental the story, falling in love seemed spontantous and irresistible, beyond anyone's control.
Mr.
Lelouch has tried and tried in the 22 years since to recapture that film's easy allure (most blatantly in ''A Man and a Woman: 20 Years Later'') but the job seems to get tougher and tougher.


Alien Farm Workers Win Fight Against I.N.S.
LEAD: A Federal judge here has ruled that the Immigration and Naturalization Service has been too restrictive in handling applications for legal status by alien farm workers.
Government lawyers said the decision might make it more difficult to keep those who are ineligible from being permanently admitted to the United States.


Passenger Shoots Cabby in Dispute Over Fare
LEAD: A taxicab driver from Queens was shot early yesterday by a Manhattan bartender in a predawn dispute over a fare, the police said.
The bartender tried to flee in another cab but she was arrested two blocks away after the driver of a third cab followed her and called the police.


Koch Plans Task Force To Combat Illegal Clubs
LEAD: Mayor Koch, branding as ''murderers'' the operators of a Bronx social club where six people were killed in a fire last weekend, said yesterday that the New York City Police, Fire and Building Departments would form a task force to crack down on similar illegal clubs around the city.


Homeless Children and Homeless Pets Share a Day
LEAD: Chris Sullivan of the Bide-a-Wee Home Association shelter on West 53d Street introducing a kitten to young children yesterday at Public School 111 on West 53d Street.
The children were from CampWIN, a summer program for preschool homeless children and their families sponsored by Women in Need.

Economic Scene; The Reagan Era: Gains and Losses
LEAD: HAS Reaganomics left Americans better off than than were eight years ago?
George Bush offered a litany of superlatives to the Republican convention last week that was only slightly marred by hyperbole.
Inflation is indeed down to 4 percent from 13 percent, and the banks' prime interest rate is now less than half the 21 percent briefly experienced during the credit crunch of 1981.


Paul F. Switz, Consultant, 82
LEAD: Paul F. Switz, an economic development consultant to Puerto Rico, died after suffering a stroke Sunday at Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Review/Film; Learning to Appreciate a Mr. Right Who Sells Pickles and Tells Jokes
LEAD: Isabelle (Izzy) Grossman's grandmother lives a life steeped in old-world Jewish culture on the Lower East Side of New York.
Her parents live, as the grandmother describes it, ''in Florida with Red Buttons'' (in a retirement community there).

Rallying for a Woman
LEAD: After a year of imprisonment for contempt of court, Dr.
Elizabeth Morgan, a plastic surgeon who defied judicial authorities by hiding her daughter from her former husband, alleging he had sexually abused their child, is becoming a rallying point for advocates of women's rights.


Jewish Father for Palestinian State?
LEAD: It seems unlikely: A Jewish philosopher, at the University of Maryland, has emerged as the father of a proposal for Palestinians to declare their independence and establish a state in the territories now occupied by Israel.


The Era of the Edible Blossom: Innovation and Rediscovery
LEAD: FLOWERS and herbs have contributed culinary color to meals, both regal and lowly, for centuries.
But today lilacs, mimosa, roses, spearmint and violets - candied, swirled into syrup, infused in cordials or otherwise preserved - are reappearing in innovative cuisine.
Flowers like squash blossoms and nasturtiums are part of the decorative-edible larder, too, and fresh herbs are playing an ever larger role.


Education; Baltimore Mobilizes To Cut Dropout Rate
LEAD: Businesses here have joined City Hall, school officials and neighborhood groups in an effort to improve the quality of potential employees by reducing the high school dropout rate, which is now about 45 percent.

Review/Theater; Three Plays on Desire
LEAD: The movie-within-the-play in Aaron Sorkin's one-act comedy ''Hidden in This Picture'' deals with a platoon of ''disillusioned marines'' on the island of Guam.
But the film is being made on a farm outside of Schenectady.
Weeks behind schedule, millions over budget, the director (Nathan Lane) watches calmly as an army of extras moves into action for the last sunset.

LEAD: The Yankees are struggling in their efforts to stay in contention in the American League East race, but they may lead the league in team meetings.


Consumer Prices a Bit Higher
LEAD: Led by higher food prices, consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Economists said the moderate increase should reduce fears of renewed inflation.

LEAD: FOR much of the last decade, commercial space developers in New Jersey have been pushing westward and building mainly to accommodate the growth of New Jersey-based companies and the desire of New York companies for cheaper alternatives to high Manhattan rent.

LEAD: An estimated 39,500 people who bought Chrysler cars that had been test-driven with disconnected odometers will receive at least $500 each under a nationwide settlement announced today.

Votes at Odds With Veterans' Causes
LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle has drawn little criticism from veterans' groups for serving in the National Guard during the Vietnam War, but his votes on several pieces of legislation have caused them more concern.


Tin Mill Prices Raised
LEAD: Two steel companies announced price increases on tin mill products today.
The USX Corporation said it would raise its prices by 9.5 percent.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would raise its prices by 8 percent.
Both price increases are scheduled to go into effect on Oct. 1.

After Surviving Razing Plan, Brooklyn Building Gets Grant
LEAD: Eight months after New York City officials sought to tear it down, the Vendome, a distinguished but ravaged old apartment house in Brooklyn, yesterday was awarded a $225,000 grant from New York State to help in its reconstruction.


Fed's View Of Foreigners Now Tougher
LEAD: In deciding to change how it treats foreign governmental entities that seek to acquire banks in the United States, the Federal Reserve Board has turned its back on a strongly worded 1983 memorandum that Paul A. Volcker, then the chairman, sent to Congress.


As Tension Rises, Solidarity Again Seeks Talks
LEAD: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity labor union appealed for talks with the Government again today, a day after a range of emergency measures were instituted to halt a wave of labor disruptions.


With Army Restrained, Burma Unrest Grows
LEAD: Anti-Government demonstrations in Burma reportedly grew larger today as the military, which killed hundreds of protesters earlier this month, maintained a newly passive presence in the streets.


A Leap and Derailing Delay Subway Service
LEAD: Subway service along the IND Eighth Avenue line in Manhattan was suspended for an hour yesterday afternoon, the Transit Authority said, when a man tried to commit suicide on one track and, in an unrelated incident, an empty train derailed on the opposite track 15 minutes later.

LEAD: John Vanbiesbrouck, the Rangers' goalie who severely cut his left wrist on June 13 when the glass top of a coffee table at his home in Rye, N.Y., broke under his weight, said yesterday he would report to Three Rivers, Quebec, on Sept. 10 when the Rangers begin preseason training.
After the 24-year-old goalie underwent five hours of microsurgery to repair three severed tendons and a sliced nerve, the team announced he was not expected back for four to six months.

Reviews/Music; Texas Romantic On Heartbreak And Foolishness
LEAD: The search for honky-tonk heaven continues in Texas.
Since the outlaw country movement of the late 1970's, songwriters in Austin have minutely examined the myth of the honky-tonk, where romance and fistfights and music and drink, exaltation and self-destruction all swirl together.
Austin's younger songwriters can't take the myth in full seriousness, but they can't shake it off, either.


Second Chance
LEAD: Kerwin Bell, who last year at the University of Florida set Southeastern Conference career records with 56 touchdowns passes and 7,585 yards gained passing, signed with the Atlanta Falcons, one day after being waived by the Miami Dolphins.
The Falcons, who finished with the worst record in the National Football League last year, have the first opportunity to claim players who are waived.


Parents Agree to Detente in the Clothes Wars
LEAD: THE clothes war between parents and children appears to be over.
Interviews with psychologists, parents and children around the nation show that while there are still some minor skirmishes on the fashion front, for the most part parents and youngsters have called a truce.
And the truce seems to be holding even as the new school year opens.

Chipwich to Merge With Peltz Food
LEAD: Chipwich Inc. has agreed to merge with the Peltz Food Corporation, a frozen-food distributor based in New York.
Robert B. Peltz, president and sole shareholder of Peltz Food, will receive 2.5 million shares of Chipwich stock, making him the largest individual shareholder.
Mr.
Peltz will also receive cash and a promissory note totaling $1.5 million.

Traders attributed the decline to continued intervention by some central banks and to a report that the Reagan Administration found the recent rise in the dollar troublesome and preferred a period of stability.

LEAD: The State Public Utilities Commission today ordered GTE California to cut its telephone rates by $218 million.

The company's president, David E. Anderson, said the reduction was excessive.

LEAD: Widespread reports of a dangerous epidemic of the eating disorder bulimia are vastly overstated, new studies conclude.


Baltic Demonstrations: A Gamble for Gorbachev
LEAD: The slogans and speeches in the three Baltic republics Tuesday night must have burned the ears of the more conservative colleagues of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.
The speakers, Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians who had received official permission to assemble, called for independence from Moscow, equated Communism with the Nazi swastika and accused the Soviet authorities of falsifying history.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  HORSE RACING  Claramount Wins Easily: Claramount splashed to a front-running 20-length victory over Whodam and Cavanagh Special in the $124,600 West Point Handicap for New York-breds yesterday at Saratoga.
The race was switched from grass to dirt because of heavy rain and the winner's margin of victory was the largest in New York this year.


Minnesota Dean Hired By Conference Board
LEAD: The Conference Board yesterday named Preston Townley, who has been dean of the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota since 1984, as its new president.


Personal Health
LEAD: The recent development of a test to determine whether people are destined to develop a devastating, inherited neurological disorder known as Huntington's disease is causing considerable anguish among potential beneficiaries.
Many, it seems, simply would prefer not to know whether they will develop the incurable disorder, even though the information may help them plan better for their future.

LEAD: The Government today rejected a demand by the Greek Orthodox Church that Martin Scorsese's film ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' be banned in Greece.
To do so, the Government said, would be contrary to the principles of Socialism and freedom of the arts.

British Unemployment
LEAD: Long-term unemployment in Britain has fallen below one million for the first time in more than five years, the Government reported today.
The number of people out of work for longer than 12 months dropped by 81,000 in the second quarter, to 948,000.
The report said the rate among the young declined by 36 percent from a year ago.

Sudan, Drowning in Troubles
LEAD: As if civil war, a $12 billion debt, locusts and drought were not enough, the Sudan now finds its capital inundated by an overflowing Nile.
In just two days this month, six times as much rain fell on Khartoum as in all of 1987.
One and a half million Sudanese are now without shelter, food or clean water.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: SOMETIMES the holes say as much about you as the fabric.
Over the years I've written half a dozen essays about my husband, too many to count about my children, a handful about my mother and one about my grandmother on the occasion of her death.
I've never written one entirely about my father.
There are lots of reasons for that, and the most important one may be, oddly enough, that my father is very much alive.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Some nails are popping out of our walls, especially near the ceiling.
A man we consulted told us the paint must be scraped off, and then the nails driven in deeper and the holes covered with perforated tape and cement.
Then the walls must be repainted.
Is all this necessary?
A.
Driving the nails deeper won't help them hold any better.

Pangia had a new job: designer and builder of cornices.

Review/Opera; The Lighter Side of Love
LEAD: Hector Berlioz toyed with the idea of setting Shakespeare's ''Much Ado About Nothing'' to music as early as 1833, but didn't get around to it until 1860.
When Berlioz finally did transform the play into an opera - ''Beatrice and Benedict,'' his last major work - he concentrated on its lighter side, jettisoning the character Don John (and with him a subplot that tells us a great deal more about Beatrice), and adding a comic figure, the musician

Schneeweiss, who lives in Midland Park, N.J., and drives a 1986 Pontiac Fiero. ''Everyone asks if I'm married, everyone says congratulations, and they bring back memories every time I look at them.

Quilted Eye Wear For a Sporty Look
LEAD: FIRST there were quilted handbags, often with the unmistakable look of Chanel.
Then came quilted clothes, quilted furs and even quilted jewelry.
Now quilting has come to eye wear.
Judging from the glasses seen about town recently, the popular material is a rich black leather.
Quilted much like the classic Chanel handbag, the material covers the sidepieces, giving a sporty look to the wearer and stiff competition to the newest plastic entries to the eye-wear scene.

LEAD: The Mair-Davis Duo (Marilynn Mair, mandolinist, and Mark Davis, guitarist) are to give a free concert a the North Plaza of Lincoln Center, tonight at 6:15 as part of Lincoln Center's Out-of-Doors series.

Rail Bailout Is Set
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge has approved a $14 million state bailout of the Chicago, Missouri &amp; Western Railway.
Two of the railroad's creditors, Citicorp and Heller Financial Inc., which are owed more than $100 million, had opposed the rescue plan, which involves a package of grants and loans, and had sought to have the railroad shut down and its assets sold.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption with The Doctor's World column in Science Times Tuesday misidentified a rare, fatal reaction to general anesthesia.
It is malignant hyperthermia.


Lisbon Shopping Area Burns
LEAD: A fire destroyed much of Lisbon's historic shopping district, killed one person and injured 43 today before firemen brought it under control.

LEAD: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man accused of manslaughter in the shooting of a police officer last week told a detective later that he did not push or touch a sergeant who fired the fatal shot, according to court testimony yesterday.


Swiss and Germans Use National 'Poison Pills'
LEAD: When two well-known Swiss food companies, Nestle and Jacob Suchard, made hostile bids for Rowntree P.L.C., the British confectioner, last spring, their competing offers sparked a debate that is still raging throughout Europe: Why can Swiss corporations succeed in hostile takeovers in other countries, while it is well-nigh impossible to succeed in a hostile bid against a Swiss company?

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of money market funds rose $369 million, to $269.1 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Institutional funds rose in value by $456 million, to $69.68 billion; general purpose funds increased by $17.6 million, to $85.37 billion, and broker-dealer funds fell by $104 million, to $114 billion.

Review/Art; After Old China's Values Crumbled
LEAD: Modern Chinese painting has not had much of an audience in the West.
It does not have the mastery or breadth of the Song and Ming Dynasty paintings with which Chinese art is largely identified.
However confident, it is groping.
It cannot reassure the ever more atomized West, as older Chinese painting and sculpture can, of the holistic potential of art.

LEAD: Art Rooney Sr., the founder of the Pittsburgh Steelers and a figure on the American sports scene for more than half a century, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Pittsburgh, eight days after suffering a stroke in his office at Three Rivers Stadium.
He was 87 years old.


Treatment for Ali
LEAD: Muhammad Ali, seeking to relieve the slurred speech and tremors that have plagued him in recent years, is undergoing blood-cleansing treatments by a doctor who blames the former heavyweight boxing champion's condition on household pesticide poisoning and not blows to the head, as had been suggested by other diagnoses.


Andrew W. L. Brown, Auto Union Official, 73
LEAD: Andrew W. L. Brown, a retired official of the United Automobile Workers, died of heart failure Aug. 16 at St.
John Hospital in Detroit.
He was 73 years old and lived in Grosse Pointe Park.


Harvard Catches 'Fenway Fever'
LEAD: As the Boston Red Sox struggle in a tight pennant race, some of their biggest fans are toiling equally hard inside ivy-covered walls, calculating the likelihood of victory in October.


YELLOWSTONE FIRE NEARS SCENIC AREA
LEAD: Brisk winds carried a 108,300-acre forest fire over defensive lines today, fanning flames to within less than half a mile of one of Yellowstone National Park's most scenic areas and forcing officials to close the park's west entrance.

LEAD: Dino Ciccarelli, believed to be the first National Hockey League player ever sentenced for an on-ice incident, said yesterday that the National Hockey League had let the situation escape its jurisdiction.

LEAD: Petroleum futures prices fell broadly yesterday, plunging sharply at times amid reports of overproduction by OPEC and renewed tensions between two of its member nations, Iran and Iraq.


Review/Art; A Forgotten Pioneer in Completely Abstract Painting
LEAD: Manierre Dawson's brief painting career is one of the forgotten cul-de-sacs of 20th-century art history, one that the small exhibition of his paintings on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art shines light into, without completely illuminating.


Dillon Acquisition
LEAD: The Dillon Companies, a supermarket chain based in Hutchinson, Kan., said its Kwik Shop Inc. subsidiary had agreed to buy forty-six 7-Eleven convenience stores from the Southland Corporation, based in Dallas.
Terms were not disclosed.
Dillon, a unit of the Kroger Company, said it would operate the stores as part of its Kwik Shop chain.


O'Brien Learning To Avoid the Sack
LEAD: For 27 straight games dating to 1986, including regular season, playoffs and exhibition, Ken O'Brien has been sacked at least once.
Over the last three regular seasons he was dumped 152 times.


Nevada's High Court Allows Suit on Rock Band's Lyrics
LEAD: The Nevada Supreme Court refused today to dismiss a lawsuit charging that a fan of the British rock band Judas Priest committed suicide and another injured himself because of the group's lyrics.

Review/Film; Growing Up, and Into Baseball
LEAD: You know what kind of girl she was.
You probably know what kind of summer it was, too.
The light was golden.
The beach was clean.
He was young and impressionable, she worldly and wise.
Whenever he had trouble, she helped get him through, and because of that he can never forget her.
Oh yes, he also had a friend, and the friend's every thought was of losing his virginity.

LEAD: More than 300 employees of a coal mine in southern Hungary returned to work today after a 20-hour strike that posed the first worker challenge to the strict economic policies of Prime Minister Karoly Grosz.

8 Hurt in Revenge Shooting
LEAD: A gunman in a car fired about 18 shots at a crowd outside a pool hall Wednesday, wounding eight people in an attack the police said was carried out in revenge for a gang shooting earlier this week.
No arrests were made, and none of the witnesses could provide a description of the vehicle, Police Officer Ralph Askew said today.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campaign on Dropouts A First for Ad Council
LEAD: The Council of State Governments, Lexington, Ky., has decided to try to lower the high school dropout rate by sponsoring a yearlong national ad campaign, with the help of the Advertising Council and Ashland Oil.
The effort, which uses ads originally produced by Ashland Oil, is the first in which the Ad Council has used a corporate campaign as the basis for a nationwide public service campaign.

LEAD: Like Yeats's rough beast in ''The Second Coming,'' apostles of political murder are slouching back into view.
The State Department reports that terrorist incidents worldwide climbed to 832 last year, a 7 percent jump.
The precision is misleading, since there's no rule for distinguishing one person's ''terrorist'' from another's ''freedom fighter.

Corrections
LEAD: A headline in some copies on Aug. 14 on an obituary of Elmo R. Zumwalt 3d, whose father ordered the spraying of Agent Orange in Vietnam, mischaracterized the younger Mr.
Zumwalt's experience with the defoliant when he served there.
He was exposed to it but said he could not prove that exposure was responsible for his illnesses.

LEAD: The rainout here three weeks ago precipitated an entire array of discomforting changes for the Yankees.
Schedules were shuffled.
Travel arrangements were reworked, and an expected day off evaporated in an instant.
It left both plans and people upset.

LEAD: Chuck Norris's big problem in ''Hero and the Terror'' is that he is a police detective who never waits for his backup.

Zydeco on the Water
LEAD: A music cruise featuring Queen Ida and her Bon Temps Zydeco Band will close a summer jazz series aboard the Hudson River Dayliner tomorrow at 9 P.M.
Queen Ida, whose real name is Ida Guillory, is an accordionist who specializes in zydeco, a combination of Cajun, Creole, jazz and rock music.
In addition to the concert, there will be a Mardi Gras celebration, with costumes, masks and Cajun food.

Jersey's Funds For Schools Found Flawed
LEAD: New Jersey's system of financing public education was declared constitutionally flawed today by a state administrative law judge who said it failed to eliminate financing disparities between affluent suburban and poor urban school districts.

LEAD: Black prosecutors, outsiders at the office and suspects at home, are struggling with painful times.
White colleagues wonder if they are too sympathetic to black defendants; other blacks accuse them of complicity with a racist system.


Pop/Jazz: From Cool to Exultant, With a Touch of Blue; 11 Days of Prime Jazz In Greenwich Village
LEAD: THE 11-day Hennessy Village Jazz Festival, which opens today with a free concert at the Village Gate from 4:30 to 7 P.M., is less a festival than a celebration of the extraordinary state of workaday jazz life in Greenwich Village.
Though there are free special events, the festival, which takes place mostly in clubs, points up the abundance of jazz that is to be found any week in the Village.

Inflation Eases in Mexico
LEAD: Consumer price rises have continued to ease under a tough anti-inflation program, with an inflation rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first half of August, the Bank of Mexico announced Wednesday.
It predicted smaller increases in consumer prices for the remainder of the month once sales taxes are reduced and other measures taken under the Government's economic solidarity pact.

Flooding in Nepal Quake Area
LEAD: Tons of food, clothing, blankets and other aid continued to flow into the region today despite heavy rains that slowed relief operations after a strong earthquake that struck last Sunday.
Doctors from Britain, Japan and France joined the effort to treat the injured and prevent epidemics from breaking out as the rains flooded many neighborhoods in Biratnagar, Nepal's second-largest city.


Japan Consumer Prices
LEAD: Consumer prices in Japan fell two-tenths of 1 percent in July from the previous month, but rose five-tenths from the year before, the Government's Management and Coordination Agency said today.
The year-to-year increase marked the 14th monthly rise in a row.
Prices had also fallen in June by two-tenths, but were up by the same amount from the previous year.


Captain Loses His Command Over Episode With Refugees
LEAD: The captain of an American warship is being permanently relieved of his command and has been ordered to prepare for a court-martial because of his failure to rescue a boatload of Vietnamese refugees, Pentagon officials said today.

LEAD: Penske Transportation Inc. has agreed to buy a majority stake in the General Motors Corporation's diesel fuel-injection business, G.M. said.
Penske Transportation, a subsidiary of the Penske Corporation of Red Bank, N.J., is to own 80 percent of the new venture, which will be formed from G.M.'s Rochester Products plant in Wyoming, Mich.

Wallace in Crash
LEAD: Rusty Wallace, the Winston Cup season point-leader, survived a crash and escaped serious injury yesterday afternoon at the Bristol (Tenn.) International Raceway during practice for the Busch 500 Nascar race, which will be run tonight.
The 31-year-old driver's Pontiac slid into the fourth-turn wall on the half-mile track, climbed to the top of the wall, turned over and rolled five times along the straightaway before coming to rest on its wheels just past the finish line.

LEAD: Greg Windsperger, who was the jumping coach of the United States ski team during the Olympic Winter Games of 1984 and 1988, has resigned, team officials announced yesterday.

Mayes Practices
LEAD: Rueben Mayes softened a bit yesterday on his statement that he has no future with the New Orleans Saints, but the running back still believes he will be playing somewhere else in 1989.
Mayes, a Pro Bowl pick in each of his two seasons in the National Football League, walked out of the Saints training camp Aug.


In Spirit, Tibet's Lamas Resemble Iran's Mullahs
LEAD: To the Editor:


U.S. Suggests Easing Fuel-Economy Rules for New Cars
LEAD: The Transportation Department today proposed relaxing the fuel economy requirements for 1989 and 1990 model automobiles, saying the move would save American jobs.
But the reduction would be less than was granted auto makers in the last three years.


Corrections
LEAD: In the Dining Out column in Weekend yesterday, an incorrect star rating was given for the Gotham Bar and Grill, 12 East 12th Street.
The restaurant received a three-star rating when it was reviewed on Oct. 4, 1985.


Toyota Leads Japan in Profit
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation reported today that its earnings surged 31.1 percent in the fiscal year that ended June 30, making it Japan's most profitable company this year.


Cocoa Plunges on Reports Of Price-Support Problems
LEAD: Cocoa futures prices plunged to their lowest level in 12 years yesterday on reports that the International Cocoa Organization was considering drastic changes in the financing of its price-support operations.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Once the Yonkers City Council approved the terms of the Consent Judgment, the Council became obligated to carrying out its commitments.
If a member of the Council is unwilling to abide by such commitments, his option is to decline to serve on the body that is bound, not to act in defiant disregard of the commitments and the federal court judgment that memorializes them.


Police and Protesters Have Clashed Before in Tompkins Square
LEAD: To the Editor:


July Incomes Up by 0.6% as Wages Rose
LEAD: Bolstered by the biggest increase in wages in seven months, Americans' personal incomes rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July.
The pace of consumer spending slowed in part because fewer people bought automobiles.


A Tool for Removing Plaque in Arteries
LEAD: A father-and-son team won a patent this week for a tool to clear human arteries of plaque, a primary cause of heart disease.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  International 2-4, 26  Two brothers arrested in Sweden have admitted working for the Hungarian intelligence service, Swedish officials said.
The Hungarian-born brothers were arrested when Western officials broke up a spy ring.
Page 1  A growing sense of futility in Gdansk has set in as a strike continues at the Lenin Shipyard.


Entwistle Raises Frequency Stake
LEAD: The Entwistle Company said it had raised its stake in Frequency Electronics Inc., a maker of precision timing equipment, to 8.2 percent from 5.6 percent.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Entwistle, a maker of insulated wire, said it had bought 132,800 Frequency shares on the open market for $10.31 a share.


WESTERN BLAZES THREATEN TOWNS
LEAD: Residents of two towns on the edge of this park were warned today that they might have to evacuate because of a 30,000-acre forest fire.
Inside the park, rangers shepherded convoys of tourists down roads otherwise closed by fires burning nearly 20 percent of the park.


Review/Concert; Beaux Arts Trio In a Marriage Of Age and Spirit
LEAD: Last summer, the Beaux Arts Trio underwent a personnel change that was, to all appearances, odd.
Its founding cellist, Bernard Greenhouse, had retired, and rather than disband the ensemble, the remaining members - Isidore Cohen, the violinist, and Menahem Pressler, the pianist - decided to find a replacement.


Gulf Peace Negotiations Hit A Potentially Serious Snag
LEAD: The peace talks between Iran and Iraq ran into potentially serious trouble today when an old dispute resurfaced between the two countries over the ownership of a waterway, diplomats and United Nations officials said.


Mary Murphy, Archivist, Wed to Robert L. Gaumer
LEAD: At St.
Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bay Shore, L.I., Mary Eleanor Murphy, a daughter of Mrs.
John J. Murphy of Bay Shore and the late Dr.
Murphy, was married yesterday to Robert L. Gaumer, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Paul D. Gaumer of Chambersburg, Pa.
The Rev.
Charles A. Lennon performed the ceremony.


Panel Upholds Contempt Finding But Curbs Fines Against Yonkers
LEAD: A Federal appeals court yesterday affirmed a lower court's finding of contempt and the imposition of fines against the City of Yonkers and four members of the City Council who have blocked compliance with a court-ordered housing desegregation plan.


Youths Charged In Death of Man Stabbed in Park
LEAD: Two youths have been charged in the slaying of a man who was stabbed to death in Central Park Monday night during a fight with a group of about 20 teen-agers, the police said.


Stacey J. Moritz Wed To David M. Brodsky
LEAD: Stacey J. Moritz and David M. Brodsky, partners in the New York law firm of Schulte Roth &amp; Zabel, were married last night at the Water Club in New York.
Judge Jose Cabranes of Federal District Court in New Haven officiated.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Little League  Hawaiian Team in Final: A team from a small Hawaiian city has won a pair of one-run games to earn a game against a Taiwanese powerhouse in the Little League World Series championship game today in Williamsport, Pa.


Joanne Brackeen
LEAD: Joanne Brackeen, a pianist, is to perform tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway (718-638-5000).
The concert is free with museum admission, which is $3 for adults and $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children under 12 years old.


Copper Prices, Now Up, Are Seen Settling Down
LEAD: After slipping for several weeks, copper prices have begun to rebound again because of a renewed tightening of supplies brought on in part by copper workers' strikes in Peru and Canada.


Rooney Mourned By Thousands
LEAD: Thousands of people today paid their last respects to the Pittsburgh Steelers' founder, Art Rooney Sr., who died Thursday.
Rooney, who was 87 years old, died of complications of a stroke he suffered last week.


Miller Returns
LEAD: Ten days after he announced that he was leaving Loyola of Chicago because of academic problems and that he was investigating the possibility of attending Oklahoma or Nevada-Las Vegas, Kenny Miller changed his mind.
On Thursday, the 20-year-old sophomore, a 6-foot-9-inch center who last season became the first freshmen to win a National Collegiate Athletic Association rebounding title, told Chuck Schwarz, the Loyola athletic director, he had decided to return to Loyola even though he will be academically ineligible to play basketball during the fall semester.

Canada Plans Test Program For a Deadly Brain Condition
LEAD: Canadian scientists announced a program today for testing people at risk of developing Huntington's disease, the devastating and fatal brain condition that usually goes undiagnosed until symptoms show up in adulthood.


American Contact With Spy Ring Was in '74, Investigators Are Told
LEAD: Two Hungarian-born Swedish brothers who were arrested this week when Western officials broke up a major espionage ring have admitted working for the Hungarian intelligence service, the Swedish authorities said today.


Korean Talks Adjourn in a Deadlock
LEAD: Talks between North and South Korea ended in a deadlock today, with the two sides saying they had no plans to resume meetings until after the Olympic Games in Seoul are over in October.


Art Work 'Fingerprint'
LEAD: To help prevent art forgeries, Ioan G. Crihan, an engineer in New York City, has developed a radioactive ''fingerprint'' that is to be placed on valuable works.
Mr.
Crihan's procedure calls for mixing a radioactive isotope with a resin and planting a speck of the material on the painting or sculpture.


Jobs Even More Out of Aliens' Reach
LEAD: Immigrants having trouble getting work because employment of illegal aliens is prohibited are now finding it even harder because of a Federal crackdown on their makeshift hiring halls: street corners.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY AUGUST 27, 1988
LEAD:  Companies


British Censors Refuse To Cut 'Temptation'
LEAD: British film censors, rejecting demands of some church leaders, decided Thursday to allow Martin Scorcese's film ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' to be shown without cuts.


Excerpts of Court's Ruling On Compulsory Oath to Flag
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 1943 decision in West Virginia State Board of Education v.
Barnette, declaring unconstitutional a state law that required students to salute the American flag and recite the Pledge of Allegiance.
Justice Robert H. Jackson wrote the opinion.


Lionel Deckle McLean, Dental Surgeon, 88
LEAD: Dr.
Lionel Deckle McLean, a dental surgeon and the first black to serve as president of the New Jersey Dental Association, died of respiratory failure last Saturday at University Hospital in Newark.
He was 88 years old and lived in Jersey City.


Trade Mission To Go to Japan
LEAD: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. will head a trade mission to Japan next month to promote sales of American consumer goods, the department said today.


Sale Deal Reached For Texas Rangers
LEAD: Eddie Chiles, the majority owner of the Texas Rangers, announced last night that he had agreed to sell his controlling interest in the American League baseball team to a group of investors who have been associated with efforts to secure a major league franchise for Tampa, Fla.


Schmidt Injury Is Pinpointed
LEAD: Mike Schmidt, the Philadelphia Phillies' third baseman, has a tear in the rotator cuff of his right shoulder and will undergo tests next week to determine the extent of the injury, the club said today.
If the tear is partial, said Dr.
Phillip Marone, the team physician, it could heal with rest.
A full tear might require surgery.


Enzo Fano, Water Specialist, 57
LEAD: Enzo Fano, an internationally known water-resources specialist at the United Nations, died of a heart attack Thursday at New York Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Chrysler and Maserati Plan To Reduce Their Joint Effort
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and the Italian auto maker Maserati said today that they had reduced the scope of their joint efforts, setting the stage for a complete severing of relations.


An All-Dvorak Concert Is Planned for St. John's
LEAD: The 147th anniversary of Antonin Dvorak's birth will be observed with an all-Dvorak concert on Sept. 10 at 7:30 P.M. at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.
The composer's actual birthdate is Sept. 8.


Judge Orders Seizure of Items Purchased in Donations Case
LEAD: A judge ordered the seizing of jewelry and other luxury items today that Maria DeSillers is reported to have purchased with some of the $690,000 donated by strangers for her dying son's liver transplants.


Police and Protesters Have Clashed Before in Tompkins Square; Gentrification's Price

U.S. Aides in Panama Deny New Harassment by Noriega
LEAD: American officials here have challenged assertions from Washington that the Government of Panama has stepped up harassment of United States military personnel and their families.


Hats Are for Horses, Not Him, Koch Says
LEAD: Mayor Koch, who last week proposed a new-fangled manure catcher to solve a problem at the tail of the carriage horses in Central Park, revealed yesterday that he has an old-fashioned idea for a problem at their heads: straw hats to keep them cool.


Making a Safer Blow-Dryer: Progress, but at a Snail's Pace
LEAD: At a time when people are grumbling about the quality of small electric appliances, many manufacturers are not listening.
Or so it seems, judging by the flimsy toasters, corn poppers, hair dryers and other disposable appliances that have given plastic and tin a bad name.

Jean Michel Basquiat: Hazards Of Sudden Success and Fame
LEAD: In a city that exalts successful artists in the fashion of rock stars, Jean Michel Basquiat seemed blessed.
When he burst onto the art scene in 1981, his paintings of anguished figures were hailed by some critics as works of genius.
Admirers besieged him at Manhattan's hottest night clubs.
Sales of his art grossed millions of dollars.


Homework For Parents
LEAD: Joshua Robert Lipkin Sautter, age 5, will begin kindergarten this fall at a public school in Washington.
His parents have bought him a shiny backpack, and his uncle has given him a ''Ghostbusters'' lunch box.

Top Executives Leave Scotty's
LEAD: Scotty's Inc., a manufacturer of building materials and retailer of hand tools, said yesterday that its chairman, James W. Sweet, had retired.
The company also said its president, Dennis Stults, had resigned to pursue other interests.


N.A.A.C.P. and Boston Settle Challenge to a Housing Plan
LEAD: The city and the N.A.A.C.P. today settled a challenge to an agreement over a non-discriminatory public housing plan worked out in June between the Boston Housing Authority and the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.


Home State Ruling Upheld
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled today that the financier Marvin L. Warner cannot avoid paying $22 million in restitution stemming from the failure of Home State Savings Bank, as he was ordered to do by an Ohio court.


Sighting an Eagle
LEAD: Greg Norman reacting as his putt dropped in for an eagle on the second hole yesterday in the second round of the World Series of Golf in Akron, Ohio.
Mike Reid and Ian Baker-Finch shared the lead. (AP) Page 46.


Baseball; Dodger Rookie Takes Seventh Straight
LEAD: Tim Belcher, a rookie, won his seventh straight decision and a two-run double by John Shelby highlighted a five-run fourth inning tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-2.


Television; Urbanites After Dark
LEAD: Even the adroit direction of Tony Richardson cannot conceal the patched-together quality of ''After Midnight,'' a one-hour drama to be shown tonight at 9 o'clock on ABC.


BUSH TURNS HEAT ON 'LIBERAL' RIVAL
LEAD: Vice President Bush offered politically conservative East Texas a scathing attack on Michael S. Dukakis today, alleging that his Democratic rival was hiding a litany of ''liberal'' faults.


Head of Lab Charged in Illegal Disposal
LEAD: The head of a diagnostic laboratory in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with illegally disposing of medical waste, including two blood vials containing the Hepatitis B virus.
He was also charged with creating a risk of serious injury to others.


L.I. Rail Service Disrupted in Wake of Crash
LEAD: The wreckage of a Long Island Rail Road train that was hit by a commuter train that had derailed Thursday night in Huntington.
Yesterday, thousands of commuters were forced to find other routes as the railroad scrambled to repair damaged tracks.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary Aug. 18 of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. omitted two survivors.
They are his brothers, James, of Santa Ana, Calif., and Elliott, of Indian Wells, Calif.


Man Is Charged in Slaying Of Midtown Pizza Deliverer
LEAD: A Queens man was charged yesterday in the stabbing to death of a pizza deliverer in a midtown building two weeks ago.


Why 2 Savings Units Struggle
LEAD: Texas may be the capital of sick savings and loan institutions, but the Northeast is by no means exempt from the problem.
The number of troubled institutions in the region is growing, and with interest rates rising that trend will continue.

Review/Theater; A Fading Prizefighter Confronts His Facade
LEAD: Joey Dillon, the title character in ''The Fighter'' by Daniel Keene, comes home to his seedy apartment and goes through his nightly ritual.
Changing to his sweat pants and putting a towel around his neck, he steps on a scale, winces at his weight and then removes the towel and tries again.
The silent scene goes on so long (at Theater for the New City) that it seems less like a prelude to a play than a play itself, somewhat on the order of Franz Kroetz's ''Request Concert.

LEAD: The first third of the trumpeter Don Cherry's set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night was filled with musical hemming and hawing: the group's tenor saxophonist, James Clay, who had Mr.
Cherry's trumpet, hadn't appeared.
Jazz is about improvisation, so the group, made up of members of Ornette Coleman's early, radical, ground-breaking group -Charlie Haden on bass and Billy


Kickoff Game: 'Bowl in Reverse'
LEAD: Miles from the intense emotions of their campuses, nearly a week before another college football game will take place, the Aggies of Texas A&amp;M and the Huskers of Nebraska attempted to define the significance of the sixth Kickoff Classic.


Tramps Leaves 15th St. For a SoHo Reopening
LEAD: Tramps, the longtime blues and rock club at 125 East 15th Street, will close at its present location tonight after the last set, by Otis Rush.


4th Jet Hobbled in Fit of Campaign Delays
LEAD: The jet carrying Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, and his entourage was grounded for repairs today after a passenger door was forced closed in an incorrect position.


U.S. Promises $1 Billion for Deals To Save Nine Savings Institutions
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had arranged to merge nine more insolvent saving institutions with healthy ones.
It said it had committed almost $1 billion in assistance to the transactions.


Jackson Rules Out Comeback Attempt
LEAD: Reggie Jackson's rumored return to the Yankees appeared to fall through today after the 42-year-old retired player and his agent denied that Jackson was interested in a comeback.
But Bill Goodstein, a New York lawyer Jackson has used on occasion for business matters, stood by his account that Jackson has been contemplating a return.


Cuban Goods Logjam
LEAD: The Cuban Government has announced emergency plans to deal with huge stockpiles of merchandise in Cuban ports.
The backlog - 311,000 tons of merchandise on Aug. 15 - is disrupting the country's economy and costing Cuba millions of dollars in penalties to foreign shipowners.
The emergency plan calls for dock workers to work on shifts around the clock.


Special Prosecutor Drops E.P.A. Case Without Indictment
LEAD: An independent prosecutor said today that she would not seek criminal charges against a former senior Justice Department official who had been accused of misleading Congress in 1983 about the handling of Environmental Protection Agency documents.


Review/Film; Enter a Talking Horse And Other Party Animals
LEAD: ''Hot to Trot,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, bills itself as ''the funniest talking horse movie ever.'' That's not so very much to live up to.
But even so, ''Hot to Trot'' doesn't qualify, since its biggest innovation is the idea of a horse named Don who's as wisecracking, irreverent and messy as the human characters.


Post on Futures Panel
LEAD: Neil Sherman, first vice president and associate general counsel at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said Thursday that he had withdrawn his name from consideration to be a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
People involved in the futures industry had said that the White House had offered Mr.


Symbolism, More Than Legal Precedent, Is the Issue in the Bush and Dukakis Clash
LEAD: For more than a week, George Bush has been taunting Michael S. Dukakis for vetoing a Massachusetts law that would have required teachers to lead their classes in the Pledge of Allegiance.
Governor Dukakis has retorted that such a law would be unconstitutional, and that Vice President Bush would not be qualified to be President if he had signed it.


Rate Rises Push Dollar Downward
LEAD: The central banks appear to have won the latest round in their bout to subdue the dollar, which finished lower against several foreign currencies yesterday.


Last Refuge For Bush
LEAD: Late in August George Bush refused to debate Michael Dukakis before late September.
Political analysts figured Bush wanted to wait and look at the polls.
If they showed he was sure to be elected, he would say he couldn't debate until October, when, if his polls were still terrific, he'd say, ''I'll be ready in February.


An Improved Form Of Anti-Cancer Drug
LEAD: The Cetus Corporation of Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week for a new form of the anti-cancer drug, interleukin-2, or IL-2.
Company officials believe the new compound, which entered human medical trials in April, can be administered in lower doses and with fewer side effects than the existing version of IL-2.


Urban Earth
LEAD: Harvie Swartz, a bassist, is to lead his group Urban Earth in a free concert tomorrow at 4 P.M. at the Rotunda in Riverside Park, at West 79th Street near the Hudson River Boat Basin.
Information: 408-0263.


Pentagon Curbs Its Use Of Private Consultants
LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci has signed a directive curtailing the Pentagon's use of private consultants in response to the investigation of such outside experts in the procurement fraud inquiry.


Tough Pitching and Luck Give Mets Fourth in Row
LEAD: The revived Mets rolled in from California last night and opened a nine-game homestand with fierce pitching, outrageous good fortune and a 3-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants.


WEST BANK UNIONS CLOSED BY ISRAEL
LEAD: Israel closed the offices of Palestinian unions representing doctors, lawyers and other West Bank professionals today, saying the groups had begun associating with ''terrorist organizations.''


'Bitterest Flavor' Created in Compound
LEAD: The Atomergic Chemetals Corporation of Plainview, L.I., has patented what it contends is the bitterest flavor in the world. ''It's vile,'' boasted Mel Blum, the compound's co-inventor and president of Atomergic. ''It has a lingering, terrible taste.''


One Challenge Left To Manville Plan
LEAD: The Manville Corporation said it faced only one remaining legal challenge to its bankruptcy reorganization plan.
It said the deadline had passed for a group of 700 people who said that they had been injured by asbestos to appeal to the United States Supreme Court to review the plan.
The group's objections to the plan had previously been dismissed by lower courts.


BURMA ARMY URGED TO AID PROTESTERS
LEAD: Large crowds gathered Friday at the Shwe Dagon Pagoda in Rangoon, where speakers called on the army to support the peaceful but leaderless insurrection that has turned much of the Burmese population against the Government.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Washington Talk Briefing column yesterday on a speech by Richard F. Schubert, president of the American Red Cross, misidentified the organization he addressed in some copies.
It is the World Jewish Congress.

Anchor Bank Alters Lending
LEAD: Anchor Savings Bank said yesterday that it would cut back on some of its non-mortgage lending activities.
Donald Thomas, Anchor's chairman, said the savings bank would no longer arrange auto loans through car dealers and was de-emphasizing commercial lending.
Anchor, based in Hewlett, L.I., said it would make new commercial loans only to its current customers.

LEAD: For those students who thought their lack of money made college an impossible dream, there is good news: funds are available, even at this late date.

LEAD: Mike Reid, a slim golfer who surprises people when he does well on strong courses against big, powerful golfers like Sandy Lyle and Greg Norman, surprised himself a bit today with a three-under-par 67 at the long Firestone Country Club South course.

LEAD: Talks on a timetable for withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola were suspended today to allow negotiators to consult their governments.

Earlier, the parties had agreed to set the timetable by Sept.

Museum Closes Sept. 6
LEAD: The Brooklyn Children's Museum will be closed from Sept. 6 through Sept. 30 while improvements are made to accommodate more visitors and school tours.
A computerized visitor-orientation system and an exhibition area for preschool children is to be completed, and repairs and painting will be done during the closing.

The Cordero Phenomenon
LEAD: Horse racing is a game in which human will is not supposed to matter.
The race may not always go to the swift but, as Damon Runyon said, that's the way to bet it.
The best horse usually wins, racing luck evens out in the long run, and the best jockeys are simply the ones who ride the best horses.
