Managing Mail
LEAD: To the Editor:


Happy Birdsday, Roger
LEAD: For most of this century, birds and Roger Tory Peterson have enjoyed a kind of symbiotic relationship, each profiting by the other's company.
He has introduced more birds to more people than anyone else - and the birds, in turn, have made him the best known of living naturalists.
Today he celebrates his 80th birthday, or ''birdsday,'' in the bird watcher's play on words.


A Kentish Countryside Possessed
LEAD: ''THE world, according to the best geographers, is divided into Europe, Asia, Africa, America and Romney Marsh.'' So wrote the Rev.
Richard Barham, who served as a rector in the fifth of those continents some 170 years ago and drew heavily on the experience when he composed his ''Ingoldsby Legends,'' a collection of tall tales immensely popular in 19th-century England.


Computer Talk
LEAD: To the Editor:


Drama vs. Noise at the Open
LEAD: In recent years, attention has focused on the negatives as many tennis players have come to view the United States Open as a necessary evil, such as visiting the dentist at least once a year.
There are the jets thundering overhead, trains rumbling nearby, boisterous crowds, scheduling quirks and sticky, late-summer New York City weather, all of which make the Open unique, but also the most disconcerting of the Grand Slam tournaments.


Waste Disposal Center Opens
LEAD: The first permanent disposal center for household hazardous waste on the East Coast opened today in this Martha's Vineyard community.
The center, financed by a $28,000 state grant, will hold household wastes like paints, solvents and pesticides from the six towns on the island.
James Gutensohn, commissioner of the state Department of Environmental Management, said, ''We are reducing the threat to the water supply that stems from disposing of these wastes in a landfill.

LEAD: PROBABLY the oldest mystery to vex mankind is what, if anything, occurs after death.
For a decade, Kenneth Ring, a psychology professor and researcher at the University of Connecticut, has looked into the question through the near-death experiences of others.

Bangladesh Floods Kill 80
LEAD: Floods set off by heavy rains have killed more than 80 people in Bangladesh and authorities have declared a disaster alert, officials said today.
They said 33 people were killed on Friday when houses collapsed and a boat ferrying flood victims capsized in the Jamuna River.
Thirty-two inches of rain have fallen in northern Bangladesh in the last three days, flooding 21 of the country's 64 districts.

Silver After the Hunt Debacle
LEAD: IT is safe to say that the Hunt brothers of Dallas have never recovered from the collapse of the silver market in 1979 and 1980.
Neither has the metal.
Silver soared from $9 an ounce in September 1979 to $50 an ounce in January 1980, only to collapse to $10 within two months; the debacle was relived last week.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  A WOMAN ON PAPER: Georgia O'Keeffe.
By Anita Pollitzer. (Touchstone/Simon &amp; Schuster, Paper, $12.95.) By showing Alfred Stieglitz some drawings by Georgia O'Keeffe, Anita Pollitzer brought about what is perhaps the most storied conjunction in American art.
Pollitzer's account of that incident in January 1916 anchors this epistolary memoir-cum-biography, written more than 30 years ago but unpublished until now because O'Keeffe, who died in 1986, refused to approve the manuscript.

Strategies for the Chip Shortage
LEAD: IT is getting hard to remember when memory was cheap.
Prices for computer memory chips have climbed in recent months as 256K D-RAM's have been in short supply.
That chip, more formally known as the 256-kilobit dynamic random access memory chip, is the most common memory chip used in personal computers.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  YANGTZE: Nature, History, and the River.
By Lyman P. Van Slyke. (Addison-Wesley, $14.95.) The Yangtze River flows 3,900 miles through China from its glacial source at 20,000 feet on the Tibetan-Qinghai plateau to the East China Sea, watering regions where nearly 350 million Chinese live.
Yet sections are so rugged that the world's third-longest river (after the Nile and the Amazon) was not navigated from source to mouth until 1986.

LEAD: ARTHUR ASHE really did not have much of a choice in the matter.

Ashe was black and he was a tennis player, a combination that made many people uneasy in a sport in which everyone wore white.

Taormina
LEAD: To the Editor: Some years ago while vacationing in Taormina, Sicily, I suffered a heart attack and was hospitalized for 20 days there.
The doctors, nurses and a Roman Catholic nun were wonderful.
The building was very old, the plumbing primitive and the bathroom unisex.
I was in an eight-man ward where there was no privacy (no screens).

LEAD:  1948-present: Middle East - force set up to watch borders between Israel and neighboring Arab countries.  1949-present: India and Pakistan - troops in Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir to monitor cease-fire between India and Pakistan  1956-1967: Egypt - force sent to secure cease-fire between Egyptian forces and Israeli, French and British troops in Sinai.

LEAD: THE Music Theater of Connecticut is getting on the bookless bandwagon.
With its current revue, ''Jukebox Saturday Night,'' the fledgling but nomadic theater, which has moved from Fairfield to Wilton in less than a year, is manifesting the latest trend in New York City's musical theater: compilation musicals, or shows that consist of hit tunes from past decades.

IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Newtown
LEAD: NEWTOWN sprawls over 60.38 square miles of wooded, rolling hills along the Housatonic River in Connecticut's northern Fairfield County, but its heart, in the view of many residents, is a few blocks of quintessential New England known as Main Street.


CRIME
LEAD:  DEATH TAKES THE STAGE by Donald Ward (St. Martin's, $15.95) is an unusual first novel.
Hard to pin down, it is a combination of tragedy and a kind of comedy that often verges on farce.
It also has moments of terror, including a Grand Guignol scene that will be hard to forget.
It pokes good-natured fun at the little-theater movement of Los Angeles and the egocentric types who slave there hoping for the big break.

Professional Engineer, 'A True Consultant'
LEAD: The July 24 article ''Checking Out Houses on the Market,'' was undoubtedly an ego trip for the three firms written about, but did little to inform the public about the all-important issue of credentials.
New York State Education Laws dictate that only licensed professional engineers or registered architects, may serve the public in the evaluation of mechanical and structural systems.

Correction
LEAD: A front-page article July 24 on the Presidential race and an accompanying map incorrectly summarized 1984 election results.
Walter F. Mondale received 40 percent or more of the 1984 major-party Presidential vote in 18 states; he received 37.93 percent in Indiana, 39.64 percent in Kentucky, 39.80 percent in Georgia and 39.98 percent in Missouri.

FICTION
LEAD:  FOREIGN MATTER.
By Robert MacLean. (Atheneum, $17.95.) Not all the mentoring goes on in the business world.
Here we have an aspiring humorist receiving instructions from the dead - in this case, P. G. Wodehouse.
Bounteous internal evidence in this first novel proclaims that Robert MacLean has closeted himself with a stock of Wodehouse's most representative works, from which he has abstracted archetypal Wodehousian characters and plot devices.

It's Time to Plan a Third-World Revival
LEAD: THE debt burden of the less developed countries can no longer be treated just as a banking problem.
More fundamentally, it is a trade problem, a jobs problem and a geopolitical problem.
Indeed, developing country debt and economic growth issues are so critical to both United States foreign policy and the domestic economy that it must be a priority item for the next President.

Schools Can Survive With the PTA
LEAD: I, too, sympathize with the plight of the organizations mentioned in the article ''Help Wanted, P/T, Immediate: Volunters Please Apply'' (July 3).
PTA's at the local, state and national levels have depended on volunteers to provide support for schools, school districts and students since 1897.


Garden Ornaments Come of Age
LEAD: Unlike their polished and pristine cousins - restored antiques for well-appointed interiors - period garden ornaments increase in value the more they show their age.
There is a premium on the mottled silvery patina of old lead or lichen-encrusted stone, the results of natural weathering.

There Are No 'Best,' Except. . .
LEAD: All sensible people with more than a casual interest in music hold these truths to be self-evident: There is no such thing as a best performance, and there is no such thing as a best performer.
Sometimes it is hard to hold on to the verities, especially when reading record reviews in which performers and their performances are treated as consumer commodities (''Miss Hooter's 'Dove sono' is carefully made and should give acceptable service over the short run, but in our tests the performance carried a potential for shock when heard in an excessively dry room.


POSTINGS: 680 for Torrington; Condos Around A Lake
LEAD: The first condominium community in Connecticut to surround and own a lake is being built in Torrington on the shores of a brass company's conceit.
Stillwater Pond was created in 1911 by the Coe Brass Company to insure a supply of fresh water for its growing business.
The Naugatuck River was dammed, and Stillwater grew to lake-size dimensions - a mile-and-a-half long and 700 feet wide.

LEAD: The toughest week of his life was coming to a close, and Senator Dan Quayle was feeling, as he says he always does, very good about himself.


FICTION
LEAD:  THE HOUSE THAT JACK BUILT.
By Ed McBain. (Henry Holt, $16.95.) Ed McBain, the prolific, pseudonymous master of the terse, fast-paced - and formulaic - mystery novel, has once again reconstructed a classic children's story and added a sardonic twist.
Jonathan Parrish, who was a homosexual and had AIDS, has been murdered at his beach-front home in the Florida Keys, and his brother Ralph, a homophobic farmer from Indiana, has been charged with the crime.

War on Drugs, War on Guns
LEAD: The first shots erupted at 12:23 A.M. when a group of six men surrounded two others, killing one and wounding the second.

WESTCESTER GUIDE
LEAD:  TUAREG CALLIGRAPHY  Some 50 pieces of calligraphy in the obscure language of the Tuareg, a Berber people of the Sahara, will go on exhibition Thursday through Oct. 2 at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers.
Tuareg comprises 21 letters and can be written in any direction, indicated by the orientation of the characters.

The Promise That Failed
LEAD: DEATH IS GRAY, AN ASHEN dusky gray.
It comes as a fog, sometimes creeping in stealthily, other times dropping like a curtain.
The eyes often register it first, drifting off to a distant horizon beyond mortal knowledge.
Curiously, those who know death intimately will look not only in the eyes, but also at the fingernails.

The Goddess in Tennessee
LEAD: IN CASE YOU DIDN'T know, the world's only full-sized replica of the Parthenon is in Nashville.
It has been thus since 1897, when a plaster model of the great, columned temple was constructed, for some reason, as part of the city's centennial celebration.
In the 1920's, the model was used to cast a permanent structure in concrete.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My patio consists of a concrete base over which is a layer of pebbles.
The pebbles are cemented in place with epoxy and form a layer a little over 1 1/2 inches thick.
Some of the pebbles are starting to loosen, leaving pockets or holes that are uncomfortable to walk on.
What clear solution can I use to anchor the pebbles and fill the cavities?

DOCTOR DOLITTLE, INNOCENT AGAIN
LEAD: Hugh John Lofting's ''Story of Doctor Dolittle,'' the first of 12 adventures starring the bluff and rotund physician from Puddleby-on-the-Marsh who loved animals and learned to speak their language, was published in 1920.

The Rise in Rates Spreads to Europe
LEAD: Interest rates headed higher in Europe, led by West Germany's central bank.
The Bundesbank lifted its discount rate to 3.5 percent, from 3 percent, and similar increases were imposed in Britain, France, Switzerland, Austria, the Netherlands and Canada.
The German move was accompanied by strong words from Karl Otto Pohl, the Bundesbank president, who said it was intended as an ''important signal'' to the world markets that Germany would act aggressively to curb further gains in the dollar's value.

The Presumed Uniqueness of Japan
LEAD: FIVE YEARS IN JAPAN HAVE LEFT me thinking a good deal about Bernstein, the scratchy-voiced business manager in the movie ''Citizen Kane.'' Washington Jail Crowding: Few Cells and Much Discord
LEAD: Some city officials refer to it as ''musical cells.'' But it is no game.
Rather, it is a desperate effort by the District of Columbia's Department of Corrections to respond to court orders that have set limits on the number of prisoners that can be housed in the city's overcrowded jails and prisons.


FICTION
LEAD:  EYESTONE.
By D. R. MacDonald. (Pushcart, $15.95.) When you pick up D. R. MacDonald's skillfully written first collection of short stories, you'll be transported to Nova Scotia, and to Cape Breton Island in particular.
The time will be spring or summer.
The modest houses you visit will be surrounded by wildflowers and mown hay; there will be rocky fields with small streams nearby.

Guadalcanal
LEAD: To the Editor: As an old South Pacific buff, I was pleased to see a remote and distant shadowline of nigh-forgotten islands reappear in print.
Thanks in no small part to the illustrious Richard Tregaskis and his epic ''Guadalcanal Diary,'' the very name of Guadalcanal must long remind the world of the legendary feat of arms performed there by our forces.

A Schoolboy Bully Looks Back, With Regret
LEAD: THE bully is a fact of school life which neither time nor circumstances has changed.
While the subjects, books, equipment and the students and teachers, themselves, change with the generations, bullies remain the same.
They are as old as Cain and Abel and they will continue to exist as long as some kids are big and mean and others are not prone to fight.

Red or Blue Blossoms for Summer
LEAD: Weed; pull them out or they will set seed that survives over winter to grow in the garden next year.
Work on the lawn: weeding, seeding and sodding; keep mowers set to cut high, at least two inches.
Prune hedges.
Plant evergreens.
Dry herbs.
Take cuttings of geraniums, impatiens and begonias to root and grow indoors as house plants.

What clear solution can I use to anchor the pebbles and fill the cavities?

A Change In Rule on Conversion Attempts
LEAD: It will be possible this college football season for a defensive team to score during a conversion attempt.
The defense can block a kick behind the line of scrimmage, recover the loose ball and return it the length of the field.
Or it can return a kick that is deflected in midair.
Or it can return an intercepted 2-point conversion pass, or a fumble caught in midair.

LEAD: IN the National Hockey League, where million-dollar-men are not a dime a dozen, the only one known to have reached that plateau is Wayne Gretzky.

LEAD: With an unusually large number of homes for sale and buyers insisting on bargains, a consensus has emerged among economists and real estate professionals that prices in the New York metropolitan region will increase little, if at all, for the rest of the decade.

The Amazon
LEAD: To the Editor: Anyone considering a cruise on the Amazon River ought to read Jules Verne's ''Eight Hundred Leagues on the Amazon.'' Published in English many years ago, it's about a four- month voyage in 1852 in which a whole village travels from Iquitos to the sea on a giant raft, complete even with a church.

Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
LEAD: The Mets don't have a hitting problem, they have a rhythm problem.
Players gain rhythm in practice, and playing regularly.
Any platoon system disrupts a player's rhythm, as he plays one day and sits the bench another.

NEW YORKERS, Etc.
LEAD: SOMEWHERE in the minds of a lot of busy, high-powered people there lurks a vision.
The vision is of themselves, in pajamas or robe, in bed or sprawled in a capacious chair, reading and occasionally running to the refrigerator.
Not in the evening, but all day long.
And the all-day-long, for goodness sake, is not a day off or a weekend, but a weekday, a business day.


Mussels: Clean, Adaptable and Relatively Safe
LEAD: MUSSELS are inexpensive to buy and adaptable to a variety of seasonings.
And since they are always eaten cooked, some of the safety concerns relating to bivalves raw on the half-shell do not apply.

Utilities Pay Builders to Cut Power Use
LEAD: ONCE upon a time, when power was cheap and everyone thought progress meant using more of it, utility companies used to advise architects and developers on ways to raise electricity consumption in new buildings.
The theory was that workers could be more productive in buildings with more artificial lighting and with cooling systems built without regard for the sun and other natural factors.

Zucchini Blossoms in Provence
LEAD: IN the shade of the yellow-and-white striped awnings of Nice's bustling market in the Cours Saleya, mounds of deep purple eggplants and stalks of garlic piled high make way for an unlikely looking neighbor - a bunch of orange flowers.
A handwritten sign stuck in their midst alerts shoppers and the curious alike to what they are: fleurs de courgettes, zucchini blossoms.

In Middle America, a Movie Finds Its Milieu
LEAD: ''She was 8 or 9.
On the evening news, a report from Vietnam - it was during the fall of Saigon, in 1975, she thought - showed some people walking along a road with bundles on their backs.
Some were carrying babies in their arms.
Army jeeps chugged along the road.
The landscape was believable - a hill in the distance, a paved road with narrow dirt shoulders, a field with something green planted in rows.

Troubled Museums Try to Master the Fine Art of Survival
LEAD: ONE by one, sometimes painfully, museums have come to realize that their task is much harder than simply hiring a staff and hanging exhibits, with the backing of a few generous patrons.
Over the last 20 years, even as museums have competed harder for attention and dollars, their expenses have risen, often outstripping the resources of even the wealthiest benefactors.

By Ernesto Sabato.

Sailors in Sunken Peru Sub Rescued
LEAD: Rescuers have freed 23 sailors trapped in a sunken Peruvian Navy submarine for almost 24 hours after it collided with a Japanese fishing trawler, Peruvian President Alan Garcia said tonight.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in the Aug. 7 issue of Education Life incorrectly listed Morehouse College in Atlanta as offering a master's degree in real estate.
The Morehouse program is restricted to undergraduates.


Correction
LEAD: A graphic accompanying the Week in Business column last week misstated the monthly increase in the rate of factory utilization.
The July rate was four-tenths of a percentage point higher than June's.


Merry Oldsmobile Still at Top of Heap
LEAD: FOR years, I wouldn't have admitted this, but as a youth I suffered from Oldsmobile envy.


Two Six-Man Teams Enter the Battle Successful Transition
LEAD: CAN two six-man teams go to battle without anyone on the bench?
Apparently not.
But a group of stars recently found a tricky solution to this problem: One team sat North-South at three tables, and became East-West at the same table for the next round.
Their opponents moved one table in the opposite direction to the boards, before the imp scores were calculated.


HALF IS BETTER THAN NONE
LEAD: Wine in half-bottles (375 ml.) will mature faster than in full-bottles (750 ml.).
This is caused primarily by oxygen permeating the cork in relatively greater proportion because of the smaller quantity of wine in the half-bottle.
Thus, a young half-bottle may be more drinkable than its full-bottle counterpart.

Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
LEAD: The Mets' incompetence at the plate can be attributed to the blatant impatience of their hitters.
Most of them simply refuse to accept a walk and consequently they swing at first pitches and balls out of the strike zone when they're ahead of the count.
The Mets are also guilty of overswinging, which could be because of their tremendous egos.


Guadalcanal
LEAD: To the Editor: Anyone who was involved in World War II, as so many of us were, naturally knows Guadalcanal, but Mrs.
Tregaskis captured the history and brought us up to the present very thoroughly and expertly.
It would be more than interesting to people involved in this era to look back on some of the other outposts that played an important part in the war.

Amtrak
LEAD: To the Editor: The article ''Across America by Rail'' (Travel, July 28) struck a strong chord with my wife and me, for we traveled from New York to California and back in April on Amtrak.
We took the train to Los Angeles, and then drove a rent-a-car up the Pacific Coast Highway to San Francisco and back to Los Angeles.

LEAD: Sir Frederick Ashton was the Shakespeare of ballet - not the Shakespeare who wrote revenge tragedies but the poet who composed love sonnets.

Can Unions Build the Ships?
LEAD: Last week in Seattle, 400 union and non-union workers bought WFI Industries, a privately held tugboat manufacturer that had been in financial difficulty for more than two years.
The purchase was made using an employee stock option plan financed by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
Donald Liddel, the leader of the Inlandboatmen's Union of the Pacific, will assume the post of chairman and chief executive of the company, renamed Unimar Industries Inc.

Among the Elderly, Togetherness Is Selling
LEAD: AS a growing number of elderly Americans become more affluent and live longer, healthier lives, many are finding themselves more in need of companionship than long-term custodial care.
An increasing number of real estate developers are responding to this demand by building group residences that, for those who can afford them, combine the convenience of a hotel with the community spirit of summer camp.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Japan's vehicle production rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in July from a year earlier, the sixth straight month of year-to-year gains, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said.
July's production of 1.1 million vehicles included 711,435 cars, down 2.3 percent from the previous year.
Truck production rose 6.8 percent, to 385,865, while buses increased 11.8 percent, to 4,697.

Ten years after legalized gambling came to this faded resort, the skyline is a facade: the city behind the Boardwalk remains a slum.

LEAD: With hundreds of club-carrying police officers keeping the groups apart, hooded Ku Klux Klansmen preaching white supremacy staged a rally today in the same park where a multiracial group was arriving for a commemoration of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr.
Fourteen people were arrested, most for disorderly conduct, in a tense afternoon at Marquette

LEAD: If you'll excuse the pun, Vice President Bush is acting like a bush leaguer.

LEAD: Youngsters warming up before taking part in Tap-O-Mania, an annual mass tap dance on West 34th Street yesterday.
To the music of ''There's No Business like Show Business'' 4,497 participants donned hats and T-shirts for the tap dance, surpassing a record set recently in Scotland. (NYT/Ruby Washington)

Willamette Valley Journal; Watching Grass Grow Is More Than a Pastime
LEAD: A variety of grass called Manhattan forms the turf in Central Park, Regal surrounds the White House, and Munich's Olympic Stadium is carpeted with Derby.
The seeds for all originated near here in the Willamette Valley, which produces 70 percent of the world's ryegrass.


Ah, the Good Old Days In the Fifth St. Pool
LEAD: To the Editor:


A New Hall Rises; So Do Opinions
LEAD: Word spread as quickly as the fire on the night in August 1985 when an arsonist burned the 234-year-old Town Hall here to the ground.
By 2 A.M., when the flaming pillars at the front of the hall came crashing down on Main Street, hundreds of people were on hand to watch.


Nomad Children, Lost in New York's Maze
LEAD: They are nomad children, hundreds of New York City children who are moved each night from one foster care home to another.
These children, ranging from infancy to adolescence, spend most of their days in field offices of the city's Special Services for Children.
At night they are shuttled from borough to borough, carrying what few possessions they have in plastic bags.


A Horror Surpassing Hitchcock?
LEAD: In a scenario reminiscent of a summer horror movie, thousands of bats have driven a family from their home in this normally placid village along the old Erie Canal in Oneida County.


The Burning of Rondonia
LEAD: A calamitous cycle of destruction is unfolding in Rondonia, the heavily forested Amazon province in western Brazil.
The tragedy is a lesson to Brazil and to the international agencies that finance its projects that heedless development can wreak havoc with the global environment, not just Brazil's.


Political Memo; Accentuating the Positive Can Lead to Nasty Campaign
LEAD: If your taste in political campaigning does not run to the harsh attack and counterattack, you would be well advised to do all of the following for the next 10 weeks: Turn off your television and radio, throw away all your newspapers, don't answer your telephone and don't open a single piece of mail that does not come from a known and dear relative.


Just a Teen-Ager With Grand Ideas
LEAD: THE guests had eaten dinner, and without any prodding from her father, Steffi Graf helped clear the table as she would if she were home in Bruehl, West Germany, returning with placesettings for coffee and dessert.
It was a reminder that the best tennis player in the world is still just a teen-ager, one who plays pinball, becomes animated when talking about books she has read and enjoys the privacy of her room, where she likes to dim the lights, turn up the stereo and dance the night away.


Gangs Kill Nine in California
LEAD: Violence among street gangs caused at least nine deaths in Los Angeles and Riverside counties over the weekend, and the Los Angeles police hastily formed a task force to patrol the worst areas.

Isuzu Selling in Germany
LEAD: Isuzu Motors Ltd. has started selling its Gemini cars equipped with 1,500-cc diesel engines in West Germany, the Japanese company's first car sales there, an Isuzu spokesman said Friday.
Isuzu's sales target is 3,000 cars in the first year.
Isuzu's 40 percent-owned IBC Vehicle Ltd., located near London, has started exporting its commercial Midi vans to continental Europe, the spokesman added.


Britain's Trade Jitters
LEAD: A record monthly trade deficit has raised fears that Britain's extraordinary economic resurgence of the 1980's is suddenly in danger.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said that its AC Spark Plug division would combine with the Rochester Products division to form the AC Rochester division, putting all units that make electronic engine-management systems into one operation.

LEAD: Kirt Myers, the father of Angel Myers, who was banned from the United States Olympic swimming team after failing a drug test, said yesterday that his daughter hoped to undergo an independent test at Indiana University and would pursue an appeal of the ban.


Korea-U.S. Trade Gap
LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States shrank by 15.7 percent in the first seven months of the year, to $4.66 billion, from $5.53 billion a year earlier, the Government reported today.
Officials attributed the reduction to Korea's revaluation of the won.
Korean merchandise exports to the United States rose 10.8 percent, to $11.39 billion, in the period, while imports from the United States surged by 41.5 percent, to $6.73 billion, the report said.


Ousted Panama Chief Visits U.S. for Talks
LEAD: Eric Arturo Delvalle, the ousted President of Panama, has arrived in the United States and is expected to meet with State Department officials.

Introductory Step Toward Powerful Chip
LEAD: NEC Informations Systems Inc., a subsidiary of the giant Japanese electronics company, last week unveiled two new personal computers based on the Intel 80386 SX microprocessor.
The SX chip, which was referred to as the P9 in its development phase, is a simplified version of the powerful 80386 processor that allows customers to step up to 386-class performance at a lower cost.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Saturday about the rescue of several ailing savings and loan institutions by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, misstated the number of institutions involved in the lead paragraph.
It was 10.
The article also misstated the number of deals arranged so far under the agency's Southwest Plan to merge more than 100 sick institutions into healthy ones.

Years of Dueling Agendas Slow Atlantic City's Growth
LEAD: People here all protest that they want the best for Atlantic City, and no one is insincere.
Everyone uses the same words, like ''redevelopment'' and ''housing'' and ''schools'' and ''amenities.'' But what they mean by those words often differs, obscuring a conflict in agendas that is the source of much of the political paralysis here, over 10 years since the first casino opened and the money began to flow.

Japan's Retail Sales Rise
LEAD: Sales at Japan's leading department stores and supermarkets in July rose 8.5 percent, to 1,736.9 billion yen ($13 billion), from the period a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.
In June, sales climbed 7.2 percent, the ministry said.
The data cover 371 department stores and 1,961 supermarkets.

Private Garbage Carters Protest at City Hall
LEAD: Private garbage trucks in a line around City Hall during a protest of higher dumping fees, which are to more than double, at city landfills and disposal sites.
The protest began shortly after 10 A.M. and ended with a news conference on the steps of City Hall.
It was sponsored by the President's Council of Trade Waste Associations, a trade group representing 350 private carters in the city.

The question now is whether Governor Cuomo is willing to buck the farm lobby and veto legislation that would almost certainly mean higher milk prices for consumers.

Market Place; Reporting Rule's Effect on Detroit
LEAD: INVESTORS who like to pore over financial statements to do their own analysis will have a tougher time when it comes to sizing up automobile companies and other industrial enterprises with large financing subsidiaries.
Because of a ruling by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, these subsidiaries' results, which have been reported separately, are going to be consolidated into the corporate parent's profit-or-loss statement and its balance sheet.

LEAD: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number.

LEAD: Early tests of the pill form of a drug used to help impotent men achieve an erection indicate that the pill is safer, more convenient and just as effective as the injectable version, according to a recent report in the Annals of Internal Medicine.

LEAD: New-home sales suffered their steepest drop in seven months in July, and economists predicted further softening as rising mortgage interest rates push up the cost of buying a home.

Global Fire Is Linked to Dinosaur's Demise
LEAD: A STUDY of ancient clay deposits has provided new evidence supporting the theory that global fires ignited by a meteorite impact contributed to the demise of the dinosaurs and many other creatures 65 million years ago, scientists at the University of Chicago reported last week.


Fashion; By Design; Plaid Makes a Comeback
LEAD: Schoolgirls in their little pleated skirts are not the only ones who will be clad in plaid in the coming months.
Plaid is back.
A fashion that comes and goes, surfacing for a few seasons and then fading away, it's turned up in new guises this time, not just as classic tartan kilts or flannel work shirts, but in everything from evening dresses to bracelets, shoes, scarfs, gloves, hats, handbags and suspenders.


Man Linked to John Gotti Is Slain on Brooklyn Street
LEAD: A 52-year-old man described as an associate of John Gotti was killed early yesterday in a fusillade as he walked to his car in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn.

LEAD: *

Mr.
Cain, who will also continue as chief operating officer and chief financial officer, is replacing Robert B. Hitchcock, who will remain chairman and chief executive.

LEAD: Marc Wilson, who spent five years trying to provide the solution to the Los Angeles Raiders' quarterback problem, was told yesterday that he wasn't the answer in Green Bay.
The eight-year veteran, cut by the Packers, was among several well-known players to be released.

LEAD: William C. Woolfson, retired administrator of the Poe Center of Bronx Community College and a founder of the United Federation of Teachers, died of a heart attack Sunday.
He was pronounced dead on arrival at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville.
He was 84 years old and lived in the Bronx.

Satellite Placed in Discovery Cargo Bay
LEAD: Workers at the Kennedy Space Center tonight finished loading the space shuttle Discovery's cargo bay with a $100 million satellite nearly identical to one destroyed in the Challenger explosion in 1986.


Canine Virus Tied to Seal Deaths
LEAD: A team of Dutch scientists announced today that they had identified an animal virus that more commonly infects dogs as the cause of the puzzling epidemic that has killed more than 7,000 seals this year in the North Sea and the Baltic.


Bernstein Tribute Tonight
LEAD: A musical tribute to Leonard Bernstein and Morton Gould in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center was rained out last night and has been rescheduled for tonight at 8:15. .
The program of music by the two composers and conductors will be played by the Harmonie Ensemble, under the direction of Steven Richman.

LEAD: Citing what it claimed was the inability of the Men's Tennis Council to govern and market the men's game effectively, the Association of Tennis Professionals has decided the explore the option of organizing its own international tour in 1990.


Los Angeles Penalized for Pollution
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would bar all new construction of major sources of air pollution in the Los Angeles area when a stopgap Congressional moratorium on such sanctions expires Wednesday.

Cotton Supply Outlook
LEAD: Prospects for another good cotton crop this year could push the total supply for the coming year to the highest level in more than two decades, the Agriculture Department reported today.
Based on Aug. 1 indications, the cotton harvest could be 14.9 million bales, up from 14.8 million bales last year, the department's Economic Research Service said in a report.

LEAD: The West German Defense Minister announced today that he was banning further displays of military aerobatic flying over West Germany.

LEAD: A frighteningly high number of babies are being exposed to cocaine or other illegal drugs in the womb, according to data from 36 hospitals around the country.
The findings, described yesterday at a news conference, were gathered from hospitals in both urban and suburban areas, serving patients from all socioeconomic groups.

Lawrence River, hard by the Thousand Islands wilderness, a few hundred yards from the Canadian border.

LEAD: A Japanese maker of construction machinery, Komatsu Ltd., has agreed to provide the Robbins Company of Seattle with technology on soft-ground tunnel-boring machinery, Komatsu said in a statement today.
Robbins, involved in boring the tunnel under the English Channel between Britain and France, has been licensing its technology for hard-rock tunneling to Komatsu since 1963.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD: ONCE upon a time, there was an exquisitely quiet wooded area in a community called Travis in western Staten Island.

Economic Scene; Forecasters' Art In 1929 and Now
LEAD: WHEN the Great Depression slammed into the economy in 1929, professional forecasters never knew what hit them.
That is understandable, given the primitive state of their science a half century ago.
But now that economists are armed with sophisticated mathematical models and big computers to crunch the numbers, forecasters could not possibly be caught asleep at the switch.

Getting Vital Drugs Into the Brain
LEAD: The brain is equipped with a sophisticated barrier that keeps foreign substances in the blood like bacteria and toxins from reaching brain tissue.
But this blood-brain barrier, as scientists call it, also keeps out potentially useful substances like drugs to treat cancer and AIDS.

Rescuing the Refrigerated Tomato
LEAD: As most anyone who grows tomatoes will tell you, the tomato tastes and smells best if it is picked, sliced and served - all within a few minutes.
Such empirical knowledge has passed down through generations of gardeners, cooks, and tomato eaters.
Now, chemists at the Department of Agriculture have confirmed this, and hope their work will point the way to enhancing the flavor of the scourge of the winter salad - the refrigerated tomato.

A Choice of Varieties As Wide as the Sea
LEAD: SEAWEED is classified by color.
Of the eight major groups, three are used for food.
Red seaweed, or Rhodphyta, includes dulse, purple nori, ogo, agar and Irish moss.
Brown seaweed, or Phaeophyta, includes kelp, kombu, wakame, arame, hijiki and rock weed.
Sea lettuce belongs to the Chlorophyta, or green seaweed group.

Time For Decision
LEAD: Events in the Middle East are moving to a crossroads.
For many years, hard choices have been put off because, on the Israeli side, so many people wanted to believe they need never be made and that the impasse would melt away with time; and because, on the Palestinian side, leaders felt more secure by temporizing than by taking political risk.

From Wall Street's perspective, Sanford C. Sigoloff is trying to buy the huge maker of auto parts and home furnishings for a song.


USX-Soviet Pact
LEAD: The USX Corporation said its steel division had concluded an agreement to provide the Soviet Union with 88,000 tons of seamless steel tube for oil well casing. ''As best we can tell, it is the largest order we've been involved with in the Soviet Union,'' a company spokesman, Thomas Ferrall, said.
The price of the deal was withheld.


Index of Economic Trends Shows Its Steepest Drop in Eight Months
LEAD: The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, slipping below its level of early spring.


Marjorie Draper, 60, Civic Leader in Jersey
LEAD: Marjorie Draper, a leader in New Jersey civic and community affairs, died Sunday at her home in Montclair, N.J., after a brief illness.
She was 60 years old.


Gould to Be Acquired By Nippon Mining
LEAD: In the fourth-largest Japanese acquisition of an American company, Gould Inc. said yesterday that it would be acquired by the Nippon Mining Company for $23.25 a share, or about $1.1 billion in cash.


Bridge
LEAD: In bridge, as in life, there is a big difference between being very poor and being destitute.
The player who appreciates this can sometimes make a positive move in the bidding because his hand is not as bad as it might have been.


Missing in Action: From a Lost War, a Haunting Echo That Won't Be Stilled
LEAD: On the wall of Ann Mills Griffiths's office in Washington is a framed rubbing of her brother's name from the Vietnam War Memorial.
Lieut.
Cmdr.
James B. Mills has been missing since Sept. 21, 1966, when his Navy F-4 was lost on a night mission over North Vietnam.


Georgia Power Faces Tax Inquiry
LEAD: In an affidavit unsealed today in Federal District Court here, a special agent of the Internal Revenue Service maintained that high-ranking executives of the Georgia Power Company and its parent, the Southern Company, had engaged in a complex six-year plan to evade millions of dollars in corporate taxes.

LEAD: Frederick Wiseman, public television's determinedly mute yet consistently eloquent guide to surprising corners of American life, takes us tonight to Vandenberg Air Force Base in California to look in on young officers who are being trained to man the launching-control centers of the Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles.

LEAD: Now a ramshackle town of one-story houses on the banks of a torrent, Garam Chasma was once a popular resort for Pakistanis who came for the natural hot springs.
But there is little tourism now.

LEAD: For a while, a general in New York City's war on drugs feared that he would become the nation's ''only homeless prosecutor.''

LEAD: After a much-heralded entry into the telecommunications marketplace, hookups that allow callers to socialize by telephone from home are fast fading in popularity.

Cablevision Stake Raised
LEAD: A group led by Sandler Associates of New York said today that it had raised its stake in the Cablevision Systems Corporation to 10.4 percent, from a previous holding of 7.3 percent.


Mollusk Lovers Are Rejected
LEAD: Gov.
George Deukmejian today vetoed a bill to make the Banana Slug the official state mollusk. ''It is not representative of the international reputation California enjoys,'' the Governor said.
The bill to recognize the slug, which is bright yellow and about the size of a banana, was introduced in the House of Assembly on behalf of the Redwood Campfire Kids, a children's group.

LEAD: It is six months since the weekend of horror when Albert M. Mamedov called his Armenian neighbors to gather the children and come quickly because a mob was going door to door, hunting for Armenians.

LEAD: Neil Bush, citing a possible conflict of interest with the Presidential campaign of his father, has resigned from the board of Silverado Banking Savings and Loan, an insolvent Denver thrift institution facing a Federal bail-out.


Food Notes
LEAD: A Bit of the Old and New The Jewish New Year, Rosh ha-Shanah, begins at sundown on Sept. 11, and of timely interest is ''Kashruth'' by Rabbi Yacov Lipschutz (Mesorah Publications), which explains the ancient principles behind kosher food rules, and also discusses some concerns of the modern cook.


Black &amp; Decker Saws Faulty
LEAD: Black &amp; Decker Inc. has agreed to send owners of 500,000 electric miter saws kits to fix a faulty blade guard.
A company spokeswoman, Barbara Lucas, said the guard sometimes jammed, leaving the blade exposed.
The company said owners should call (800) 541-7136 for kits for these models: 1703 (type 1), 1703-1, 3090 (types 2 and 11), 3091 (type 1), 3417 (type 11), 3417-04 (type 3), 7715, 7715-1 (types 1, 2 and 3), 7715-04 (type 2), 7716 (types 1A1, 2, 11), 7716-04 (type 1), 7717 (types 3, 11 and 21), 7718 (type 2), and Sears Model 901.23470.


Washington Talk: Briefing; More Nixon Tapes
LEAD: Sometime next year, the National Archives will make available to the public about 60 hours of President Nixon's White House tapes - the first such since 12 1/2 hours were entered into evidence in court trials, including cases concerning Watergate.
More tapes will be made public in subsequent years.

LEAD: With Mats Wilander, Brad Gilbert, Tim Mayotte and Yannick Noah by his side, Hamilton Jordan, the chief executive officer of the Association of Tennis Professionals, reiterated yesterday that the players will organize their own international tour in 1990 because of the inability of the Men's Tennis Council to effectively govern the men's game.

LEAD: *
Chief Executive Magazine says its rate base climbed 7 percent, to 30,000, and will increase its ad rates 11 percent, effective with its January/February issue.


With Macrobiotic Cooking, A Balance of Yin and Yang
LEAD: FOR most of his life, a Japanese man named George Ohsawa devoted his time to developing and promulgating the concepts of macrobiotic eating, which he believed would lead to a healthier, more balanced life.
While Mr.
Ohsawa lectured all over the world, his wife, Lima, was always with him.
It was her job to develop the application of the theory: to create the recipes and cook food that would exemplify the macrobiotic way.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The index of leading indicators fell 0.8 percent in July, to a level below that of early spring.
The drop in the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge was the steepest in eight months.
Economists said the fall in the index, along with other recent data, seemed to suggest that the brisk economic conditions of recent months may be waning.


Bergdorf Will Open A 2d Store
LEAD: Bergdorf Goodman said yesterday that it would open an additional store across the street from its base at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street.
The building, at 745 Fifth Avenue, is the former home of F.A.O.
Schwarz.


Continental To Cut Fares
LEAD: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it planned to cut its lowest urestricted fares by an average of 55 percent on 38 routes from Denver.
The service has been plagued by overcapacity and decreased travel because of the depressed oil economy.

LEAD: The flight attendants' union at Trans World Airlines asserted yesterday that T.W.A.'s future and the safety of the flying public are jeopardized by Carl Icahn's proposal to take the airline private.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today announced the completion of a campaign to seize drugs that involved agencies from 30 nations, including Panama, whose de facto leader is under indictment in the United States on charges of narcotics smuggling.

LEAD: A 65-foot tall Latin cross erected 22 years ago at a Marine base in Hawaii must be removed or replaced by a nonreligious symbol, a Federal judge ruled today.

New Jersey's Faulty No-Fault
LEAD: In California, high automobile insurance rates have inspired a consumer revolt and a set of ballot initiatives aimed at controlling costs.
In New Jersey, where rates are even higher, residents may be forgiven a certain cynicism about efforts to control costs.
Every time Trenton has put its collective hand to this problem in recent years, the result has been higher rates, not lower.

LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorp is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1993 at a price of 99.92 to yield 9.77 percent through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

LEAD: Morocco and the Polisario Front guerrillas agreed today to a United Nations peace plan to end the 13-year-old war in the former Spanish colony of Western Sahara.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Mark IV Industries, New Haven, has filed suit against the Armtek Corp., accusing Armtek's board of misusing anti-takeover measures to prevent shareholders from determining whether they want to accept Mark IV's $44-a-share, or $500 million cash tender offer.


Critic's Notebook; Behind the Blessings of a Prodigy, Risks for Child, Music andListener
LEAD: The promoting, encouraging and marketing of child prodigies may not constitute child abuse, but it is a form of robbery.
When children are deprived of childhood the loss to all of us is great.
Children show us things about ourselves we would not otherwise see.
They offer us an education at least as valuable as the one we extend to them.

LEAD: Western diplomats said today that the Soviet Union had taken steps to integrate northern Afghanistan's economy with that of Soviet Central Asia.

LEAD: Irving Honigsberg, a real-estate lawyer, died of complications after surgery Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The General Services Administration yesterday awarded Diners Club Inc., a subsidiary of Citibank, a one-year contract to provide credit card service to more than 400,000 Federal employees who travel frequently on Government business.

LEAD: It's back to the drawing board for 35-year-old Wilmer C. Ames, who had a dream to start a black-oriented magazine, but failed to come up with enough financial backing.

LEAD: A former fugitive, identified by the authorities as the leader of a drug organization linked to the Colombo crime family, pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of racketeering and extortion.

LEAD: The University of Vermont, prodded by a tiny but restless number of students who are members of minority groups, is moving on several fronts to promote racial and cultural diversity on its 10,000-student campus here.

LEAD: The three major television networks and the Hollywood studios that create most of their programming are joining in a coordinated attack against drinking and driving that will include dialogue in popular entertainment shows as well as public-service advertising.


Elementary Curriculum According to Bennett
LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett today presented his version of the ideal elementary school curriculum, a course of study that emphasizes classic children's literature, rigorous mathematics lessons and foreign language instruction beginning no later than the fourth grade.


Report Finds a 10% Decline in U.S. Use of Water
LEAD: While the drought this summer is imposing new water restrictions on many Americans, water use is already down nationally, partly because of a declining supply of water.


The Gulf War Isn't Over
LEAD: An ancient quarrel over the vital waterway separating Iran and Iraq threatens to scuttle the gulf war truce even before talks begin in Geneva.
Iraq now balks at compliance with the terms of the United Nations cease-fire resolution, insisting on full naval access to the disputed Shatt al-Arab in advance of peace talks.

LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Mexico today announced a $250 million cost-cutting program and immediately eliminated 799 jobs, or more than 19 percent of its 4,126 staff.

LEAD: A principal who was dismissed after accusing school committee members of interfering too much in his high school's operations was ordered reinstated Monday by a Middlesex Superior Court judge.


Chrysler Rebate
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation increased cash incentives for its Eagle Premier automobiles to $750 from $600, retroactive to Sunday.
The nation's third-largest car maker said the incentives would be available on 1988 and 1989 models and the offer would be available indefinitely.
The company said it sold 2,058 of the cars in the first 20 days of August, down 10.8 percent from the 2,281 sold in the July period.


Quake Jeopardizes Development Plans in Nepal
LEAD: The earthquake last week in eastern Nepal is likely to deal a serious setback to the country's economic development, according to officials here.


B.C. Willis, 86; Led Chicago Schools for 13 Years
LEAD: Benjamin C. Willis, who as Superintendent of Schools in Chicago in the 1960's was accused of perpetuating segregation by refusing to move black children into white schools, died at his home in Plantation, Fla., on Saturday, his family said yesterday.
He was 86 years old.


Rates Up Slightly On Citicorp Paper
LEAD: Interest rates rose slightly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.369 percent, up from 8.36 percent last week.

South Africa Blast Hurts 7
LEAD: A powerful explosion badly damaged the headquarters of the South African Council of Churches, an influential antiapartheid organization, early today, officials here said.
A police spokesman said seven people were injured, none seriously.
The council represents almost 11 million South African Christians and vigorously opposes apartheid.


Lessons
LEAD: The Board of Education in New York City was understandably reluctant to say how many people work at its Brooklyn headquarters.

LEAD: Domtar Inc., a Montreal-based manufacturer of pulp and paper products, is offering $100 million of 9 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.79 to yield 9.68 percent though underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
The notes are noncallable and yield about 68 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
